{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Donald Trump series}} U.S. president [[Donald Trump]] currently has six residences.
Trump grew up in [[Jamaica Estates]], an affluent neighborhood in [[Queens]], [[New York City]]. During his time at the [[New York Military Academy]], he lived on campus; he later rented [[row house]]s in college. In 1971, Trump moved to a studio on 75th Street in Manhattan.<ref name="ForbesALL"/> Since the completion of [[Trump Tower]] in 1983, Trump has lived in a three-level penthouse on the top floors. He purchased the Seven Springs mansion in [[Bedford (town), New York|Bedford, New York]], in 1995. Upon Trump's election to the US presidency, he moved into the [[White House]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], while First Lady [[Melania Trump|Melania]] and their son initially stayed at Trump Tower in [[Manhattan]] until the end of the school year before moving to the White House as well.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jun/12/melania-barron-trump-move-into-white-house|title=Melania and Barron Trump officially move into White House|first=Associated|last=Press|date=June 12, 2017|work=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref> From his birth in 1946 until 2019, Trump listed his primary state of residence as [[New York (state)|New York]]; in September 2019, Donald and Melania moved their primary residence to [[Mar-a-Lago]] in [[Florida]].<ref name=cbsnewsresidence>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/donald-trump-primary-residence-trump-moving-primary-residence-from-new-york-city-to-florida/|title=Lifelong New Yorker Trump moving primary residence to Florida|first=Caroline|last=Linton|publisher=CBS News|date=October 31, 2019|accessdate=November 1, 2019}}</ref><ref name=nytresidency />
==Current residences== ===Mar-a-Lago=== [[File:Maralago1 (4158314102).jpg|thumb|[[Mar-a-Lago]]]] {{Main|Mar-a-Lago}}
Since September 2019, Trump's resort and residence Mar-a-Lago has served as the primary residence for Donald and Melania Trump.<ref name=nytresidency>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/31/us/politics/trump-new-york-florida-primary-residence.html|title=Trump, Lifelong New Yorker, Declares Himself a Resident of Florida|first=Maggie|last=Haberman|publisher=New York Times|date=October 31, 2019|accessdate=November 1, 2019}}</ref><ref name=cbsnewsresidence /> The legality of this has been disputed because, in 1993, Trump signed a "use agreement" with the [[Palm Beach, Florida|Town of Palm Beach, Florida]] that changed Mar-a-Lago's designation from a single-family residence to a private club. The agreement specified that guests, including Trump, could not stay there more than three non-consecutive weeks per year.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Roig-Franzia|first=Manuel|date=8 May 2020|title=Trump made Florida his official residence. He may have also made a legal mess.|work=Washington Post|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/trump-made-florida-his-official-residence-he-may-have-also-made-a-legal-mess/2020/05/07/17d53fb2-849c-11ea-878a-86477a724bdb_story.html|url-status=live|access-date=8 May 2020}}</ref>
===Seven Springs=== Trump owns a {{convert|39000|sqft}} mansion on {{convert|213|acre}} in [[Bedford (town), New York|Bedford]] and [[New Castle, New York]]. The mansion has an indoor pool of white marble on its first floor and sixty rooms, including thirteen bedrooms and twelve baths.<ref name="ForbesALL"/><ref name="NYT1"/> The property has a glass and stone orangery for growing citrus, with a bowling alley in its basement. Also on the property is a formal garden pavilion, a fountain in the front lawn, a greenhouse and root cellar, stone water tower, and a Tudor Revival house and courtyard known by the name of "Nonesuch".<ref name="NYT1"/>
It was formerly the home of [[Eugene Meyer (financier)|Eugene Meyer]] and his family, including [[Katharine Graham]]. In 1919, Meyer had artist and architect [[Charles A. Platt]] design the mansion of sandstone from the property. He spent $2 million constructing it. Trump purchased the property in 1995 for $7.5 million. Trump originally planned to build a golf course there, however he was opposed by the governments of the three municipalities the property lies within, and he wanted to prevent a new course competing with his [[Trump National Golf Club Westchester|existing course]] nearby in [[Briarcliff Manor]]. Trump's plans changed for Seven Springs to include building fifteen mansions, each to sell for about $25 million, and renovating the two existing houses.<ref name="NYT1">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/21/realestate/homes-by-and-for-donald-trump.html|title=Homes by (and for) Donald Trump|first=Elsa|last=Brenner|date=May 21, 2006|publisher=|accessdate=April 14, 2017|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> In 2015, Trump placed most of the property under a [[conservation easement]], apparently signaling the abandonment of any major development plans.<ref>{{cite news|title=Seven Springs, Trump's N.Y. property, spared spotlight — for now|newspaper=USA Today|first=Michael P.|last=McKinney|date=April 25, 2017|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/04/25/seven-springs-trumps-ny-property-spared-spotlight-now/100905078/|accessdate=May 14, 2018}}</ref>
===Trump Parc=== Donald Trump developed the 38-story Trump Parc condominium skyscraper at 106 [[Central Park]] South, and often privately owns multiple units within it, which he rents for up to $100,000 a month.<ref name="ForbesALL"/>
===Trump Park Avenue=== Trump has several apartments at [[Trump Park Avenue]], where his daughter [[Ivanka Trump|Ivanka]] lives.<ref name="ForbesALL"/>
===Trump Tower penthouse=== [[File:Shinzō Abe and Donald Trump (5).jpg|thumb|Trump, [[Shinzō Abe]], and others at Trump's penthouse, 2016]] {{Main|Trump Tower}} Described as [[Louis XIV]]-style, Trump's penthouse at Trump Tower has three stories and is reportedly worth $100 million. The interior, designed by [[Angelo Donghia]], has gold-trimmed furniture, marble floors, columns, tables, and walls, frescoed ceilings, bronze statues, and crystal chandeliers.<ref name="ForbesALL"/>
===White House=== {{Main|White House}} As the president, Donald Trump currently lives in [[Washington, D.C.]] with his wife [[Melania Trump]], the [[First Lady of the United States|first lady of the United States]], and their son [[Barron Trump]]. They have been the current tenants of the [[White House]] since Trump's inauguration on January 20, 2017.
==Former residences== ===Queens, New York City=== [[File:85-15 Wareham Place, Trump childhood home.jpeg|thumb|upright|[[85-15 Wareham Place]]]] Trump lived with his family in [[Jamaica Estates]], an affluent suburban neighborhood in [[Queens]]. They lived at [[85-15 Wareham Place]] until he was four. The house, a six-bedroom [[neo-Tudor]], was built in 1940 by his father [[Fred Trump]]. In 1950, the family moved into a nine-room [[Colonial Revival]] house built on two adjoining lots on Midland Parkway, directly behind the backyard of the house on Wareham Place.{{sfn|Kranish|Fisher|2017|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=x2jUDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA32 32]}}<ref name="ForbesALL">{{cite web|title=Donald Trump's Estates Through The Years (Pre-White House)|first=Keith|last=Flamer|publisher=|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/keithflamer/2016/05/27/deconstructing-donald-trump-a-homespun-tale-4/#6c32e1b05c9f|accessdate=April 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Warren|first=Katie|title=I visited Trump's childhood neighborhood on the outskirts of NYC, and it didn't take long to see why he's called it an 'oasis'|website=Business Insider|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-childhood-neighborhood-queens-new-york-city-photos-2018-11|date=December 19, 2019|access-date=March 14, 2020}}</ref> Over several decades, Trump's parents gradually retrofitted the house into a 23-room [[mansion]]<ref>https://www.google.com/books/edition/Trump/ZQ_9CwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&bsq=jamaica%20estates</ref> and resided there for the rest of their lives.<ref name="visit">{{cite web|last=Walsh|first=Kevin|title=Tripping to Trumpville|work=Splice Today|url=https://www.splicetoday.com/writing/tripping-to-trumpville|accessdate=March 15, 2020}}</ref>
===School living=== [[File:New York Military Academy Main Gate (2006-05-22).jpg|thumb|[[New York Military Academy]]]] Beginning at age 13, Trump attended and resided at [[New York Military Academy]], a private boarding school in [[Cornwall, New York]].{{sfn|Kranish|Fisher|2017|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=x2jUDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA38 38]}} He subsequently attended [[Fordham University]] for two years and transferred to the [[Wharton School]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], where he lived in rented off-campus [[row house]]s.<ref name="ForbesALL"/>
===Manhattan penthouse=== Around the 1970s Trump lived in a penthouse apartment at the Phoenix, a luxury apartment building on 65th Street in the [[Upper East Side]] in [[Manhattan]]. The apartment had large panoramic windows; he decorated the interior in beige, brown, and chrome.<ref name="ForbesALL"/>
===Greenwich mansion=== Trump purchased a {{convert|20000|sqft|adj=on}} mansion in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], in 1982 for $4 million. The house has eight bedrooms, eleven baths, a {{convert|4000|sqft}} guest house, a putting green and tennis court, indoor and outdoor pools, and a sauna.<ref name="ForbesALL"/>
===Fifth Avenue apartment=== Trump and his wife Ivana lived in an apartment on Manhattan's [[Fifth Avenue]], which was decorated with beige velvet sofas and goatskin tables.<ref name="ForbesALL"/> According to family friend Nikki Haskell, Donald and Ivana lived in [[Olympic Tower]] prior to moving to 800 Fifth Avenue <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/the-frontline-interview-nikki-haskell/|title=The FRONTLINE Interview: Nikki Haskell|date=September 27, 2016|work=pbs.org}}</ref>
===Virginia residence=== Trump had a residence at [[Trump Vineyard Estates]], a 45-room {{convert|23000|sqft}} mansion.<ref name="ForbesALL"/>
===Beverly Hills=== Trump owned a five-bedroom mansion on North Rodeo Drive in [[Beverly Hills, California]] from 2007 to 2019. Trump had rarely used it, and had put on the market and rented it out at different times.<ref name="ForbesALL"/> In June 2019, he quietly sold the property, off-market, for $13.5 million. He had originally purchased it for $7 million, and claimed the house was worth $6 million for tax purposes.<ref name="lat">{{cite web|last=Flemming|first=Jack|title=Donald Trump’s Beverly Hills home quietly sells for $13.5 million|work=Los Angeles Times|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/hot-property/la-fi-hotprop-trump-organization-beverly-hills-20190612-story.html|date=June 12, 2019|accessdate=March 15, 2020}}</ref>
From 2008 to 2009, Trump owned a neighboring house, an 11-bedroom Greek Revival mansion built in 1981. Trump purchased it for $10.35 million, but sold it for $9.5 million. It was previously a residence of [[Gabon|Gabonese]] president [[Omar Bongo]], who died in office in 2009.<ref name="lat2">{{cite web|last=Leitereg|first=Neal J.|title=The high price of living next door to Donald Trump in L.A.: $30 million|work=Los Angeles Times|url=https://www.latimes.com/business/realestate/hot-property/la-fi-hotprop-donald-trump-former-home-beverly-hills-20160809-snap-story.html|date=August 9, 2016|accessdate=March 15, 2020}}</ref>

{{short description|Use of pseudonyms by Donald Trump}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2020}} [[File:President Trump's First 100 Days- 6 (34252546901).jpg|thumb|President Trump making a phone call in 2017. He <!--Not "allegedly", because his court testimony proved he did it.--> used pseudonyms during call-in interviews throughout the 1980s and 1990s.]]
[[Donald Trump]], an American businessman, politician, and [[List of Presidents of the United States|45th]] [[President of the United States|president]] of the [[United States]], has <!--Not "allegedly", because his court testimony proved he did it.--> used several pseudonyms, including "John Barron" (or "John Baron"), "John Miller" and "David Dennison". His practice of sometimes speaking to the media under the guise of a spokesperson has been described as "an open secret" at [[the Trump Organization]] and in New York media circles.<ref name="Diamond" /> Some New York editors recalled that "calls from Barron were at points so common that they became a recurring joke on the city desk."<ref name="Kimble" /> A writer for ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' reported that Trump's father [[Fred Trump]] had used the pseudonym Mr. Green in business dealings.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2016/05/18/donald-trump-fake-names/|title=Donald Trump's Long, Strange History of Using Fake Names|last=D'Antonio|first=Michael|date=May 18, 2016|work=Fortune|accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref>
=="John Barron" (1980s)== Trump used the pseudonym "John Barron" (sometimes "John Baron") throughout the 1980s, with its earliest known usage in 1980 and its last acknowledgment in 1990. According to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the name was a "go-to alias when [Trump] was under scrutiny, in need of a tough front man or otherwise wanting to convey a message without attaching his own name to it."<ref name="Borchers">{{cite news|last=Borchers|first=Callum|title=The amazing story of Donald Trump's old spokesman, John Barron – who was actually Donald Trump himself|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/03/21/the-amazing-story-of-donald-trumps-old-spokesman-john-barron-who-was-actually-donald-trump-himself/|accessdate=July 20, 2016|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=May 13, 2016}}</ref> Barron would be introduced as a spokesperson for Trump.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Taking a Bath on Madison|journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=August 13, 1984|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z-UCAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA9&dq=%22spokesman+john+barron%22#v=onepage|language=en|last=Churcher|first=Sharon}}</ref>
The pseudonym first appeared within a June 6, 1980 ''New York Times'' article about Trump's decision to destroy two controversial sculptures from the [[Bonwit Teller]] flagship store (now the site of [[Trump Tower]]) that he had promised to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. "Barron", describing himself as "a Trump Organization vice president", acted as the spokesperson for Trump for three days in that case.<ref name="Surico">{{cite news|url=https://www.vice.com/read/remembering-john-barron-donald-trumps-spokesman-alter-ego-116|title=Remembering John Barron, Donald Trump's 'Spokesman' Alter Ego|last=Surico|first=John|date=November 6, 2015|work=Vice|accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref> Trump continued to pose as "Barron" on occasion for the rest of the decade. In 1983 "Barron" told the press that Trump had decided not to purchase the [[Cleveland Indians]].<ref name="Joseph">{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/donald-trump-posed-john-barron-times-article-1.2636536|title=Donald Trump has apparently gotten away with posing as his own publicist 'John Barron' many times before|last=Joseph|first=Cameron|date=May 13, 2016|work=New York Daily News|accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref>
In May 1984, "Barron" lied to then-''[[Forbes]]'' reporter Jonathan Greenberg about Trump's wealth and assets to get Trump on the [[Forbes 400]] list. "Barron" stated to Greenberg that "[m]ost of the assets [of Donald’s father Fred Trump] have been consolidated to Mr. [Donald] Trump." In April 2018, Greenberg retrieved and made public the original audio recordings of his exchange with "Barron", and stated that "Trump, through this [Barron] sockpuppet, was telling me he owned 'in excess of 90 percent'" of Fred Trump's assets. Ultimately, Greenberg included Trump at the end of the Forbes 400 list at $100 million, one fifth of the $500 million which "Barron" was claiming as Donald Trump's net worth. According to Greenberg, Donald Trump was only ever worth just under $5 million, which was 5% of the net worth which was attributed to him by Forbes at the time and only 1% of what "Barron" was claiming.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/trump-lied-to-me-about-his-wealth-to-get-onto-the-forbes-400-here-are-the-tapes/2018/04/20/ac762b08-4287-11e8-8569-26fda6b404c7_story.html|title=Perspective Trump lied to me about his wealth to get onto the Forbes 400. Here are the tapes.|last=Greenberg|first=Jonathan|date=April 20, 2018|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Greenberg has corrected the record by stating that, as revealed in court documents in proceedings years later, Donald Trump never owned any of Fred Trump's assets until 1999 after Fred's death, and even then, inheriting only his share of Fred's deceased estate, with Donald Trump's three siblings and some grandchildren beneficiaries inheriting their corresponding shares.
Also in 1984, "Barron" gave the press a positive spin on the 1984 collapse of a plan to build Trump Castle in New York.<ref name="JSurico">{{cite magazine |last=Surico|first=Jay|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/exqkbp/remembering-john-barron-donald-trumps-spokesman-alter-ego-116|title=Remembering John Barron, Donald Trump's 'Spokesman' Alter Ego|magazine=Vice|date=November 6, 2015|access-date=June 13, 2018}}</ref> In 1985, "Barron" urged fellow [[United States Football League]] team owners to partially reimburse Trump for a high-priced player.<ref>{{cite news|last=United Press International|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/04/02/sports/trump-asks-help-in-paying-flutie.html|title=Trump Asks Help in Paying Flutie|website=The New York Times|date=April 2, 1985|access-date=June 13, 2018}}</ref> In April 1985, "John Baron, a vice president in the Trump Organization," announced to the press that the Trump Organization had signed an agreement to buy an unopened Hilton Hotel in Atlantic City.<ref name="WSaxon">{{cite news|last=Saxon|first=Wolfgang|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/04/28/nyregion/trump-buys-hilton-s-hotel-in-atlantic-city.html|title=Trump Buys Hilton's Hotel in Atlantic City|website=The New York Times|date=April 28, 1985|access-date=June 13, 2018}}</ref>
Trump stopped using the pseudonym after he was compelled to [[testify]] in court proceedings that “John Barron” was one of his pseudonyms. ''The Washington Post'' suggested that Trump might have used the pseudonym longer if not for the “lawsuit in which he testified, under oath in 1990, that 'I believe on occasion I used that name.'"<ref name=Borchers/>
=="John Miller" (1991)== In 1991, a reporter for ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' attempted to interview Trump about the end of his marriage to [[Ivana Trump|Ivana]] and his rumored association with other women. She was called back by a publicist who gave his name as "John Miller", who gave her a long interview about Trump's marital affairs ("He's a good guy, and he's not going to hurt anybody. . . . He treated his wife well and . . . he will treat Marla well."), his attractiveness to women, and his wealth. The reporter thought at the time that "Miller" sounded remarkably like Trump, and played the tape to several people who knew Trump and agreed it was Trump.<ref name="Fisher">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/donald-trump-alter-ego-barron/2016/05/12/02ac99ec-16fe-11e6-aa55-670cabef46e0_story.html|title=Donald Trump masqueraded as publicist to brag about himself|last1=Fisher|first1=Marc|last2=Hobson|first2= Will|date=May 13, 2016|work=Washington Post|accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref> She says Trump later told her it was a "joke gone awry".<ref name="Kimble">{{cite news|last=Kimble|first=Lindsay|title=Donald Trump Admitted to Posing as His Own Spokesperson to PEOPLE in 1991, Despite New Denials|url=https://people.com/celebrity/trump-previously-said-posing-as-his-own-spokesperson-was-a-joke-gone-awry/|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=May 15, 2016|access-date=May 9, 2019}}</ref> Trump denied that he posed as John Miller to tell ''People'', "[[Madonna (entertainer)|[Madonna]]] called and wanted to go out with him, that I can tell you."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/05/magazine/madonna-madame-x.html|title=Madonna at Sixty|first=Vanessa|last=Grigoriadis|date=June 5, 2019|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
In 2016, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' obtained a copy of the tape and reported that it was Trump using a pseudonym. Trump denied it, saying "It was not me on the phone." Later, when a reporter asked Trump if he had ever employed a spokesperson named John Miller, he hung up.<ref name="Diamond">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/13/politics/donald-trump-recording-john-miller-barron-fake-press/|title=Donald Trump on recording: Not me|last1=Kopan|first1=Tal|last2=Diamond|first2=Jeremy|date=May 14, 2016|work=CNN|accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref>
=="Carolin Gallego" (1992)== A 1992 letter to ''New York Magazine'' signed by "Carolin Gallego" replied to an article by Julie Baumgold. The letter asserted that "as his secretary" she knew Trump to treat women with respect.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Read Letters to New York From Spike Lee, Mimi Sheraton, and Donald Trump |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2017/10/read-letters-to-new-york-from-spike-lee-and-donald-trump.html |date=October 24, 2017 |website=New York Magazine |language=en |access-date=January 27, 2019}}</ref> This letter resurfaced in a 2017 article in the ''[[Washingtonian (magazine)|Washingtonian]]'' which highlighted similarities between patterns of repetition in Trump's speech and the final line in the letter, which read: "I do not believe any man in America gets more calls from women wanting to see him, meet him, or go out with him. The most beautiful women, the most successful women—all women love Donald Trump." The ''Washingtonian'' was unable to find any record of a Carolin Gallego as secretary to Trump.<ref>{{Cite web |first=Abbey |last=Gingras |title=Carolin Gallego Wrote a 1992 Letter Saying Women Love Donald Trump. We're Having Trouble Finding Her |url=https://www.washingtonian.com/2017/10/26/trump-carolin-gallego-letter/ |date=October 26, 2017 |website=Washingtonian |language=en |access-date=January 27, 2019}}</ref>
=="David Dennison" (2016)== The name "David Dennison" was used as a pseudonym for Trump by his personal lawyer [[Michael Cohen (lawyer)|Michael Cohen]] in a 2016 pre-election [[non-disclosure agreement]] with [[pornographic film]] actress [[Stormy Daniels]] (born Stephanie Gregory Clifford and identified in the document as Peggy Peterson) regarding her allegation that she and Trump had [[Stormy Daniels–Donald Trump scandal|an extramarital affair]] in 2006.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=[[NBC News]] |first=Sarah |last=Fitzpatrick |date=March 6, 2018 |title=Stormy Daniels sues Trump, says 'hush agreement' invalid because he never signed |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180307015816/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/stormy-daniels-sues-trump-says-hush-agreement-invalid-because-he-n854246 |archive-date=March 7, 2018 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/stormy-daniels-sues-trump-says-hush-agreement-invalid-because-he-n854246}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/video/trump-admits-to-using-alias-david-dennison-1190498371908 |title=Trump admits to using alias "David Dennison" |work=NBC News |date=March 20, 2018 |access-date=May 2, 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref> Keith Davidson acted as Stormy Daniels’ legal representative in that agreement. A later legal representative of Daniels, [[Michael Avenatti]], later claimed that Davidson was a [[double agent]] all along working for Trump and Cohen.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.in/Stormy-Daniels-lawyer-Michael-Avenatti-has-turned-up-the-heat-on-another-target-his-clients-first-lawyer/articleshow/64246388.cms|title=Stormy Daniels lawyer Michael Avenatti has turned up the heat on another target - his client's first lawyer|last=Smith|first=Allan|date=May 20, 2018|publisher=Business Insider}}</ref>
The same pseudonyms were also later used in a similar 2016 pre-election agreement involving payment for the silence of [[Playboy]] [[Playmate]] model [[Shera Bechard]] about an alleged extramarital affair, with a consequent pregnancy and subsequent abortion, between "Dennison" and "Peterson". That agreement was also drafted by Trump's personal lawyer Cohen, while Bechard was also represented by the same Keith Davidson who had negotiated Stormy Daniels’ agreement with Trump.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-lawyer-michael-cohen-negotiated-1-6-million-settlement-for-top-republican-fundraiser-1523638726|title=Trump Lawyer Michael Cohen Negotiated $1.6 Million Settlement for Top Republican Fundraiser|last1=Palazzolo|first1=Joe|last2=Rothfeld|first2=Michael|date=April 13, 2018|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=April 13, 2018}}</ref>
In Bechard's case, sources identified "Dennison" as Republican fundraiser [[Elliott Broidy]], who then acknowledged in an ambiguously worded statement that he had a “relationship” (the nature of which was not specified) and that he made the $1.6 million payment to her after being made aware of her pregnancy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/tasneemnashrulla/elliott-broidy-michael-cohen-payment-playboy-playmate|title=A Top GOP Official Admitted He Had An Affair With A Playboy Model And Gave Her Money To Terminate Her Pregnancy|last=Nashrulla|first=Tasreem|date=April 13, 2018|work=Buzzfeed|accessdate=May 23, 2018}}</ref> The phrasing of his statement also omitted any assertion that he was in fact the father of the unborn child. Some legal scholars and columnists have since speculated that [[Donald Trump]] was really the person who had the affair with Bechard.<ref name="Campos_5/8/2018">{{cite web | last=Campos | first=Paul | title=Theory: Playboy Model Who Got $1.6 Million Had Affair With Trump, Not Broidy | website=New York magazine | date=May 8, 2018 | url=https://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/05/theory-playboy-model-had-affair-with-trump-not-broidy.html | access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Campos_5/22/2018">{{cite web | last=Campos | first=Paul | title=Here's More Evidence Broidy May Have Been Covering for Trump in Playmate Affair | website=New York magazine | date=May 22, 2018 | url=https://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/05/more-evidence-that-broidy-was-covering-for-trump-in-affair.html | access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Bunch_5/22/2018">{{cite web | last=Bunch | first=Will | title=Is this Playboy model keeping the biggest secret of the Trump presidency? | website=Philly.com | date=May 22, 2018 | url=http://www.philly.com/philly/columnists/will_bunch/shera-bechard-donald-trump-playboy-model-elliott-broidy-20180522.html | access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref>
==In popular culture== Cartoonist [[Ruben Bolling]] occasionally satirizes Trump's use of John Barron in comics titled ''Donald and John: A Boy and His Imaginary Publicist''. It is drawn as a [[Homage (arts)|homage]] to the comic strip ''[[Calvin and Hobbes]]'', about a boy with a rich fantasy life.<ref>{{Cite comics image |title=Donald and John, a Boy and His Imaginary Publicist |url=https://boingboing.net/2016/05/17/tom-the-dancing-bug-donald-a.html |site=[https://boingboing.net/author/ruben_bolling BoingBoing] |date=May 17, 2016 |accessdate=March 19, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite comics image |title=A Calvinesque and Hobbesian look at "Go Back to Where You Came From" |url=https://boingboing.net/2019/07/24/a-calvinesque-and-hobbesian-lo-6.html |site=[https://boingboing.net/author/ruben_bolling BoingBoing] |date=July 24, 2019 |accessdate=July 24, 2019}}</ref>
In season 3, episode 5 of ''[[The Good Fight]]'' that airs on [[CBS All Access]] a character places a fake call to ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' using the name John Barron. This is followed by a musical interlude written by [[Jonathan Coulton]] and animated by Steve Angel explaining Trump’s use of the alias.<ref>{{cite episode |title=The Legend of John Barron |series=The Good Fight |URL=https://www.msn.com/en-us/video/t/the-good-fight-short-the-legend-of-john-barron/vp-BBVSFZZ |season=3 |number=5 }} the animated explanation of John Barron.</ref>
In [[Don Winslow]]'s 2019 novel ''The Border'', the Trump-like president is named "John Dennison".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Maslin|first=Janet|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/17/books/review-border-don-winslow.html|title='The Border' Is a Stunning and Timely Conclusion to Don Winslow's Drug-War Trilogy|date=February 17, 2019|work=The New York Times|access-date=April 17, 2020|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

{{update|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox park | name = Donald J. Trump State Park | photo = TrumpStatePark001.jpg | photo_width = | photo_caption = Entrance sign to Donald J. Trump State Park | map = New York#USA | map_size = | map_caption = Location of Donald J. Trump State Park | coords = {{coord|41.263|-73.803|type:landmark_region:US-NY|format=dms|display=title,inline}} | type = [[State park]] (undeveloped) | location = [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] and [[Putnam County, New York|Putnam]] counties, [[New York (state)|New York]] | nearest_city = | area = {{convert|436|acre|km2}} | created = {{Start date|2006}} | operator = [[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]] | visitation_num = | open = No | camp_sites = | hiking_trails = | other_info = | website = }}
'''Donald J. Trump State Park''' is a {{convert|436|acre|km2|1|adj=on}} [[state park]] located within the towns of [[Yorktown, New York|Yorktown]] and [[Putnam Valley, New York|Putnam Valley]] in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]] and [[Putnam County, New York|Putnam County]], [[New York (state)|New York]].
The park consists of undeveloped property that was donated to New York State in 2006 by developer and future President [[Donald J. Trump]]. Maintenance of the park was halted in 2010 due to budget constraints, and the park remains largely undeveloped as of 2015. Most of the buildings have been demolished, only a few foundations and the existing tennis court remain {{as of|2017|lc=on}}.
== History == Trump purchased the property for $2 million in the 1990s, and donated it in 2006<ref name=Pataki_Release/><ref name=Today_Trump>{{cite web |url=http://www.today.com/id/12387111 |title=Spend a lovely day in... Trump State Park |website=Today.com |date=April 19, 2006 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref> after he was unable to gain town approvals to develop a private golf course on the property.<ref name=NYT_closing>{{cite news |title=Trump State Park Fired. Trump Displeased. |first=Corey |last=Kilgannon |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/03/03/trump-state-park-to-close-trump-displeased/ |newspaper=The New York Times |date=March 3, 2010 |accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref> At that time Trump claimed the parcel was worth $100 million. He used the donation as a [[tax write-off]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.deathandtaxesmag.com/274545/donald-trumps-shitty-100-million-tax-break-park/ |title=I went to Donald Trump's shitty $100 million tax break park |last=Peck |first=Jamie |date=December 21, 2015 |website=DeathandTaxes.com}}</ref><ref name=Newsmax_signs>{{cite web |url=https://www.newsmax.com/Headline/donald-trump-state-park-signs-vacant-land/2015/08/10/id/669393/ |title=Donald J. Trump State Park Signs Still Lead to Vacant Land |newspaper=Newsmax |date=August 10, 2015 |author=Coren, Courtney |accessdate= September 25, 2015}}</ref>
New York State announced the park's closure due to budget cuts in February 2010.<ref name=NYSP_closures>{{cite web |url=http://parks.ny.gov/newsroom/press-releases/release.aspx?r=776 |title=Statements from Governor David A. Paterson and Commissioner Carol Ash on Parks Budget Cuts |website=NYS Parks, Recreation & Historic Preservation |date=February 19, 2010 |author= |accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref> It was questioned whether the closure was necessary since the operating budget for the park was only $2,500 a year and it was maintained by workers from the nearby [[Franklin D. Roosevelt State Park]].<ref name=NYT_closing/> Although Trump threatened to take the parkland back after the closure was announced,<ref name=NYT_closing/> his attempt was unsuccessful and the land remained in the control of the [[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]].<ref name=Crains>{{cite web |url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20150731/BLOGS02/150729822/the-charities-donald-trump-gave-money-to-and-what-it-says-about-his-candidacy |title=The charities Donald Trump gave money to and what it says about his candidacy |website=Crain's New York Business |date=July 31, 2015 |author=Elstein, Aaron |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref>
An attempt to convert a portion of the park's French Hill section for use as a dog park in 2010 revealed that at least one of the park's abandoned buildings contained asbestos.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://patch.com/new-york/yorktown-somers/town-board-discusses-trump-parks-dog-park |title=Town Board Discusses Trump Park's Dog Park |author=Pesheva, Plamena |date=June 25, 2010 |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> By 2012, the planned dog park remained on hold due to difficulties raising funds for fences and [[asbestos abatement]].<ref name=Dogpark_2012>{{cite web |url=http://yorktown.dailyvoice.com/politics/yorktown-dog-park-advocates-peeved-obstacles |title=Yorktown Dog Park Advocates Peeved With Obstacles |website=Yorktown Daily Voice |date=July 7, 2012 |author= |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref>
{{As of|2015}}, the park remains officially closed and is not listed at the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation park locator,<ref name=NYSP_search_2015>{{cite web |url=http://nysparks.com/parks/park-results.aspx?n=&src=1&tab=2 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150802145316/http://nysparks.com/parks/park-results.aspx?n=&src=1&tab=2 |title=State Park Search Results |website=Nysparks.com |archivedate=August 2, 2015 |date= |author=NYS Office of Parks, Recreation & Historic Preservation |accessdate=August 2, 2015}}</ref> although signs along the nearby [[Taconic State Parkway]] direct visitors to Donald J. Trump State Park.<ref name=Newsmax_signs/><ref name=Reisman_signs>{{cite web |url=http://www.lohud.com/story/opinion/columnists/phil-reisman/2015/07/02/phil-reisman-trump-signs-taconic/29634473/ |title=Reisman: Mr. Trump, take down those signs on the Taconic Parkway |newspaper=The Journal News |date=July 2, 2015 |author=Reisman, Phil |accessdate=July 19, 2015}}</ref> During a 2015 visit by ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show]]'' there were no signs of any recent upkeep; instead, the publicly accessible land was found to contain crumbling graffiti-covered buildings, empty map kiosks, and weed-choked parking lots.<ref name=Maddow_2015>{{cite AV media |work=The Rachel Maddow Show |date=July 17, 2015 |title=Donald J Trump State Park? Not exactly. |url=http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/donald-j-trump-state-park--not-exactly.-486748227809 |access-date=July 18, 2015 |publisher=MSNBC}}</ref>
In 2017, website ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' published a report that the park was an "abandoned wasteland," with "muddy fields, overgrown tennis courts, and dilapidated buildings" and a swimming pool in disrepair.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.avclub.com/donald-j-trump-state-park-is-as-ugly-and-dilapidated-a-1798258679|title=Donald J. Trump State Park is as ugly and dilapidated as its namesake's soul|last=Eakin|first=Marah|work=News|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Attempts to rename == In late 2015, State Senator [[Daniel Squadron]] introduced an "Anything But Trump Act" to change the park's name.<ref name="Telegraph_nameChange">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/donald-trump/12059218/Calls-to-rename-Donald-Trump-state-park-in-New-York.html|title=Calls to rename Donald Trump state park in New York|author=Millward, David|date=December 18, 2015|accessdate=December 18, 2015|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> Several suggestions for a name change were offered by elected officials. Assemblyman [[Charles D. Lavine]] suggested that the park be named for [[Peter Salem]], an African American who served in the [[American Revolutionary War]] and is thought by some historians to have been Muslim,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/ny-pols-introduce-act-remove-trump-state-park-article-1.2469133|title=New York lawmakers introduce 'Anything But Trump Act' to strip Donald Trump's name from undeveloped state park|last1=Edelman|first1=Adam|date=December 17, 2015|work=New York Daily News}}</ref> while the district's [[U.S. Representative]] [[Sean Patrick Maloney]] suggested that the park be named after folk singer [[Pete Seeger]].<ref name="NYT_nameChange">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/19/nyregion/demands-to-rename-donald-j-trump-state-park-gain-ground.html|title=Demands to Rename Donald J. Trump State Park Gain Ground|author=Foderaro, Lisa W.|date=December 18, 2015|accessdate=December 18, 2015|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> In response, Trump suggested that New York State return the park's land to his ownership.<ref name="LoHud_nameChange">{{cite web|url=http://www.lohud.com/story/news/politics/politics-on-the-hudson/2015/12/18/trump-state-park-fight-if-they-want-they-can-give-me-land-back/77587584/|title=Trump on state park fight: "If they want, they can give me the land back"|author=Spector, Joseph|date=December 18, 2015|accessdate=December 18, 2015|newspaper=The Journal News}}</ref> Efforts to rename the park after Peter Seeger continued in early 2016 with a petition by activist group "People for the Pete Seeger State Park" on [[Change.org]].<ref name="People for the Pete Seeger State Park">{{cite web|url=http://grist.org/politics/a-movement-to-make-trump-park-great-again-by-renaming-it-for-pete-seeger|title=A movement to make Trump Park great again — by renaming it for Pete Seeger|author=Adler, Ben|date=February 5, 2016|accessdate=September 28, 2016|magazine=Grist}}</ref>
In September 2017, New York's 25th Assembly District Representative [[Nily Rozic]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], suggested renaming the park in honor of Heather Heyer, who died in the [[Charlottesville car attack]] protesting the [[Unite the Right rally]] in Charlottesville, Virginia. No renaming of the park has been undertaken and the proposal was largely ignored.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2017/09/06/new-york-lawmaker-aims-to-rename-trump-park-for-charlottesville-victim-heather-heyer.html|title=New York lawmaker aims to rename Trump park for Charlottesville victim Heather Heyer|website=Fox News|accessdate=7 September 2017|date=2017-09-06}}</ref> Rozic, along with New York State Senator [[Brad Hoylman]], reintroduced legislation to rename the park in 2018 but it did not make it out of committee. They again introduced legislation in 2019 to rename the park.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/State-Lawmakers-Again-Trying-to-Remove-Trump-Name-From-Park--504015121.html|title=State Lawmakers Again Trying to Remove Trump Name From Park|website=NBC New York|language=en|access-date=2019-02-10}}</ref>
==Geography== The park is subdivided into two sections, the {{convert|282|acre|km2|1|adj=on}} Indian Hill parcel in northern Jefferson Valley (part of the Town of Yorktown in Westchester County) and Putnam Valley (Putnam County), and the {{convert|154|acre|km2|1|adj=on}} French Hill parcel in southern Yorktown Heights, fully within the Town of Yorktown. The parkland features a mix of continuous forest, open meadows, and several large wetlands. Headwaters for two streams, French Hill Brook and Dogwood Creek, are located within the French Hill section of the park.<ref name=Pataki_Release>{{cite web|title=Governor Pataki and Donald Trump Announce Land Gift|url=http://www.ny.gov/governor/press/06/0419061.html|website=New York State Governor's Press Releases|accessdate=April 14, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061209105048/http://www.ny.gov/governor/press/06/0419061.html|archivedate=December 9, 2006|date=April 19, 2006}}</ref>

{{for|hotels currently associated with the Trump family|The Trump Organization}} {{Infobox company | name = Trump Entertainment Resorts, Inc | logo = Trump Entertainment Resort logo.jpg | type = [[Subsidiary]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1995}} | location = Unknown (previously Trump Taj Mahal) | industry = {{hlist|[[Gambling]]|[[Entertainment]]|[[Hospitality industry|Hospitality]]}} | products = TrumpOne Card | revenue = $175.6M (2016) | parent = [[Icahn Enterprises]] | key_people = Donald Trump (founder), Carl Icahn (controlling stakeholder) }} {{Donald Trump series}}
'''Trump Entertainment Resorts, Inc.''' was a [[gambling]] and [[hospitality industry|hospitality]] company that currently does not own or operate any properties. The company previously owned and operated the now-renamed [[Trump Taj Mahal]], the now-shuttered [[Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino|Trump Plaza]], the demolished [[Trump World's Fair]], the now-renamed [[Trump Marina]], and the now-renamed [[Spotlight 29 Casino|Trump 29]]. Formerly known as '''Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts''', it was founded in 1995 by [[Donald Trump]].<ref>Bary, Andrew. [http://www.barrons.com/articles/SB50001424052970203579804576285341283000706 "More Troubles in Trump Land"], [[Barron's (newspaper)|''Barron's'']] (April 30, 2011): "Trump, the former chairman, plays no formal role in the new company."</ref> The company filed for bankruptcy in 2004, 2009 and 2014. It has been a subsidiary of [[Icahn Enterprises]] since 2016. Trump Entertainment Resorts currently owns one property, Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, which is currently shuttered and vacant.
== History ==
=== The beginning === Donald Trump began purchasing properties along the Atlantic City boardwalk in the early 1980s and received a casino license from the [[New Jersey Casino Control Commission]] (CCC) on March 15, 1982.<ref>Trump, Donald and Schwartz, Tony, '''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Ye6e_VxM00kC&pg=PA210&lpg=PA210&dq=March+15,+1982,+trump&source=bl&ots=6XqTkqINzl&sig=u2IAZz7oTsgVDdcPJgnsIVhplG8&hl=en&ei=dAa7TdeSFpS-tgem26TdBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Trump: the art of the deal]''', Random House Digital, Inc., 2004, page 204</ref> He had planned to build his own casino on the boardwalk, but was stalled on the project when Mike Rose, then CEO of [[Holiday Inn]] and [[Harrah's]] approached him to manage construction of a Holiday Inn Casino-Hotel. It opened in May 1984 and two years later Trump bought out Holiday Inn's shares in the property and renamed it the [[Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino]].<ref>Blair, Gwenda, '''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PmrwtRTQ3fMC&pg=PA345&lpg=PA345&dq=trump,+%22mike+rose%22&source=bl&ots=RKbhq2cdaE&sig=EyNYOx049y-LWxqVEdYtLV4TRxw&hl=en&ei=Pw27TbN1iumBB9WiyN0G&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=trump%2C%20%22mike%20rose%22&f=false The Trumps: Three Generations That Built an Empire]'', Simon and Schuster, 2001, page 345 [[The Trumps: Three Generations That Built an Empire]]</ref>
In 1985, Trump purchased the nearly-complete Atlantic City Hilton hotel and casino property at the Atlantic marina from [[Hilton Hotels]] for $325 million. The hotel chain sold the property after its application for a gaming license was turned down by the CCC.<ref>Delugach, Al, [https://articles.latimes.com/1985-04-19/business/fi-15078_1_atlantic-city-hotel Hilton Negotiating to Sell Its Atlantic City Hotel-Casino to Trump], L.A. Times, April 19, 1985</ref> Trump originally opened the property as Trump's Castle Hotel Casino, and later renamed it the [[Trump Marina]].
In 1988, Trump purchased the unfinished Taj Mahal property from [[Resorts International]] for $230 million after negotiations with [[Merv Griffin]] in which the two men divided the assets of the failing company.<ref>Easton, Nina, [https://articles.latimes.com/1988-07-24/magazine/tm-10039_1_merv-griffin/14 Merv Griffin's Outrageous Fortune...], L.A. Times, July 24, 1988</ref> The casino, at the time the largest in Atlantic City, would eventually cost almost $1 billion by the time it opened in 1990. Trump completed the project using [[High-yield debt|junk bonds]], a decision that hurt the company afterward as the gaming industry struggled in [[Early 1990s recession|a recession]] and interest rates became unmanageable.<ref>Clark, Kenneth, [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-04-06/news/9001280173_1_donald-trump-marla-maples-trump-taj-mahal Trump Taj Mahal Casino-hotel Opens With A Bang], Chicago Tribune, April 6, 1990</ref><ref>{{cite web | title=After his gloom went over like a lead balloon, Trump tries to sell happiness, in junk bonds | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/07/business/markets-market-place-after-his-gloom-went-over-like-lead-balloon-trump-tries.html |work=The New York Times | date=May 7, 2002 | accessdate=December 18, 2018 | author=Atlas, D. Riva}}</ref>
The company was shaken by the deaths of three key executives in an April 10, 1989 helicopter crash in northern New Jersey while they were returning from a New York press conference promoting an upcoming Atlantic City boxing event. The men were Steven F. Hyde, the CEO of Trump's casino operations, Mark Grossinger Etess, the president and chief operating officer of the Taj Mahal, and Trump Plaza executive vice president Jonathan Benanav.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/11/nyregion/copter-crash-kills-3-aides-of-trump.html?mcubz=0</ref>
In 1995, Trump established '''Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts''' (THCR) as a publicly traded company, granting it ownership of the Trump Plaza and the under-development [[Majestic Star II|Trump Casino]] in [[Gary, Indiana]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump Plaza casino stock trades today on Big Board|newspaper=New York Times|author=Floyd Norris|date=June 7, 1995|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/06/07/business/trump-plaza-casino-stock-trades-today-on-big-board.html|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref> The following year, THCR bought the Trump Taj Mahal at a valuation of $890 million,<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump moves to put Taj Mahal in his company|newspaper=New York Times|author=David Cay Johnston|date=January 9, 1996|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/09/business/trump-moves-to-put-taj-mahal-in-his-company.html|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite report|title=Form 8-K: Current Report|publisher=Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts Inc.|date=May 2, 1996|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/943320/0000950130-96-001492.txt|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref> and bought the Trump Castle from Trump for $486 million (including $355 million in assumed debt).<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump co. buying Castle|newspaper=New York Daily News|author=Douglas Feiden|date=October 1, 1996|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/money/trump-buying-castle-donald-130m-stock-885g-cash-article-1.737340|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref>
In 1996, the company opened [[Trump World's Fair]], a casino adjunct to the Trump Plaza.<ref>{{cite news|title=At Trump's World's Fair opening, gamblers hope casino 13 is lucky|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|author=Amy S. Rosenberg|date=May 16, 1996|url=http://articles.philly.com/1996-05-16/news/25625256_1_fourth-casino-casino-license-casino-official|accessdate=2014-12-15}}</ref> The World's Fair was closed in 1999, with plans to replace it with a larger resort.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump closes old resort for new one in Atlantic City, N.J.|newspaper=Knight Ridder/Tribune Business News|author=Patrick Jenkins|date=February 17, 2000|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-59513389.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150329081014/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-59513389.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 29, 2015|accessdate=2014-12-15}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref>
In 1997, THCR was one of eleven applicants for three casino licenses available in [[Detroit]], with a $542-million proposal for the Trump Motor City Hotel Casino, in partnership with [[Mel Farr]].<ref name="reindl">{{cite news|title=Donald Trump's 1997 bid for Detroit casino showed off campaign style|newspaper=Detroit Free Press|author=JC Reindl|date=June 21, 2016|url=http://www.freep.com/story/money/business/michigan/2016/06/20/donald-trump-bid-detroit-casino-showed-off-campaign-style/85931570/|accessdate=2016-07-19}}</ref> The bid was ultimately dropped from consideration because of Mayor [[Dennis Archer]]'s doubts about the company's financial condition.<ref name="reindl" />
In 1998, THCR business consultants spent at least $68,000 on a trip to [[Cuba]] in violation to the [[United States embargo against Cuba]]. According to a report by ''[[Newsweek]]'', the consulting firm Seven Arrows Investment and Development instructed THCR on how to evade the embargo by linking the money to a charitable effort.<ref name="Newsweek">{{cite web |last=Eichenwald |first=Kurt |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2016/10/14/donald-trump-cuban-embargo-castro-violated-florida-504059.html |title=Donald Trump's company violated the U.S. embargo against Cuba |work=Newsweek |date=September 29, 2016 |access-date=September 30, 2016}}</ref>
In 1999, THCR agreed to purchase the [[Isle of Capri Kansas City|Flamingo Hilton Casino Kansas City]] for $15 million,<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump buying casino in KC|newspaper=Kansas City Star|author=Rick Alm|date=January 15, 1999|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F0EAF46B10E72859D&rft_id=info%3Asid%2Finfoweb.newsbank.com&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&svc_dat=AWNB&req_dat=1028A39C75C2B899|via=NewsBank}}</ref> but the deal fell through when Missouri gaming regulators did not approve the company's gaming license by a contractual deadline.<ref>{{cite news|title=KC Flamingo to be bought by Station|newspaper=Kansas City Star|author=Rick Alm|date=September 14, 1999|url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/resources/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_dat=document_id%3Anews%252F0EAF477F16FA846B&rft_id=info%3Asid%2Finfoweb.newsbank.com&rft_val_format=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Actx&svc_dat=AWNB&req_dat=1028A39C75C2B899|via=NewsBank}}</ref>
THCR entered a management agreement in 2000 to operate the [[Spotlight 29 Casino]], an [[Indian casino]] in [[Coachella, California]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Palm Springs tribe, Trump sign casino deal|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|author1=Tom Gorman|author2=Dan Morain|date=March 9, 2000|url=https://articles.latimes.com/2000/mar/09/news/mn-6942|accessdate=2014-12-15}}</ref>
===Financial troubles=== Trump Entertainment Resorts and its predecessors have filed for [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection]] four times, in 1991, following construction of the $1-billion Trump Taj Mahal, and in 2004, 2009 and 2014.
In 2004, Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts explored various options for restructuring its debt, amid speculation that it might file for bankruptcy. A possible arrangement with [[Credit Suisse First Boston]] was not completed because the bondholders rejected it.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/money/trump-bets-new-debt-deal-345m-csfb-rescue-plan-crumbles-article-1.563901 |title=Trump Hotels says deal with Credit Suisse First Boston is dead |work=Daily News |author= Lore Croghan |date=September 24, 2004}}</ref>
On October 21, 2004, the company announced a preliminary agreement with its investors. Trump, who had been the majority owner, would reduce his stock ownership from 56 to 27 percent. Bondholders would surrender some of their debt in exchange for stock. On October 27, the company announced that [[Morgan Stanley]] would be the joint lead arranger for a $500 million financing as part of the restructuring plan. On November 21, the company filed for bankruptcy. Trump said the filing was "really just a technical thing" as the best way to implement the restructuring plan.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/id/6556470 |title=Trump casinos file for bankruptcy; 'Apprentice' star's firm seeks protection from creditors |work=Associated Press |date=November 22, 2004}}</ref> The plan was submitted to the [[bankruptcy court]] on December 16, 2004.
After the 2004 bankruptcy, Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts changed its name to Trump Entertainment Resorts (TER).
In 2005, the company's involvement in the Spotlight 29 Casino ended, as the tribe bought out the casino management agreement for $6 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Casino reannointed 'Spotlight 29' in Trump-deal buyout|newspaper=The Public Record|location=Palm Springs, CA|author=Rick Davis|date=February 15, 2005|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-796885631.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150329081012/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-796885631.html|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 29, 2015}} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> Later that year, TER sold its Indiana casino to [[The Majestic Star Casino, LLC]] for $253 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump to sell Gary casino to Majestic Star for $253 million|newspaper=The Times of Northwest Indiana|date=November 4, 2005|url=http://www.nwitimes.com/news/local/trump-to-sell-gary-casino-to-majestic-star-for-million/article_585fc7eb-80db-5d01-a6d2-476641ad9f8f.html|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|title=Trump Entertainment Resorts completes sale of Trump Indiana riverboat to Majestic Star|publisher=Trump Entertainment Resorts|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/943320/000090951805000995/mv12-22ex99_1.txt|date=December 21, 2005|via=EDGAR|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref> The company had also been awarded a license to build a second casino in [[Orange County, Indiana]], but dropped this plan, due in part to the state's concerns about the company's viability.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump drops plans for Orange County casino|newspaper=WIBC-FM|date=March 2, 2005|url=http://www.wibc.com/blogs/trump-drops-plans-orange-county-casino|accessdate=2014-12-14}}</ref>
In 2007, the company attempted to negotiate a [[buyout]] with several public and private firms, but on July 2, it announced that it could not reach a deal, and would take itself off the market. The company planned to lay off employees in order to cut costs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/trump-entertainment-shares-plummet-no/story.aspx?guid=%7B94B3DE7D%2D5F9C%2D4F6B%2D87AE%2D43EC0A68CC1A%7D&siteid=yhoof |publisher=MarketWatch |title=No Trump Entertainment deal; shares plunge |author=William Spain|date=July 2, 2007}}</ref>
===2009 bankruptcy and restructuring=== The casino group filed for bankruptcy again in February 2009,<ref>{{cite web|title=Trump Entertainment Resorts Chapter 11 Petition|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/UIAP7CQ/Trump_Entertainment_Resorts,_Inc.__njbke-09-13655__0001.0.pdf|website=PacerMonitor|accessdate=31 May 2016}}</ref><ref>Love, Zach, [http://www.law.com/jsp/tal/PubArticleTAL.jsp?id=1202428342063 Bankruptcy Roundup: Trump Dumps Casinos, Fortunoff Gets Sued, and Peanut Corp. Goes Under], Law.Com, Feb. 17, 2009</ref> owing $1.2 billion. Two sets of debt holders eventually proposed reorganization plans for the group in U.S. bankruptcy court.
Trump initially made an agreement with banker and poker player [[Andrew Beal]], owner of [[Beal Bank]], which held $500 million in the group's debt, to take over the resorts. However, citing concerns about the bank's lack of gaming experience, he dropped them in favor of hedge fund [[Avenue Capital Management]], a plan favored by other bondholders. Beal then partnered with investor, [[Carl Icahn]], who had worked on restructuring another Atlantic City casino, the [[Tropicana Casino and Resort Atlantic City|Tropicana]].<ref>Grant, Peter, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704467804574589771542215910 Icahn Leaps Into Trump Casino Battle], Wall Street Journal, Dec. 14, 2009</ref> In court, Trump argued that he would fight the Icahn/Beal team if they sought to use his name and likeness on the group's properties.<ref>Church, Steven, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aCuQLtkCp0js Trump Argues Name Can't Be Used By Icahn for Casinos (Update4)], Bloomberg, February 23, 2010</ref> Instead he signed an agreement with Avenue Capital in which he would receive 5% stock in the reorganized company and another 5% in exchange for the use of his name and likeness in perpetuity.
The bankruptcy court eventually sided with the Trump/Avenue partnership, favored by bond holders who believed that Trump's brand would result in a stronger company after reorganization.<ref>Gallagher, Mary Pat, [http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1202473063287&rss=newswire&slreturn=1&hbxlogin=1 Trump-Icahn Bankruptcy Pact OK'd but Bondholders' Legal Fees Unresolved], Law.Com, Oct. 8, 2010</ref>
In 2011, TER sold the [[Trump Marina]] to [[Landry's Restaurants]], which also operates the [[Golden Nugget Las Vegas|Golden Nugget]] in Las Vegas.<ref>[http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2011/02/trump_to_sell_atlantic_city_ma.html Trump Entertainment to sell Atlantic City Marina Hotel for $38M], Star-Ledger, Feb. 14, 2011</ref>
===Post 2009 bankruptcy=== In February 2013, the company agreed to sell the Trump Plaza for $20 million to the [[Meruelo Group]], a California-based company whose holdings include the [[Grand Sierra Resort]] in [[Reno, Nevada]]. The proceeds would be used to pay down the company's debt to a level of $270 million. CEO Robert Griffin said TER would consider also selling the Trump Taj Mahal for the right price.<ref>{{cite news|title=Atlantic City's Trump Plaza goes for bargain $20M|newspaper=Miami Herald|agency=AP|author=Wayne Parry|date=February 14, 2013|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/02/14/3234803/apnewsbreak-acs-trump-plaza-sold.html|accessdate=2013-02-14}}</ref> However, Carl Icahn, who held the mortgage on the Trump casinos, would reject the sale of the Trump Plaza.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/press/atlantic_city/carl-icahn-won-t-approve-sale-of-trump-plaza-for/article_6bf05244-abb4-11e2-97a7-0019bb2963f4.html|title=Carl Icahn won't approve sale of Trump Plaza for $20M|work=Press of Atlantic City|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
In early August 2014, Donald Trump filed a lawsuit demanding removal of his name from the company's two casinos, because they had allegedly been allowed to fall into disrepair, in breach of the licensing agreement for Trump's name.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Parry|first1=Wayne|title=Trump: Plaza and Taj Mahal too shabby to bear his name anymore|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/20140806_Trump__Plaza_and_Taj_Mahal_casinos_too_shabby_to_bear_his_name_anymore.html|website=philly.com|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref>
===2014 bankruptcy=== In September 2014, Trump Entertainment Resorts filed again for bankruptcy,<ref>{{cite web|title=Trump Entertainment Resorts|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/view/QGLEBUY/Trump_Entertainment_Resorts_Inc__debke-14-12103__0001.0.pdf|website=PacerMonitor|publisher=PacerMonitor|accessdate=31 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/09/trump-bankruptcy-atlantic-city_n_5789826.html |agency=Reuters| title=Trump Entertainment Resorts Files For Bankruptcy| publisher=Huffington Post |date=September 9, 2014 |accessdate=February 19, 2015}}</ref> and closed the Trump Plaza.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump Plaza closes, making it official: A third of Atlantic City's casinos have closed this year|newspaper=Washington Post|author=Mark Berman|date=September 16, 2014|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2014/09/16/trump-plaza-closes-making-it-official-a-third-of-atlantic-citys-casinos-have-closed-this-year/|accessdate=2016-03-25}}</ref> On a motion made by union [[UNITE HERE]] Local 54,<ref>http://www.esquireglobalcrossings.com/files/2016/01/Trump-Entertainment-Resorts.pdf</ref> relating to the bankruptcy action, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]] ruled in Trump Entertainment's favor on January 15, 2016 and held that Trump Entertainment could reject the continuing terms and conditions of a [[collective bargaining]] agreement with the union, an agreement that had already expired by its terms. This case was significant as it was a matter of [[first impression (law)|First impression]] among the courts of appeal and could significantly alter the balance of power between debtor-employers and their unions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Salzberg|first1=Mark A.|title=Trump (Entertainment) Wins! Chapter 11 Bankruptcy and Union CBAs|journal=The National Law Review|date=23 January 2016|url=http://www.natlawreview.com/article/trump-entertainment-wins-chapter-11-bankruptcy-and-union-cbas|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Taj Mahal Atlantic City New Jersey.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the Trump Taj Mahal at night, [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]]]]The company eventually exited bankruptcy in February 2016 and became a subsidiary of [[Icahn Enterprises]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump's former Atlantic City jewel exits bankruptcy, now Icahn's|newspaper=Bloomberg Business|author=Christopher Palmieri|date=February 26, 2016|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-02-27/trump-s-former-atlantic-city-jewel-exits-bankruptcy-now-icahn-s|accessdate=2016-02-26}}</ref>
==Folding of the company== On October 10, 2016 the Trump Taj Mahal, the company's last operating property, closed for the final time. Trump Entertainment will remain operating to deal with the transfer of some points on the Trump One card account.<ref>there is only ''This site is currently under maintenance'', retrieved June 14, 2017.</ref> All of the websites related to the company redirect to DonaldJTrump.com. Trump Plaza is still owned by the company, and has been vacant since its closure in September 2014. The Plaza has been liquidated of its assets in rumor of implosion. On December 14, 2018, the demolition deadline officially passed, meaning Trump Plaza will remain standing through the winter.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/press/casinos_tourism/no-word-on-future-of-trump-plaza-as-another-demolition/article_3533e20b-ec5c-5cf6-8068-ca5e9b5114ba.html|title=No word on future of Trump Plaza as another demolition deadline passes|last=Writer|first=DAVID DANZIS Staff|website=Press of Atlantic City|language=en|access-date=2019-01-02}}</ref> In late December 2018, Carl Icahn, the owner of Icahn Enterprises which owns Trump Entertainment Resorts, terminated the deed restriction on the property, and bought out a complicated lease. This is important as it makes a sale much more attractive.
==Former properties== The company's former properties include: *[[Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino|Harrah's at Trump Plaza]] in Atlantic City, New Jersey (formerly a 50/50 partnership with [[Caesars Entertainment Corporation|Harrah's]]) now wholly owned and renamed as the [[Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino|Trump Plaza]], which was closed on September 16, 2014. *[[Spotlight 29 Casino|Trump 29 Casino]] in [[Coachella, California]] (formerly a 50/50 partnership with the [[Twenty-Nine Palms Band of Mission Indians of California]]) 2006 Trump officially got out. Now [[Spotlight 29 Casino]]. *[[Majestic Star II|Trump Casino]] in [[Gary, Indiana]] now the [[Majestic Star II]]. * [[Trump World's Fair]] at Trump Plaza in Atlantic City, New Jersey. Operated as a wing of Trump Plaza, but with its own casino license, it was closed in 1999, and demolished in 2000. * [[Trump Castle]] (renamed [[Trump Marina]] in 1997) in Atlantic City, New Jersey, sold to [[Landry's, Inc.]] in 2011 and renamed the [[Golden Nugget Atlantic City]] * [[Steel Pier]], sold in 2011 * [[Trump Taj Mahal]], a casino resort on the Atlantic City boardwalk; closed on October 10, 2016; purchased by [[Hard Rock Cafe|Hard Rock International]] and reopened as the [[Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Atlantic City]] in June 2018

Sobe Life (2004–2007)
Ocean Drive Media Group (2007–2009) | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | circulation_year = | total_circulation = | founder = | founded = | firstdate = {{Start date and age|1997|02}} (''Trump Style'') | finaldate = {{End date|2009|05}} (''Trump Magazine'') | finalnumber = | company = | country = United States | based = | language = English | website = | issn = | oclc = }} Several '''magazines named after [[Donald Trump]]''' were published between 1997 and 2009. '''''Trump Style''''', launched in February 1997, was available for free to VIP guests at [[Trump Entertainment Resorts|Trump's hotel-casino properties]], and was also available to residents of Trump's condominium buildings and members of his [[Mar-a-Lago]] club. A new magazine known as '''''Trump World''''', initially pitched to Trump by Michael Jacobson, was launched in November 2002, as a replacement for ''Trump Style''. Because of a dispute between Jacobson and the magazine's publishing company, ''Trump World'' was discontinued after its second issue was printed in May 2003. ''Trump World'' was relaunched in September 2004, and was renamed as '''''Trump Magazine''''' in March 2006. A special edition for the New York City area was launched later that year. A new version of ''Trump Magazine'' was launched in November 2007; the publication ended in May 2009, due to poor advertising sales as a result of the [[Great Recession in the United States|Great Recession]]. ==History== ===''Trump Style'' (1997–2002)=== In October 1996, [[Donald Trump]] announced plans for ''Trump Style'', a magazine to be distributed at his condo and hotel properties beginning in early 1997. The magazine was to be published by [[the New York Times Company]]'s custom-publishing division, with 100,000 copies to be distributed on two separate occasions in 1997. Trump planned to switch the magazine to a quarterly publication in 1998. The premiere issue was to include fashion and food information, as well as [[horoscope]]s, a story about Italy's [[Amalfi Coast]], and the latest information regarding Trump's casino games and shows.{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Karen|title=Pageants, 'Style' in Trump's cards|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/|accessdate=May 30, 2017|work=[[USA Today]]|date=October 24, 1996|url-access=subscription}} ''Trump Style'' was launched by New York Times Custom Publishing in February 1997.{{cite news|title=The Donald....|url=http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article/the-donald-115468|accessdate=May 30, 2017|work=Casino City Times|date=February 17, 1997}} The magazine had a circulation of 130,000, and was available for free to VIP guests who stayed at [[Trump Entertainment Resorts|Trump's hotel-casino properties]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]].{{cite news|last=Huhn|first=Mary|title=Style Without Substance – Ivana vs. Donald in Match of Egos|url=https://nypost.com/1999/02/17/style-without-substance-ivana-vs-donald-in-match-of-egos/|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=[[New York Post]]|date=February 17, 1999}} ''Trump Style'' was also available to residents of Trump's five Trump-branded condominium buildings in New York, and to members of his [[Mar-a-Lago]] club in Florida.{{cite news|last=DeAngelis|first=Martin|title=Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous, from an Expert|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/|accessdate=May 30, 2017|work=[[The Press of Atlantic City]]|date=March 16, 1997|url-access=subscription}} The premiere issue contained 68 color pages made of heavyweight paper, and was arranged into several sections: Trump News, providing information on Trump's new [[Trump International Hotel and Tower (New York City)|Trump International Hotel and Tower]] in Manhattan; Trump Scene, featuring six pictures of famous visitors to Mar-a-Lago, including multiple pictures of Trump and his wife [[Marla Maples]]; Casino News, offering information about Trump's casinos; and horoscopes written by [[Athena Starwoman]]. Other sections included Wines and Spirits, and Trends. Martin DeAngelis of ''[[The Press of Atlantic City]]'' wrote a positive review of ''Trump Style'', and noted that the magazine "is, tragically, not on sale - anywhere." ===''Trump World'' (2002–2003)=== Michael Jacobson, who was involved with Lockwood Publications, stayed in a suite at the [[Golden Nugget Atlantic City|Trump Marina]] hotel-casino in Atlantic City at the end of 2001. Jacobson conceived the idea for a Trump-branded magazine after noticing that his suite offered no magazines to read. Jacobson met Trump shortly thereafter and the two agreed to start a magazine that would be named after Trump. On November 14, 2002, at the World Bar inside [[Trump World Tower]] in New York, Trump unveiled plans to replace ''Trump Style'' with a new magazine to be known as ''Trump World''. Jacobson expected to spend under $1 million to launch the new magazine, which would be published quarterly. A total of 50,000 copies would be offered to guests for free at Trump's country clubs, condominium properties, and hotel-casinos, while another 50,000 would be mailed to upper-class people. Trump, who would not be spending any money on the magazine, would still earn a portion of the profits. Trump said, "I have editorial control, but I also have a tremendous lack of time. I'm not going to be checking commas. I'm not going to be very involved." The magazine's [[editor-in-chief]] was Alyson Boxman Levine. [[Charlotte Ross]] appeared on the cover of the new magazine.{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Keith J.|title=Trump, the Magazine: The Donald Launches Luxury Lifestyle Quarterly|url=https://nypost.com/2002/11/14/trump-the-magazine-the-donald-launches-luxury-lifestyle-quarterly/|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=New York Post|date=November 14, 2002}} After the second issue was published in May 2003, Lockwood Publications ended its publication of ''Trump World'' because of a dispute between Jacobson and Lockwood. Jacobson had wanted to turn ''Trump World'' into a paid-circulation magazine and increase its distribution, an idea that Lockwood rejected. Lockwood had already done so for another magazine that it published {{ndash}} known as ''Smoke'' {{ndash}} and was reluctant to do the same for another one of its magazines. Lockwood sold ''Trump World'' to Jacobson for less than $100,000. ===''Trump World'' revival (2004–2006)=== In June 2004, Trump announced plans for a redesigned version of ''Trump World'' that would be sold to the public as a bimonthly magazine, with an initial printing of 200,000 copies.{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Peter|title=It's Trump's 'World'; we're just living in it|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2004-06-28-trump-magazine_x.htm|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=[[USA Today]]|date=June 28, 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140307040514/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2004-06-28-trump-magazine_x.htm|archivedate=March 7, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Groves|first=Lloyd|title=Trump Fires Up the Presses|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/gossip/trump-fires-presses-article-1.635539|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=New York Daily News|date=June 29, 2004}}{{cite news|title=Donald Trump Will Launch Magazine|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/jul/01/business/fi-rup1.6|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 1, 2004}} Jacobson would serve as the editor and publisher of a new company known as Sobe Life LLC, which had more than $1 million in financial support from Lee Fry, a Chicago entrepreneur who would serve as the magazine's primary financial backer and as [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) of Sobe Life. Jacobson said the new magazine would be distributed to approximately 50,000 rooms located at Trump's properties, and would be offered for free to guests, while an additional 150,000 would be for sale nationally.{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Keith J.|title=Makeover at Trump World – Startup Company Selling The Donald for $29.99 a Year|url=https://nypost.com/2004/09/08/makeover-at-trump-world-startup-company-selling-the-donald-for-29-99-a-year/|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=New York Post|date=September 8, 2004}} The magazine would be targeted at people between the ages of 21 and 55, and would focus on diverse topics including arts and entertainment, food and wine, travel, and real estate, as well as successful business stories, and information about [[The Apprentice (U.S. season 2)|the second season]] of Trump's [[reality television]] series, ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]''. Jacobson, who believed that the success of ''The Apprentice'' would help sales of the new ''Trump World'', said that 30 percent of the magazine would focus on Trump's properties. ''Trump World'' went on sale in September 2004.{{cite news|last=Traub|first=James|title=Trumpologies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/12/magazine/trumpologies.html|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=September 12, 2004}} Model [[Caprice Bourret]] appeared on the cover of the first issue.{{cite news|last=Dash|first=Eric|title=Trump-isms, For Only $5.95|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/01/business/openers-suits-trump-isms-for-only-5.95.html?_r=0|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 1, 2004}} As of December 2005, the magazine had lost more than $3 million and was largely considered to be a failure. However, as part of a licensing agreement, Trump earned $120,000 for each issue published that year. Beginning in 2006, Trump received a [[Royalty payment|royalty fee]] of $135,000 for each issue, and was to continue receiving royalty fees through 2009. Trump also had the right to read and approve each issue at least 10 days prior to its publication. ===''Trump Magazine'' (2006–2009)=== In March 2006,{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Keith J.|title=Trump Mag Publisher to Make OTC Play|url=https://nypost.com/2006/07/27/trump-mag-publisher-to-make-otc-play/|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=New York Post|date=July 27, 2006}} Jacobson renamed the magazine as ''Trump Magazine'' and began marketing it towards men. Jacobson changed the magazine to focus on Trump's lifestyle and personality, and also placed Trump on the cover of the spring 2006 issue. The changes were successful, with the spring issue earning approximately $250,000. Trump's daughter, model [[Ivanka Trump]], appeared on the summer 2006 cover of the revamped magazine to help attract male readers.{{cite news|last=Groves|first=Lloyd|title=In Divorce Saga, Ron Has the Last Word|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/gossip/divorce-saga-ron-word-article-1.654231|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=New York Post|date=March 23, 2006}} In October 2006, a New York City edition of ''Trump Magazine'' was launched and sold out within 30 days. At that time, ''Trump World'' had a circulation of 207,000, a quarter of which was distributed to Trump's properties. That month, plans were announced to launch a [[south Florida]] edition in February 2007.{{cite news|last=Schneiderman|first=R.M.|title=Trump Launches South Florida Magazine|url=https://www.forbes.com/2006/10/06/donald-trump-magazine-cx_rs_1006autofacescan06.html|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=[[Forbes]]|date=October 6, 2006}} Premiere Publishing Group {{ndash}} the parent company of Sobe Life, with Jacobson as its CEO{{cite web|title=Premiere Publishing Group Announces a Trump Animation Series|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Premiere+Publishing+Group+Announces+a+Trump+Animation+Series.-a0152690476|publisher=The Free Library|accessdate=April 12, 2017|date=October 12, 2006}} {{ndash}} published ''Trump Magazine'' until 2007. Ocean Drive Media Group announced plans for a new ''Trump Magazine'' in September 2007, with the first issue scheduled for launch in November 2007. The new magazine would be published quarterly, with wider distribution than the previous version of ''Trump Magazine''. The initial printing would consist of 100,000 copies, which would be distributed for free at Trump properties and would also be sold in several cities where the properties were located. Glen Albin would serve as the editor.{{cite news|last=Pérez-Peña|first=Richard|title=If You Have Money, Trump Knows How to Use It|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/25/business/25trump.html?ex=1348372800&en=b457f8de010e2e57&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=The New York Times|date=September 25, 2007}} [[Niche Media]] acquired ''Trump Magazine'' in 2007, as part of its acquisition of Ocean Drive Media.{{cite web|url=http://www.regionalmediaadvisors.com/press-releases/145-donald-j-trump-joins-publisher-jerry-powers-to-host-magazine-kick-off-at-trump-tower|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150307095736/http://www.regionalmediaadvisors.com/press-releases/145-donald-j-trump-joins-publisher-jerry-powers-to-host-magazine-kick-off-at-trump-tower|url-status=dead|archive-date=7 March 2015|title=Ocean Drive Media Group Partners with Trump Magazine|date=7 March 2015|accessdate=22 July 2018}} Niche ended the magazine in May 2009, because of low advertisement sales as a result of the [[Great Recession in the United States|Great Recession]].{{cite news|last= Kelly|first= Keith J.|title= Trump's Magazine Closed|url= https://nypost.com/2009/05/20/trumps-magazine-closed/|accessdate= April 12, 2017|work= New York Post|date= May 20, 2009}} In February 2016, the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' reported that issues of ''Trump World'' "are nowhere to be found online and hardcopies are likely a rare collector's item."{{cite news|last=Bult|first=Laura|title=The Donald's failed shot at media glory: Even the blowhard billionaire couldn't keep Trump Magazine afloat|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/remembering-failed-wealth-porn-trump-magazine-article-1.2528638|accessdate=April 12, 2017|work=[[New York
