{{pp-protected|small=yes}} {{short description|Donald Trump}} {{Use American English|date = August 2019}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2019}} {{Donald Trump series}} The net worth of [[Donald Trump]], the 45th [[president of the United States]], is not publicly known. Various news organizations have attempted to estimate Trump's wealth, including ''[[Forbes]]'', which put it at about US $2.1 billion {{as of|2020|4|7|lc=y|df=}}.<ref name="forbes-2019-billionaires2">{{cite magazine|year=2019|title=The World's Billionaires – No. 715 Donald Trump|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/donald-trump/?list=billionaires|magazine=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=April 10, 2019}}</ref>
==Gifts, loans, and other wealth from his father== According to an investigation by the ''New York Times'', Donald Trump received at least $413 million (2018 prices) from his father's business empire.<ref name = "takeaways"/> The ''New York Times'' drew upon more than 100,000 pages of tax returns and financial records from [[Fred Trump]]'s businesses and interviews with former advisers and employees, finding 295 distinct streams of revenue that Fred Trump created over five decades in order to channel his wealth to his son.<ref name="takeaways"/><ref name="Tax_Schemes">{{cite news| url= https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/10/02/us/politics/donald-trump-tax-schemes-fred-trump.html| title= Trump Engaged in Suspect Tax Schemes as He Reaped Riches From His Father|last1=Barstow|first1=David|date=October 2, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=October 2, 2018| last2=Craig|first2=Susanne|last3=Buettner|first3=Russ|author1link=David Barstow| author2link=Susanne Craig}}</ref>
===Trust funds=== Trump is the beneficiary of several trust funds set up by his father and paternal grandmother beginning in 1949 when he was three years old.<ref name="Kessler160303">{{cite news |first=Glenn |last=Kessler |authorlink=Glenn Kessler (journalist) |title=Trump's false claim he built his empire with a 'small loan' from his father |date=March 3, 2016 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/03/03/trumps-false-claim-he-built-his-empire-with-a-small-loan-from-his-father}}</ref> According to the New York Times, he "was a millionaire by age 28",<ref name="takeaways">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/02/us/politics/donald-trump-wealth-fred-trump.html |title=11 Takeaways From The Times's Investigation Into Trump's Wealth|last1=Barstow|first1=David|date=October 2, 2018|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=October 3, 2018|last2=Craig|first2=Susanne|last3=Buettner|first3=Russ|author1link=David Barstow|author2link=Susanne Craig}}</ref><ref name="Tax_Schemes" /> In 1976, Fred set up trust funds of $1 million (${{Inflation|US|1|1976|r=1}} million in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars) for each of his five children and three grandchildren. Donald Trump received $90,000 in 1980 and $214,605 in 1981 through the fund.<ref name="Kessler160303" />
===Alleged tax-fraud schemes=== Donald Trump was also involved in a number of purportedly fraudulent tax schemes. When Fred Trump sold shares in ''Trump Palace'' condos to his son well below their purchase price, masking what could be considered a hidden donation, and benefiting from a tax write-off.<ref name="Tax_Schemes" /> A lawyer for Trump denied the allegations, calling them "100 percent false, and highly defamatory". A spokesman for the New York State tax department said the agency was "vigorously pursuing all appropriate areas of investigation".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/10/03/new-york-trump-tax-fraud/1512265002/|title=New York could levy hefty penalties if Trump tax fraud is proven|last=Campbell|first=Jon|date=October 3, 2018|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=October 5, 2018| last2=Spector| first2=Joseph}}</ref> New York City officials also indicated they are examining the matter of Trump's alleged fraudulence.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/04/us/politics/donald-trump-fred-trump-tax-schemes.html|title=New York Regulators Examine the Trump Family's Tax Schemes|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=October 6, 2018}}</ref>
===Inheritance=== In 1993, when Trump took two loans totaling $30 million from his siblings, their anticipated shares of Fred's estate amounted to $3.5 million each.<ref name="OBrien2005Oct">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/23/business/yourmoney/whats-he-really-worth.html |title=What's He Really Worth? |first=Timothy L. |last=O'Brien |authorlink=Timothy L. O'Brien |accessdate=February 25, 2016 |date=October 23, 2005 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref name="Kessler160303" /> Upon Fred Trump's death in 1999, his will divided $20 million after taxes among his surviving children.<ref name="Kessler160303" /><ref name="Rozhon26June">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/26/nyregion/fred-c-trump-postwar-master-builder-of-housing-for-middle-class-dies-at-93.html |title=Fred C. Trump, Postwar Master Builder of Housing for Middle Class, Dies at 93 |first=Tracy |last=Rozhon |date=June 26, 1999 |accessdate=August 19, 2015 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref><ref name="For Donald Trump, Lessons From a Brother's Suffering">{{cite news |last=Horowitz |first=Jason |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/03/us/politics/for-donald-trump-lessons-from-a-brothers-suffering.html |title=For Donald Trump, Lessons From a Brother's Suffering |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 2, 2016 |quote=Then came the unveiling of Fred Sr.'s will, which Donald had helped draft. It divided the bulk of the inheritance, at least $20 million, among his children and their descendants, 'other than my son Fred C. Trump Jr.'}}</ref>
===Acknowledged loans from his father=== His immense wealth from childhood notwithstanding, Trump has sought to burnish a reputation for business acumen by minimizing the amount of money he received from his father.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/03/03/trumps-false-claim-he-built-his-empire-with-a-small-loan-from-his-father/|title=Trump's false claim he built his empire with a 'small loan' from his father|last=Checker|first=Glenn Kessler closeGlenn KesslerThe Fact CheckerEmailEmailBioBioFollowFollowThe Fact|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2019-11-13}}</ref> He has acknowledged borrowing just $1 million from his father as a young adult, in a sworn deposition and repeatedly on the campaign trail, calling his loan "a very small amount of money"<ref name="Massie5Nov">{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/christophermassie/donald-trump-in-deposition-96-million-i-borrowed-from-dads-e#.eyXQGBEPq|title=Trump In Deposition: $1 Million I Borrowed From Dad's Estate A "Small Amount"|last=Massie|first=Christopher|date=November 5, 2015|work=Buzzfeed|accessdate=February 29, 2016}}</ref><ref name="small-loan">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/10/26/donald-trump-my-dad-gave-me-a-small-loan-of-1-million-to-get-started.html|title=Donald Trump: My dad gave me 'a small loan' of $1 million to get started|last=Stump|first=Scott|date=October 26, 2015|accessdate=November 13, 2016|publisher=[[CNBC]]}}</ref>
==Net worth== [[File:Las-Vegas-Trump-Hotel-8480.jpg|thumb|upright|right|alt=A tall rectangular-shaped tower in Las Vegas with exterior windows reflecting a golden hue. It is a sunny day and the building is higher than many of the surrounding buildings, also towers. There are mountains in the background.|[[Trump International Hotel Las Vegas]], with gold-infused glass<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael J. |last=Mishak |title=Trump's tower a sore spot on the Strip |date=April 30, 2011 |accessdate=November 11, 2016 |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |url=https://articles.latimes.com/2011/apr/30/nation/la-na-0430-trump-vegas-20110430 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018102438/http://articles.latimes.com/2011/apr/30/nation/la-na-0430-trump-vegas-20110430 |archive-date=October 18, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref>]]
Trump was listed on the initial ''Forbes List'' of wealthy individuals in 1982 as having a share of his family's estimated $200 million net worth.<ref name="OBrien2005Oct" /> Former ''Forbes'' reporter Jonathan Greenberg said in 2018 that during the 1980s Trump had deceived him about his actual net worth and his share of the family assets in order to appear on the list. According to Greenberg,
"it took decades to unwind the elaborate farce Trump had enacted to project an image as one of the richest people in America. Nearly every assertion supporting that claim was untrue. Trump wasn't just poorer than he said he was. Over time, I have learned that he should not have been on the first three Forbes 400 lists at all. In our first-ever list, in 1982, we included him at $100 million, but Trump was actually worth roughly $5 million—a paltry sum by the standards of his super-monied peers—as a spate of government reports and books showed only much later."<ref name="WP-20180420">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/trump-lied-to-me-about-his-wealth-to-get-onto-the-forbes-400-here-are-the-tapes/2018/04/20/ac762b08-4287-11e8-8569-26fda6b404c7_story.html|title=Trump lied to me about his wealth to get onto the Forbes 400. Here are the tapes.|last=Greenberg|first=Jonathan|date=April 20, 2018|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=April 20, 2018}}</ref><ref name="CNN-20180420">{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/20/politics/trump-john-barron-forbes-wealth/index.html|title=A new allegation says Trump lied about his wealth. Here's what we do know|last=Wolf|first=Byron|date=April 20, 2018|accessdate=April 20, 2018|publisher=CNN}}</ref>
After several years on the ''Forbes List'', Trump's financial losses in the 1980s caused him to be dropped from 1990 to 1995, and reportedly obliged him to borrow from his siblings' trusts in 1993;<ref name="OBrien2005Oct" /> in 2005, ''The New York Times'' referred to Trump's "verbal billions" in a skeptical article about Trump's self-reported wealth.<ref name="OBrien2005Oct" /> At the time, three individuals with direct knowledge of Trump's finances told reporter [[Timothy L. O'Brien]] that Trump's actual net worth was between $150 and $250 million, though Trump then publicly claimed a net worth of $5 to $6 billion.<ref name="OBrien2005Oct" /> Claiming libel, Trump sued the reporter (and his book publisher) for $5 billion, lost the case, and then lost again on appeal; Trump refused to turn over [[Tax returns of Donald Trump|his unredacted tax returns]] despite his assertion they supported his case.<ref name="Geraghty25Feb">{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/431915/donald-trump-worth-tax-returns-mitt-romney|title=What if Trump Doesn't Have Billions?|last=Geraghty|first=Jim|date=February 25, 2016|work=National Review|accessdate=February 25, 2016}}</ref>
In April 2011, amid speculation whether Trump would run as a candidate in the United States presidential election of 2012, [[Politico]] quoted unnamed sources close to him stating that, if Trump should decide to run for president, he would file "financial disclosure statements that [would] show his net worth [was] in excess of $7 billion with more than $250 million of cash, and very little debt".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0411/53498.html|title=Donald Trump: The $7 billion dollar man|last=Haberman|first=Maggie|work=[[Politico]]|accessdate=May 12, 2013}}</ref> Although Trump did not run as a candidate in the 2012 elections, his "professionally prepared" 2012 financial disclosure was published in his book, which claimed a $7{{nbsp}}billion net worth.<ref name="Regnery2011">{{cite book|title=Time to Get Tough: Making America #1 Again|author=Trump, Donald J.|date=December 5, 2011|publisher=[[Regnery Publishing]]|isbn=978-1-59698-773-9|title-link=Time to Get Tough}}</ref>
On June 16, 2015, just before announcing his candidacy for president of the United States, Trump released a one-page financial statement "from a big accounting firm—one of the most respected"<ref name="NPR17June">{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2015/06/17/415003043/the-problem-with-donald-trumps-one-page-summary-on-his-wealth|title=The Problem With Donald Trump's One-Page Summary on His Wealth|last1=Overby|first1=Peter|date=June 17, 2015|accessdate=August 17, 2015|publisher=NPR|last2=Montanaro|first2=Domenico}}</ref>—stating a net worth of $8,737,540,000.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/exclusive-trump-will-declare-9-billion-net-worth-as-he-reveals-2016-plans/2015/06/15/a00e74c0-137c-11e5-9ddc-e3353542100c_story.html|title=Donald Trump will declare $9 billion in assets as he reveals 2016 plans|last1=Costa|first1=Robert|date=June 15, 2015|last2=Gold|first2=Matea|website=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref> "I'm really rich," Trump said.<ref name="NPR17June" /> ''Forbes'' believed his claim of $9{{nbsp}}billion was "a whopper", figuring it was actually $4.1 billion.<ref name="Carlyle16June">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erincarlyle/2015/06/16/trump-exaggerating-his-net-worth-by-100-in-presidential-bid/|title=Trump Exaggerating His Net Worth (By 100%) In Presidential Bid|last=Carlyle|first=Erin|date=June 16, 2015|work=Forbes|accessdate=August 17, 2015}}</ref> In June 2015, ''[[Business Insider]]'' published Trump's June 2014 financial statement, noting that $3.3 billion of that total is represented by "Real Estate Licensing Deals, Brand and Branded Developments", described by ''Business Insider'' as "basically [implying] that Trump values his character at $3.3 billion".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-net-worth-2015-6|title=Donald Trump's self-described net worth is $8.7 billion – here's the breakdown|last=Udland|first=Myles|date=June 16, 2015|work=Business Insider}}</ref> ''Forbes'' reduced its estimate of Trump's net worth by $125 million following Trump's controversial 2015 remarks about Mexican undocumented immigrants, which ended Trump's business contracts with [[NBCUniversal]], [[Univision]], [[Macy's]], [[Serta (company)|Serta]], [[PVH (company)|PVH Corporation]], and Perfumania.<ref name="Carlyle15July">{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erincarlyle/2015/07/15/donald-trump-says-he-is-worth-10-billion-files-personal-financial-disclosure/ |title=As Trump Files FEC Disclosure, He Raises Claimed Net Worth To $10 Billion; Forbes Disagrees |work=Forbes |first=Erin |last=Carlyle |date=July 15, 2015 |accessdate=August 17, 2015}}</ref>
In 2016, ''Forbes'' estimated Trump's net worth at $3.7 billion.<ref name="Melby19July">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-07-19/trump-is-richer-in-property-and-deeper-in-debt-in-new-valuation|title=Trump Is Richer in Property and Deeper in Debt in New Valuation|last=Melby|first=Caleb|date=July 19, 2016|work=[[Bloomberg Politics]]|quote=In the year that Donald Trump was transformed ... into the presumptive Republican nominee, the value of his golf courses and his namesake Manhattan tower soared{{nbsp}}... His net worth rose to $3 billion on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index ...}}</ref><ref name="forbes-2019-billionaires" /> During the three years after Trump announced his presidential run in 2015, Forbes estimated his net worth declined 31% and his ranking fell 138 spots.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-forbes-wealthiest-people-in-the-us-list-2018-10|title=Trump has fallen 138 spots on Forbes' wealthiest-Americans list, his net worth down over $1 billion, since he announced his presidential bid in 2015|work=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=October 3, 2018}}</ref> Discrepancies in estimates of various organizations is due in part to the uncertainty of appraised property values, as well as Trump's own assessment of the value of his [[personal brand]].<ref name="Melby19July" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/john-cassidy/just-how-rich-is-donald-trump|title=Just How Rich Is Donald Trump?|last=Cassidy|first=John|date=May 17, 2016|quote=The gap between...[the two figures] is largely attributable to differences in how the two publications appraised individual properties.|publisher=[[The New Yorker]]}}</ref>
In its 2018 billionaires ranking, ''Forbes'' estimated Trump's net worth at $3.1 billion (766th in the world, 248th in the U.S.).<ref name="forbes-2019-billionaires" /> [[Bloomberg Billionaires Index]] listed Trump's net worth as $2.48 billion on May 31, 2018,<ref name="BBI">{{cite news |title=Bloomberg Billionaires Index – Donald Trump |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/profiles/donald-j-trump/ |publisher=[[Bloomberg News]] |accessdate=July 16, 2018 |date=May 31, 2018}}</ref> and Wealth-X listed it as at least $3.8 billion on July 16, 2018.<ref name="WX">{{cite web |title=Donald John Trump – Wealth-X Dossiersier |url=https://www.wealthx.com/dossier/donald-john-trump/ |website=Wealth-X |accessdate=July 16, 2018}}</ref>
In its 2019 billionaires ranking, ''Forbes'' estimated Trump's net worth at $3.1 billion (715th in the world, 259th in the U.S.) {{as of|2019|3|5|lc=y}}.<ref name="forbes-2019-billionaires">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/donald-trump/?list=billionaires |title=The World's Billionaires – No. 715 Donald Trump |magazine=[[Forbes]] |year=2019 |accessdate=April 10, 2019}}</ref>
===FEC filings and debt=== In July 2015, federal election regulators released new details of Trump's self-reported wealth and financial holdings when he became a Republican presidential candidate, reporting that his assets are worth above $1.4 billion, which includes at least $70 million in stocks, and a debt of at least $265 million.<ref name="Yahoo News">{{cite news |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/donald-trump-wealth-details-released-federal-regulators-165854286--finance.html/ |publisher=[[Yahoo News]] |title=Donald Trump wealth details released by federal regulators |accessdate=August 9, 2015 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150801033902/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/donald-trump-wealth-details-released-federal-regulators-165854286--finance.html |archivedate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> According to ''Bloomberg'', for the purposes of Trump's FEC filings Trump "only reported revenue for [his] golf properties in his campaign filings even though the disclosure form asks for income", noting independent filings showing all three of his major European golf properties were unprofitable.<ref name="Melby19July" />
Mortgages on Trump's major properties—including Trump Tower, [[The Trump Building|40 Wall Street]], and the [[Trump National Doral Miami|Trump National Doral]] golf course—each fall into the "above $50 million" range, the highest reportable category on FEC filings, with Trump paying interest rates ranging from 4% to 7.125%.<ref name=Zurcher23July>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-33644498 |title=Five take-aways from Donald Trump's financial disclosure |publisher=BBC |date=July 23, 2015 |accessdate=March 2, 2016 |first=Anthony |last=Zurcher}}</ref> Mortgages on those three properties were separately reported as $100 million, $160 million, and $125 million in 2013.<ref name=Clarke1Jul>{{cite web |url=http://therealdeal.com/issues_articles/the-8-billion-dollar-man/ |title=What does Donald Trump really own |publisher=The Real Deal |date=July 1, 2013 |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |first=Katherine |last=Clarke}}</ref> Trump is a leaseholder, not owner, of the land beneath 40 Wall Street.<ref name=Craig20Aug /> Other outstanding Trump mortgages and debts are pegged to current market interest rates.<ref name=Zurcher23July /> A 2012 report from Trump's accounting firm estimated $451.7 million in debt and other collateral obligations.<ref name=Clarke1Jul /> Filings in 2015 disclosed debt of $504 million, according to ''Fortune'' magazine.<ref name=Tully2Mar>{{cite news |url=http://fortune.com/2016/03/02/donald-trump-tax-returns-income/ |title=Why Donald Trump's Tax Returns May Prove He's Not That Rich |work=Fortune |first=Shawn |last=Tully |date=March 2, 2016 |accessdate=March 10, 2016}}</ref> ''Bloomberg'' documented debt of at least $605 million in 2016.<ref name=Melby19July /> Trump's outstanding debt was at least $650 million in August 2016, in addition to an outstanding loan of $950 million to the [[Bank of China]] and [[Deutsche Bank]] (among other creditors) on 1290 Avenue of the Americas, in which Trump is a minority owner.<ref name=Craig20Aug>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/21/us/politics/donald-trump-debt.html|title=Trump's Empire: A Maze of Debts and Opaque Ties|date=August 20, 2016|accessdate=August 25, 2016|first=Susanne|last=Craig|work=The New York Times}}</ref> In April 2020 it is reported Trump is tens of millions of dollars in debt to China. In 2012, Trump’s real estate partner refinanced [[Trump Tower]] for almost $1 billion. The debt includes $211 million from the state-owned Bank of China, which matures in 2022. Trump owns a 30% stake in Trump Tower.<ref>https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2020/04/24/trumps-emoluments-just-fancy-name-corruption</ref><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/apr/24/donald-trump-bank-of-china-debt-report</ref><ref>https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/24/trump-biden-china-debt-205475</ref>
Trump reported a yearly income of $362 million for 2014<ref name="financial-pr">{{cite web |url=https://www.donaldjtrump.com/images/uploads/DJT_PFD_Statement_(1).pdf |title=Donald J. Trump Files Personal Financial Disclosure Statement With Federal Election Commission |first1=Corey R. |last1=Lewandowski |author1link=Corey Lewandowski |first2=Hope |last2=Hicks |date=July 15, 2015 |accessdate=March 8, 2016 |archive-date=March 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309043101/https://www.donaldjtrump.com/images/uploads/DJT_PFD_Statement_%281%29.pdf |url-status=dead}}</ref> and $611 million from January 2015 to May 2016.<ref name="cnn-20160519"/><ref name="cnn-20160519">{{cite news |url=https://money.cnn.com/2016/05/18/news/trump-finances/ |title=A peek at Donald Trump's finances |first1=Cristina |last1=Alesci |author1link=Cristina Alesci |first2=Laurie |last2=Frankel |first3=Jeanne |last3=Sahadi |publisher=CNN |date=May 19, 2016 |accessdate=May 20, 2016}}</ref> Trump and his family reported more than $500 million of income in mid-2018 financial disclosure forms.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Harwood |first1=John |title=Trump's money-making power as unprecedented as his words |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/28/trump-collects-on-business-and-presidency-is-boosting-brand.html |accessdate=December 21, 2018 |work=www.cnbc.com |date=June 29, 2018}}</ref>
A July 2015 campaign press release, issued one month after Trump announced his presidential run, said the FEC filing "was not designed for a man of Mr. Trump's massive wealth"<ref name="Zurcher23July" /> and that his net worth is "in excess of [10 billion dollars]".<ref>{{cite web|title=The government just released a document detailing Donald Trump's alleged $10 billion fortune|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trumps-10-billion-financial-disclosure-report-2015-7|last=Walker|first=Hunter|publisher=Business Insider|date=July 22, 2015|accessdate=February 2, 2020}}</ref>
===Trump on his own net worth=== Trump has often given much higher values for his wealth than organizations estimating it. Trump has testified that "my net worth fluctuates, and it goes up and down with markets and with attitudes and with feelings—even my own feelings".<ref name="Mullany15July">{{cite news |work=The New York Times |date=July 15, 2015 |accessdate=August 17, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2015/07/15/donald-trump-says-hes-worth-more-than-10-billion/ |title=Donald Trump Claims His Wealth Exceeds 'TEN BILLION DOLLARS' |first=Gerry |last=Mullany}}</ref> On the same day, Trump's own stated estimates of his net worth have varied by as much as $3.3 billion.<ref name="OBrien2005Oct" /> Trump has also acknowledged that past exaggerated estimates of his wealth have been "good for financing".<ref name="Lane22Oct">{{cite news |url=http://forbesindia.com/printcontent/41321 |title=What's Donald Trump really worth? |date=October 22, 2015 |accessdate=December 4, 2015 |work=Forbes India |first=Randall |last=Lane}}</ref> ''Forbes'' has said that although Trump "shares a lot of information with us that helps us get to the figures we publish", he "consistently pushes for a higher net worth—especially when it comes to the value of his personal brand".<ref name="Carlyle16June" />
==Investment performance== A 2016 analysis of Trump's business career in ''[[The Economist]]'' concluded that his performance since 1985 had been "mediocre compared with the stock market and property in New York".<ref name="econ_From">{{cite news |title=From the Tower to the White House |work=[[The Economist]] |date=February 20, 2016 |accessdate=February 29, 2016 |url=https://www.economist.com/news/united-states/21693230-enigma-presidential-candidates-business-affairs-tower-white |quote=Mr Trump's performance has been mediocre compared with the stockmarket and property in New York.}}</ref> A subsequent analysis in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' similarly noted that Trump's estimated net worth of $100 million in 1978 would have increased to $6 billion by 2016 if he had invested it in a typical retirement fund, and concluded that "Trump is a mix of braggadocio, business failures, and real success."<ref>{{cite news |first=Ana |last=Swanson |title=The myth and the reality of Donald Trump's business empire |date=February 29, 2016 |website=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/02/29/the-myth-and-the-reality-of-donald-trumps-business-empire/}}</ref>
==House subpoenas and court ruling== On May 10, 2019, House Ways and Means Committee chairman [[Richard Neal]] subpoenaed the Treasury Department and the IRS for six years of Trump's tax returns. Seven days later, Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin refused to comply with the subpoenas.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/10/us/politics/democrats-trump-tax-returns.html|title=House Ways and Means Chairman Subpoenas Trump Tax Records|first=Nicholas|last=Fandos|date=May 10, 2019|website=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mnuchin-defies-subpoena-for-president-trumps-tax-returns-11558123367|title=Mnuchin Defies Subpoena for President Trump's Tax Returns|first=Richard|last=Rubin|date=May 17, 2019|website=wsj.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fox |first=Lauren |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/05/17/politics/steve-mnuchin-tax-returns-repsonse/index.html |title=Mnuchin defies House Democrats' subpoenas for Trump's tax returns |work=Cnn.com |date=May 17, 2019}}</ref>
On May 20, 2019, President Trump lost an unrelated lawsuit in which he sought to stop his accounting firm, Mazars USA, from complying with a subpoena from the House Oversight Committee for various financial records.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wolfe |first=Jan |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trump-loses-lawsuit-challenging-subpoena-financial-records-211051655.html |title=Trump loses lawsuit challenging subpoena for financial records |work=Finance.yahoo.com |date=May 20, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/legal-issues/us-judge-denies-trump-bid-to-quash-house-subpoena-for-years-of-financial-records/2019/05/20/74e45880-7b21-11e9-8bb7-0fc796cf2ec0_story.html |title=Judge rules against Trump in fight over president's financial records |work=The Washington Post |date= |accessdate=June 1, 2019}}</ref> The ruling against Trump was issued by Judge [[Amit Mehta]] of the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia]], who also denied the president a [[stay of proceedings|stay]] of the ruling pending any future appeal.<ref name="may20ruling">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-court-mazars-idUSKCN1SQ29H|title=Trump loses lawsuit challenging subpoena for financial records|last=Wolfe|first=Jan|date=2019-05-21|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=2019-08-24|language=en}}</ref>
==New York tax law== In May 2019, both houses of the [[New York State Legislature]], which is based in Trump's native and business home of [[New York (state)|New York]], approved a bill which allows the state's tax commissioner to release any state tax return requested by the leaders of the House Ways and Means Committee, the Senate Finance Committee or the Joint Committee on Taxation for any "specific and legitimate legislative purpose".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/22/nyregion/trump-state-tax-returns.html|title=New York Passes Bill Giving Congress a Way to Get Trump's State Tax Returns|first=Jesse|last=McKinley|date=May 22, 2019|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/ny-state-senate-passes-bill-allowing-congress-get-trump-tax-n1003396 |title=N.Y. state Senate passes bill allowing Congress to get Trump tax returns |publisher=Nbcnews.com |date= |accessdate=June 1, 2019}}</ref>
==Perception of wealth== According to a 2019 study in the journal [[Political Behavior (journal)|''Political Behavior'']], many voters were convinced that Trump is a keen business man and the right choice for the presidency by being told that he [[Inheritance|inherited]] money from his father but then grew a major empire and increased his net worth.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McDonald|first=Jared|last2=Karol|first2=David|last3=Mason|first3=Lilliana|date=January 9, 2019|title="An Inherited Money Dude from Queens County": How Unseen Candidate Characteristics Affect Voter Perceptions|journal=Political Behavior|language=en|doi=10.1007/s11109-019-09527-y|issn=1573-6687}}</ref>
==Foundation== {{main|Donald J. Trump Foundation}}
Trump formed his own charitable foundation in 1988. In the first decade of the 2000s, he gave away $2.8 million through the foundation (though he had pledged three times that amount). He stopped personally contributing to the foundation in 2008, though he accepted donations from others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-promised-millions-to-charity-we-found-less-than-10000-over-7-years/2016/06/28/cbab5d1a-37dd-11e6-8f7c-d4c723a2becb_story.html|title=Trump promised millions to charity. We found less than $10,000 over 7 years.|last=Fahrenthold|first=David A.|date=28 June 2016|work=Washington Post|access-date=12 August 2019}}</ref> In 2018, the foundation agreed to shut down. It was facing a civil lawsuit by the New York attorney general that alleged "persistently illegal conduct" including self-dealing and funneling campaign contributions. Furthermore, it had never been properly certified in New York and did not submit to the annual audit that would have been required.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-foundation-lacks-the-certification-required-for-charities-that-solicit-money/2016/09/29/7dac6a68-8658-11e6-ac72-a29979381495_story.html|title=Trump Foundation lacks the certification required for charities that solicit money|last=Fahrenthold|first=David A.|date=29 September 2016|work=Washington Post|access-date=13 August 2019}}</ref>

{{Italic title}} {{Taxobox | name= ''Tetragramma donaldtrumpi'' | image = | image_caption = | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Echinoderm]]ata | classis = [[Echinoidea]] | ordo = [[Phymosomatoida]] | familia = [[Diplopodiidae]] | genus = ''[[Tetragramma]]'' | species = '''''T. donaldtrumpi''''' | binomial = ''Tetragramma donaldtrumpi'' | binomial_authority = Thompson, 2016 }} '''''Tetragramma donaldtrumpi''''' is a species of fossil [[sea urchin]]s discovered and identified by William R. Thompson, Jr. in 2016.<ref name=Th2016>{{cite book|last1=Thompson Jr.|first1=William R.|title=Fossil Echinoids of Texas: A Monograph of Fossil Sea Urchins|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/310479936|date=November 2016|publisher=River Stix|isbn=978-1617042782}}</ref> The specimen locality is from the [[Early Cretaceous|Lower Cretaceous]], [[Trinity Group (geologic formation)|Trinity Group]], of the [[Glen Rose Formation]] near [[Fischer, Texas]], in the United States.<ref name=Th2016/><ref name="Zoo">{{cite web |title=Tetragramma donaldtrumpi Thompson, 2016 |url=http://zoobank.org/NomenclaturalActs/C0F80BB8-728C-4151-B639-C764B5D8FA4A |website=[[ZooBank]] |accessdate=3 January 2019}}</ref>
Based from the fossils discovered of ''Tetragramma donaldtrumpi'', the species is known to have been about {{convert|1|in|cm}} in size and round in shape, with the appearance of a [[Life Savers]] candy.<ref name="wmur">{{cite web|last1=Wheeler|first1=Christine DeLong|title=New species of fossil sea urchin named after Donald Trump|url=http://www.wmur.com/article/new-species-of-fossil-sea-urchin-named-after-donald-trump/8252764|website=WMUR|accessdate=17 February 2017|language=en|date=7 November 2016}}</ref> The genus ''[[Tetragramma]]'' is known from the Upper Jurassic ([[Oxfordian (stage)|Oxfordian]]) to the Upper Cretaceous ([[Turonian]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/echinoid-directory/taxa/taxon.jsp?id=1424|title=Tetragramma Agassiz, 1838|work=The Echinoid Directory|publisher= Natural History Museum, London|access-date=2017-01-24}}</ref>
Thompson named the species to honor then Republican presidential nominee [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mendoza|first1=Madalyn|title=With fossil, Donald Trump becomes 'permanent part of the scientific record'|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Seguin-restaurant-owner-names-new-fossil-after-10599248.php|website=San Antonio Express-News|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> A paleontology lab at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] holds a fossil of the species, along with 45 others.<ref name="wmur"/>
==See also== * [[List of organisms named after famous people]] * [[List of things named after Donald Trump]]
==References== {{Wiktionary|''Tetragramma donaldtrumpi''}} {{Reflist|2}}

{{Donald Trump series}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2019}} The '''tax returns of Donald Trump''' have been the subject of controversy for the past several years, particularly over their not having been made public despite his political career.
Before Trump announced his candidacy for president, he repeatedly promised to release his tax returns, making such pledges in 2011, 2014 ("absolutely") and 2015.<ref name="FactPence"/><ref name="Harwell"/> During [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign|his presidential campaign]], Trump first said he would release his returns after they were "worked on.”<ref name=fivetimes/> From 2016 to 2019, Trump claimed<!-- Since no evidence has ever been presented that this is true, using "claimed" is justified. --> that, because the returns were being audited, he could not make them public, but would do so in the future. No law actually prevents tax returns from being released due to an audit, as emphasized by the [[Commissioner of Internal Revenue|commissioner of internal revenue]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Davison|first1=Laura|last2=Talev|first2=Margaret|title=Trump Falsely Says Law Prevents Him Releasing Tax Returns Under Audit|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-04-05/trump-refutes-democrats-authority-to-obtain-his-tax-returns|work=[[Bloomberg News]]|access-date=9 April 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first1=Orion|last1=Rummler|title=IRS commissioner: No rule against releasing Trump's tax returns while under audit|url=https://www.axios.com/trump-tax-returns-irs-commissioner-audit-20ebb0a7-dc47-4177-bf4c-565aa5cfb734.html|date=10 April 2019|website=[[Axios.com]]|access-date=11 April 2019}}</ref> Trump later said that voters were not interested in his returns; that "there's nothing to learn from them"; and that his tax rate is "none of your business".<ref name="Harwell"/>
Since Trump's election, he has refused requests to release the returns, making him one of the few presidents in recent times to not reveal their tax returns. Trump was the first major party nominee since 1976 not to make his tax returns public. Several states have proposed bills that would require presidential candidates to release their tax returns in order to be listed on the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 ballot]]; such a bill was passed by the [[California Legislature]] and signed by Democratic Governor [[Gavin Newsom]], but was overturned several months later by the [[California Supreme Court]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2019/07/30/californias-newsom-signs-bill-to-force-trump-tax-returns-1122154|title=California's Newsom signs bill to force Trump tax returns|last=White|first=Jeremy|date=July 30, 2019|work=Politico|access-date=5 August 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/22/trump-tax-returns-safe-after-california-court-ruling-on-primary.html|title=California high court tosses law aimed at forcing Trump to release tax returns to get on state primary ballot|date=July 30, 2019|work=CNBC|access-date=20 April 2020}}</ref>
The [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|Ways and Means Committee]] of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] made a formal request to the [[Internal Revenue Service]] (IRS), and later issued a [[subpoena]] to the IRS, for six years of Trump's returns, as part of an effort by the committee to evaluate "the extent to which the I.R.S. audits and enforces the federal tax laws against a president."<ref name=WaysMeansSub>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/10/us/politics/trump-tax-returns-subpoena.html|title=House Ways and Means Chairman Subpoenas Trump Tax Returns|first=Nicholas|last=Fandos|date=May 10, 2019|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref> Treasury Secretary [[Steven Mnuchin]] defied the subpoena.<ref name=UPIfinal>{{cite web|last1=Uria|first1=Daniel|title=Mnuchin: Treasury to make 'final decision' on Trump tax returns May 6|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2019/04/23/Mnuchin-Treasury-to-make-final-decision-on-Trump-tax-returns-May-6/8181556063426/|publisher=[[United Press International]]|access-date=April 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Rappeport|first1=Alan|title=Steven Mnuchin Refuses to Release Trump's Tax Returns to Congress|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/06/us/politics/trump-tax-returns-mnuchin.html|website=The New York Times|access-date=7 May 2019|date=6 May 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/10/us/politics/democrats-trump-tax-returns.html|title=House Ways and Means Chairman Subpoenas Trump Tax Records|first=Nicholas|last=Fandos|date=May 10, 2019|website=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mnuchin-defies-subpoena-for-president-trumps-tax-returns-11558123367|title=Mnuchin Defies Subpoena for President Trump's Tax Returns|first=Richard|last=Rubin|date=May 17, 2019|newspaper=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Upon the Trump administration's refusal to turn over the documents, the Ways and Means Committee filed a suit to enforce the subpoena.<ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2019/07/02/738030272/house-democrats-sue-for-trumps-tax-returns|title=House Democrats Sue For Trump's Tax Returns|author=Kelsey Snell|date=July 2, 2019|website=NPR|access-date=July 2, 2019}}</ref><ref name="auto3">Quinta Jurecic, [https://www.lawfareblog.com/house-ways-and-means-committee-sues-trump-tax-returns House Ways and Means Committee Sues for Trump Tax Returns], ''Lawfare'' (July 2, 2019).</ref> That case is pending.<ref name=Thomsen/> A draft IRS legal memo, written in fall 2018 and reported in May 2019, concluded that the IRS must provide the requested tax returns to Congress unless Trump invokes executive privilege, contradicting the administration's justification for defying the earlier subpoena.<ref>{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/confidential-draft-irs-memo-says-tax-returns-must-be-given-to-congress-unless-president-invokes-executive-privilege/2019/05/21/8ed41834-7b1c-11e9-8bb7-0fc796cf2ec0_story.html|title=Confidential draft IRS memo says tax returns must be given to Congress unless president invokes executive privilege|newspaper=Washington Post|date=May 21, 2019}}</ref>
Separately, the [[House Committee on Oversight and Reform|House Oversight Committee]] issued a subpoena to Trump's accounting firm for tax records and other records, as part of the committee's investigation into (1) whether Trump "may have engaged in illegal conduct before and during his tenure in office"; (2) whether Trump "has undisclosed [[conflicts of interest]] that may impair his ability to make impartial policy decisions"; (3) whether Trump was complying with the Constitution's [[Foreign Emoluments Clause]] and [[Domestic Emoluments Clause]]; and (4) whether Trump "has accurately reported his finances to the Office of Government Ethics and other federal entities."<ref name=DCCirDecision/> Trump sued to block the subpoena; the [[U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia]], and later the [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia]], rejected Trump's position and have held that the subpoena must be complied with.<ref name=DCtDDCOversight/><ref name=FahrentholdDCCir/><ref name=Hemel/>
In late August 2019, the Office of the [[New York County District Attorney]] issued a subpoena to Trump seeking eight years of his personal and corporate tax returns, as part of state prosecutors' investigation into [[Stormy Daniels–Donald Trump scandal|hush-money payments made during the 2016 presidential election campaign]].<ref name=TurnOver>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/07/nyregion/trump-taxes-lawsuit-vance.html|title=Trump Taxes: President Ordered to Turn Over Returns to Manhattan D.A.|last=Rashbaum|first=Weiser|website=The New York Times|date=October 7, 2019}}</ref> Trump sought to quash the subpoena, contending that a sitting president enjoys "absolute immunity from criminal process of any kind."<ref name=TurnOver/> In October 2019, Judge [[Victor Marrero]] of the [[U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York]] rejected Trump's effort to prevent his tax returns from being turned over to the New York grand jury, and ordered Trump to comply with a subpoena. In a 75-page opinion, the court called Trump's contention an overreach of executive power that is "repugnant to the nation's governmental structure and constitutional values."<ref name=TurnOver/><ref name=SDNYDecision>{{cite court|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2019/10/07/politics/sdny-ruling-trump-tax-returns/index.html|litigants=Trump v. Vance|vol=395|reporter=F. Supp. 3d.|page=283|opinion=court=S.D.N.Y.}}</ref> The [[U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] upheld the lower court's ruling in November 2019, rejecting Trump's claim that presidents are immune from state grand jury subpoenas.<ref name=WeiserLiptak>Benjamin Weiser & Adam Liptak, [https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/04/nyregion/trump-taxes-vance-appeal.html Trump Taxes: Appeals Court Rules President Must Turn Over 8 Years of Tax Returns], ''New York Times'' (November 4, 2019).</ref><ref name=2dCir>''[https://int.nyt.com/data/documenthelper/6407-trump-vance-appeal/a0279d1a81a92e6abce8/optimized/full.pdf#page=1 Trump v. Vance]'' (2d Cir. Nov. 4, 2019).</ref>
Separately, a [[New York law|New York state law]] was enacted in July 2019, authorizing New York state tax officials to release state tax returns, including Trump's, for any "specified and legitimate legislative purpose" to the House Ways and Means Committee and three other congressional committees.<ref name="McKinley2019">{{cite news|last1=McKinley|first1=Jesse|last2=Fandos|first2=Nicholas|title=Cuomo Signs a Bill to Allow Release of Trump's State Tax Returns|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/08/nyregion/trump-ny-taxes-cuomo.html|work=The New York Times|date=8 July 2019}}</ref> Trump sued the State and the House Ways and Means Committee fifteen days later to block release of the tax returns.<ref name="TrumpSuitNY">{{Cite newspaper|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/23/us/politics/trump-tax-returns-new-york.html|title=Trump Sues New York and Congress to Shield His State Tax Returns|first1=Nicholas|last1=Fandos|first2=Jesse|last2=McKinley|date=July 23, 2019|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref> In November 2019, Trump's suit was dismissed on jurisdictional grounds.<ref name="Polantz">Katelyn Polantz, [https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/11/politics/donald-trump-tax-returns/index.html Trump can't sue New York state in DC federal court to stop release of tax returns, judge says], CNN (November 11, 2019).</ref>
==Background== The IRS has stated that nothing prevents an individual from releasing their tax returns; an audit cannot stop the tax return release, and several former leaders of IRS have said that audits are a poor reason to justify not releasing tax returns. In any case, Trump has the ability to put on hold a current audit. Before Trump's election, every elected president from [[Richard Nixon]] onward has released their tax returns annually. While president, Nixon himself released his tax returns despite them being under audit. Also, all major presidential nominees from 1976 onward released their tax returns.<ref name=WaPoBus/>
==Tax figures from 1985 through 1994== Trump lost $1.17 billion between 1985 and 1994 according to 10 years of Trump's tax information obtained by the ''New York Times'', with the amount more than "nearly any other individual American taxpayer" during that period. Although Trump has acknowledged the tax-advantaged nature of the real estate business due to large depreciation write-offs to generate losses and reduce tax liabilities, the ''Times'' reported "depreciation cannot account for the hundreds of millions of dollars in losses."<ref name="Red">{{cite news|last1=Buettner|first1=Russ|last2=Craig|first2=Susanne|title=Decade in the Red: Trump Tax Figures Show Over $1 Billion in Business Losses|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/05/07/us/politics/donald-trump-taxes.html|access-date=May 7, 2019|work=The New York Times|date=May 7, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/07/us/trump-tax-figures.html|title=5 Takeaways From 10 Years of Trump Tax Figures|last1=Buettner|first1=Russ|last2=Craig|first2=Susanne|date=May 7, 2019|website=The New York Times|access-date=May 8, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/08/trump-defends-tax-tactics-after-nyt-story-says-he-racked-up-more-than-1-billion-in-losses-it-was-sport.html|title=Trump defends tax tactics after NYT probe says he racked up more than $1 billion in losses: 'It was sport'|last=Calia|first=Mike|date=May 8, 2019|website=CNBC|access-date=May 8, 2019}}</ref> Due to losing more than $500 million in combined losses, section 172 of the [[Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993]] gave Trump $915.7 million in tax exemption, which he used to pay off 8 years of taxes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/07/us/trump-tax-figures.html|title=5 Takeaways From 10 Years of Trump Tax Figures|last1=Craig|first1=Susanne|last2=Buettner|first2=Russ|date=May 7, 2019|work=The New York Times|access-date=May 9, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/103rd-congress/house-bill/2264/text|title=Text - H.R.2264 - 103rd Congress (1993-1994): Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993|last=Sabo|first=Martin Olav|date=August 10, 1993|publisher=[[Congress.gov]]|access-date=May 9, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-early-financial-losses-were-so-steep-that-he-did-not-pay-income-taxes-for-eight-years-according-to-new-report/2019/05/07/cb019e4a-7120-11e9-8be0-ca575670e91c_story.html|title=Trump's early financial losses were so steep that he did not pay income taxes for eight years, according to new report|last=Fahrenthold|first=David A.|date=May 5, 2019|work=The Washington Post|access-date=May 5, 2019}}</ref>
==Partially leaked returns of 1995 and 2005== Parts of Trump's 1995 and 2005 tax returns have been leaked.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/new-york-times-trump-declared-a-916-million-loss-in-1995-tax-returns/|title=Trump incurrs $916 million loss on his income tax returns|last=Doe|first=John|date=October 1, 2016|work=CBS News|access-date=October 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002062654/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/new-york-times-trump-declared-a-916-million-loss-in-1995-tax-returns/|archive-date=October 2, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trumps-tax-return-leaked-rachel-maddow-what-accountants-think-alternative-minimum-tax/|title=A Trump tax return revealed -- here's what accountants think of it|website=cbsnews.com|access-date=April 5, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180929010525/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trumps-tax-return-leaked-rachel-maddow-what-accountants-think-alternative-minimum-tax/|archive-date=September 29, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
In October 2016, ''[[The New York Times]]'' published some tax documents from 1995. ''The New York Times'' reported that the ''Times'' had been given three pages of certain state tax returns for Trump for the year 1995. The materials indicated that Trump incurred a $916 million [[net operating loss]] which, for Federal income tax purposes, could have prevented Trump from owing any Federal income taxes for up to 18 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/new-york-times-trump-declared-a-916-million-loss-in-1995-tax-returns/|title=Trump incurrs $916 million loss on his income tax returns|last=Doe|first=John|date=October 1, 2016|publisher=CBS News|access-date=October 2, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161002062654/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/new-york-times-trump-declared-a-916-million-loss-in-1995-tax-returns/|archive-date=October 2, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> [[Marc Kasowitz]] of [[Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman]] wrote to the ''Times'' stating, according to one report, that "the publication of Trump's tax records was illegal because Trump had not authorized their disclosure ... [and] threatening 'prompt initiation of appropriate legal action.'"<ref>Zaretsky, Staci, [http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/donald-trump-chooses-biglaw-firm-to-fight-new-york-times-over-publication-of-tax-documents/ "Donald Trump Chooses Biglaw Firm To Fight New York Times Over Publication Of Tax Documents"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180617093028/https://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/donald-trump-chooses-biglaw-firm-to-fight-new-york-times-over-publication-of-tax-documents/|date=June 17, 2018}}, ''[[Above the Law (website)|Above the Law]]'', October 3, 2016. Retrieved January 17, 2017.</ref>
Trump claimed on his tax returns that he lost money, but did not recognize it in the form of canceled debts. Trump might have performed a [[Swap (finance)|stock-for-debt swap]]. This would have allowed Trump to avoid paying [[Income tax in the United States|income taxes]] for at least 18 years. An [[Income tax audit|audit]] of Trump's tax returns for 2002 through 2008 was "closed administratively by agreement with the [[Internal Revenue Service|I.R.S.]] without assessment or payment, on a net basis, of any deficiency." Tax attorneys believe the government may have reduced what Trump was able to claim as a loss without requiring him to pay any additional taxes.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/11/01/a-big-dirty-secret-from-donald-trumps-tax-returns-has-been-exposed/ "A big, dirty secret from Donald Trump's tax returns has been exposed"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190210192856/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/11/01/a-big-dirty-secret-from-donald-trumps-tax-returns-has-been-exposed/|date=February 10, 2019}}. ''The Washington Post''. November 1, 2016. Retrieved November 2, 2016.</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/04/us/politics/donald-trump-taxes.html "How a Simple Tax Rule Let Donald Trump Turn a $916 Million Loss Into a Plus"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181209120846/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/04/us/politics/donald-trump-taxes.html|date=December 9, 2018}}. ''The New York Times''. October 4, 2016. Retrieved November 2, 2016.</ref> It is unknown whether the I.R.S. challenged Trump's use of the swaps because he has not released his tax returns. Trump's lawyers advised against Trump using the equity for debt swap, as they believed it to be potentially illegal.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/02/opinion/avoiding-taxes-trump-style.html "Avoiding Taxes, Trump-Style"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181220230939/https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/02/opinion/avoiding-taxes-trump-style.html|date=December 20, 2018}}. ''The New York Times''. November 2, 2016. Retrieved November 2, 2016.</ref>
On March 14, 2017, the first two pages of Trump's 2005 federal income tax returns were leaked to [[Rachel Maddow]] and shown on [[MSNBC]]. The document states that Trump had a gross adjusted income of $150 million and paid $38 million in federal taxes. The White House confirmed the authenticity of these documents and claimed: "Despite this substantial income figure and tax paid, it is totally illegal to steal and publish tax returns."<ref name="nyt-taxes">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/14/us/politics/donald-trump-taxes.html|title=Trump Wrote Off $100 Million in Business Losses in 2005|last1=Baker|first1=Peter|author1-link=Peter Baker (journalist)|last2=Drucker|first2=Jesse|last3=Craig|first3=Susanne|author3-link=Susanne Craig|last4=Barstow|first4=David|author4-link=David Barstow|date=March 15, 2017|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=March 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name="hill-taxes">{{cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/324016-wh-releases-trump-tax-info-ahead-of-msnbc-report-made-150m-in-2005|title=WH releases Trump tax info ahead of MSNBC report: He paid $38M in federal taxes in '05|last=Jagoda|first=Naomi|access-date=March 15, 2017|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}}</ref>.
==Before his presidency== {{further|Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Timeline of Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections (July 2016–election day)|Veracity of statements by Donald Trump}} In 1999, while Trump was considering whether [[Donald Trump 2000 presidential campaign|to run for president]] under the [[Reform Party of the United States of America|Reform Party]], he said "probably wouldn't have a problem with" releasing his tax returns if he ran.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kaczynski|first1=Andrew|title=Trump In 1999: I Probably Wouldn't Have A Problem Releasing My Tax Returns If I Ran|url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/andrewkaczynski/during-1999-run-trump-vowed-to-release-his-tax-returns|website=[[Buzzfeed News]]|access-date=August 7, 2019|date=March 4, 2016}}</ref>
In April 2011, Trump said that when President [[Barack Obama]] produces "[[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|his birth certificate]] ... I’d love to give my tax returns". [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories#Long form, 2011|Obama's birth certificate was released a week later]], resulting in Trump saying his tax returns would be released "at the appropriate time".<ref name="FactPence">{{cite web|last1=Qiu|first1=Linda|title=Pence's False claim that Trump 'hasn't broken' tax return promise|url=https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/oct/05/mike-pence/pences-false-claim-trump-hasnt-broken-tax-return-p/|publisher=[[Politifact]]|access-date=11 April 2019}}</ref>
In 2012, Trump implored for Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney's tax returns to be released on April 1, which "historically is the time that everybody gives them".<ref name="WaPoBus">{{cite web|last1=Harwell|first1=Drew|title=All the excuses Trump has given for why he won't release his tax returns|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/business/wp/2016/09/15/a-running-tally-of-trumps-many-excuses-for-why-he-wont-release-his-tax-returns/|website=[[Washington Post]]|access-date=August 7, 2019|date=September 15, 2016}}</ref> That year, Trump also said that not seeing a presidential candidate's tax returns would lead people to think there was "almost, like, something wrong. What's wrong?"<ref>{{cite web|last=Kelly|first=Nora|title=How Hillary Clinton Is Using Her Taxes as a Political Weapon|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/08/clinton-tax-returns-trump/495755/|website=[[The Atlantic]]|access-date=August 7, 2019|date=August 12, 2016}}</ref>
According to Trump's former political adviser [[Sam Nunberg]] said in 2013 and 2014 that Trump had considered the possibility of releasing his tax returns as part of a presidential campaign, believing that showing how little he paid in taxes would make him appear to be a savvy businessman.<ref name=Ward>[[Vicky Ward]], [https://edition.cnn.com/2019/10/14/politics/trump-originally-wanted-to-release-tax-returns/index.html Trump wanted to release his taxes in 2013 to show how smart he was for paying so little], CNN (October 14, 2019).</ref> Nunberg said by November 2014, he had persuaded Trump to reverse course and withhold his tax returns, as Trump decided that he "wanted to look rich rather than smart."<ref name=Ward/> In May 2014, Trump said in an interview: "If I decide to run for office, I’ll produce my tax returns, absolutely and I would love to do that."<ref name="FactPence"/>
In February 2015, Trump said that if he ran for the presidency: "I would release tax returns".<ref name="FactPence"/> On another occasion that month, he declared: "I have no objection to certainly showing tax returns".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gass|first1=Nick|title=Carson: Trump will release tax returns before election|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/trump-release-tax-records-222887|website=[[Politico]]|access-date=August 7, 2019|date=June 5, 2016}}</ref> Later in February 2015, Trump warned: "I will tell you upfront ... I want to pay as little taxes as I can as a private person".<ref name="FactPence"/> In May 2016, Trump voiced similar sentiments, stating he tries "very hard to pay as little tax as possible". However, Trump has in 2015 criticized corporate executives and "hedge fund guys" for paying zero or negligible taxes. He also alleged in 2011 and 2012 that half of all Americans do not pay income taxes, stating: "it's a problem", while noting "crippling" government debt. Trump also in 2012 criticized President Barack Obama for "only" paying a tax rate of around 20%.<ref name=WaPoBus/> Trump announced his candidacy for President in June 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Santucci|first1=John|last2=Stracqualursi|first2=Veronica|title=Donald Trump Announces 2016 Presidential Campaign: 'We Are Going Make our Country Great Again'|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-announces-2016-presidential-campaign-make-country/story?id=31799741|work=[[ABC News]]|access-date=19 April 2019}}</ref>
In January 2016, Trump was asked by [[Chuck Todd]] if he would release his tax returns, to which Trump answered: "we'll be working that over in the next period of time, Chuck. Absolutely. [...] at the appropriate time, you'll be very satisfied."<ref name=fivetimes>{{cite web|last1=Blake|first1=Aaron|title=5 things Donald Trump promised he'd do, but hasn't|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/12/13/5-things-donald-trump-promised-hed-do-but-hasnt/|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=19 April 2019}}</ref> In February 2016, Trump said that he would release his tax returns "[p]robably over the next few months. They’re being worked on now."<ref name=fivetimes/> Later that month, Trump said that he could not release his tax returns because he was under audit.<ref name="POLITICOtwelve">{{cite web|last1=Becker|first1=Bernie|last2=Faler|first2=Brian|title=IRS chief: 'Rare' for taxpayer to be audited several years in a row, as Trump claims|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2016/02/donald-trump-irs-audit-experts-219889|publisher=[[Politico]]|access-date=11 April 2019}}</ref> Trump has elaborated that he has been audited for a consecutive "twelve years or something like that."<ref name="POLITICOtwelve"/> In 2016, Trump's tax attorneys have stated that Trump has been under audit since 2002. However, in 2011, 2014, and 2015, Trump made offers to release his tax returns, presumably while he was still under audit.<ref name="FactPence"/>
The IRS commissioner at the time, [[John Koskinen]], said that an IRS audit does not prevent the taxpayer from releasing tax returns. Koskinen also said that it "would be rare for anyone to be audited every year", and that if a past audit revealed no problems, "it’s a number of years — two or three at least" before the IRS would conduct an audit again.<ref name=POLITICOtwelve/><ref name="POLITICOtwelve"/>
There is no requirement that presidential candidates release their tax returns but candidates are legally free to do so even when under audit.<ref name=release>{{cite news|author=Alan Rappeport|url=https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/05/11/donald-trump-breaks-with-recent-history-by-not-releasing-tax-returns/|title=Donald Trump Breaks With Recent History by Not Releasing Tax Returns|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190106222213/https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/05/11/donald-trump-breaks-with-recent-history-by-not-releasing-tax-returns/|archive-date=January 6, 2019|work=The New York Times|date=May 11, 2016}}</ref><ref name=Stockman>{{cite news|url=http://lawnewz.com/politics/legal-experts-side-with-trump-it-would-be-totally-stupid-to-release-his-taxes-during-audit/|title=Legal Experts Side With Trump; It Would Be Crazy to Release His Taxes During Audit|last=Stockman|first=Rachel|date=May 13, 2016|work=Law Newz|access-date=July 19, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160716130007/http://lawnewz.com/politics/legal-experts-side-with-trump-it-would-be-totally-stupid-to-release-his-taxes-during-audit/|archive-date=July 16, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Tax lawyers differ as to whether releasing tax returns is legally advisable for someone like Trump who has stated he is under audit.<ref name=Stockman /><ref>Stewart, Emily. [https://www.thestreet.com/story/13687015/1/would-no-tax-lawyer-advise-trump-release-his-tax-returns-it-s-complicated.html "Would No Tax Lawyer Advise Trump Release His Tax Returns? It's Complicated"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924183723/https://www.thestreet.com/story/13687015/1/would-no-tax-lawyer-advise-trump-release-his-tax-returns-it-s-complicated.html|date=September 24, 2016}}, [[TheStreet.com]] (August 27, 2016).</ref> According to [[NPR]], tax experts, such as [[New York University Law School]] professor Daniel Shaviro, say that "Trump's lawyers may advise him not to release the returns for legal strategy purposes."<ref>Zarroli, Jim. [https://www.npr.org/2016/02/26/468278769/fact-check-donald-trump-cant-release-his-taxes-while-being-audited "Fact-Check: Donald Trump Can't Release His Taxes While Being Audited?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190302140445/https://www.npr.org/2016/02/26/468278769/fact-check-donald-trump-cant-release-his-taxes-while-being-audited|date=March 2, 2019}}, [[NPR]] (February 26, 2016).</ref> In contrast, economist [[Paul Krugman]] argued that Trump should be more willing to reveal his tax information if he were already under audit, as the reveal might have triggered an audit if there was not one.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/democracy-in-america/2016/06/01/the-saga-over-donald-trumps-tax-returns-rolls-on|title=The saga over Donald Trump's tax returns rolls on|date=June 1, 2016|work=The Economist|access-date=July 18, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714030549/http://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2016/06/donalds-taxes|archive-date=July 14, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
In May 2016, Trump said that he did not plan to release his tax returns before the November 2016 election;<ref name="Rappeport">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/05/11/donald-trump-breaks-with-recent-history-by-not-releasing-tax-returns/|title=Donald Trump Breaks With Recent History by Not Releasing Tax Returns|last=Rappeport|first=Alan|date=May 11, 2016|work=The New York Times|access-date=July 18, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160719083106/http://www.nytimes.com/politics/first-draft/2016/05/11/donald-trump-breaks-with-recent-history-by-not-releasing-tax-returns/|archive-date=July 19, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> the tax returns were not released.<ref name=MoneyWhen>{{Cite web|url=http://money.com/money/5634725/donald-trump-tax-returns-released-2019-democrats/|title=Will Donald Trump's Tax Returns Be Released? Democrats Just Made Their First Move|website=Money|language=en|access-date=April 5, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190217002556/http://money.com/money/5634725/donald-trump-tax-returns-released-2019-democrats/|archive-date=February 17, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Trump also said in May 2016 that "there's nothing to learn from" his tax returns,<ref name="Rappeport"/> and said on [[ABC News]] that his tax rate is "none of your business".<ref name="Harwell">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-income-tax-returns-once-became-public-they-showed-he-didnt-pay-a-cent/2016/05/20/ffa2f63c-1b7c-11e6-b6e0-c53b7ef63b45_story.html|title=Trump once revealed his income tax returns. They showed he didn't pay a cent.|last=Harwell|first=Drew|date=May 21, 2016|work=The Washington Post|access-date=July 18, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160706210006/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-income-tax-returns-once-became-public-they-showed-he-didnt-pay-a-cent/2016/05/20/ffa2f63c-1b7c-11e6-b6e0-c53b7ef63b45_story.html|archive-date=July 6, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
Trump was criticized for his refusal to release tax information. Former Republican presidential candidate [[Mitt Romney]] said, "It is disqualifying for a modern-day presidential nominee to refuse to release tax returns to the voters." Romney speculated, "There is only one logical explanation for Mr. Trump's refusal to release his returns: there is a bombshell in them."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/05/11/romney-calls-decision-by-trump-not-to-release-tax-returns-disqualifying.html|title=Romney calls decision by Trump not to release tax returns 'disqualifying'|date=May 11, 2016|work=Fox News|access-date=July 18, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160619110559/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2016/05/11/romney-calls-decision-by-trump-not-to-release-tax-returns-disqualifying.html|archive-date=June 19, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> [[John Fund]] of the ''[[National Review]]'' said that Republican convention delegates should abstain from voting for Trump if he does not release the information, fearing that the returns could contain an electoral "time bomb".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/435254/donald-trumps-tax-returns-delegates-should-abstain-if-he-wont-release|title=Trump's Refusal to Release Tax Returns Is a Ticking Time Bomb for the GOP|last=Fund|first=John|date=May 11, 2016|work=National Review|access-date=July 18, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160718073935/http://www.nationalreview.com/article/435254/donald-trumps-tax-returns-delegates-should-abstain-if-he-wont-release|archive-date=July 18, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
During the [[2016 United States presidential debates]], rival presidential candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] criticized Trump, saying that only "a couple of years" of Trump's tax returns were publicly available, "and they showed he didn't pay any federal income tax". Trump directly responded: "That makes me smart." Clinton went on to suggest that Trump might not have "paid any federal income tax for a lot of years"; this resulted in Trump saying that the taxes he paid "would be squandered" by the government.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mangan|first=Dan|title=Trump brags about not paying taxes: 'That makes me smart'|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/09/26/trump-brags-about-not-paying-taxes-that-makes-me-smart.html|publisher=[[CNBC]]|access-date=April 9, 2019}}</ref>
==During his presidency== {{further|Timeline of the Donald Trump presidency}}
Trump has continued to withhold his tax returns even into his presidency as of September 2019.<ref name=MoneyWhen/>
In May 2017, Trump said that he "might" release his tax returns only after he had stepped down as President. This was in spite of his previous commitment made during his campaign to release his tax returns once they were not under audit.<ref>{{cite web|title=Release his tax returns after an audit is completed - Trump-O-Meter: Broken|url=https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/promises/trumpometer/promise/1421/release-his-tax-returns-after-audit-completed/|publisher=[[Politifact]]|access-date=11 April 2019}}</ref>
===Tax March protests=== {{main|Tax March}} In January 2017, an online petition on the "We the People" portion of the White House's website calling for the release of Trump's tax returns was set up.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/01/petition-didnt-make-trump-give-tax-returns-made-listen/|title=A Petition Didn't Make Trump Give Up His Tax Returns—But It Made Him Listen|last=Ellis|first=Emma Grey|newspaper=WIRED|language=en-US|date=January 26, 2017|access-date=January 31, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170128213639/https://www.wired.com/2017/01/petition-didnt-make-trump-give-tax-returns-made-listen/|archive-date=January 28, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> The petition gained over 1 million signatures, becoming the most signed petition on the White House's website. However, the White House gave no official response to the petition as of April 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lam|first1=Bourree|title=The Fight Over Trump's Tax Returns Isn't Over|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/04/trump-tax-march/523116/|work=[[The Atlantic]]|access-date=April 9, 2019}}</ref> Trump spokesperson [[Kellyanne Conway]] then said that "The White House response is that he’s not going to release the tax returns" and that "people didn't care" about Trump's tax returns.<ref>{{cite news|last=Revesz|first=Rachel|title=Kellyanne Conway says President Trump will not release his tax returns|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/donald-trump-kellyanne-conway-tax-returns-will-not-release-under-audit-conflicts-of-interest-a7540621.html|access-date=7 October 2019|work=The Independent|date=January 22, 2017}}</ref> In response, [[Jennifer Taub]] and others planned the [[Tax March]] on April 15, 2017 ([[Tax Day]]) to demand that Trump release his tax returns;<ref>Amber Jamieson, [https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/12/tax-march-trump-tax-returns-activism-jennifer-taub Tax March: how a law professor sparked a global event to demand Trump's returns], ''The Guardian'' (April 12, 2017).</ref> tens of thousands of people marched in New York and dozens of cities across the country.<ref>[https://www.cbsnews.com/news/tax-march-protests-demand-donald-trump-to-release-tax-returns/ "Tax March" protests demand release of Trump's tax returns], CBS News/Associated Press (April 15, 2017).</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Francescani|first1=Chris|last2=Ramstack|first2=Tom|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-taxes/thousands-at-rallies-demand-trump-release-tax-returns-idUSKBN17H0FW|title=Thousands at rallies demand Trump release tax returns|work=Reuters|date=April 15, 2017}}</ref>
===Congressional requests and subpoenas for Trump's tax returns=== After winning control of the House in the [[United States House of Representatives election, 2018|2018 elections]], House Democrats signaled their intent to use their new power to demand Trump's tax returns in the new Congress, which convened in January 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/watch/with-house-majority-dems-intend-to-request-for-trump-s-tax-returns-1363758147582|title=With House majority, Dems intend to request Trump's tax returns|website=MSNBC.com|language=en|access-date=April 6, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190218175948/https://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/watch/with-house-majority-dems-intend-to-request-for-trump-s-tax-returns-1363758147582|archive-date=February 18, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-tax-returns-democrats-will-demand-presidents-records-house-1205085|title=Democrats set to demand Donald Trump's tax returns after winning House majority|last=Porter|first=Tom|date=November 7, 2018|website=Newsweek|language=en|access-date=April 6, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190328065104/https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-tax-returns-democrats-will-demand-presidents-records-house-1205085|archive-date=March 28,
