=== Hispanic judge === In 2013, the [[New York (state)|State of New York]] filed a $40 million civil suit against [[Trump University]] alleging that the company had made false statements and defrauded consumers.<ref>{{cite news |first=David |last=Halperin <!-- not sure: |authorlink=David Halperin --> |title=NY Court Refuses to Dismiss Trump University Case, Describes Fraud Allegations |date=March 3, 2016 |publisher=[[HuffPost]] |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/ny-court-refuses-to-dismi_b_9358360}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2016/02/27/donald-trumps-misleading-claim-that-hes-won-most-of-lawsuits-over-trump-university/ |first=Michelle Ye Hee |last=Lee |title=Donald Trump's misleading claim that he's 'won most of' lawsuits over Trump University |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=February 27, 2016 |access-date=February 27, 2016}}</ref> Two class-action civil lawsuits were also filed naming Trump personally as well as his companies.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/08/26/trump-entrepreneur-initiative-case/2700811/ |title=Trump faces two-front legal fight over 'university' |work=[[USA Today]] |first=Kevin |last=McCoy |date=August 26, 2013}}</ref> During the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|presidential campaign]], Trump criticized Judge [[Gonzalo P. Curiel]] who oversaw those two cases, alleging bias in his rulings because of his Mexican heritage.<ref name="NYT 2016-06-04">{{cite news |last=Rappeport |first=Alan |date=June 3, 2016 |title=That Judge Attacked by Donald Trump? He's Faced a Lot Worse |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/04/us/politics/donald-trump-university-judge-gonzalo-curiel.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date= June 4, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Ford |first=Matt |date=June 3, 2016 |title=Why Is Donald Trump So Angry at Judge Gonzalo Curiel? |magazine=The Atlantic |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/06/donald-trump-gonzalo-curiel/485636/|access-date=June 3, 2016}}</ref> Trump said that Curiel would have "an absolute conflict" due to his Mexican heritage which led to accusations of racism.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/04/20/politics/juan-manuel-montes-bojorquez-judge-curiel/index.html |title=Judge whose Mexican heritage Trump denigrated will hear deportation case |first1=Tal |last1=Kopan |first2=Laura |last2=Jarrett |publisher=CNN}}</ref> Speaker of the House and a Trump supporter, Republican [[Paul Ryan]] commented, "I disavow these comments. Claiming a person can't do the job because of their race is sort of like the textbook definition of a racist comment. I think that should be absolutely disavowed. It's absolutely unacceptable."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/article/2016/jun/08/donald-trumps-racial-comments-about-judge-trump-un/ |title=Donald Trump's racial comments about Hispanic judge in Trump University case |work=[[Politifact]] |first= Tom |last=Kertscher |date=June 8, 2016 |access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
===New Jersey Arabs=== At a rally in [[Birmingham, Alabama]] on November 21, 2015, Trump falsely claimed that he had seen television reports about "thousands and thousands" of [[Arab Americans]] in [[New Jersey]] celebrating as the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] collapsed during the [[9/11 attacks]]. In an interview with [[George Stephanopoulos]], Trump doubled-down on the assertion, insisting that "there were people that were cheering on the other side of New Jersey, where you have large Arab populations".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Phelps |first1=Jordyn |title=Trump Again Says He Saw Cheering in NJ on 9/11 |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/donald-trump-cheering-jersey-911/story?id=35355447 |accessdate=19 December 2018 |work=ABC News |date=23 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump 'wrong' on 9/11 cheering claims |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-34902748 |accessdate=19 December 2018 |work=BBC News |date=23 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Lauren |first1=Carroll |title=Fact-checking Trump's claim that thousands in New Jersey cheered when World Trade Center tumbled |url=https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/nov/22/donald-trump/fact-checking-trumps-claim-thousands-new-jersey-ch/ |accessdate=19 December 2018 |work=Politifact |date=22 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Gavin |first1=Hailey |title=Trevor Noah Says Trump's Bizarre Tweet Is His Best Attempt at Commemorating 9/11 Yet |url=https://slate.com/culture/2018/09/trump-9-11-tweets-daily-show-response.html |accessdate=19 December 2018 |work=Slate Magazine |date=12 September 2018}}</ref>
=== Somali refugees === In August 2016 Trump campaigned in [[Maine]], which has a large immigrant [[Somalis|Somali]] population. At a rally he said, "We've just seen many, many crimes getting worse all the time, and as Maine knows — a major destination for Somali refugees — right, am I right?" Trump also alluded to risks of terrorism, referring to an incident in June 2016 when three young Somali men were found guilty of planning to join the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] in [[Syria]].<ref name="bostonglobe.com">{{cite news |title=Mainers defend Somali neighbors against Trump |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2016/08/05/maine-sees-somalian-community-starkly-different-than-what-donald-trump-portrayed/qOh4IjKY3VYYcxNG7zkcBM/story.html |newspaper=[[Boston Globe]] |first1=Brian |last1=MacQuarrie |first2=Vivian |last2=Wang |date=August 6, 2016 |access-date=January 22, 2018}}</ref>
In [[Lewiston, Maine|Lewiston]], home to the largest population of Maine Somalis, the police chief said Somalis have integrated into the city and they have not caused an increase in crime; crime is actually going down, not up. The mayor said Lewiston is safe and they all get along. At a Somali support rally following Trump's comments the Portland mayor welcomed the city's Somali residents, saying, "We need you here." Maine Republican senator [[Susan Collins]] commented, "Mr. Trump's statements disparaging immigrants who have come to this country legally are particularly unhelpful. Maine has benefited from people from Europe, the Middle East, Asia, and, increasingly, Africa — including our friends from Somalia."<ref name="bostonglobe.com"/><ref>{{cite news |first=Story |last=Hinckley |title=In one town, how Mainers and new immigrants learned to coexist – until Trump |url=https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Society/2017/0306/In-one-town-how-Mainers-and-new-immigrants-learned-to-coexist-until-Trump |newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=March 6, 2017 |access-date=February 2, 2018}}</ref>
=== Racial accusations on Twitter and in debates === Prior to and during the 2016 campaign, Trump used his political platform to spread disparaging messages against various racial groups. Trump claimed, "the overwhelming amount of violent crime in our cities is committed by blacks and Hispanics,"<ref>{{cite news |first=Meghan |last=Keneally |title=5 times Trump was accused of making racially tinged comments about immigrants, people of color |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/times-trump-accused-making-racially-tinged-comments-immigrants/story?id=52306112 |newspaper=[[ABCNews]] |date=January 12, 2018 |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> that "there's killings on an hourly basis virtually in places like Baltimore and Chicago and many other places,"<ref>{{cite news |first=Kiran |last=Moodley |title=Donald Trump says African-American youths 'have no spirit' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/donald-trump-says-african-american-youths-have-no-spirit-10342030.html |newspaper=[[ABCNews]] |date=June 24, 2015 |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> that "There are places in America that are among the most dangerous in the world. You go to places like Oakland. Or Ferguson. The crime numbers are worse. Seriously," and retweeted a false claim that 81% of white murder victims were killed by black people (the actual percentage was 15%, according to the FBI for 2014).<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Greenberg |title=Trump's Pants on Fire tweet that blacks killed 81% of white homicide victims |url=https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/nov/23/donald-trump/trump-tweet-blacks-white-homicide-victims/ |work=[[Politifact]] |date=November 23, 2015 |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref>
During the campaign Trump was found to have retweeted the main influencers of the [[White genocide conspiracy theory|#WhiteGenocide]] movement over 75 times, including twice that he retweeted a user with the handle @WhiteGenocideTM.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Kharakh |title=Donald Trump's Social Media Ties to White Supremacists |url=https://fortune.com/longform/donald-trump-white-supremacist-genocide/ |newspaper=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=March 22, 2016 |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> Trump also falsely claimed that, "African American communities are absolutely in the worst shape they've ever been in before. Ever, ever, ever,"<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump's Pants on Fire claim that black communities 'are absolutely in the worst shape' ever |url=https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/sep/22/donald-trump/trumps-pants-fire-claim-blacks-are-absolutely-wors/ |work=[[Politifact]] |date=September 22, 2016 |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> that "You go into the inner cities and you see it's 45 percent poverty, African Americans now 45 percent poverty in the inner cities,"<ref>{{cite news |title=PolitiFact's annotated transcript of the second presidential debate |url=https://medium.com/@PolitiFact/politifacts-annotated-transcript-of-the-second-presidential-debate-b54f45edeb99 |newspaper=[[Politifact]] |date=October 9, 2016 |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref> and that "African Americans and Hispanics are living in hell. You walk down the street and you get shot."<ref>{{cite news |first=Melissa |last=Chan |title=Donald Trump Claims Black and Hispanic People Are 'Living in Hell' |url=https://fortune.com/2016/09/26/presidential-debate-donald-trump-living-in-hell-black-people/ |work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=September 27, 2016 |access-date=July 9, 2018}}</ref>
Other claims were directed towards President Barack Obama. Trump also suggested that evangelicals should not trust [[Ted Cruz]] because Cruz is [[Cuban Americans|Cuban]] and that [[Jeb Bush]] "has to like the Mexican illegals because of his wife," who is [[Mexican Americans|Mexican American]].<ref name="Saletan"/>
=== Minority outreach during 2016 campaign ===
Trump's popularity among [[Hispanic and Latino Americans]] was low according to polling data; a nationwide survey conducted in February 2016 showed that some 80 percent of Hispanic voters had an unfavorable view of Trump (including 70 percent who had a "very unfavorable" view), more than double the percentage of any other Republican candidate.<ref name="BalzClement">Dan Balz and Scott Clement, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2016/02/25/poll-trumps-negatives-among-hispanics-rise-worst-in-gop-field/ Poll: Trump's negatives among Hispanics rise; worst in GOP field], ''The Washington Post'' (February 25, 2016).</ref> These low rankings are attributed to Trump campaigning in support of a proposed Mexican border wall and his rhetoric against illegal immigration.<ref name="BalzClement" /><ref>James Oliphant & Luciana Lopez, [https://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/stateroundup/in-florida-donald-trump-finds-some-support-among-hispanic-republicans/2269150/ Some Hispanic Republicans fear for party's future if Trump wins in Florida], Reuters (March 11, 2016).</ref><ref name="Preston">{{Cite news |first=Julia |last=Preston |title=More Latinos Seek Citizenship to Vote Against Trump |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/08/us/trumps-rise-spurs-latino-immigrants-to-naturalize-to-vote-against-him.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=March 8, 2016|date=2016-03-07 }}</ref> Despite expectations of low Latino support, Trump received about 29% of the Hispanic vote, slightly more than Romney received in 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/2016/11/09/hispanic-vote-election-2016-donald-trump-hillary-clinton/93540772/ |title=Another election surprise: Many Hispanics backed Trump |last=Gomez |first=Alan |work=USA Today |date=November 9, 2016 |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref>
In June 2016, at a rally in [[Redding, California]], Trump pointed to a man in the audience—Gregory Cheadle, a real estate broker—and said, "Look at my African American over here. Look at him. Are you the greatest?" Cheadle later declared in 2019 that he was so unhappy with Trump's "white superiority complex" and the "pro-white" Republican Party's usage of blacks as "political pawns" that he was leaving the Republican Party.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/man-trump-once-called-my-african-american-leaves-republican-party|title=Why the man Trump once called 'my African American' is leaving the GOP|date=2019-09-12|work=PBS NewsHour|access-date=2019-09-13}}</ref>
According to polling data during the 2016 U.S. presidential election, Trump was receiving little support from [[African Americans]]. In a [[Morning Consult]] poll in August 2016, only 5% of black voters said they intend to vote for Trump.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://morningconsult.com/2016/08/28/trump-gains-ground-clinton-black-voters-still-wary/ |title=Trump Gains Ground on Clinton; Black Voters Still Wary |last=Johnson |first=Fawn |date=August 28, 2016 |work=Morning Consult |accessdate=September 16, 2016}}</ref> However, Trump ended up receiving 8% of the African-American vote (about 500,000 more votes than [[Mitt Romney]] received in 2012).<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/why-so-many-blacks-backed_b_12913720 |title=Why So Many Blacks Backed Trump |last=Hutchinson |first=Earl |date=November 14, 2016 |work=The Huffington Post |accessdate=November 16, 2016}}</ref> Speaking in Virginia in August 2016, Trump said, "You're living in your poverty, your schools are no good, you have no jobs, 58 percent of your youth is unemployed – what the hell do you have to lose by trying something new, like Trump?"<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/donald-trump-courts-black-vote-while-avoiding-african-american-communities-1471944606 |title=Donald Trump Courts Black Vote While Avoiding African-American Communities |last=Epstein |first=Reid |date=August 24, 2016 |work=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=September 10, 2016}}</ref>
==Presidency== === Immigration policy === {{see also|Protests against Executive Order 13769|List of protests against Executive Order 13769}} [[File:Trump_Immigration_Order_Sparks_Protests_at_NY_Airport.webmhd.webm|thumb|right|'Trump Immigration Order Sparks Protests at NY Airport' report from [[Voice of America]]]] On January 27, 2017, via [[Executive Order 13769|executive order]], which he titled [[Executive Order 13769|Protecting the Nation from Foreign Terrorist Entry into the United States]], President Trump ordered the U.S border indefinitely closed to [[Refugees of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian refugees]] fleeing the [[Syrian Civil War|civil war]]. He also abruptly temporarily halted (for 90 days) immigration from six other Muslim-majority nations: Iraq, Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen. Human rights activists described these actions as government-approved [[religious persecution]]. The order was stayed by Federal courts.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Shear |first1=Micheal D. |last2=Cooper |first2=Helen |title=Trump Bars Refugees and Citizens of 7 Muslim Countries |work=The New York Times |date=January 27, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/27/us/politics/trump-syrian-refugees.html| access-date =January 14, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Shear |first1=Micheal D.|last2=Kluish |first2=Nicholas |last3=Feuer |first3=Alan |title=Judge Blocks Trump Order on Refugees Amid Chaos and Outcry Worldwide |work=The New York Times |date=January 28, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/28/us/refugees-detained-at-us-airports-prompting-legal-challenges-to-trumps-immigration-order.html| access-date =January 14, 2018}}</ref> The Trump White House would go on to issue [[Executive Order 13780|revised versions of the ban]] on March 6, 2017 and September 24, 2017. The [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] eventually [[Trump v. Hawaii|upheld the third version]] in June 2018, with Chief Justice Roberts writing for the majority that "The Proclamation is expressly premised on legitimate purposes: preventing entry of nationals who cannot be adequately vetted and inducing other nations to improve their practices".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-44619976 |title=Travel ban: Trump hails 'tremendous' Supreme Court ruling|publisher=BBC |date=26 June 2020 |accessdate=30 May 2020}}</ref> However, dissenting, Justice [[Sonia Sotomayor]] compared the opinion to one made in 1944 which allowed the [[internment of Japanese Americans]] during World War II.<ref>{{cite news |last1=de Vogue |first1=Ariane |last2=Stracqualursi |first2=Veronica |title=Supreme Court upholds travel ban |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/26/politics/travel-ban-supreme-court/index.html |accessdate=26 June 2018 |publisher=CNN |date=26 June 2018}}</ref> In a ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' editorial writer [[Moustafa Bayoumi]] criticised the Supreme Court for upholding the Executive Order, commenting, "The Muslim ban ruling legitimates Trump's bigotry [...] and the racist view that Muslims are a unique national security threat because they are Muslims persists.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bayoumi |first1=Moustafa |title=The Muslim ban ruling legitimates Trump's bigotry |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jun/27/muslim-ban-ruling-trumps-bigotry |work=The Guardian |accessdate=October 27, 2019}}</ref>
=== Black Caucus === In a February 2017 presidential press conference, White House press correspondent [[April Ryan]] asked Trump if he would involve the [[Congressional Black Caucus]] when making plans for executive orders affecting inner city areas. Trump replied, "Well, I would. I tell you what. Do you want to set up the meeting?" When Ryan said she was just a reporter, Trump pursued, "Are they friends of yours?" ''The New York Times'' wrote that Trump was "apparently oblivious to the racial undertones of posing such a query to a black journalist". Journalist [[Jonathan Capehart]] commented, "Does he think that all black people know each other and she's going to go run off and set up a meeting for him?"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Grynbaum|first1=Michael|title=For April Ryan, Clashes With the White House Bring a New Kind of Prominence|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/31/business/media/april-ryan-white-house-spicer-trump.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref>
In March 2017, six members of the Congressional Black Caucus met with President Trump to discuss the caucus's reply to Trump's campaign-rally question to African Americans, "What do you have to lose?" (by voting for him). The question was part of Trump's campaign rhetoric that was seen as characterizing all African Americans in terms of helpless poverty and inner-city violence.<ref>{{cite news |title=Donald Trump to African American and Hispanic voters: 'What do you have to lose?' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/08/22/donald-trump-to-african-american-and-hispanic-voters-what-do-you-have-to-lose/ |author=Johnson, Jenna |date=August 22, 2016 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=January 13, 2018}}</ref> According to two people who attended the March meeting, Trump asked caucus members if they personally knew new cabinet member [[Ben Carson]] and appeared surprised when no one said they knew him. Also, when a caucus member told Trump that cuts to [[Temporary Assistance for Needy Families|welfare programs]] would hurt her constituents, "not all of whom are black",<ref name="newsweek 2018-01-20">{{cite news |last1=Sit|first1=Ryan|title=Trump Thinks Only Black People Are on Welfare, But, Really, White Americans Receive Most Benefits |url=https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-welfare-black-white-780252 |work=Newsweek |accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref> the president replied, "Really? Then what are they?", although most welfare recipients are white.<ref name="newsweek 2018-01-20" /> The caucus chairman, Rep. [[Cedric Richmond]], later said the meeting was productive and that the goals of the caucus and the administration were more similar than different: "The route to get there is where you may see differences. Part of that is just education and life experiences."<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump's history of breaking decorum with remarks on race, ethnicity |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-s-history-breaking-decorum-remarks-race-ethnicity-n837181 |author=Salama, Vivian |date=January 12, 2018 |publisher=[[NBC News]]|access-date=January 13, 2018}}</ref>
=== Derogatory statements towards Haiti and Nigeria === In June 2017, Trump called together a staff meeting to complain about the number of immigrants who had entered the country since his inauguration. ''The New York Times'' reported that two officials at the meeting state that when Trump read off a sheet stating that 15,000 persons had visited from [[Haiti]], he commented, "They all have [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]]," and when reading that 40,000 persons had visited from [[Nigeria]], he said that after seeing America the Nigerians would never "go back to their huts." Both officials who heard Trump's statements relayed them to other staff members at the time, but the White House has denied that Trump used those words and some of the other officials present claim not to remember them being used.<ref>{{cite news |title=STOKING FEARS, TRUMP DEFIED BUREAUCRACY TO ADVANCE IMMIGRATION AGENDA |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/23/us/politics/trump-immigration.html |author=Shear, Michael |date=December 23, 2017 |work=The New York Times|access-date=July 15, 2018}}</ref>
=== Hurricane Maria === [[File:Hurricane_Maria_(2017)_170923-H-NI589-0007_(36602415074).jpg|thumb|right|Homes damaged in Puerto Rico following [[Hurricane Maria]].]] In September 2017 after [[Hurricane Maria]] struck Puerto Rico and decimated services across the island, the Mayor of San Juan Carmen Yulín Cruz went on television to plea for help and accused the federal response of fatal inefficiency. Trump responded with a series of tweets claiming that the Puerto Rican leadership were "not able to get their workers to help" because "They want everything to be done for them" while claiming that federal workers were doing a "fantastic job."<ref>{{cite news |title=Donald Trump: Puerto Rico Wants 'Everything to Be Done for Them' |url=https://time.com/4963903/donald-trump-puerto-rican-leaders-want-everything-to-be-done-for-them/ |last=Segarra |first=Lisa Marie |date=September 30, 2017 |work=Time|access-date=July 22, 2018}}</ref> As the death toll on the island reached into the thousands, Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York and others criticized the federal government and suggested that racism was partially to blame for the insufficient response.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cuomo blames racism for weak federal response to Hurricane Maria victims |url=https://nypost.com/2018/06/10/cuomo-blames-racism-for-weak-federal-response-to-hurricane-maria-victims/ |author=Attanasio, Cedar |date=June 10, 2018 |publisher=New York Post|access-date=July 22, 2018}}</ref>
=== Pardon of Joe Arpaio === {{Main|Pardon of Joe Arpaio}} The [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]] concluded that [[Arizona]] sheriff [[Joe Arpaio]] oversaw the worst pattern of racial profiling in U.S. history.<ref name="phoenixNewTimesArpaio">{{cite news|last1=Stern|first1=Ray|title=Sheriff Joe Arpaio's Office Commits Worst Racial Profiling in U.S. History, Concludes DOJ Investigation|url=https://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/news/sheriff-joe-arpaios-office-commits-worst-racial-profiling-in-us-history-concludes-doj-investigation-6655328 |work=Phoenix New Times |accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref> The illegal tactics that he was using included "extreme racial profiling and sadistic punishments that involved the torture, humiliation, and degradation of Latino inmates".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stern|first1=Mark Joseph|title=White Nationalist Rule Is Already Here|url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2017/08/donald-trump-is-considering-pardoning-former-sheriff-joe-arpaio.html|work=Slate|accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref> The DoJ filed suit against him for unlawful discriminatory police conduct. He ignored their orders and was subsequently convicted of [[contempt of court]] for continuing to racially profile Hispanics. Calling him "a great American patriot", President Trump pardoned him soon afterwards, even before sentencing took place.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://fortune.com/2017/08/26/donald-trump-pardons-joe-arpaio/|title=Trump, Playing to His Base, Pardons Anti-Immigrant Sheriff Joe Arpaio|last=Morris|first=David Z.|work=Fortune|access-date=August 26, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Jacobs |first1=Ben |authorlink=Ben Jacobs (journalist) |last2=Gambino |first2=Lauren |title=Joe Arpaio, pardoned racial profiler, to run for Arizona Senate seat |newspaper=The Guardian |date=January 9, 2018 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/09/joe-arpaio-arizona-senate-seat |access-date=January 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Perez-Pena |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Pérez-Peña |title=Former Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio Is Convicted of Criminal Contempt |work=The New York Times |date=July 31, 2017 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/31/us/sheriff-joe-arpaio-convicted-arizona.html}}</ref> [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|House speaker]] [[Paul Ryan]], and both Arizona senators, [[John McCain]] and [[Jeff Flake]], were critical of Trump's decision.<ref>{{cite news|title=John McCain Rips Donald Trump For Pardoning Joe Arpaio|first=Sam|last=Levine|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/entry/john-mccain-trump-arpaio_n_59a17023e4b05710aa5c7fdc|date=August 26, 2017|accessdate=August 26, 2017|newspaper=[[HuffPost]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/348069-flake-on-arpaio-pardon-i-would-have-preferred-trump-honor-the-judicial|title=Flake: Trump should have honored judicial process on Arpaio pardon|last=Manchester|first=Julia|date=August 25, 2017|work=The Hill|access-date=August 26, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-41064787|title=Trump Arpaio: Top Republican Paul Ryan condemns pardon for sheriff |date=August 27, 2017|publisher=BBC News|access-date=November 18, 2017}}</ref> Constitutional scholars also opposed the decision to grant the pardon, which according to [[Harvard Law School]] professor [[Noah Feldman]] was "an assault on the [[Federal judiciary of the United States|federal judiciary]], the [[Constitution of the United States|constitution]] and the [[rule of law]] itself". The [[American Civil Liberties Union]], which was involved in the case resulting in Arpaio's conviction, tweeted: "By pardoning Joe Arpaio, Donald Trump has sent another disturbing signal to an emboldened white nationalist movement that this White House supports racism and bigotry." According to ACLU deputy legal director Cecilia Wang, the pardon was "a presidential endorsement of racism".<ref>{{cite news|title=Donald Trump pardons Joe Arpaio, former sheriff convicted in racial profiling case|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/aug/25/donald-trump-joe-arpaio-pardon-arizona-sheriff|work=The Guardian |date=August 26, 2017 |accessdate=January 23, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Carter>{{cite news | url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/348071-aclu-trumps-pardon-of-arpaio-a-presidential-endorsement-of | title=ACLU: Trump's pardon of Arpaio 'a presidential endorsement of racism' | work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date=August 25, 2017 | accessdate=February 18, 2018 | last=Carter | first=Brandon}}</ref>
=== NFL national anthem protests === {{See also|U.S. national anthem protests (2016–present)}} In August 2016 [[Colin Kaepernick]], an [[National Football League|NFL]] [[quarterback]], began sitting (later kneeling) during the playing of the [[The Star-Spangled Banner|U.S. national anthem]] before games as a protest of police brutality and racial inequality suffered by Black Americans. Then-candidate Trump entered into the debate within days, stating of Kaepernick, "I think it’s personally not a good thing, I think it’s a terrible thing. And, you know, maybe he should find a country that works better for him. Let him try, it won’t happen."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wilder|first1=Charlotte|title=Donald Trump says Colin Kaepernick should find a new country|url=https://ftw.usatoday.com/2016/08/donald-trump-colin-kaepernick-new-country-national-anthem-protest-response|newspaper=USAToday|date=August 30, 2016 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref>
Shortly after the start of the next [[2017 NFL season|NFL season]] in September 2017, President Trump commented extensively on the protests during a rally for Alabama Senate candidate [[Luther Strange]], stating, "Wouldn't you love to see one of these NFL owners, when somebody disrespects our flag, to say, 'Get that son of a bitch off the field right now, out, he's fired. He's fired.' You know, some owner is going to do that. He's going to say, 'That guy that disrespects our flag, he's fired.' And that owner, they don't know it they'll be the most popular person in this country. Because that's a total disrespect of our heritage."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mindock|first1=Clint|title=Taking a knee: Why are NFL players protesting and when did they start to kneel?|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/taking-a-knee-national-anthem-nfl-trump-why-meaning-origins-racism-us-colin-kaepernick-a7966961.html|newspaper=Independent|date=May 24, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> Trump later pushed back against the players' concerns regarding racial inequality via Twitter, stating, "The issue of kneeling has nothing to do with race. It is about respect for our Country, Flag and National Anthem. NFL must respect this!"<ref name="Vox20180204">{{cite news |last1=Lockhart|first1=P.R.|title=Trump's reaction to the NFL protests shows how he fights the culture war |url=https://www.vox.com/identities/2018/2/4/16967902/nfl-protests-patriotism-race-donald-trump-super-bowl |newspaper=Vox|date=February 4, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> In October of that year, Trump had Vice President [[Mike Pence]] attend an NFL game in Indianapolis, telling him "to leave stadium if any players kneeled, disrespecting our country."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Watkins|first1=Eli|title=Pence leaves Colts game after protest during anthem |url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/10/08/politics/vice-president-mike-pence-nfl-protest/index.html |newspaper=CNN|date=October 9, 2017 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> Pence left after the anthem, an action that was seen by many as a publicity stunt.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Axson|first1=Scooby|title=Trump: NFL "Weak and Out of Control' For Allowing Protests |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/11/28/donald-trump-nfl-protest-anthem |newspaper=Sports Illustrated|date=November 28, 2017 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> Trump's public criticisms of the player protests continued throughout the year.
In October 2017 Trump publicly praised [[Dallas Cowboys|Dallas Cowboys's]] owner [[Jerry Jones]] after he announced that he would bench players who failed to stand during the anthem.<ref name="Vox20180204" /> That month Colin Kaepernick filed a collusion case against the NFL, charging that NFL owners, under the influence of Trump, had colluded to agree not to hire Kaepernick as punishment for his protests. In a player-owner meeting several owners expressed reluctance to continue allowing players to protest as they feared Trump. [[New England Patriots]] owner [[Robert Kraft]], a public supporter of Trump, stated "The problem we have is, we have a president who will use that as fodder to do his mission that I don’t feel is in the best interests of America. It's divisive and it’s horrible."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Belson|first1=Ken|title=Inside the Confidential N.F.L. Meeting to Discuss National Anthem Protests |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/25/sports/nfl-owners-kaepernick.html |work=The New York Times|date=April 25, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> Kaepernick lawyer [[Mark Geragos]] stated, "They were clearly colluding because they were intimidated by the president. The only reason — and the owners will admit this — that they haven’t signed him is because of Trump, and they’ve colluded because of Trump."<ref name="SBNation20180607">{{cite news |last1=Stites|first1=Adam|title=Colin Kaepernick's collusion case will hinge on President Donald Trump's involvement in anthem debate |url=https://www.sbnation.com/2018/5/30/17409356/colin-kaepernick-eric-reid-collusion-case-donald-trump-national-anthem-policy |newspaper=SBNation|date=June 7, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> [[Miami Dolphins]] owner [[Stephen M. Ross|Stephen Ross]] admitted in a deposition that he had originally supported the players' protest but then changed his position due to Trump, and several other owners testified that Trump had contacted them directly regarding the protests.<ref name="SBNation20180607" /> Trump later praised NFL owners when they voted to allow protesters to be penalized or dismissed for their actions, taking the occasion to suggest that players who didn't want to stand for the anthem didn't belong in the country.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lockhart|first1=P.R.|title=Trump praises NFL anthem rule, says kneeling players "maybe shouldn't be in the country" |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/5/24/17389288/donald-trump-nfl-kneeling-protest-national-anthem |newspaper=Vox|date=May 24, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> Several commentators saw this move by the NFL as a decision to stand with Trump and against the Black protesters.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stahl|first1=Jeremy|title=The NFL Just Gave Donald Trump Everything He Wanted |url=https://slate.com/culture/2018/05/the-nfls-new-anthem-policy-is-a-political-gift-from-roger-goodell-to-donald-trump.html |newspaper=Vox|date=May 23, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref>
In June 2018 Trump dis-invited the [[Super Bowl LII|Super Bowl Champion]] [[Philadelphia Eagles]] from their White House visit after finding that only a minority of the players were planning on attending due to their general disagreement with Trump's policies. Trump claimed that the players' motivation for not coming was his insistence on standing during the anthem, a claim that was refuted by several Eagles players,<ref name="CNN20180605">{{cite news |last1=Collison|first1=Stephen|title=Trump to NFL players: Patriotism is my way or the highway |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/05/politics/donald-trump-philadelphia-eagles-patriotism/index.html|newspaper=CNN|date=June 5, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> as in fact none of the players on that team had knelt during that season.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tatum|first1=Sophie|title=Trump cancels Philadelphia Eagles visit to the White House |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/04/politics/trump-eagles-nfl/index.html|newspaper=CNN|date=June 4, 2018 |accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref> Commentators noted that Trump's redirection of the issue towards the anthem controversy was an attempt to play on social and racial issues in order to fire up his base<ref name="CNN20180605" /> and have connected it to his public criticisms of Black [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] players, Black [[UCLA Basketball|UCLA basketball]] players, and a Black anchor on [[ESPN]].<ref name="Vox20180204" />
=== Charlottesville rally === {{Main|Unite the Right rally|Charlottesville car attack}} [[File:Charlottesville_'Unite_the_Right'_Rally_(35780274914)_crop.jpg|thumb|right|Protesters at the Unite the Right rally. Trump was criticized for saying there were "very fine people on both sides" of the event.]] [[File:Trump's Remarks on Violence in at White Supremacist Rally in Virginia.webm|thumb|right|300px|start=00:06|Trump states "We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides, on many sides."]] A [[far-right]] rally called "Unite the Right" was held in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]], on August 11–12, 2017.<ref>{{cite news |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/us/far-right-groups-blaze-into-national-view-in-charlottesville.html |date=August 13, 2017 |title=Far-Right Groups Surge into National View in Charlottesville |first1=Richard |last1=Fausset |first2=Alan |last2=Feuer|url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816015808/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/us/far-right-groups-blaze-into-national-view-in-charlottesville.html |archivedate=August 16, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40912509|title=Charlottesville: One killed in violence over US far-right rally|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821054540/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40912509|archive-date=August 21, 2017|work=BBC News|date=August 13, 2017}}</ref> Its stated goal was to oppose the removal of [[Robert Edward Lee (sculpture)|a statue of Robert E. Lee]] from [[Emancipation Park (Charlottesville, Virginia)|Emancipation Park]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stolberg |first1=Sheryl |last2=Rosenthal |first2=Brian M. |date=August 12, 2017 |title=Man Charged After White Nationalist Rally in Charlottesville Ends in Deadly Violence |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/12/us/charlottesville-protest-white-nationalist.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=August 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="HeimWaPo">{{cite news|first1=Joe|last1=Heim|first2=Ellie|last2=Silverman|author3=T. Rees Shapiro|first4=Emma|last4=Brown|date=August 13, 2017|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/fights-in-advance-of-saturday-protest-in-charlottesville/2017/08/12/155fb636-7f13-11e7-83c7-5bd5460f0d7e_story.html |title= One dead as car strikes crowds amid protests of white nationalist gathering in Charlottesville; two police die in helicopter crash|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812103231/https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/fights-in-advance-of-saturday-protest-in-charlottesville/2017/08/12/155fb636-7f13-11e7-83c7-5bd5460f0d7e_story.html|archive-date=August 12, 2017|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> Protesters included [[White supremacy|white supremacists]], [[White nationalism|white nationalists]], [[neo-Confederates]], [[Ku Klux Klan|Klansmen]], [[neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]], and various [[Militia organizations in the United States|militias]]. Some chanted racist and antisemitic slogans, and carried [[Nazi flag]]s, [[Confederate battle flag]]s, [[Islamophobia|anti-Muslim]] and antisemitic banners, and [[semi-automatic rifles]].<ref name="HeimWaPo"/><ref name="nyt-boost" /><ref>{{cite news |work=[[The Atlantic]] |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2017/08/nazis-racism-charlottesville/536928/ |title=Why the Charlottesville Marchers Were Obsessed With Jews |date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> Some of the protesters and counterprotesters carried shields and sticks, and both groups were "swinging sticks, punching and spraying chemicals", forcing police to declare [[unlawful assembly]] and disperse the crowds.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2017/local/charlottesville-timeline/|title=Recounting a day of rage, hate, violence and death|work=The Washington Post| date=August 14, 2017| accessdate=February 12, 2018}}</ref> Two hours after the dispersal order, a woman was killed and 35 other people injured at a nearby mall, when a self-professed neo-Nazi drove his car into a group of people who had been protesting against the rally.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/driver-accused-of-plowing-into-charlottesville-crowd-killing-heather-heyer-due-in-court/2017/12/13/6cbb4ce8-e029-11e7-89e8-edec16379010_story.html |title=Charge upgraded to first-degree murder for driver accused of ramming Charlottesville crowd |first=Paul |last=Duggan |date=December 14, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref>
In his initial statement on the rally, Trump condemned "hatred, bigotry, and violence on many sides" but did not directly denounce white nationalists. His statement and his subsequent defenses of it, in which he also referred to "very fine people on both sides", suggested a moral equivalence between the white supremacist marchers and those who protested against them, leading some observers to state that he was sympathetic to white supremacy.<ref name="nyt-boost">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/15/us/politics/trump-charlottesville-white-nationalists.html |title=Trump Gives White Supremacists an Unequivocal Boost |work=[[The New York Times]] |first1=Glenn |last1=Thrush |first2=Maggie |last2=Haberman |author-link1=Glenn Thrush |author-link2=Maggie Haberman |date=August 15, 2017 |archive-url=https://archive.is/dOezP |archive-date=August 16, 2017 |url-status=live |url-access=limited}}</ref> Trump later said: "I'm not talking about the neo-Nazis and the white nationalists, because they should be condemned totally".<ref name=Blake-190426>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/04/25/meet-trump-charlottesville-truthers/ | title=Trump tries to re-write his own history on Charlottesville and 'both sides' | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=April 26, 2019 | accessdate=January 14, 2020 | first=Aaron | last=Blake}}</ref><ref name=McAuliffe-190730>{{cite news | url=https://www.newsweek.com/2019/08/09/charlottesville-donald-trump-speech-terry-mcauliffe-1451610.html | title=How Donald Trump Decided to go Soft on White Supremacists | work=[[Newsweek]] | date=July 30, 2019 | accessdate=January 14, 2020 | first=Terry | last=McAuliffe}}</ref>
Two days later, following a wave of disapproval that met his initial remarks, Trump delivered a prepared statement, saying "Racism is evil, and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs."<ref name=NYT-20170814>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/14/us/politics/trump-charlottesville-protest.html |title=New Outcry as Trump Rebukes Charlottesville Racists 2 Days Later |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Glenn |last=Thrush |date=August 14, 2017 |access-date=February 16, 2018}}</ref> However, the next day he defended the original rally, stating, "You had people in that group who were protesting the taking down of what to them is a very, very important statue...You're changing history; you're changing culture," and again placed blame on the counterprotesters in affirming, "I think there's blame on both sides. And I have no doubt about it. You had a group on one side that was bad and you had a group on the other side that was also very violent. No one wants to say that, but I’ll say it right now: You had a group on the other side that came charging in without a permit and they were very, very violent."<ref name="Washpost20170815">{{cite news|title=Trump again blames 'both sides' in Charlottesville, says some counterprotesters were 'very, very violent'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/08/15/trump-again-blames-both-sides-in-charlottesville-says-some-counterprotesters-were-very-very-violent/|accessdate=July 16, 2018|work=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> Former [[Grand Wizard|KKK Grand Wizard]] [[David Duke]] praised Trump's remarks in a tweet: "Thank you President Trump for your honesty & courage to tell the truth about #Charlottesville & condemn the leftist terrorists in BLM/Antifa."<ref name="Washpost20170815" />
Five days after the rally, Trump returned to Twitter to express sympathy with the original rally and their defense of [[List of Confederate monuments and memorials|Confederate statues]], writing, "Sad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments" and "the beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!"<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump mourns loss of 'beautiful statues and monuments' in wake of Charlottesville rally over Robert E. Lee statue|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2017/08/17/trump-mourns-loss-of-beautiful-statues-and-monuments-in-wake-of-charlottesville-rally-over-robert-e-lee-statue/|accessdate=July 16, 2018|work=The Washington Post|date=August 17, 2017}}</ref>
Ten days after the rally, in prepared remarks at an [[American Legion]] conference, Trump called for the country to unite. He said: "We are not defined by the color of our skin, the figure on our paycheck or the party of our politics. Rather, we are defined by our shared humanity, our citizenship in this magnificent nation and by the love that fills our hearts." The remarks came a day after further racially divisive remarks he had made at a rally in Phoenix, Arizona, where he had said of those who wish to take down Confederate statues, "They’re trying to take away our culture. They’re trying to take away our history."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fabian|first1=Jordan|title=After divisive rally, Trump calls for unity|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/347689-after-divisive-rally-trump-calls-for-unity|newspaper=The Hill |date=August 23, 2017 |accessdate=January 16, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Trump paints himself as the real victim of Charlottesville in angry speech|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/aug/23/donald-trump-arizona-rally-phoenix|accessdate=February 23, 2018|work=The Guardian|date=August 23, 2017}}</ref>
In a tweet to mark the first anniversary, Trump stated "The riots in Charlottesville a year ago resulted in senseless death and division. We must come together as a nation. I condemn all types of racism and acts of violence. Peace to ALL Americans!" Critics contended that the wording "all types of racism" could be seen as a veiled defense of white nationalists, similarly to his "both sides" remarks on the rally.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trump condemns 'all types of racism' on Charlottesville anniversary; critics slam wording|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/08/11/donald-trump-charlottesville-anniversary-condemn-all-racism/965715002/|accessdate=August 12, 2018|work=USA Today|date=August 12, 2018}}</ref>
=== Elizabeth Warren === [[File:Elizabeth_Warren,_official_portrait,_114th_Congress.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Trump gave Senator [[Elizabeth Warren]] the [[List of nicknames used by Donald Trump|nickname]] "[[Pocahontas]]" due to a controversy over her ancestry.]] In 2012, controversy arose when it was charged that Senator [[Elizabeth Warren]] had used a claim of Native American ancestry early in her career to gain hiring preference.<ref>{{cite news|title=Did Elizabeth Warren check the Native American box when she 'applied' to Harvard and Penn?|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/post/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-controversy-over-elizabeth-warrens-claimed-native-american-heritage/2012/09/27/d0b7f568-08a5-11e2-a10c-fa5a255a9258_blog.html|work=The Washington Post|date=September 28, 2012|accessdate=February 13, 2018}}</ref> Warren denies that she ever claimed to be a minority to secure employment, and a review of her employment history and interviews of her past employers has been unable to find anything that supports the charge.<ref>{{cite web|last1=D'Angelo|first1=Gore|title=Elizabeth Warren's 'Pocahontas' Controversy|url=https://www.factcheck.org/2017/12/elizabeth-warrens-pocahontas-controversy/|work=Fact Check.org|accessdate=February 13, 2018|date=December 2017}}</ref> Picking up on the controversy, Trump has frequently referred to her as "[[Pocahontas]]", including at a White House event where he addressed Native American veterans who served in the US military during World War II.<ref name=nbc-vitali>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/trump-calls-warren-pocahontas-event-honoring-native-americans-n824266 |title=Trump calls Warren 'Pocahontas' at event honoring Native Americans |publisher=[[NBC News]] |last=Vitali |first=Ali |date=November 27, 2017 |access-date=January 13, 2018 }}</ref> Warren responded: "It was deeply unfortunate that the President of the United States cannot even make it through a ceremony honoring these heroes without throwing out a racial slur."<ref name=nbc-vitali /> Speaking on ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'', [[Mark Shields]] commented, "It's one thing when Donald Trump uses Pocahontas to attack or taunt one senator, Elizabeth Warren. This, quite frankly, is beyond that. I mean, this is racial. It's racist. It is."<ref name=pbs-shields-brooks>{{cite news |title=Shields and Brooks on Trump's 's***hole' comments, 'Fire and Fury' fallout |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/shields-and-brooks-on-trumps-shole-comments-fire-and-fury-fallout#transcript |work=[[PBS NewsHour]] |date=January 12, 2018 |access-date=January 13, 2018}}</ref>
The general secretary of the Alliance of Colonial Era Tribes, John Norwood, said Trump's nickname for Warren is "insulting to all American Indians" and "smacks of racism", adding that Trump should "stop using our historical people of significance as a racial slur against one of his opponents."<ref name=nbc-vitali /> The president of the [[National Congress of American Indians]] said: "We regret that the president's use of the name Pocahontas as a slur to insult a political adversary is overshadowing the true purpose of today's White House ceremony."<ref name=nbc-vitali /> White House press secretary [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] said that complaints that the nickname is a racial slur are "ridiculous", and that "What most people find offensive is Senator Warren lying about her heritage to advance her career."<ref name=nbc-vitali /><ref>{{cite news |title=Why Trump keeps calling Elizabeth Warren "Pocahontas" |url=https://www.axios.com/why-trump-keeps-calling-elizabeth-warren-pocahontas-1513307195-dfbd4f53-fd10-4480-be25-1471ed199e4e.html |work=[[Axios (website)|Axios]] |first=Alayna |last=Treene |date=November 27, 2017 |access-date=February 15, 2018}}</ref>
=== "Pretty Korean lady" === In an intelligence briefing on hostages held by a terrorist group in [[Pakistan]], Trump repeatedly interrupted the briefing to ask an [[Asian-American]] intelligence analyst who specializes in hostage situations "where are you from?" After she told him she was from New York he asked again and she clarified that she was from [[Manhattan]]. He pressed with the question until she finally told him that her parents were Korean. Trump then asked one of his advisers why "the pretty Korean lady" was not negotiating for him with [[North Korea]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/12/trump-intelligence-analyst-pretty-korean-lady |title=Trump asked why 'pretty Korean lady' analyst wasn't negotiating with North Korea |first=Martin |last=Pengelly |date=January 12, 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-s-history-breaking-decorum-remarks-race-ethnicity-n837181 |title=Trump comments on race, ethnicity raised eyebrows before 'shithole' furor|last=Salama|first=Vivian|date=January 12, 2018|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=January 12, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/368774-trump-questioned-why-pretty-korean-lady-wasnt-negotiating-for-us-with |title=Trump questioned why 'pretty Korean lady' analyst wasn't working on North Korea: report |first=John |last=Bowden |date=January 12, 2018 |newspaper=The Hill}}</ref> [[NBC News]] characterized this exchange as Trump having "seemed to suggest her ethnicity should determine her career path".<ref>{{cite news|last=Salama|first=Vivian|title=Trump's history of breaking decorum with remarks on race, ethnicity|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-s-history-breaking-decorum-remarks-race-ethnicity-n837181|accessdate=January 18, 2018}}</ref> ''[[Vox Media|Vox]]'' suggested that when Trump refused to accept New York as an answer he is "saying that children of Asian immigrants [[perpetual foreigner|can never truly be 'from' America]]. This isn't just simple bigotry; it feels like a rejection of the classic American 'melting pot' ideal altogether."<ref name=Beauchamp>{{cite news |last=Beauchamp |first=Zack |title=Trump reportedly interrupted intel briefing to ask Korean American, "Where are you from?" |url=https://www.vox.com/world/2018/1/12/16885546/trump-asian-american-intelligence-briefing |work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=January 12, 2018 |access-date=January 19, 2018}}</ref>
=== "Shithole countries" === {{See also|Immigration policy of Donald Trump}} On January 11, 2018, during an [[Oval Office]] meeting about immigration reform, commenting on immigration figures from El Salvador, Haiti, Honduras, and African countries, Trump reportedly said: "Those shitholes send us the people that they don't want",<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.factcheck.org/2018/01/trump-say-immigration-meeting/ |title=What Did Trump Say at Immigration Meeting? |work=[[FactCheck.org]] |first=Eugene |last=Kiely |date=January 16, 2018 |access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> and suggested that the US should instead increase immigration from "places like Norway"<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/1/11/16880750/trump-immigrants-shithole-countries-norway |title=Trump wants fewer immigrants from 'shithole countries' and more from places like Norway |work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |first=Jen |last=Kirby |date=January 11, 2018 |access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> and Asian countries.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-attacks-protections-for-immigrants-from-shithole-countries-in-oval-office-meeting/2018/01/11/bfc0725c-f711-11e7-91af-31ac729add94_story.html |title=Trump derides protections for immigrants from 'shithole' countries|last1=Dawsey |first1= Josh |date=January 12, 2018 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=February 19, 2018 |quote=The president, according to a White House official, also suggested he would be open to more immigrants from Asian countries because he felt that they help the United States economically.}}</ref> The comments received widespread domestic and international condemnation;<ref name="The Guardian 2018-01-12">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/12/donald-trump-shithole-countries-tweet-denies-immigration-talks |title=Donald Trump denies using the phrase 'shithole countries' in immigration talks |first=Alan |last=Yuhas |date=January 12, 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Beauchamp |first=Zack |title=Trump's "shithole countries" comment exposes the core of Trumpism |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/1/11/16880804/trump-shithole-countries-racism |work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |date=January 11, 2018 |access-date=January 11, 2018}}</ref><ref name="wapo-20180111">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-attacks-protections-for-immigrants-from-shithole-countries-in-oval-office-meeting/2018/01/11/bfc0725c-f711-11e7-91af-31ac729add94_story.html|title=Trump's history of making offensive comments about nonwhite immigrants|last=Dawsey|first=Josh|date=January 11, 2018|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=January 11, 2018|url-status=live|url-access=limited}}</ref> news anchors such as [[Anderson Cooper]] and [[Don Lemon]] called Trump a racist.<ref name="normalized"/>
In a statement issued the same day, the White House did not deny that the president made the remarks, but on the following day Trump did tweet out a partial denial, saying that he "never said anything derogatory about Haitians", and denied using "shithole" specifically to refer to those countries but did admit to using "tough language".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-appears-deny-shithole-slur-defends-tough-immigration-stance-n837056 |title=Trump denies Haiti slur amid fallout from 'shithole' comment |publisher=NBC News}}</ref><ref name="The Guardian 2018-01-12"/> [[Party leaders of the United States Senate|Senate minority whip]] [[Dick Durbin]], the only Democrat present at the Oval Office meeting, stated that Trump did use racist language and referred to African countries as "shitholes" and that "he said these hate-filled things, and he said them repeatedly."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-42664173 |title=Trump's 'racist slur' prompts fury |date=January 12, 2018 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
Homeland Security secretary [[Kirstjen Nielsen]] testified under oath to the Senate regarding the incident. She said she did not "specifically remember a categorization of countries from Africa." Asked about the president's language, Nielsen said, "I don't remember specific words", while remembering "the general profanity that was used in the room by almost everyone" but not Dick Durbin. Later on during the questioning, Nielsen said, "I remember specific cuss words being used by a variety of members," without elaborating on what was said or by whom.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cillizza|first1=Chris|title=Here's exactly how Dick Durbin destroyed Kirstjen Nielsen's 'shithole' explanation|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/16/politics/durbin-nielsen-analysis/index.html|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Cory Booker blasts Republicans for amnesia over Trump's 'shithole' remark |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/17/cory-booker-blasts-republicans-for-amnesia-over-trumps-shithole-remark |work=The Guardian |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=2019-03-11|date=2018-01-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Booker to Nielsen: Your Silence is Complicity|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BJeYvCZUDu0|publisher=Associated Press Archive|via=YouTube|date=2018-01-21|accessdate=2019-03-11}}</ref>
Republican senators [[Tom Cotton]] of Arkansas and [[David Perdue]] of Georgia, also present at the meeting, initially issued a joint statement stating that they "do not recall the President saying those comments specifically".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/1/12/16885312/trump-shithole-countries-denial |title=2 Republican senators have come down with a case of "shithole"-related amnesia |work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]}}</ref> Later, both senators denied that Trump had said "shithole". Perdue said Trump "did not use that word ... The gross misrepresentation was that language was used in there that was not used,"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Moore|first1=Mark|title=GOP senator denies Trump made 'shithole' comment|url=https://nypost.com/2018/01/14/gop-senator-denies-trump-made-shithole-comment/ |work=[[New York Post]] |accessdate=January 18, 2018}}</ref> and Cotton said, "I didn't hear it, and I was sitting no further away from Donald Trump than Dick Durbin". Cotton elaborated that he "did not hear derogatory comments about individuals or persons", and went on to affirm with the interviewer that the "sentiment [attributed to Trump] is totally phony".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sorkin|first1=Amy|title=Tom Cotton, David Perdue, and the Trap of Lying for Donald Trump|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/tom-cotton-david-perdue-and-the-trap-of-lying-for-donald-trump|work=[[The New Yorker]]|accessdate=January 18, 2018}}</ref> Meanwhile, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported that Cotton and Perdue told the White House they heard "[[outhouse|shithouse]]" rather than "shithole".<ref name="Wash Post 2018-01-15">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/inside-the-tense-profane-white-house-meeting-on-immigration/2018/01/15/13e79fa4-fa1e-11e7-8f66-2df0b94bb98a_story.html |title=Inside the tense, profane White House meeting on immigration |first1=Josh |last1=Dawsey |first2=Robert |last2=Costa |first3=Ashley |last3=Parker |date=January 15, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Prokop |first1=Andrew |title=The "shithouse defense," explained: how Trump's allies are trying to dig him out of his "shithole" |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/1/16/16897016/trump-shithole-shithouse-countries |work=Vox |accessdate=7 March 2019|date=2018-01-16}}</ref>
Senator [[Tim Scott]] (R-SC) stated that Senator [[Lindsey Graham]] (R-SC), present at the meeting, had confirmed that Trump indeed called El Salvador, Haiti and some African nations "shithole countries".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/368744-sen-tim-scott-sen-graham-confirmed-trumps-reported-shithole |title=Sen. Tim Scott: Sen. Graham confirmed Trump's reported 's---hole' quote was accurate |first=John |last=Bowden |date=January 12, 2018 |newspaper=The Hill blogs}}</ref> Graham refused to confirm or deny hearing Trump's words, but rather released a statement in which he said, "[I] said my piece directly to [Trump]."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dumain |first1=Emma |title=A day later, Lindsey Graham breaks public silence on Trump's 'shithole' remarks |url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/congress/article194434204.html |publisher=McClatchyDC |accessdate=January 12, 2018}}</ref> In what was interpreted as a response to Cotton and Purdue, Graham later said, "My memory hasn't evolved. I know what was said and I know what I said," while also asserting "It's not where you come from that matters, it's what you're willing to do once you get here."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lovegrove |first1=Jaime |title=Graham: 'My memory hasn't evolved' on meeting where others say Trump referred to 'shithole countries' |url=https://www.postandcourier.com/politics/graham-my-memory-hasn-t-evolved-on-meeting-where-others/article_8c2fe722-fa06-11e7-8443-97610df90839.html |work=[[The Post and Courier]] |accessdate=January 16, 2018}}</ref> Senator [[Jeff Flake]] (R-AZ) said that the meeting participants had told him about Trump making those remarks before the account went public.<ref>{{cite news |title='This Week' Transcript 1-14-18: Rep. John Lewis, Sen. David Perdue and Sen. Jeff Flake |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/week-transcript-14-18-rep-john-lewis-sen/story?id=52328080 |publisher=[[ABC News]] |accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref>
Conservative columnist [[Erick Erickson]] said Trump had privately bragged to friends about making the remarks, thinking "it would play well with the base."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Savransky|first1=Rebecca|title=Conservative writer: Trump called friends to brag about 's---hole countries' remark|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/368967-conservative-writer-trump-called-friends-to-brag-about-s-hole|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> ''The Washington Post'' quoted Trump's aides as saying Trump had called friends to ask how his political supporters would react to the coverage of the incident, and that he was "not particularly upset" by its publication.<ref name="Wash Post 2018-01-15"/>
==== Response from Republicans ==== Vice President [[Mike Pence]] stated that he "knows the president's heart", and that Trump's goal is to reform the immigration system so that it is merit-based regardless of race, creed or country of origin, encouraging immigration by those who want to "contribute to a growing American economy and thriving communities."<ref name=ap-20180122>{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/7fa410a4b30b443bbddc8cee267fc3c0 |title=VP defends Trump over vulgar remarks on African immigrants |agency=[[Associated Press]] |first=Ken |last=Thomas |access-date=February 18, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Time-01-22-18">{{cite news | title=Pence Defends Trump's 'Shithole Countries' Remark | work=Time | agency=Associated Press | date=January 22, 2018 | url=http://time.com/5112715/mike-pence-donald-trump-immigrants-israel/ | access-date=February 18, 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125174545/http://time.com/5112715/mike-pence-donald-trump-immigrants-israel/ | archive-date=January 25, 2018 | url-status=dead}}</ref> Some Republican lawmakers denounced Trump's comments, calling them "unfortunate" and "indefensible", while others sidestepped or did not respond to them.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kaplan |first1=Thomas |last2=Baumbaertner |first2=Emily |last3=Parlapiano |first3=Alicia |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/01/12/us/politics/republican-statements-trump-shithole.html |title=How Republican Lawmakers Responded to Trump's Vulgar Immigration Remarks |date=January 14, 2018 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=January 24, 2018}}</ref> House speaker [[Paul Ryan]] said, "So, first thing that came to my mind was very unfortunate, unhelpful." Senator [[Susan Collins]] of Maine, who said she would not vote for Trump and has been very critical of him, said: "These comments are highly inappropriate and out of bounds and could hurt efforts for a bipartisan immigration agreement. The president should not denigrate other countries." Senator [[Tim Scott]] of South Carolina, the only African-American Republican in the Senate, and Senator [[James Lankford]] of Oklahoma, called the comments "disappointing".<ref name="cnnreact" />
Representative [[Mia Love]] of Utah, who is of Haitian descent, tweeted that the comments were "unkind, divisive, elitist, and fly in the face of our nation's values". She later stated they were "really difficult to hear, especially because my [Haitian immigrant] parents were such big supporters of the president.... there are countries that struggle out there but ... their people are good people and they're part of us."<ref>{{cite news |title=Haitian-American GOP congresswoman demands Trump apologize |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/11/politics/mia-love-response-trump-shithole/index.html|author=Kenny, Caroline |date=January 12, 2018 |publisher=[[CNN]]|access-date=January 14, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=GOP Rep. Mia Love on Trump's vulgar remarks: 'I can't defend the indefensible' |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/gop-rep-mia-love-trump-s-vulgar-remarks-i-can-n837616 |author=Silva, Daniella |date=January 14, 2018 |publisher=[[NBC News]]|access-date=January 14, 2018}}</ref> Senator [[Jeff Flake]] of Arizona wrote "The words used by the President, as related to me directly following the meeting by those in attendance were not 'tough', they were abhorrent and repulsive."<ref name="shitr" /> Representatives [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] of Florida and [[Erik Paulsen]] of Minnesota also denounced the comments.<ref name="shitr">{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/12/trump-shithole-comment-reaction-337926|title=Trump's 'shithole' comment denounced across the globe|date=January 12, 2018|work=Politico|accessdate=January 21, 2018}}</ref>
==== Response from Democrats==== When asked if he believed Senator Durbin's reporting of the incident, Senate Minority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] replied, "I have no doubts. First, Donald Trump has lied so many times, it's hard to believe him on anything, let alone this."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Thompsen|first1=Jaqueline|title=Schumer: 'I totally believe' Durbin over Trump|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/369073-schumer-i-totally-believe-durbin-on-trumps-shithole-countries-comments|newspaper=The Hill|accessdate=January 18, 2018}}</ref> Both House minority whip [[Steny Hoyer]] of Maryland and civil rights leader Representative [[John Lewis (civil rights leader)|John Lewis]] of Georgia said Trump's remarks confirm his racism.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/16/steny-hoyer-trump-racist-341232 | title=Hoyer: Trump is a 'racist' | work=[[Politico]] | date=January 16, 2018 | last1=Caygle | first1=Heather | last2=Bresnahan | first2=John | accessdate=January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/369199-hoyer-calls-trump-a-racist-for-shithole-remarks | title=Hoyer blasts Trump for 'racist rhetoric' | work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date=January 16, 2018 | last=Josh | first=Delk | accessdate=January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/368992-john-lewis-i-think-trump-is-a-racist | title=John Lewis: I think Trump is a racist | work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | date=January 14, 2018 | last=Samuels | first=Brett | accessdate=January 17, 2018}}</ref> Representative [[Jim McGovern (American politician)|Jim McGovern]] of Massachusetts said, "America's president is a racist and this is the proof. His hateful rhetoric has no place in the White House."<ref name="cnnreact">{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/11/politics/congress-reaction-trump-shithole-countries/index.html |title=Lawmakers condemn Trump's 'shithole' remark |first1=Sophie |last1=Tatum |first2=Ashley |last2=Killough |publisher=CNN}}</ref> Representative [[Tim Walz]] of Minnesota said, "This is racism, plain and simple, and we need to call it that. My Republican colleagues need to call it that too." Senator [[Richard Blumenthal]] of Connecticut said that Trump's comments "smack of blatant racism – odious and insidious racism masquerading poorly as immigration policy".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bowden |first1=John |title=Trump's 's---hole' remark sparks bipartisan backlash B |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/368636-lawmakers-rail-against-trump-after-s-hole-comment |newspaper=The Hill |accessdate=January 16, 2018}}</ref> Representative [[Karen Bass]] of California said: "You would never call a predominantly white country a 'shithole' because you are unable to see people of color, American or otherwise, as equals."<ref name="cnnreact"/> Representative [[Bill Pascrell]] of New Jersey tweeted that Trump is "showing his bigoted tendencies in ways that would make [[Archie Bunker]] blush", and called him a "national disgrace".<ref name="cnnreact"/>
==== International response ==== [[File:Museveni_July_2012_Cropped.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|After the supposed "shithole countries" remark, Ugandan president [[Yoweri Museveni]] praised Trump saying "I love Trump because he talks to Africans frankly."]] Rupert Colville, a spokesman for the [[United Nations Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights]], said at a news briefing, "There is no other word one can use but racist. You cannot dismiss entire countries and continents as 'shitholes', whose entire populations, who are not white, are therefore not welcome."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/12/unkind-divisive-elitist-international-outcry-over-trumps-shithole-countries-remark |title=UN condemns Donald Trump's 'shithole countries' remark as racist |first1=Patrick |last1=Wintour |first2=Jason |last2=Burke |first3=Anna |last3=Livsey |date=January 12, 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
The [[African Union]] issued a statement strongly condemning the remarks and demanding a retraction and apology; an AU spokeswoman said, "Given the historical reality of how many Africans arrived in the United States as slaves, [Trump's statement] flies in the face of all accepted behavior and practice. This is particularly surprising as the United States of America remains a global example of how migration gave birth to a nation built on strong values of diversity and opportunity."<ref name="Kranz">{{cite news |last1=Kranz |first1=Michael |title='Irresponsible, reprehensible, and racist': Here's how the world reacted to Trump's 'shithole' comments |url=https://www.businessinsider.sg/reactions-around-the-world-to-trump-shithole-comments-2018-1/ |work=Business Insider |accessdate=January 16, 2018}}</ref>
The president of [[Uganda]] [[Yoweri Museveni]] praised Trump saying "I love Trump because he talks to Africans frankly. I don't know if he's misquoted or whatever, but when he speaks I like him because he speaks frankly."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Karimi|first1=Faith|title=Uganda's President says he loves Donald Trump because he's frank about Africa|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/24/africa/uganda-museveni-comments-trump-trnd/index.html|accessdate=February 25, 2018|publisher=CNN|date=January 24, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Lucey|first1=Catherine|title=Trump is trying to mend relations with a key African leader after 'shithole' comments|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-shithole-comments-african-union-davos-2018-1|accessdate=February 25, 2018|work=Business Insider|agency=Associated Press|date=January 26, 2018}}</ref>
The Ministry of International Affairs of [[Botswana]] summoned the US ambassador, and said in a statement "We view the utterances by the current American President as highly irresponsible, reprehensible, and racist."<ref name="Kranz"/> The [[African National Congress]], the ruling party in South Africa, tweeted "its offensive for President Trump to make derogatory statements about countries that do not share policy positions with the US. Developing countries experience difficulties. The US also faces difficulties."<ref>{{cite news|title='Racist' And 'Shameful': How Other Countries Are Responding To Trump's Slur|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2018/01/12/577599691/racist-and-shameful-how-other-countries-are-responding-to-trumps-slur|accessdate=January 21, 2018|publisher=NPR|date=January 12, 2018}}</ref> [[Mmusi Maimane]], the leader of South Africa's opposition party, said "The hatred of Obama's roots now extends to an entire continent."<ref name="shitr"/>
Haiti's ambassador to the US said Haiti "vehemently condemn[ed]" Trump's comments, saying they were "based on stereotypes". Haiti's former prime minister [[Laurent Lamothe]] said, "It shows a lack of respect and ignorance never seen before in the recent history of the US by any President."<ref name="Kranz"/>
=== "The Snake" song and story === Starting with his presidential run in 2016, Trump has often told the story of "The Snake," inspired by [[The Snake (song)|the song written by Oscar Brown Jr]]. In Trump's retelling, the story becomes an allegory used to warn of the danger posed by immigrants. In February 2018, Trump faced criticism after including the story during a speech to the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]]. Maggie Brown, daughter of Oscar Brown Jr., stated that Trump's immigration agenda "deals with separatism, racism, sexism, and it's kind of thing that's polar opposite to what Oscar Brown Jr was about." Conservative communications and public affairs strategist Steve Schmidt said "Trump’s snake story is vicious, disgraceful, utterly racist and profoundly un-American."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/trump-the-snake-lyrics-immigration-policy-daughters-anger-us-president-a8230771.html|title=Daughter of man who wrote "The Snake" tells Trump: Stop using my father's poem to smear immigrants|date=2018-02-27|work=The Independent|access-date=2019-12-10}}</ref> Austrian language researcher Kateryna Pilyarchuk claims that "Trump has used 'The Snake' to whip up racist fervor at raucous rallies."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/insects-floods-and-the-snake-what-trumps-use-of-metaphors-reveals/|title=Insects, Floods and "The Snake": What Trump's Use of Metaphors Reveals|work=Frontline|publisher=PBS|access-date=2019-12-10}}</ref>
=== Immigrants in Europe === In July 2018, while on a trip to Europe, Trump said in an interview with [[The Sun (United Kingdom)|''The Sun'']] newspaper that "I think allowing millions and millions of people to come into Europe is very, very sad, I think what has happened to Europe is a shame. I think it changed the fabric of Europe and, unless you act very quickly, it’s never going to be what it was and I don’t mean that in a positive way, I think you are losing your culture. Look around. You go through certain areas that didn’t exist ten or 15 years ago," On the same trip, during a joint press conference with Prime Minister [[Theresa May]], Trump again commented on immigration in Europe: "I think it's been very bad for Europe. I think Europe is a place I know very well and I think what has happened is very tough. It's a very tough situation, I just think it's changing the culture. It's a very negative thing for Europe." May responded by saying that "Over the years, overall immigration has been good for the UK. It brought people with different backgrounds and outlooks here to the UK and we've seen them contributing to our society and economy."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/immigration-changing-culture-europe-trump/story?id=56564695|title=Immigration is a 'very negative thing' for Europe: Trump|publisher=ABC News|access-date=2019-11-28}}</ref>
=== White farmers in South Africa === In August 2018, Trump sent a tweet stating that he had ordered Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to look into [[Land reform in South Africa|land seizures]] and [[South African farm attacks|the mass killing of white farmers]] in South Africa, acting on a [[White genocide conspiracy theory|racist conspiracy theory]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump's tweet echoing white nationalist propaganda about South African farmers, explained |url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2018/8/23/17772056/south-africa-trump-tweet-afriforum-white-farmers-violence |author=Williams, Jennifer |date=August 23, 2018 |publisher=Vox|access-date=August 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump under fire for claim of 'large scale killing' of white farmers in South Africa |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-under-fire-claim-large-scale-killing-white-farmers-south-n903171 |author=Jamieson, Allistair |date=August 23, 2018 |publisher=[[NBC News]]|access-date=August 23, 2018}}</ref> In fact, farming organisation [[AgriSA]] had recently reported that the murder rate on farms had declined to the lowest level in twenty years,<ref name="agriSA20Years">{{cite news |url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/farm-murder-rate-lowest-in-20-years-remoteness-the-reason-for-brutality-20180531 |title=Farm murders lowest in 20 years, 'remoteness' the reason for brutality |first=Jan |last=Bornman |date=May 31, 2018 |work=News24 |accessdate=August 20, 2018}}</ref> one-third of the level recorded in 1998.<ref name="southAfricanLowest20">{{cite news |url=https://www.thesouthafrican.com/farm-murders-at-their-lowest-in-20-years-report/ |title=Farm murders at their lowest rate in 20 years - report |first=Siviwe |last=Breakfast |date=May 31, 2018 |work=The South African |accessdate=August 20, 2018}}</ref> In response, the [[Anti-Defamation League]] issued a statement: {{quote|It is extremely disturbing that the President of the United States echoed a long-standing and false white supremacist claim that South Africa’s white farmers are targets of large-scale, racially-motivated killings by South Africa’s black majority. We would hope that the President would try to understand the facts and realities of the situation in South Africa, rather than repeat disturbing, racially divisive talking points used most frequently by white supremacists.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tharoor |first1=Ishaan |title=Trump's racist coda to a terrible week |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2018/08/24/trumps-racist-coda-terrible-week/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=August 24, 2018}}</ref>}}
