=== "I am a nationalist" === At a rally in Houston in October 2018, Trump stated "You know, they have a word – it’s sort of became old-fashioned – it’s called a nationalist. And I say, really, we’re not supposed to use that word. You know what I am? I’m a nationalist, okay? I’m a nationalist. Nationalist. Nothing wrong. Use that word. Use that word." Trump later denied that there was any racial connotation connected to his use of the word. Many others, however, suggested that his use of the word nationalist was dangerously close to the phrase white nationalist. Reformed neo-Nazi Christian Picciolini, for example, tweeted that "Trump's 'I'm a Nationalist' comment will likely represent the biggest boon for white supremacist recruitment since the film Birth of a Nation glorified the Klan in 1915 and gained the KKK 4 million members by 1925."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/10/24/trump-says-hes-nationalist-what-means-why-its-controversial/1748521002/|title='I am a nationalist': Trump's embrace of controversial label sparks uproar|last=Cummings|first=William|work=USA Today|access-date=2019-12-10}}</ref>
=== Trump-backed ad removed === In November 2018, [[Facebook]], NBC, and [[Fox News]] withdrew a controversial political campaign ad which was backed by Trump after critics described it as racist. Shown prior to the midterm elections, the ad focused on a migrant caravan then traveling through Mexico with hopes of immigration to the U.S., and [[Luis Bracamontes]], an undocumented immigrant who was convicted of killing two sheriff's deputies in California in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fox News, NBC and Facebook Pull Trump-Backed Anti-Migrant Ad |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-05/nbc-pulls-trump-backed-anti-migrant-ad-after-prime-time-airing |agency=Bloomberg News |accessdate=December 9, 2018}}</ref>
=== Harriet Tubman on the twenty-dollar bill ===
In May 2019, the Trump administration announced that the plan to replace the portrait of [[Andrew Jackson]] on the [[United States twenty-dollar bill|twenty-dollar bill]] with that of [[Harriet Tubman]] by 2020, as had been planned by the Obama administration, would be delayed until 2026.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/may/23/trump-delays-putting-harriet-tubman-on-20-bill-outrage |title=Outrage as Trump delays putting Harriet Tubman on $20 bill until 2026 |publisher=The Guardian |date=23 May 2019 |accessdate=29 May 2020}}</ref> Some critics viewed this decision as a reflection of Trump's racism, including Representative [[Ayanna Pressley]], who said "Secretary Mnuchin has allowed Trump’s racism and misogyny to prevent him from carrying out the will of the people."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/14/us/politics/harriet-tubman-bill.html|title=See a Design of the Harriet Tubman $20 Bill That Mnuchin Delayed|last=Rappeport|first=Alan|date=2019-06-14|work=The New York Times|access-date=2019-11-28|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Trump is a great admirer of Andrew Jackson and had his portrait installed in the Oval Office immediately after moving into the White House. Critics have suggested that Trump's support of Jackson is "barely veiled racism" as an attempt to appeal to his largely white political base. Critics of Trump's embrace of Jackson point to Jackson's ownership of slaves and genocide against Native Americans.<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Man Who Put Andrew Jackson in Trump’s Oval Office|url=http://politi.co/2mZOuHp|last=Glasser|first=Susan B.|website=POLITICO Magazine|language=en|access-date=2020-06-02}}</ref>
=== Democratic congresswomen should "go back" to their countries ===
On July 14, 2019, Trump tweeted about four Democratic congresswomen, and although he did not mention any member of Congress by name, it was widely inferred that he was referring to [[Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez]], [[Ayanna Pressley]], [[Ilhan Omar]], and [[Rashida Tlaib]]. This group, known collectively as [[The Squad (United States Congress)|the Squad]], had verbally sparred with Speaker of the House [[Nancy Pelosi]] a week earlier:<ref name="APgoback">{{cite news |last1=LeMire |first1=Jonathan |last2=Woodward |first2=Calvin |title=Leave the US, Trump tells liberal congresswomen of color |url=https://www.apnews.com/728ada1e918a482c9e9b1f3e24937caa |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=July 15, 2019}}</ref><ref name="BBCgoback">{{cite news |title=Trump under fire for racially-charged tweets against congresswomen |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-48982172 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=July 15, 2019}}</ref>
{{quote |text = So interesting to see "Progressive" Democrat Congresswomen, who originally came from countries whose governments are a complete and total catastrophe, the worst, most corrupt and inept anywhere in the world (if they even have a functioning government at all), now loudly and viciously telling the people of the United States, the greatest and most powerful Nation on earth, how our government is to be run. Why don’t they go back and help fix the totally broken and crime infested places from which they came. Then come back and show us how it is done. These places need your help badly, you can’t leave fast enough. I’m sure that Nancy Pelosi would be very happy to quickly work out free travel arrangements! |author = Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump on Twitter, July 14, 2019)<ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |author-link=Donald Trump |number=1150381394234941448 |title=So interesting to see "Progressive" Democrat Congresswomen, who originally came from countries whose governments are a complete and total catastrophe, the worst, most corrupt and inept anywhere in the world (if they even have a functioning government at all), now loudly...... |date=July 14, 2019 |access-date=July 15, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |author-link=Donald Trump |number=1150381395078000643 |title=....and viciously telling the people of the United States, the greatest and most powerful Nation on earth, how our government is to be run. Why don’t they go back and help fix the totally broken and crime infested places from which they came. Then come back and show us how.... |date=July 14, 2019 |access-date=July 15, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |author-link=Donald Trump |number=1150381396994723841 |title=....it is done. These places need your help badly, you can’t leave fast enough. I’m sure that Nancy Pelosi would be very happy to quickly work out free travel arrangements! |date=July 14, 2019 |access-date=July 15, 2019}}</ref> }}
The [[U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] (EEOC) specifically cites the phrase "[[Go back where you came from|Go back to where you came from]]" as the type of language that may violate [[Employment discrimination law in the United States|anti-discrimination employment laws]]. "Ethnic slurs and other verbal or physical conduct because of nationality are illegal if they are severe or pervasive and create an intimidating, hostile or offensive working environment, interfere with work performance, or negatively affect job opportunities." The EEOC's website states: "Examples of potentially unlawful conduct include insults, taunting, or ethnic epithets, such as making fun of a person's foreign accent or comments like, 'Go back to where you came from,' whether made by supervisors or by co-workers."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Silverstein |first1=Jason |title=Federal agency: "Go back to where you came from" is discrimination |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/eeoc-go-back-where-you-came-from-discrimination-federal-law-trump-tweets/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=July 18, 2019 |date=July 17, 2019}}</ref>
Only one of those congresswomen is an immigrant; the other three were born in the United States, making Trump's comments an example of the [[Perpetual foreigner|false attribution of foreignness]] to members of minorities.<ref name=APgoback/><ref name=BBCgoback/> Nancy Pelosi labelled Trump's comments as "xenophobic" and commented: "When @realDonaldTrump tells four American congresswomen to go back to their countries, he reaffirms his plan to 'Make America Great Again' has always been about making America white again."<ref>{{cite tweet |user=SpeakerPelosi |author-link=Nancy Pelosi |number=1150408691713265665 |title=When @realDonaldTrump tells four American Congresswomen to go back to their countries, he reaffirms his plan to "Make America Great Again" has always been about making America white again.<br/> Our diversity is our strength and our unity is our power. |date=July 14, 2019 |access-date=July 15, 2019}}</ref> Among the [[2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries|2020 presidential candidates]], [[Bernie Sanders]] said Trump was a racist, while [[Elizabeth Warren]], [[Kamala Harris]], and [[Beto O'Rourke]] called his statements racist.<ref name=APgoback/><ref name=BBCgoback/> [[Justin Amash]], a U.S. Representative who had recently left the Republican Party, called the statements "racist and disgusting".<ref>{{cite news |title='Racist and disgusting': ex GOP Congressman Justin Amash blasts Trump after he says Congresswomen should 'go back' to their countries |url=https://www.newsweek.com/racist-disgusting-ex-gop-congressman-justin-amash-blasts-trump-1449164 |accessdate=July 15, 2019 |work=[[Newsweek]] |date=July 14, 2019}}</ref> Republican lawmakers were initially mostly silent on Trump's statements, with those in leadership positions at first declining to comment.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stanley-Becker |first1=Isaac |title=Republicans are quiet as Trump urges minority congresswomen to leave the country |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/nation/2019/07/15/republicans-trump-quiet-minority-congresswomen-leave/ |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=July 15, 2019 |date=July 15, 2019}}</ref> By July 20, around 20 Republican lawmakers had criticized Trump's statements, around 60 Republican lawmakers either supported Trump or instead criticized Democratic lawmakers, around 60 Republican lawmakers criticized both Trump and Democratic lawmakers, and around 110 were silent or offered vague answers.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Uhrmacher |first1=Kevin |last2=Schaul |first2=Kevin |title=The complete list of GOP lawmakers reacting to Trump's 'go back' tweet |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2019/politics/trump-go-back-gop-reactions-list/ |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=July 22, 2019 |date=July 20, 2019}}</ref> White nationalist publications and social media sites praised Trump's remarks; "This is the kind of WHITE NATIONALISM we elected him for," wrote Andrew Anglin on his ''[[Daily Stormer]]'' neo-Nazi website.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/16/politics/white-supremacists-cheer-trump-racist-tweets-soh/index.html|title=Trump said 'many people agree' with his racist tweets. These white supremacists certainly do.|last1=Simon|first1=Mallory|last2=Sidner|first2=Sara|date=July 16, 2019|work=CNN|accessdate=20 July 2019}}</ref>
{{Quote box|width = 25em|align=right|"We wanted, just to be clear, that it wasn't just racially charged, racially inflamed whatever; we wanted to make clear that that is an old racist phrase that was reused."<br >|source=Mark Memmot, Supervising Senior Editor for Standards & Practices at [[NPR]]<ref name="CodeTalk"/>}}
''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' news analyst [[Peter Baker (journalist)|Peter Baker]] drew controversy for writing an article on the tweets but avoiding to directly call the tweets "racist".<ref name="Vox">{{Cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/2019/7/18/20697940/trump-racist-tweets-racially-infused-charged|title=The controversy over whether the media should call Trump's racist tweets "racist," explained|accessdate=22 July 2019|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]}}</ref> The direct application of the term "racist" is typically controversial and avoided in journalism, with euphemisms such as "racially-charged" or "racially-infused" typically used instead. However, many publications directly called Trump's tweets and language as racist, including ''[[The Washington Post]]'',<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/how-a-racist-tweet-became-a-trump-rally-chant-in-three-short-days/2019/07/18/bd81b798-a968-11e9-9214-246e594de5d5_story.html|title=How a racist tweet became a Trump rally chant in three short days|accessdate=22 July 2019|work=[[Washington Post]]}}</ref> ''[[Vox (website)|Vox]]'',<ref name="Vox"/> and [[CNN]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/16/politics/trump-racist-comment-vote-house-gop-list/index.html|title=Here are the 4 Republicans who voted to condemn Trump's racist tweets|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=22 July 2019}}</ref> as well as the [[Associated Press]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Black voters say they won't forget Trump's racist tweets |url=https://apnews.com/urn:publicid:ap.org:cdfdd19f44db4fb6b1ed9cbac9d5d287 |accessdate=July 24, 2019 |agency=Associated Press |date=July 24, 2019}}</ref> [[NPR]] has had a policy imposed since January 2018 to generally avoid using the word "racist" when describing the Trump administration, but the news room agreed on an editorial decision to describe Trump's tweets as racist.<ref name="CodeTalk">{{Cite web|url=https://one.npr.org/?sharedMediaId=742448398:742481310|title=Oh So Now It's Racist?|date=17 July 2019|accessdate=18 July 2019|publisher=NPR}}</ref>
''The Washington Post'', after interviews with 26 involved sources, reported that after the backlash, Trump defended his statements to his advisers. Trump said that he had been watching ''[[Fox & Friends]]'', that his statements were aimed at bringing more attention to the four congresswomen because he believed they were 'good foils'.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Scherer |first1=Michael |last2=Dawsey |first2=Josh |last3=Parker |first3=Ashley |last4=Kim |first4=Seung Min |title='He always doubles down': Inside the political crisis caused by Trump's racist tweets |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/he-always-doubles-down-inside-the-political-crisis-caused-by-trumps-racist-tweets/2019/07/20/b342184c-aa2e-11e9-86dd-d7f0e60391e9_story.html |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=July 22, 2019}}</ref>
Later on July 14, Trump tweeted: "So sad to see the Democrats sticking up for people who speak so badly of our Country and who, in addition, hate Israel with a true and unbridled passion. Whenever confronted, they call their adversaries, including Nancy Pelosi, "RACIST.""<ref>{{cite news |last1=Silverstein |first1=Jason |title=Trump tells Democratic congresswomen of color to "go back" to their countries |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-tweets-aoc-pelosi-slam-president-for-telling-democratic-congresswomen-to-go-back-to-their-countries/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=July 15, 2019 |date=July 15, 2019}}</ref> The next day, Trump demanded that "the Radical Left Congresswomen" apologize to him, as well as the people of the United States and Israel, for "the terrible things they have said".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Edelman |first1=Adam |title=After insulting them, Trump demands congresswomen of color apologize to him, the U.S., Israel |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-demands-radical-left-congresswomen-apologize-him-u-s-israel-n1029831 |publisher=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=July 15, 2019 |date=July 15, 2019}}</ref> He also accused them of propagating "racist hatred".<ref>{{cite news |last1=LeMire |first1=Jonathan |last2=Woodward |first2=Calvin |last3=Corvin |first3=Jill |title=Trump digs in amid censure of racist tweets about lawmakers |url=https://apnews.com/9924c846abf84cfeabb76e6045190b42 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=July 15, 2019 |date=July 15, 2019}}</ref> In response to a journalist, Trump said he wasn't concerned if [[white nationalist]]s agreed with him, "because many people agree with me."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Buncombe |first1=Andrew |title=Trump says he is not concerned that white nationalists agree with him: 'I don't care' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-press-conference-twitter-aoc-ilihan-omar-white-house-latest-a9005891.html |work=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=July 16, 2019 |date=July 15, 2019}}</ref>
On July 16, the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] rebuked his remarks, passing H.Res. 489 which says the House "strongly condemns President Donald Trump's racist comments that have legitimized and increased fear and hatred of new Americans and people of color." Four Republican representatives ([[Brian Fitzpatrick (American politician)|Brian Fitzpatrick]], [[Fred Upton]], [[Will Hurd]] and [[Susan Brooks]]) joined the Democratic majority and independent Justin Amash in a 240-to-187 vote. Before the vote, Trump continued his insults towards the congresswomen and top Republicans accused the four congresswomen of being socialists.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Fram |first1=Alan |last2=Superville |first2=Darlene |title=House condemns Trump 'racist' tweets in extraordinary rebuke |url=https://apnews.com/a67df9b560fc416f8326827b36b0de81 |accessdate=July 16, 2019 |agency=Associated Press |date=July 17, 2019}}</ref> After the vote, Trump praised the Republican Party for being unified in rejecting the House resolution, while acknowledging that the resolution was regarding his comments on "four Democrat Congresswomen".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Segers |first1=Grace |last2=Tillet |first2=Emily |last3=Montoya-Galvez |first3=Camilo |title=House passes resolution formally denouncing Trump tweets as racist |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/house-to-vote-on-resolution-condemning-racist-trump-tweets-today-2019-07-16/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=July 19, 2019 |date=July 17, 2019}}</ref>
Also on July 16, Republican Senate Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] and Republican House Minority Leader [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]] commented on Trump's statements. McConnell was asked if Trump's initial statements were racist. McConnell replied: "The president's not a racist." McConnell also said it was a "mistake" to "single out any segment" of widespread "incendiary rhetoric" in American politics. McCarthy was also asked if Trump's initial statements were racist; McCarthy replied: "No."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Philips |first1=Amber |title='The president is not a racist:' Mitch McConnell's defense of Trump, annotated |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/07/16/president-is-not-racist-mitch-mcconnells-defense-trump-annotated |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=July 17, 2019 |date=July 16, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Brufke |first1=Juliegrace |title=House GOP leader says Trump's tweets were not racist |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/453289-house-gop-leader-says-trumps-tweets-were-not-racist |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |accessdate=July 17, 2019|date=July 16, 2019}}</ref> Republican [[Lindsey Graham]], [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|chair of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary]], tweeted "We all know that AOC and this crowd are a bunch of communists. They hate Israel. They hate our own country. They’re calling the guards along our border — Border Patrol agents — concentration camp guards. They accuse people who support Israel of doing it for the Benjamins. They’re anti-Semitic. They’re anti-America."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Blake |first1=Aaron |title=Lindsey Graham's and the GOP's initial responses to Trump's 'go back' tweets are a mess |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/07/15/lindsey-grahams-gops-initial-responses-trumps-go-back-tweets-are-mess/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=July 18, 2019}}</ref> On July 18 he said that he did not think Trump's initial statements were racist because: "I don't think a Somali refugee embracing Trump would be asked to go back. If you're racist, you want everybody to go back because they are black or Muslim." Previously in 2015, Graham had called Trump a "race-baiting, xenophobic religious bigot".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kwong |first1=Jessica |title=Lindsey Graham says Donald Trump's not racist, but called him a 'race-baiting bigot' in 2015 |url=https://www.newsweek.com/lindsey-graham-trump-not-racist-tweets-1450060 |work=[[Newsweek]] |accessdate=July 19, 2019 |date=July 18, 2019}}</ref>
[[File:Ilhan_Omar,_official_portrait,_116th_Congress.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Following his tweets, Trump held a rally and falsely claimed that Representative [[Ilhan Omar]] supported [[al-Qaeda]]. The crowd at the rally later started chanting "Send her back, Send her back."]] At a [[Donald Trump 2020 presidential campaign|presidential campaign]] rally on July 17 in North Carolina, Trump continued to attack the four congresswomen: "They never have anything good to say. That's why I say, 'Hey if you don’t like it, let 'em leave' ... if they don't love it, tell them to leave it."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Reichmann |first1=Deb |title=Trump slams congresswomen; crowd roars, 'Send her back!' |url=https://www.apnews.com/eb7f2bf6a7bd41e282a95dcf3904a877 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=July 18, 2019 |date=July 17, 2019}}</ref><ref name=falsestop>{{cite news |last1=Rizzo |first1=Salvador |title=Trump falsely claims he tried to stop 'Send her back!' chants about Rep. Ilhan Omar |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/07/18/trump-falsely-claims-he-tried-stop-send-her-back-chants-about-rep-ilhan-omar/ |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=July 19, 2019 |date=July 18, 2019}}</ref> "Love it or leave it" is a slogan often directed toward critics of the government or anyone who is perceived as not being sufficiently patriotic, particularly if they are non-white; it was commonly used against [[Lists of protests against the Vietnam War|Vietnam War protesters]] in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2019/07/love-it-or-leave-it-has-a-racist-history-a-lot-of-americas-language-does/|title="Love It or Leave It" Has a Racist History. A Lot of America's Language Does.|last=Rosenberg|first=Jacob|date=July 20, 2019|work=Mother Jones|accessdate=9 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190728093117if_/https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2019/07/love-it-or-leave-it-has-a-racist-history-a-lot-of-americas-language-does/|archive-date=2019-07-28|url-status=live}}</ref> In his speech, Trump referenced Rashida Tlaib calling him a 'motherfucker', stating: "that's not somebody that loves our country".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/after-house-rejects-stupid-impeachment-trump-fuels-rally-crowd-chant-n1031066|title=After House rejects 'stupid' impeachment, Trump fuels rally crowd chant of 'send her back!' at Omar|last1=Allen|first1=Jonathan|date=July 18, 2019|publisher=[[NBC News]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190808135336if_/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2020-election/after-house-rejects-stupid-impeachment-trump-fuels-rally-crowd-chant-n1031066|archive-date=2019-08-08|url-status=live|accessdate=July 18, 2019}}</ref> Trump also named Ilhan Omar and misrepresented comments Omar made in 2013, falsely claiming that Omar had praised [[al-Qaeda]]. As Trump continued that Omar "looks down with contempt" on Americans, the crowd of Trump supporters reacted by chanting: "Send her back, Send her back."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Yen |first1=Hope |last2=Seitz |first2=Amanda |title=Trump goes after Omar at rally |url=https://www.apnews.com/e6690d5b6e8c496580e2dc0cc78c2f17 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |accessdate=July 18, 2019|date=July 18, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=McDonald |first1=Scott |title=Trump Slams Progressive Democrat Women, Talks 'Bulls**t' at North Carolina Rally |url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-slams-progressive-democrat-women-talks-bullst-north-carolina-rally-1449883 |work=[[Newsweek]] |accessdate=July 18, 2019 |date=July 17, 2019}}</ref> After the rally, Trump tweeted: "What a crowd, and what great people". Asked about the chants on July 18, Trump said he disagreed with the chants from the crowd. He falsely claimed that he tried to stop the chant by "speaking very quickly". In reality, Trump stopped speaking for 13 seconds while the chant was occurring, and did not discourage the crowd. He continued criticizing Omar after resuming his speech.<ref name=falsestop/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2019/jul/18/trump-ilhan-omar-news-today-live-send-her-back-racist-rally-chant-latest-updates|title=Ilhan Omar on Trump: 'I believe he is fascist' – live updates|first=Sabrina Siddiqui Joanna Walters New|last=York (earlier)|date=July 18, 2019|work=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Wagner |first1=John |title=Trump disavows 'send her back' chant after it sparks backlash |url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/north-america/send-her-back-chant-at-trump-rally-inspires-hashtag-condemnations-20190719-p528ne.html |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |accessdate=July 19, 2019 |date=July 19, 2019}}</ref> On July 19, Trump praised the North Carolina crowd as "incredible people" and "incredible patriots".<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump renews attacks on Omar, praises 'send her back' crowd |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/07/trump-renews-attacks-omar-praises-send-crowd-190719195445128.html |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |accessdate=July 20, 2019 |date=July 20, 2019}}</ref>
Foreign media has widely covered the incident. The social media hashtag #IStandWithIlhanOmar was soon trending in the United States and other countries. Many foreign politicians commented, condemning Trump. On July 19, German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]], commented, "I reject [Trump’s comments] and stand in solidarity with the congresswomen he targeted."<ref>{{cite news |title=Angela Merkel says she rejects Trump's racist remarks, stands 'in solidarity' with Ilhan Omar |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2019/07/18/trump-supporters-chanted-send-her-back-around-world-others-said-istandwithilhan/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=July 20, 2019}}</ref> Canadian Pirme Minister [[Justin Trudeau]] said, "The comments made were hurtful, wrong and completely unacceptable. I want everyone in Canada to know that those comments are completely unacceptable and should not be allowed or encouraged in Canada".<ref name = Tusk>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/eu-president-trump-trudeau-meeting-1.5216559|title=EU president takes shot at Trump's 'unacceptable' tweets after Trudeau meeting|last=Tasker|first=John Paul|date=July 18, 2019|work=CBC|accessdate=20 July 2019}}</ref> British Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] also condemned Trump's remarks, calling them "completely unacceptable."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hassan |first1=Jennifer |title='1950s racism straight from the White House': Trump's tweets revolt politicians around the world |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2019/07/15/racism-straight-white-house-trumps-tweets-revolt-politicians-around-world/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=July 20, 2019}}</ref> [[Donald Tusk]], [[President of the European Council]], commented "I've been, for many years, one of the most pro-American politicians in Europe.... (but) sometimes if you feel that something is totally unacceptable you have to react despite business, despite interests.<ref name = Tusk/>
In a [[CBS News]] and [[YouGov]] poll of almost 2,100 American adults conducted from July 17 to 19, it was found that 34% felt that Trump's initial tweets were not racist, and 48% felt that they were racist. 70% of Republican respondents felt that the tweets were not racist. 84% of Democrat respondents felt that the tweets were racist. 59% of respondents disagreed with Trump's initial tweets, while 40% agreed.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Backus |first1=Fred |last2=Salvanto |first2=Anthony |title=Most Americans disagree with Trump's "go back" tweets — CBS News poll |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/most-americans-disagree-with-trumps-go-back-tweets-cbs-news-poll/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=July 22, 2019}}</ref>
=== "Rat and rodent infested mess" ===
On July 27, 2019, Trump used Twitter to criticize Representative [[Elijah Cummings]], the [[Maryland's 7th congressional district|Maryland district he represents]], and the city of [[Baltimore]]. Cummings, who is black, was Chairman of the House Oversight Committee, which was heading investigations of the Trump administration, including of [[Trump administration migrant detentions|its migrant detentions]]. The district Cummings represents is over 50% black according to the [[U.S. Census]]. It includes parts of Baltimore as well as suburban areas. Trump's tweets came less than an hour after a ''Fox & Friends'' segment by Kimberly Klacik criticizing Cummings and his district. Klacik, who is also black, reacted positively, believing that Trump had watched her segment.<ref name=Ming1>{{cite news |title=Trump's 'rat-infested' attack on lawmaker was racist, says Pelosi |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-49141521 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=July 28, 2019 |date=July 28, 2019}}</ref><ref name=Ming2>{{cite news |last1=Lowell |first1=Hugo |title=Trump attacks black congressman Elijah Cummings in remarks condemned by Pelosi as racist |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2019/07/28/trump-attacks-black-congressman-elijah-cummings-remarks-condemned/ |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=July 28, 2019 |date=July 28, 2019}}</ref><ref name=Ming3>{{cite news |last1=Baker |first1=Peter |title=Trump Assails Congressional Critic, Calling His Majority-Black District a 'Disgusting' Rat-Infested 'Mess' |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/27/us/politics/trump-elijah-cummings.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=July 28, 2019 |date=July 27, 2019}}</ref><ref name=Ming4>{{cite news |last1=Wu |first1=Nicholas |title=Trump attacks Elijah Cummings' Baltimore district as 'far worse' than southern border |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2019/07/27/trump-lashes-out-rep-elijah-cummings-baltimore-district/1845890001/ |work=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=July 28, 2019 |date=July 27, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Duncan |first1=Conrad |title=Trump launches vicious attack on senior congressman from 'rat-infested district', apparently regurgitating Fox News segment |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-elijah-cummings-fox-news-tweet-rat-infested-district-brutal-bully-a9023691.html |work=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=July 28, 2019 |date=July 28, 2019}}</ref>
{{quote |text= Rep, Elijah Cummings has been a brutal bully, shouting and screaming at the great men & women of Border Patrol about conditions at the Southern Border, when actually his Baltimore district is FAR WORSE and more dangerous. His district is considered the Worst in the USA...... As proven last week during a Congressional tour, the Border is clean, efficient & well run, just very crowded. Cumming District is a disgusting, rat and rodent infested mess. If he spent more time in Baltimore, maybe he could help clean up this very dangerous & filthy place ... His district is considered the Worst in the USA......|date=July 27, 2019 |access-date=July 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |user=realDonaldTrump |author-link=Donald Trump |number=1155073965880172544 |title=....As proven last week during a Congressional tour, the Border is clean, efficient & well run, just very crowded. No human being would want to live there. Where is all this money going? How much is stolen? Investigate this corrupt mess immediately!|date=July 27, 2019 |access-date=July 28, 2019}}</ref> }}
Trump has a history of describing largely black populated areas as being "infested", including African nations in 2014, Atlanta in 2017, sanctuary cities in 2018, and the places he decided the "Squad" should "go back" to in 2019.<ref>{{cite news |title=Whenever Trump says 'infested', we know he's talking about people of colour |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/jul/30/trump-infested-baltimore-congresswomen |accessdate=August 3, 2019 |work=The Guardian |date=July 30, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Trump Twitter Archive |url=http://www.trumptwitterarchive.com/archive/infest/ttff |accessdate=August 13, 2019}}</ref> When Representative [[John Lewis (civil rights leader)|John Lewis]] refused to attend Trump's inauguration in 2017, Trump said that Lewis "should spend more time on fixing and helping his district, which is in horrible shape and falling apart (not to mention crime infested)".<ref name=Ming1/><ref name=Ming2/><ref name=Ming3/><ref name=Ming4/>
Cummings responded that it was his "moral duty to fight for [his] constituents", pointing out that to do so, he had previously asked for Trump's support in passing laws to lower prescription drug prices, while linking to a 2017 article from Democratic representatives lamenting that Trump did not offer support on such issues. Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, who was born in Baltimore, and Senator Elizabeth Warren condemned his remarks as racist.<ref name=Ming1/><ref name=Ming2/><ref name=Ming3/>
Trump continued his attacks hours later: "Elijah Cummings spends all of his time trying to hurt innocent people through "Oversight." He does NOTHING for his very poor, very dangerous and very badly run district!" Cummings' Maryland district's median income is above the average for American districts.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Segers |first1=Grace |title=Trump sparks outrage with derogatory tweets about Rep. Elijah Cummings |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-cummings-tweet-president-sparks-outrage-brutal-bully-maryland-rep-elijah-cummings-dangerous-filthy-baltimore/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=July 28, 2019 |date=July 27, 2019}}</ref>
On July 27, the editorial board of ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'' responded to Trump's statements. They argued that Trump also has a responsibility to solve Baltimore's problems, since the White House has more power than any single congressman. They concluded: "Better to have some vermin living in your neighborhood than to be one."<ref>Baltimore Sun Editorial Board, ''[https://www.baltimoresun.com/opinion/editorial/bs-ed-0728-trump-baltimore-20190727-k6ac4yvnpvcczlaexdfglifada-story.html Better to have a few rats than to be one]'', The Baltimore Sun, Saturday, July 27, 2017</ref>
On July 28, Trump wrote "There is nothing racist in stating plainly what most people already know, that Elijah Cummings has done a terrible job for the people of his district, and of Baltimore itself. Dems always play the race card when they are unable to win with facts. Shame!". Trump's Acting chief of staff, [[Mick Mulvaney]], defended the comments in television interviews, saying that he understood why some people think Trump's comments are racist, "but that doesn’t mean that it is racist." Trump also called Cummings a "racist", without explanation, and retweeted a British right-wing commentator that labelled Baltimore as a "proper sh*thole".<ref>{{cite news |title=Stepping up feud, Trump assails Cummings as 'racist' |url=https://apnews.com/76da6dbad40e4209827abacc0b3d3ea7 |accessdate=29 July 2019 |agency=Associated Press |date=29 July 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Smith |first1=Allan |title=Trump calls Cummings a 'racist' in second day of attacks on lawmaker, Baltimore |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-continues-attacks-cummings-baltimore-n1035466 |publisher=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=July 29, 2019 |date=July 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Tubman |first1=Kadia |title=Trump doubles down on Cummings attacks, shares vulgar comment about Baltimore on Twitter |url=https://news.yahoo.com/trump-doubles-down-on-cummings-attacks-shares-vulgar-comment-about-baltimore-on-twitter-205406597.html |work=[[Yahoo! News]] |accessdate=July 29, 2019 |date=July 29, 2019}}</ref>
On July 29, [[Al Sharpton]], a black activist for civil rights, tweeted: "Arrived in DC from Atlanta, headed to Baltimore. Long day but can’t stop." Trump quoted and responded to that tweet of Sharpton's, declaring: "I have known Al for 25 years. Went to fights with him & Don King, always got along well. He 'loved Trump!' He would ask me for favors often. Al is a con man, a troublemaker, always looking for a score. Just doing his thing. Must have intimidated Comcast/NBC. Hates Whites & Cops!" This led Sharpton to reply: "I do make trouble for bigots. If he really thought I was a con man he would want me in his cabinet."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Raymond |first1=Adam |title=Trump Picks a Fight With Al Sharpton, Calls Him a 'Con Man' Who 'Hates Whites' |url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2019/07/trump-calls-al-sharpton-a-con-man-who-hates-whites.html |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |accessdate=July 29, 2019 |date=July 29, 2019}}</ref>
On July 30, Trump said that "thousands" of people have told his administration they were "thankful" for his comments on Baltimore, in particular the black majority of the residents of Baltimore, who he said were "living in hell". <ref>{{cite news |last1=Watson |first1=Kathyn |title=Trump says people of Baltimore are "living in hell" |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/residents-of-baltimore-and-other-democrat-run-cities-are-living-in-hell-trump-declares/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=August 6, 2019 |date=July 30, 2019}}</ref>
Regarding Trump's rhetoric, the [[Washington National Cathedral]] issued a statement from its leaders [[Mariann Budde]], [[Randolph Hollerith]] and Kelly Douglas. They condemned Trump's statements as "dangerous", because "violent words lead to violent actions". They asked when would Americans declare that they "have had enough" of Trump's words and actions, which both attract and shield "white supremacists who consider people of color a sub-human 'infestation' in America ... The question is less about the president's sense of decency, but of" Americans'.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Zauzmer |first1=Julie |title='Have we no decency?' National Cathedral criticizes Trump's 'dehumanizing words.' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/religion/2019/07/31/have-we-no-decency-local-church-leaders-respond-trumps-criticism-baltimore/ |work=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=August 6, 2019 |date=July 31, 2019}}</ref>
===Mass shooting in Texas=== {{See also|2019 El Paso shooting}} Following the [[2019 El Paso shooting|mass shooting]] that took place in [[El Paso, Texas]] during the first week of August 2019, Trump's anti-immigrant rhetoric was widely criticized, especially remarks regarding Hispanics and his repeated warnings about an immigrant "invasion", the same wording used by the El Paso shooter in his anti-immigrant manifesto in which he wrote, "this attack is a response to the Hispanic invasion of Texas." Representative [[Veronica Escobar]], whose district includes a large part of the city, said "Words have consequences. The president has made my community and my people the enemy. He has told the country that we are people to be feared, people to be hated." Presidential candidate [[Beto O'Rourke]], who is from El Paso, stated: "Anyone who is surprised is part of this problem right now — including members of the media who ask, ‘Hey Beto, do you think the president is racist?' Well, Jesus Christ, of course he’s racist. He’s been racist from day one."<ref>{{cite news |title='Of Course He's Racist': 2020 Democrats Criticize Trump After Shootings |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/08/05/us/politics/beto-trump.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=August 6, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title='We were safe until he started talking': El Paso residents respond to President Trump |url=https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2019-08-05/el-paso-shooting-residents-respond-to-president-trump |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=August 6, 2019}}</ref>
In a speech on August 5 commenting on the recent shootings, Trump strongly condemned racism and white supremacy, stating "These sinister ideologies must be defeated. Hate has no place in America."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-49240310 |title=US mass shootings: Trump condemns racism and white supremacy |work=[[BBC News]] |date=August 5, 2019 |access-date=August 6, 2019}}</ref>
