==="Chinese Virus"=== {{See also|COVID-19 pandemic in the United States}}[[File:President Trump and Administration Officials Deliver Remarks and Hold a Press Briefing on Testing.webm|thumb|right|300px|start=01:00:28|During a press conference on May 11, 2020, CBS News White House Correspondent [[Weijia Jiang]] asked Trump "Why does that matter?” referring to testing for Coronavirus, "Why is this a global competition to you if every day Americans are still losing their lives?”, Trump tells her to "They’re losing their lives everywhere in the world. And maybe that’s a question you should ask China. Don’t ask me, ask China that question, OK?"<ref>{{Cite web|title=The Tiresome Taunting Of President Trump|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/patriciagbarnes/2020/05/12/the-tiresome-taunting-of-president-trump/|last=Barnes|first=Patricia|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2020-05-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Washington|first=Adam Gabbatt David Smith in|date=2020-05-12|title=Trump accused of racism after clash with Asian American reporter|language=en-GB|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/may/12/trump-weijia-jiang-china-attack-racism-accusations|access-date=2020-05-14|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>]] After he was widely criticized for using the term, Trump defended his use of the phrase "Chinese Virus" for [[Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2|SARS-CoV-2]]. Trump said, "it comes from China...it's not racist at all".<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Rogers|first1=Katie|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/18/us/politics/china-virus.html|title=Trump Defends Calling the Coronavirus the 'Chinese Virus'|date=2020-03-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2020-03-18|last2=Jakes|first2=Lara|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Many people and organizations disagreed, including the [[Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund]], which tweeted in March 2020 "Of course he called it "Chinese Virus," because he doesn't care that Asians and [[Asian Americans]] are subjected to hate violence because of this racist description of #coronavirus."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-condemned-racism-after-calling-coronavirus-chinese-virus-1492666|title=Trump condemned for racism after calling coronavirus "Chinese Virus' shortly after telling Americans to "band together"|last=EDT|first=Chantal Da Silva On 3/17/20 at 6:24 AM|date=2020-03-17|website=Newsweek|language=en|access-date=2020-03-18}}</ref> The [[World Health Organization]] has "called on scientists, national authorities and the media to follow best practices in naming new human infectious diseases to minimize unnecessary negative effects on nations, economies and people."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/notes/2015/naming-new-diseases/en/|title=WHO {{!}} WHO issues best practices for naming new human infectious diseases|website=WHO|access-date=2020-03-18}}</ref>
On June 20, 2020, in a speech in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], Trump used racist language, referring to [[Coronavirus disease 2019|Covid-19]] as "Kung Flu",<ref>{{cite news |title=Donald Trump calls Covid-19 'kung flu' at Tulsa rally |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jun/20/trump-covid-19-kung-flu-racist-language |accessdate=22 June 2020 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=20 June 2020 |location=[[London]]}}</ref> a phrase that White House staff [[Kellyanne Conway]] had previously described as "wrong", "highly offensive"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Riechmann |first1=Deb |last2=Tang |first2=Terry |title=Trump continues to call coronavirus ‘Chinese virus’ in spite of hate crime risks |url=https://globalnews.ca/news/6698597/donald-trump-coronavirus-racism/ |accessdate=22 June 2020 |work=[[Global News]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=18 March 2020}}</ref> and "very hurtful".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Benen |first1=Steve |authorlink=Steve Benen |title=On virus, Trump uses phrase even the White House considers offensive |url=https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/virus-trump-uses-phrase-even-white-house-considers-offensive-n1231702 |accessdate=22 June 2020 |work=[[MSNBC]] |date=22 June 2020}}</ref>
=== "When the looting starts, the shooting starts"=== {{see also|Death of George Floyd|George Floyd protests}} In May 2020, Trump was accused of racism for tweeting "[[when the looting starts, the shooting starts]]" and stating of the looters "these thugs are dishonoring the memory of [[Death of George Floyd|George Floyd]]" in response to a third night of arson and rioting in Minneapolis, during which the Minneapolis Third Precinct police station was set on fire by rioters,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.foxnews.com/us/minneapolis-third-precinct-police-station-set-on-fire-after-rioters-break-in |title=Minneapolis Third Precinct police station set on fire after rioters break in |publisher=Fox News |date=29 May 2020 |accessdate=29 May 2020}}</ref> over the police killing of the unarmed black man.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-twitter-trump-minneapolis/trump-threatens-shooting-response-to-minneapolis-riot-over-police-killing-idUSKBN2350UC |title=Trump threatens 'shooting' response to Minneapolis riot over police killing |publisher=reuters |date=29 May 2020 |accessdate=29 May 2020}}</ref> The phrase had been used previously in 1967 by a Miami police chief, Walter E. Headley, that was widely condemned by civil rights groups and repeated in 1968 during the [[George Wallace 1968 presidential campaign|presidential campaign]] of segregationist [[George Wallace]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/29/us/looting-starts-shooting-starts.html |title='Looting' Comment From Trump Dates Back to Racial Unrest of the 1960s |work=The New York Times |date=29 May 2020 |accessdate=29 May 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2020/05/29/864818368/the-history-behind-when-the-looting-starts-the-shooting-starts |title=The History Behind 'When The Looting Starts, The Shooting Starts' |work=NPR |date=29 May 2020 |accessdate=12 June 2020}}</ref>
As protests continued, Washington, D.C. mayor [[Muriel Bowser]] criticised Trump for stating that protesters who climbed over the White House fence would be met by "the most vicious dogs and ominous of weapons", saying it was "no subtle reminder to African-Americans of segregationists that let dogs out on women, children and innocent people in the South".<ref>[https://www.bostonglobe.com/2020/05/30/nation/trump-encourages-supporters-rally-threatens-military-response-protests/ Trump encourages supporters to rally, threatens military response to protests]</ref>
=== Changing the names of military bases=== In June 2020, the [[United States Army|US Army]] proposed opening discussions surrounding the renaming of bases that have been named after [[Confederate States Army|Confederate Army]] generals. Many people and organizations such as the NAACP have suggested renaming the bases after military heroes of color rather than white supremacist traitors. Trump responded with a tweet stating that "my Administration will not even consider the renaming of these Magnificent and Fabled Military Installations.” <ref>{{Cite news|last=Ismay|first=John|date=2020-06-10|title=The Army Was Open to Replacing Confederate Base Names. Then Trump Said No.|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/10/magazine/army-confederate-base-names.html|access-date=2020-06-11|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
=== Moving date of Tulsa rally === Trump had planned to hold his first rally since March on 19 June 2020 in Tulsa, Oklahoma, but this provoked an outcry as it would have overlapped [[Juneteenth]] - a day commemorating the end of slavery. The rally also caused controversy due to the location's associations with the [[Tulsa race massacre|Tulsa massacre]], the worst case of [[Mass racial violence in the United States|racial violence]] in American history.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Davidson|first=Paul|title='Black Wall Street': Trump's plan for rally in Tulsa calls attention to 1921 race massacre|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2020/06/15/trump-tulsa-rally-juneteenth-black-wall-street-massacre-greenwood/3179886001/|access-date=2020-06-15|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US}}</ref> Trump initially defended the plans, stating that his rally would be a celebration, but then announced that the rally would be moved to 20 June "out of respect".<ref>{{citeweb |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trump-moves-tulsa-rally-juneteenth-june-20-respect/story?id=71231688 |title=Trump moves his Tulsa rally from Juneteenth to June 20 'out of respect' |publisher=abcnews |date=13 June 2020 |accessdate=13 June 2020}}</ref> === Lincoln's end result "questionable" === In a June 12, 2020 interview with Fox News host [[Harris Faulkner]], a black woman, Trump claimed to have done more for blacks than the 16th president [[Abraham Lincoln]]. Trump further suggested that although Lincoln "did good", the end result was "always questionable" but when pressed admitted "So I’m going to take a pass on Abe." <ref>{{Cite web|date=2020-06-12|title=Watch: Trump's Harris Faulkner Exchange on Abraham Lincoln|url=https://www.mediaite.com/tv/trump-awkwardly-tells-harris-faulkner-hes-done-more-for-african-americans-than-any-president-lincoln-did-good-although/|access-date=2020-06-13|website=Mediaite|language=en}}</ref> ===Nazi symbol in Facebook ads=== In June 2020, Facebook removed Trump campaign ads that included an upside down red triangle, a symbol which the Nazis had used to label opponents of their regime. The Trump campaign claimed that the symbol was used by Antifa, but experts contend that this is inaccurate and some critics viewed the symbol as a racist dog whistle.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Morrison|first=Sara|date=2020-06-18|title=Facebook takes down another Trump campaign ad, this time for Nazi imagery|url=https://www.vox.com/recode/2020/6/18/21295226/facebook-trump-campaign-nazi-symbol-antifa|access-date=2020-06-22|website=Vox|language=en}}</ref> Facebook stated that “We removed these posts and ads for violating our policy against organized hate.”<ref>{{Cite news|last=Karni|first=Annie|date=2020-06-18|title=Facebook Removes Trump Ads Displaying Symbol Used by Nazis|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/06/18/us/politics/facebook-trump-ads-antifa-red-triangle.html|access-date=2020-06-21|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> == Impact == Donald Trump has been accused of "inflaming racial, ethnic and religious tensions across the United States."<ref>{{cite news|title=Five months of Trump: Muslims' fears were high but neighbors stood by them|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jun/20/trump-muslims-pennsylvania-the-promise|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=January 27, 2018}}</ref> The [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] recorded 867 "hate incidents" in the 10 days after the US election, a phenomenon it partly blamed on Trump's rhetoric. They consider the actual number of incidents to be much higher because most [[hate crimes]] go unreported. SPLC president Richard Cohen blamed the recent surge on the divisive language used by Trump throughout his campaign. In a statement he said: "Mr Trump claims he's surprised his election has unleashed a barrage of hate across the country. But he shouldn't be. It's the predictable result of the campaign he waged."<ref name="theguardian.com">{{cite news|last1=Sidahmed|first1=Mazin|title=Trump's election led to 'barrage of hate', report finds|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/nov/29/trump-related-hate-crimes-report-southern-poverty-law-center|newspaper=The Guardian|accessdate=January 27, 2018}}</ref>
In 2016, [[US Attorney General|US attorney general]] [[Loretta Lynch]] said [[FBI]] statistics for 2015 showed a 67% increase in hate crimes against Muslim Americans; hate crimes against Jewish people, African Americans and LGBT individuals increased as well. Lynch reported a 6% overall increase, though she said the number could be higher because many incidents go unreported. In New York City the number of hate crimes increased 31.5% in the year from 2015 to 2016. Mayor [[Bill de Blasio]] commented, "A lot of us are very concerned that a lot of divisive speech was used during the campaign by the President-elect, and we do not yet know what the impact of that will be on our country."<ref>{{cite news|title='Make America White Again': Hate speech and crimes post-election|url=https://www.cnn.com/2016/11/10/us/post-election-hate-crimes-and-fears-trnd/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=January 28, 2018}}</ref>
Between 2014 and 2018, the number of hate groups skyrocketed 30%, reaching 892 in 2015; 917 in 2016; 954 in 2017; and to a record number 1,020 in 2018.<ref name="splc2016">{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2016/year-hate-and-extremism|title=The Year in Hate and Extremism|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/02/hate-groups-grow-straight-year-splc-180221192119355.html|title=Hate groups in US grow for third straight year: SPLC|publisher=Al Jazeera}}</ref> According to Mark Potok at the SPLC, [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's presidential campaign]] speeches "demonizing statements about Latinos and Muslims have electrified the radical right, leading to glowing endorsements from white nationalist leaders such as [[Jared Taylor]] and former Klansman [[David Duke]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/anonymous-shut-down-kkk-website_n_5720c204e4b0b49df6a9b333|title=How Anonymous Is Fighting White Supremacy Online|first=Casey|last= Williams|work=The Huffington Post|date=April 27, 2016}}</ref>
The [[Loyal White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan|Ku Klux Klan]] held a rally at the Charlottesville [[Unite the Right rally]] in 2017. Former grand wizard David Duke spoke calling the demonstrations a "turning point" saying, "We are going to fulfill the promises of Donald Trump. That’s what we believed in. That’s why we voted for Donald Trump, because he said he’s going to take our country back."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nelson |first1=Libby |title="Why we voted for Donald Trump": David Duke explains the white supremacist Charlottesville protests |url=https://www.vox.com/2017/8/12/16138358/charlottesville-protests-david-duke-kkk |work=Vox |accessdate=August 6, 2019}}</ref>
A 2018 study found that Trump's anti-establishment campaign positions, for example his frequent "drain the swamp" rhetoric, was less of a draw for voters than were his negative attitudes towards ethnic minorities and sexism.<ref>{{cite web |title=Explaining the Trump Vote: The Effect of Racist Resentment and Anti-Immigrant Sentiments |url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/537A8ABA46783791BFF4E2E36B90C0BE/S1049096518000367a.pdf/explaining_the_trump_vote_the_effect_of_racist_resentment_and_antiimmigrant_sentiments.pdf |website=Politics (study) |accessdate=October 25, 2019}}</ref> One study found that "Trump’s rhetoric and rallies served to heighten white identity and increase the perceived threat facing white Americans [and found] that counties which hosted a Trump rally saw a 226% increase in hate-motivated incidents."<ref>{{cite news |title=Counties that hosted a 2016 Trump rally saw a 226 percent increase in hate crimes |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/03/22/trumps-rhetoric-does-inspire-more-hate-crimes/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=October 25, 2019}}</ref> In 2019, the [[Brookings Institution]] reported that statistics show that Trump's racist rhetoric has resulted in an increase in violence in America. Their study found "substantial evidence that Trump has encouraged racism and benefitted politically from it." Looking at hate crime figures in which Trump had won the election they found a jump of hate crimes, the second largest jump in 25 years, the first being [[September 11, 2001]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump and racism: What do the data say? |url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2019/08/14/trump-and-racism-what-do-the-data-say/ |publisher=Brookings Institution |accessdate=October 25, 2019}}</ref>
=== Effects on students === A survey of over 10,000 teachers conducted by the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]]'s Teaching Tolerance project after the 2016 presidential election showed that "the results of the election are having a profoundly negative impact on schools and students." Most respondents believe the impact will be long-lasting. Respondents reported an increase in "verbal harassment, the use of slurs and derogatory language, and disturbing incidents involving swastikas, Nazi salutes and Confederate flags". "Nearly a third of the incidents were motivated by anti-immigrant sentiment and anti-black incidents were the second-most common, with frequent references to lynching. Antisemitic and anti-Muslim attacks were common as well. SPLC believes "the dynamics and incidents these educators reported are nothing short of a crisis and should be treated as such."<ref>{{cite news|title=The Trump Effect: The Impact of The 2016 Presidential Election on Our Nation's Schools|url=https://www.splcenter.org/20161128/trump-effect-impact-2016-presidential-election-our-nations-schools#about%20the%20survey|publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center|accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref><ref name="pri.org"/><ref name="theguardian.com"/> Southern Poverty president Richard Cohen commented, "We've seen Donald Trump behave like a 12 year old, and now we're seeing 12 year olds behave like Donald Trump."<ref name="pri.org">{{cite news|title=What's the 'Trump Effect' in schools? Here's how 2,000 teachers explain it.|url=https://www.pri.org/stories/2016-04-20/whats-trump-effect-schools-heres-how-2000-teachers-explain-it|publisher=PRI|accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Woffard |first=Ben |title=Inside the Trump Effect: How One District Is Fighting Hate at School |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/features/trump-effect-how-one-district-is-fighting-hate-at-school-w465998 |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=March 23, 2017 |access-date=January 26, 2018}}</ref>
A 2020 survey of news stories since Trump's election found 300 reports that involved incidents of student bullying that were related to Trump's remarks or his MAGA campaign chants. At least three-quarters of the attacks were directed at black, Hispanic or Muslim students, but the report also found 45 cases of students being attacked because they were Trump supporters. The survey found that parents, players, or fans had used Trump's name or his words at least 48 times directed at students competing in elementary, middle and high school sporting events. Since most incidents are never reported it is believed that the figures they found are only a fraction of the actual total.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump's words, bullied kids, scarred schools |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/local/school-bullying-trump-words/ |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=May 31, 2020}}</ref>
=== Effects on children ===
Sociologist Margaret Hagerman studies and writes about young people's views on racism and current events in America. In her latest work, published in 2018, she reports on her conversations with young people as related to the election of Trump as president. She writes:
:"Every child of color I interviewed not only articulated disgust and outrage with the president’s racist language and actions but also described feeling scared, angry, anxious, upset, and worried because of Trump’s presidency and specifically what his racist actions might mean for themselves or the people they love."
Comparing the children of color to white children she writes:
:"For some of the white children I spoke with, this reality [of racism] seems to be connected to empathy, anger, and a sense of concern for their peers. But, for other white children, this reality simply does not matter, even though they know and can acknowledge that it exists."<ref>{{cite web |title=Those Who Care and Those Who Don't: Children and Racism in the Trump Era |url=https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/care-dont-children-racism-trump-era/ |work=[[Los Angeles Review of Books]] |accessdate=August 6, 2019}}</ref>
=== Reactions by the Congressional Black Caucus === Members of the [[Congressional Black Caucus]] (CBC) have criticized Trump for "repeatedly stirring racial controversies."<ref name=hill-20180201 /> [[Emanuel Cleaver]], former head of the CBC, voiced concerns when Trump began raising doubts about President Obama's birthplace: "I don't know if the people around the country understand that he has launched ... an assault against African-American people starting with his refusal to accept the first African-American president, by continuing to declare that he was from Kenya. No other president in history has had to face that kind of criticism. We've come to conclude that this is a part of his belief system."<ref name=hill-20180201>{{cite news |title=Black Dems take lead in push to impeach Trump |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/371743-black-dems-take-lead-in-push-to-impeach-trump |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |first1=Cristina |last1=Marcos |first2=Mike |last2=Lillis |date=February 1, 2018 |access-date=February 1, 2018}}</ref>
Some lawmakers protested by refusing to attend Trump's [[2018 State of the Union Address]]. [[John Lewis (civil rights leader)|John Lewis]] said "I've got to be moved by my conscience," and [[Barbara Lee]] said "This president does not respect the office, he dishonors it." [[Frederica Wilson]], whom Trump called "wacky" after she supported the wife of a soldier killed in Niger,<ref name="McC">{{cite news |last=McCaskill |first=Roland |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/10/19/john-kelly-frederica-wilson-trump-243956 |title=Kelly emotionally defends Trump's call to military widow |work=[[Politico]] |date=October 20, 2017 |access-date=February 1, 2018}}</ref> also skipped the address. [[Maxine Waters]] released a video response wherein she said, "He claims that he's bringing people together but make no mistake, he is a dangerous, unprincipled, divisive, and shameful racist."<ref>{{cite news |title=Maxine Waters Delivers Scathing SOTU Response: 'Make No Mistake. Trump Is a Dangerous Racist' |url=https://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/a15954306/maxine-waters-sotu-response/ |work=[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]] |first=Tess |last=Koman |date=February 1, 2018 |access-date=February 2, 2018}}</ref> Other black lawmakers attended the address wearing [[kente cloth|kente stoles]] as a show of support following Trump's "shithole" comments about African and other countries.<ref name=hill-20180201 />
Almost two-thirds of the CBC have backed [[efforts to impeach Donald Trump]] in House floor votes forced by Representative [[Al Green (politician)|Al Green]]. Green's articles of impeachment assert that Trump has "brought the high office of president of the United States in contempt, ridicule, disgrace and disrepute" and "has sown discord among the people of the United States".<ref name=hill-20180201 />
== Defenses of Donald Trump == [[File:President Trump Delivers Remarks Upon Departure July 30, 2019.webm|thumb|right|300px|start=10:19|Donald Trump states "I am the least racist person there is anywhere in the world." July 30, 2019]] Trump has repeatedly denied claims that he is racist, often stating that he is "the least racist person".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2018/01/17/six-times-president-trump-said-he-is-the-least-racist-person/ | title=Six times President Trump said he is the least racist person | newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] The Fix blog| date=January 17, 2018 | accessdate=January 17, 2018 | last=Scott | first=Eugene}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.vox.com/2015/8/3/9089495/donald-trump-racist | title=Timeline: Donald Trump has been getting called racist since 1973 | publisher=[[Vox Media|Vox]] | date=December 9, 2015 | accessdate=January 17, 2018 | last=Lind | first=Dara}}</ref> Various friends, members of his administration and people who have known him, including some black Americans, have stated that Trump is not racist.<ref name=apprentice4/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.foxbusiness.com/politics/trump-is-not-a-racist-he-is-a-great-man-nfl-legend-herschel-walker |title=Trump is not a racist, he is a great man: NFL legend Herschel Walker |publisher=foxbusiness.com |date= 2 February 2018 | accessdate= 17 May 2020}}</ref><ref name="Hill872019">{{cite web |url=https://thehill.com/opinion/white-house/456523-donald-trumps-no-racist-as-past-acts-and-presidential-record-prove |title=Donald Trump's no racist, as past acts and presidential record prove |publisher=thehill.com |date=7 August 2019 |accessdate=22 May 2020}}</ref> [[Ben Carson]] explained his evidence for this belief, stating "When he bought [[Mar-a-Lago]], he was the one who fought for Jews and blacks to be included in the clubs that were trying to exclude them. You know, people say he's a racist, he is not a racist."<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/07/ben-carson-trump-racist-112051 |title= Ben Carson points to Mar-a-Lago to show that Trump is 'not a racist' | publisher=www.politico.com |date= 7 February 2020 |accessdate= 19 May 2020}}</ref> According to ''Politico'', Trump recognized that there were a large number of wealthy residents in Palm Beach who were unable to join the other private clubs because most of them did not admit Black or Jewish applicants.<ref name="Politico Leamer">{{cite web |last1=Leamer |first1=Laurence |title=How Mar-a-Lago Taught Trump to Play Politics |url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2019/02/01/donald-trump-mar-a-lago-anti-semitism-town-council-palm-beach-politics-224537 |accessdate=24 May 2020 |ref=February 1, 2019}}</ref>
Though perceived as anti-immigrant, Trump is himself the son of immigrants and has twice married wives who were immigrants. He has often celebrated his immigrant heritage.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2015/08/24/politics/donald-trump-immigrant-wives/index.html |title=Donald Trump's immigrant wives|publisher=CNN |date=25 August 2015|accessdate=30 May 2020}}</ref> During the [[2016 U.S. presidential election]], Trump defended himself against accusations that his immigration policies were racist, stating "I will never apologize for pledging to enforce and uphold every single law of the United States, and to make my immigration priority defending and protecting American citizens above every other single consideration."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Levy |first1=Gabrielle |title=Trump: We Are Not Racists |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2016-08-25/trump-we-are-not-racists |accessdate=January 26, 2018 |work=U.S. News & World Report |date=August 25, 2016}}</ref>
Though it is sometimes claimed that President Trump has not adequately condemned white supremacy,<ref>{{citeweb|date=9 February 2020|title='This Week' Transcript 2-9-20: Joe Biden, Pete Buttigieg, Sen. Elizabeth Warren|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/week-transcript-20-joe-biden-pete-buttigieg-sen/story?id=68859404|accessdate=1 June 2020|publisher=absnews}}</ref> he has denounced it on various occasions in response to these allegations. In a 2017 prepared statement following criticism of his initial remarks on the attacks in Charlottesville, Virginia, he stated "Racism is evil -- and those who cause violence in its name are criminals and thugs, including KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists, and other hate groups are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans".<ref>{{Cite web|title=Trump calls white supremacists 'repugnant'|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/08/14/politics/trump-condemns-charlottesville-attackers/index.html|first=Dan |last=Merica|website=CNN|access-date=2020-06-01}}</ref> In a 2019 response to mass shootings he stated "In one voice, our nation must condemn racism, bigotry and white supremacy".<ref>{{Cite news|date=2019-08-05|title=Trump: US must condemn white supremacy|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-49240310|access-date=2020-06-01}}</ref>
Trump and his allies have often pointed to record-low unemployment numbers among blacks and Hispanics during his presidency as evidence that he is not a racist and that his administration is benefiting racial minorities.<ref name="Hill872019"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2018/01/08/576552028/fact-check-trump-touts-low-unemployment-rates-for-african-americans-hispanics |title=FACT CHECK: Trump Touts Low Unemployment Rates For African-Americans, Hispanics |last=Kurtzleben |first=Danielle |date=January 8, 2018 |publisher=NBC |access-date=May 30, 2020}}</ref> In 2019, Trump received an award from the 20/20 Bipartisan Justice Center for his administration’s work to pass the [[First Step Act]], which granted early release to thousands of nonviolent offenders who were serving time in federal prisons,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/kamala-harris-flip-flop-criminal-justice-forum-trump-award|title=Kamala Harris flip-flops on attending criminal justice forum, after announcing boycott over Trump award |publisher=Fox News |date=26 October 2019 |accessdate=30 May 2020}}</ref> with evidence suggesting that black men were the main beneficiaries of the Act.<ref>{{citeweb |url=https://www.charlestonchronicle.net/2019/07/21/report-black-men-are-biggest-beneficiaries-of-the-first-step-act/ |title=REPORT: Black Men Are Biggest Beneficiaries of the First Step Act |publisher= Charleston Chronicle |date=21 July 2019 |accessdate=2 June 2020}}</ref>
Following White House protests over the death of [[George Floyd]], Trump tweeted, "The professionally managed so-called 'protesters' at the White House had little to do with the memory of George Floyd. They were just there to cause trouble. The [[U.S. Secret Service]] handled them easily. Tonight, I understand, is MAGA NIGHT AT THE WHITE HOUSE???". Speaking to reporters on June 1, Trump was questioned as to whether he wanted to see his "Make America Great Again" (MAGA) supporters confront the Americans protesting for racial justice. Trump clarified his message saying:
<blockquote>"MAGA says '[[Make America Great Again]]' These are people that love our country. I have no idea if they're going to be here. I was just asking. But I have no idea if they're going to be here. But MAGA is 'Make America Great Again.' By the way, they love African-American people. They love black people. MAGA loves the black people."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dorman |first1=Sam |title=Trump defends his supporters amid riots: 'MAGA loves the black people' |url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/trump-maga-likes-black-people |website=FOX News |accessdate=June 2, 2020}}</ref></blockquote>
== Analysis ==
=== Journalists and pundits === CNN White House correspondent [[Jim Acosta]] said the ''Washington Post'' report combined with statements made in 2016 and 2017 shows "the president seems to harbor racist feelings about people of color from other parts of the world."<ref>{{cite news |title=Acosta: Trump seems to harbor racist feelings |publisher=CNN |date=January 11, 2018 |url=https://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2018/01/11/acosta-trump-slur-analysis-tsr.cnn/video/playlists/situation-room-highlights/ |access-date=January 11, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Samuels |first=Brett |title=CNN's Acosta: Trump 'seems to harbor racist feelings' |newspaper=The Hill |date=January 11, 2018 |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/media/368602-cnns-acosta-trump-seems-to-harbor-racist-feelings |access-date=January 11, 2018}}</ref>
Following the incident in which Trump referred to several nations as "shithole countries", some media commentators moved from describing certain words and actions of Trump as manifesting racism, to calling Trump racist.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bauder |first=David |url=https://www.apnews.com/4cfbf11db6274a21b4f3a76f6c2ed03f |title=Some media figures call Trump racist after profane remarks |agency=Associated Press |date=January 13, 2018 |accessdate=March 4, 2018}}</ref> [[David Brooks (cultural commentator)|David Brooks]], speaking on ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'', called the president's statements "pretty clearly racist" and said, "It fits into a pattern that we have seen since the beginning of his career, maybe through his father's career, frankly. There's been a consistency, pattern of harsh judgment against black and brown people."<ref name=pbs-shields-brooks /> Trump has been called a racist by a number of ''New York Times'' columnists including [[Nicholas Kristof]] ("I don't see what else we can call him but a racist"),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kristof|first1=Nicholas |authorlink=Nicholas Kristof |title=Mr. Trump, Meet a Hero Whom You Maligned|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/12/opinion/sunday/trump-shithole-countries-emmanuel-mensah.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 22, 2018|date=January 12, 2018}}</ref> [[Charles M. Blow]] ("Trump Is a Racist. Period."),<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blow|first1=Charles M.|title=Trump Is a Racist. Period.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/14/opinion/trump-racist-shithole.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 22, 2018|date=January 14, 2018}}</ref> and [[David Leonhardt]] ("Donald Trump is a racist").<ref>{{cite news |first1=David |last1=Leonhardt |authorlink=David Leonhardt |first2=Ian Prasad |last2=Philbrick |title=Donald Trump's Racism: The Definitive List|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/01/15/opinion/leonhardt-trump-racist.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 22, 2018|date=January 15, 2018}}</ref> Additionally, [[John Cassidy (journalist)|John Cassidy]] of ''The New Yorker'' concluded, "we have a racist in the Oval Office."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cassidy|first1=John|title=A Racist in the Oval Office|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/trump-shithole-comment-racist-in-the-oval-office|work=The New Yorker|accessdate=January 22, 2018|date=January 12, 2018}}</ref>
Conservative pundit and former [[Republican National Committee]] chairman [[Michael Steele]], when asked in an interview in January 2018 if he thought Trump was a racist replied, "Yeah, I do. At this point the evidence is incontrovertible."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/368702-ex-rnc-chair-says-trump-is-racist-the-evidence-is-incontrovertible |title=Ex-RNC chair says Trump is racist: 'The evidence is incontrovertible' |first=Brandon |last=Carter |date=January 12, 2018 |newspaper=The Hill}}</ref> Speaking on [[MSNBC]], Steele said, "There are a whole lot of folks like Donald Trump. White folks in this country who have a problem with the browning of America. When they talk about [wanting] their country back, they are talking about a country that was very safely white, less brown and less committed to that browning process."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Herrerla|first1=Carla|title=Few Republicans Acknowledged Trump's 'Shithole' Slur|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/republicans-trump-shithole_us_5a5815b4e4b02cebbfda6179|publisher=HuffPost|accessdate=January 24, 2018}}</ref>
Australian political commentator and former [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal party]] leader [[John Hewson]] writes in January 2018 that he believes the recent global movements against traditional politics and politicians are based on racism and prejudice. He comments: "There should be little doubt about US President Donald Trump's views on race, despite his occasional 'denials', assertions of 'fake news', and/or his semantic distinctions. His election campaign theme was effectively a promise to 'Make America Great Again; America First and Only' and – nod, nod, wink, wink – to Make America White Again."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hewson|first1=John|title=No place for the race card in the political pack, but Trump plays it anyway|url=https://www.smh.com.au/opinion/no-place-for-the-race-card-in-the-political-pack--but-donald-trump-plays-it-anyway-20180118-h0k5wv.html|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=January 25, 2018}}</ref>
In July 2019, five ''New York Times'' writers stated that Trump has "decades" of history where he exploited "America's racial, ethnic and religious divisions" for personal gains of "ratings, fame, money or power", while ignoring negative consequences.<ref name=apprentice4/>
=== Academics === [[Doug McAdam]] writes that Trump "is just giving unusually loud and frank voice to views already typical among large numbers of Republicans" and "has pushed the GOP toward ever further racist and nativist extremes." McAdam believes that the Republican Party shift away from more liberal views on matters of racial equality began with [[Richard Nixon]]'s presidency in 1968.<ref>{{cite web|title=Making Sense of the Rise and Impact of Donald Trump|url=https://scholars.org/contribution/making-sense-rise-and-impact-donald-trump|publisher=[[Scholars Strategy Network]]|accessdate=March 7, 2018}}</ref>
Presidential historian [[Douglas Brinkley]] said "What Trump is doing has popped up periodically, but in modern times, no president has been so racially insensitive and shown outright disdain for people who aren't white."<ref name=ap-20180113>{{cite news |title=Trump's own words revive debate over whether he's racist |url=https://www.apnews.com/bce2dc7a054e4541bc77e2971c1bde4e/Trump%2527s-own-words-revive-debate-over-whether-he%2527s-racist |agency=[[Associated Press]] |first=Julie |last=Pace |date=January 13, 2018 |access-date=February 28, 2018}}</ref>
[[George Yancy]], a professor at [[Emory University]] known for his work on racial issues, concluded that Trump is racist, describing his outlook as "a case of unabashed white supremacist ideas."<ref name="Baker">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/12/us/politics/trump-racism.html|title=A President Who Fans, Rather Than Douses, the Nation's Racial Fires|last=Baker|first=Peter|date=January 12, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=January 12, 2018|url-status=live|author-link=Peter Baker (journalist)|url-access=limited}}</ref>
Speaking shortly after Trump's election, [[John Mcwhorter]] discussed the fact that 8% of black voters and around 25% of Latinos voted for Donald Trump, saying "many would see it as 'conservative' for a person of color to vote for a racist, as if it were still a time when racism was socially acceptable." In his view, people of color who voted for Trump were willing to look beyond Trump's racism to the promise of economic improvement.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mcwhorter|first1=John|title=Race in Trump's America|url=https://democracyjournal.org/magazine/43/race-in-trumps-america/|work=[[Democracy (journal)|Democracy]]|accessdate=January 29, 2018|date=2017-01-03}}</ref>
David P. Bryden, a professor of law emeritus at the [[University of Minnesota]], suggested that Trump was willing to "vilif[y] all those of any race whom he regards as obstacles to his ambitions." According to Bryden, Trump's targets are largely from minority groups because he wants to appeal to white working class voters who believe that progressives resent them.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bryden |first=David P. |url=http://www.startribune.com/counterpoint-trump-a-racist-not-a-helpful-argument/444544843/ |title=Counterpoint: Trump a racist? Not a helpful argument |work=Star Tribune |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref>
Pulido et al. published a study in 2018 comparing racism and environmental deregulation during the first year of Trump's presidency. The authors described that "transgressive" racism, or "spectacular" racism, is a "hallmark" of Trump's presidential campaign and presidency, with Trump employing it for "numerous political objectives, including dehumanizing his targets, consolidating his power, eroding democratic norms, and distracting from policy and legal changes". The result of Trump's racism is that "U.S. racial formation" has changed. "Overt white supremacy" has emerged in racial culture. The authors document that in the first year of Trump's presidency, there were 83 racial actions and 173 environmental actions; meanwhile there were 271 instances of racial speech and 22 instances of environmental speech. The authors concluded that "actions were more likely to be environmentally related, whereas rhetoric was more likely to be racist", further positing that "spectacular racism has helped obscure the relatively smooth and devastating deregulation." However, the authors also cautioned that the numbers of actions taken "do not indicate impact", specifically pointing to the Muslim ban and restriction of asylum claims.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Pulido|first1=Laura|first2=Tianna|last2=Bruno|first3=Cristina|last3=Faiver-Serna|first4=Cassandra|last4=Galentine|date=2018|title=Environmental Deregulation, Spectacular Racism, and White Nationalism in the Trump Era|journal=Journal of Race, Ethnicity, and Politics|volume=109|issue=2|pages=520–532|doi=10.1080/24694452.2018.1549473}}</ref>
== Opinion polling == According to an August 2016 Suffolk University poll, 7% of those planning to vote for Trump thought he was racist. A November 2016 ''Post''-ABC poll found that 50% of Americans thought Trump was biased against black people; the figure was 75% among black Americans.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/11/06/most-americans-think-trump-is-biased-against-women-or-black-people/ |title=Analysis - Most Americans think Trump is biased against women or black people |first=Philip |last=Bump |date=November 6, 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> According to an October 2017 Politico/Morning Consult poll, 45% of voters thought Trump was a racist, a plurality.<ref name=politico-20171025>{{cite news |title=Poll: Voters see Trump as reckless, not honest |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/10/25/trump-poll-reckless-honest-244126 |work=[[Politico]] |first=Steven |last=Shepard |date=October 25, 2017 |access-date=March 1, 2018}}</ref>
A [[Quinnipiac poll]] asking the question, "Since the election of Donald Trump, do you believe the level of hatred and prejudice in the U.S. has increased, the level of hatred and prejudice has decreased, or hasn't it changed either way" was conducted in December 2017. Of the respondents, 62% believed that the level had increased, 4% felt that it had decreased, and 31% felt it was without change.<ref>{{cite web |title=Quinnipiac Poll |url=https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=2507 |publisher=Quinnipiac University Poll |accessdate=January 12, 2018}}</ref>
A Quinnipiac poll conducted in January 2018 after Trump's Oval Office comments about immigration showed that 58 percent of American voters found the comments to be racist, while 59 percent said that he does not respect people of color as much as he respects white people.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2018/01/17/most-americans-saw-trumps-shithole-comments-as-racist/ | title=Most Americans considered Trump's 'shithole' comments racist | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=January 17, 2018 | last=Bump | first=Philip | accessdate=January 17, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Quinnipiac Poll |url=https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=2513 |publisher=Quinnipiac University Poll |accessdate=January 17, 2018}}</ref>
Analysis of pre- and post-election surveys from the [[American National Election Studies]], as well as numerous other surveys and studies, show that since the rise of Trump in the Republican Party, attitudes towards racism have become a more significant factor than economic issues in determining voters' party allegiance.<ref name="nation-20170508">{{cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/economic-anxiety-didnt-make-people-vote-trump-racism-did/|title=Economic Anxiety Didn't Make People Vote Trump, Racism Did|last1=McElwee|first1=Sean|date=May 8, 2017|work=[[The Nation]]|access-date=January 13, 2018|url-status=live|last2=McDaniel|first2=Jason|author-link=Sean McElwee}}</ref><ref name="vox-20171215">{{cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/identities/2017/12/15/16781222/trump-racism-economic-anxiety-study|title=The past year of research has made it very clear: Trump won because of racial resentment|last=Lopez|first=German|date=December 15, 2017|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|access-date=January 14, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> According to a July 2019 Politico/Morning Consult poll, 54% of American voters viewed Trump as racist and 38% did not.<ref name=politico-20190205>{{cite news |last1=Shepard |first1=Steven |title=Poll: Majority of voters say 'send her back' chants were racist |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/07/24/send-her-back-chants-racist-poll-1428357 |accessdate=July 30, 2019 |work=POLITICO |date=July 24, 2019}}</ref> A [[Quinnipiac University poll]] released in July found that 51% of voters believed that Trump is a racist while 45% said that he is not a racist.

{{short description|Planned settlement in the Golan Heights}} {{pp-30-500|small=yes}} {{Infobox Kibbutz | name= Trump Heights | hebname = {{hebrew|רמת טראמפ}} | meaning = | image = רמת טראמפ.jpg | caption = The sign at the entrance to the settlement | image_size = 250 | region = [[Golan Heights]] | council = [[Golan Regional Council|Golan]] | district = north | founded = 2019 | affiliation = | popyear = | population = | population_footnotes= | pushpin_map = Israel Golan#Syria Golan | pushpin_mapsize=250 | pushpin_label_position = top |coordinates = {{coord|33|7|57|N|35|41|26|E|display=inline,title}} }}
'''Trump Heights''' ({{lang-he|רמת טראמפ}}, ''Ramat Trump'', {{IPA-he|ʁaˈmat ˈtʁamp|}}) is a planned [[Israeli settlement]] in the [[Israeli-occupied territories|Israeli-occupied]] [[Golan Heights]] named after and in honor of the 45th President of the United States, [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Sign-for-Trump-Heights-goes-up-on-Golan-592725|title=Trump thanks Netanyahu as sign for 'Trump Heights' goes up on Golan - Israel News - Jerusalem Post|website=www.jpost.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-48656431|title=Israel unveils 'Trump Heights' in Golan|date=16 June 2019|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/world/2019/6/16/18681116/benjamin-netanyahu-israel-town-golan-heights-trump-heights|title=Benjamin Netanyahu just unveiled Israel's newest town: "Trump Heights"|first=Zeeshan|last=Aleem|date=16 June 2019|website=Vox}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/israel-names-golan-heights-settlement-trump-1444237|title=Israel officially renames Golan Heights settlement after President Donald Trump|first=Jason Lemon On 6/16/19 at 4:02 PM|last=EDT|date=16 June 2019|website=Newsweek}}</ref> Israeli settlements in the Golan Heights are widely regarded as [[International law and Israeli settlements|illegal under international law]], but the Israeli government disputes this.<ref name="BBC_The_Geneva_Convention">{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/1682640.stm | title = The Geneva Convention | publisher = [[BBC]] | date=10 December 2009 }}</ref>
It will be under the jurisdiction of [[Golan Regional Council]].
==Location== The settlement is expected to be built east of the community of [[Kela Alon]], where the [[Beruchim]] community, which was founded in 1991, was located. The area of the settlement of Beruchim was planned for future expansion of the settlement of Kela Alon, and is inhabited by a few residents.
The settlement is very close to the [[Petroleum Road]]. This route separates Beruchim / Ramat Trump from East, and Kela Alon to the west of it.
== History == In 1991 an Israeli settlement called [[Brukhim]] was established on the land of the future Trump Heights. However, it failed to attract many residents.<ref name=“veconomist” >{{cite news|author=|title=Trump Heights, Binyamin Netanyahu's tribute to America's president|url=https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2019/06/22/trump-heights-binyamin-netanyahus-tribute-to-americas-president|work=[[The Economist]]|date=22 June 2019}}</ref>
The [[government of Israel]] convened on June 16, 2019, at the planned location in the abandoned settlement of Brukhim, very close to [[Kela Alon]] in the north-west of the Golan Heights, and declared the establishment of the new settlement as [[gratitude]] to Donald Trump for support for Israel and [[United States recognition of the Golan Heights as part of Israel|recognition of Israeli sovereignty over the Golan Heights]].
"In appreciation of the work of the 45th President of the United States, President Donald Trump, on behalf of the State of Israel in a wide range of fields and out of gratitude for the American recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and the recognition of Israeli sovereignty on the Golan Heights, It was decided to initiate the establishment of a new community settlement in the Golan Heights called ''Trump Heights''." <ref>Eric Bander, [https://m.maariv.co.il/news/politics/Article-703519 "רמת טראמפ": היישוב החדש על שם נשיא ארה"ב ברמת הגולן], on [[Maariv]] website (In Hebrew), 13 June 2019 </ref> In the first stage, 110 housing units are planned.
On August 6, 2019, the National Planning and Building Council approved the establishment of the new settlement. <ref>[https://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1001296253]</ref>
It is the first community in Israel and [[Israeli-occupied territories]] named after a sitting American president since [[Kfar Truman]].<ref>{{Cite tweet |user=USAmbIsrael |number=1140284207673090048 |date = 16 June 2019 |title=A great day on the Golan. }}</ref>
{{As of|June 2020}}, the site remained deserted and all but two letters of the entrance sign had been stolen by vandals.<ref>{{cite news| author = Ilan Ben Zion | newspaper = The Forward | title = One year later, is the Golan’s desolate ‘Trump Heights’ a ‘hoax’? | date = 16 June 2020 | url = https://forward.com/news/israel/448892/one-year-later-is-the-golans-desolate-trump-heights-a-hoax/?utm_source=PostUp&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Afternoon%20Newsletter%20(Sunday%20RSS)&utm_maildate=06/16/2020 }}</ref>

McMaster joins the very long list of high-profile White House departures|website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|author1=Jen Kirby|author2=Emily Stewart|date=March 23, 2018|accessdate=April 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180325053727/https://www.vox.com/2018/3/6/17088334/mcmaster-trump-white-house-staff-exits|archive-date=March 25, 2018|url-status=live}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-white-house-staffing/|title=Here Are All the Officials Who Have Left the Trump White House|website=Bloomberg|author=Lauren Leatherby|date=March 31, 2018|accessdate=April 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180331173123/https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2018-white-house-staffing/|archive-date=March 31, 2018|url-status=live}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/03/16/us/politics/all-the-major-firings-and-resignations-in-trump-administration.html|title=Turnover at a Constant Clip: The Trump Administration's Major Departures|website=The New York Times|author1=Denise Lu|author2=Karen Yourish|date=March 22, 2018|accessdate=April 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180401024228/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/03/16/us/politics/all-the-major-firings-and-resignations-in-trump-administration.html|archive-date=April 1, 2018|url-status=live}} Several Trump appointees, including [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] [[Michael Flynn]], [[White House Chief of Staff]] [[Reince Priebus]], [[White House Communications Director]] [[Anthony Scaramucci]], and [[United States Secretary of Health and Human Services|Secretary of Health and Human Services]] [[Tom Price (American politician)|Tom Price]] have the shortest-service tenures in the history of their respective offices.{{efn|Excluding interim appointments.}} On September 18, 2019, a reporter asked Trump about the lack of stability in his administration, particularly in DHS. He replied: "We have acting people. The reason they are acting is because I'm seeing how I like them, and I'm liking a lot of them very, very much. There are people who have done a bad job, and I let them go. If you call that turmoil, I don't call that turmoil. I say that is being smart. That's what we do."{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/remarks-president-trump-visit-border-wall-san-diego-ca/|title=Remarks by President Trump During Visit to the Border Wall|date=September 18, 2019|access-date=November 7, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191107140554/https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/remarks-president-trump-visit-border-wall-san-diego-ca/|archive-date=November 7, 2019|url-status=live}} For comprehensiveness, the list below includes, in addition to dismissals and resignations, routine job changes such as promotions (e.g. Gina Haspel from CIA Deputy Director to Director), officials moving to a comparable position (e.g. John F. Kelly from Secretary of Homeland Security to Chief of Staff), and acting or temporary officials being replaced by permanent ones. The list does not include many lower level positions, however, such as that of executive director of the [[United States Interagency Council on Homelessness]], Matthew Doherty, dismissed in November 2019,{{cite news |last=Stein |first=Jeff |authorlink=Jeff Stein (author) |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/11/16/trump-administration-ousts-top-homelessness-official-white-house-prepares-broad-crackdown/ |title=Trump administration ousts top homelessness official as White House prepares broad crackdown |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=November 16, 2019 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20191229004258/https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2019/11/16/trump-administration-ousts-top-homelessness-official-white-house-prepares-broad-crackdown/?wpisrc=nl_evening&wpmm=1 |archivedate=December 29, 2019}} without a replacement to lead the council that was created in 1987. But some less prominent officials are listed because their departure was newsworthy. As of May 25, 2020, there have been 415 unique names dismissed and/or resigned. ==Color key== Color key: {{Color box|gold|border=darkgray}} Denotes appointees serving in an acting capacity. {{Color box|lightgray|border=darkgray}} Denotes appointees of an office which has since been abolished ==Executive Office of the President== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" ! data-sort-type="text" | Name ! data-sort-type="text" | Office ! data-sort-type="date" | Took office ! data-sort-type="date" | Left office ! width="35%" | Notes |- | [[File:White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus at CPAC 2017 February 23rd 2017 by Michael Vadon 21.jpg|100px]]

page.title: List of short-tenure Donald Trump political appointments

revision.text:
{{short description|Wikipedia list article}} {{Donald Trump series}} {{See also|Cabinet of Donald Trump|Political appointments by Donald Trump}} {{use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} This is a list of '''notably short [[Political appointments by Donald Trump|political appointments]] by [[Donald Trump]],''' the 45th and current [[President of the United States]]. The [[Turnover (employment)|turnover rate]] in the [[Trump Administration|Trump administration]] has been noted by various publications.{{cite web|last=Kanetkar|first=Riddhima|work=[[International Business Times]]|title=Brenda Fitzgerald Joins Long List Of Short-Serving Trump Administration Officials|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/brenda-fitzgerald-joins-long-list-short-serving-trump-administration-officials-2648230|date=February 1, 2018|accessdate=August 18, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Keith|first=Tamara|work=[[NPR]]|title=Turnover In Trump's White House Is 'Record-Setting,' And It Isn't Even Close|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/01/19/578858897/turnover-in-trumps-white-house-is-record-setting-and-it-isn-t-even-close|date=January 19, 2018}}{{cite web|last=Bach|first=Natasha|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|title=Trump Staff Turnover Hits 34%—a First Year Presidential Record|url=http://fortune.com/2017/12/28/trump-white-house-record-first-year-turnover-rate/|date=December 28, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Stokols|first=Eli|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|title=Trump White House Saw Record Number of First-Year Staff Departures|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-white-house-saw-record-number-of-first-year-staff-departures-1514457002|date=December 28, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/03/23/politics/trump-cohn-bolton-tillerson-mcmaster/index.html|title=Donald Trump just totally overhauled his White House. In 16 days.|work=CNN|author=Chris Cillizza|date=March 23, 2018|accessdate=April 1, 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2018/3/6/17088334/mcmaster-trump-white-house-staff-exits|title=H.R. In the [[United States]], '''Obama-Trump voters''' (also known as '''Trump Democrats''' or Obama Republicans) voted for [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] nominee [[Barack Obama]] in the [[2008 United States presidential election|2008]] or [[2012 United States presidential election|2012]] presidential elections (or both), but later voted for [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] nominee [[Donald Trump]] in [[2016 United States presidential election|2016]]. These voters comprise 13% of Trump voters and 9% of Obama voters.<ref name=bump>Philip Bump, "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2018/03/12/4-4-million-2012-obama-voters-stayed-home-in-2016-more-than-a-third-of-them-black/ 4.4 million 2012 Obama voters stayed home in 2016 — more than a third of them black]", ''[[Washington Post]]'', March 12, 2018.</ref> In contrast, 7% of Obama voters did not vote and 3% voted for a third party candidate.<ref name=bump /> While some analysts consider them to have been decisive in Trump's victory, others have disputed this conclusion. Compared to other voters, Obama-Trump voters tend to have liberal economic views and conservative social views. They expressed skepticism of congressional Republicans and a desire to change the [[status quo]].
==Studies==
A study by the [[Democracy Fund]] Voter Study Group found that 9.2% of Obama voters voted for Trump in 2016.<ref name=cohn/> According to the [[American National Election Study]], 13% of Trump voters had voted for Obama in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/qvjke5/regretful-trump-voters-i-dont-understand-how-it-could-be-worse |title=Regretful Trump Voters: 'I Don't Understand How It Could Be Worse' |last=Dent |first=David |date=2017-09-20 |website=Vice |language=en-us |access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> Some analysts have argued that these voters had a disproportionately large impact on the 2016 election because they were concentrated in key [[swing state]]s in the [[United States Midwest|Midwest]], while others have said they were actually "Obama Republicans" rather than Democrats to begin with.<ref name=cohn>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/15/upshot/the-obama-trump-voters-are-real-heres-what-they-think.html |title=The Obama-Trump Voters Are Real. Here's What They Think. |last=Cohn |first=Nate |date=2017-08-15 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2018-02-25 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name="Levitz">{{Cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/08/trump-democrats-are-rare-but-electorally-important.html |title=Trump Democrats Are Rare—But Electorally Important |last=Levitz |first=Eric |date=2017-08-16 |website=Daily Intelligencer |language=en |access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> A May 2017 analysis by [[Global Strategy Group]] estimated that Obama-Trump voters accounted for more than two-thirds of [[Hillary Clinton]]'s loss.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/05/it-was-obama-trump-voters-in-the-midwest-with-econ-anxiety.html |title=Autopsy: It Was Obama-Trump Voters, in the Rust Belt, With the Economic Anxiety |last=Levitz |first=Eric |date=2017-05-02 |website=Daily Intelligencer |language=en |access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
==Significance==
[[Dana Milbank]] has disputed both the quantity and the significance of Obama-Trump voters in deciding the outcome of the 2016 election. Milbank argued in an August 2017 ''[[Washington Post]]'' column that the number of such voters was initially overstated, and that most of them were Republicans who only defected from their party to vote for Obama, not Democrats who defected to support Trump.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/08/may-not-be-as-many-trump-democrats-as-previously-imagined.html |title=There May Not Be As Many 'Trump Democrats' As Previously Imagined |last=Kilgore |first=Ed |date=2017-08-04 |website=Daily Intelligencer |language=en |access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> [[Nate Cohn]] responded to Milbank's criticism by arguing that Milbank's focus on national data obscured the magnitude of Democratic defection to support Trump. Cohn noted that when looking specifically at white Obama voters with no higher education than a [[high school diploma]], Clinton won only 74% (based on data from the Democracy Fund Voter Study Group) or 78% (based on the [[Cooperative Congressional Election Study]] (CCES)).<ref name=cohn/>
==Voters' views==
Shortly before the 2016 election, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Obama voters who now planned to vote for Trump felt he was now the embodiment of the "change" they had hoped for when they voted for Obama.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/03/us/politics/obama-donald-trump-voting.html |title=Some Who Saw Change in Obama Find It Now in Donald Trump |last=Alcindor |first=Yamiche |date=2016-11-02 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2018-02-25 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Multiple [[focus group]]s of Obama-Trump voters convened by the [[Roosevelt Institute]] and [[Democracy Corps]] in early 2017 showed that, in general, these voters wanted to change the [[status quo]], and had skeptical views of Congressional Republicans and their proposals. The same focus groups also indicated that these voters hoped President Trump would help reduce health care costs for working-class Americans, and that they were anxious about some immigrant groups.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://rooseveltinstitute.org/obama-trump-voters-expect-change-dont-trust-gop/ |title=Focus Group: Obama-to-Trump Voters Expect Change, Don't Trust GOP to Deliver |date=2017-03-15 |website=Roosevelt Institute |language=en-US |access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> A survey conducted by the Democracy Fund Voter Study Group found that Obama-Trump voters generally had liberal views on economic issues, but conservative views on social issues.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/polyarchy/2017/6/16/15817702/democrats-economics-trump-obama-voters |title=Democrats are unlikely to win back Obama-Trump voters. But they should still have an economic agenda to help them. |date=2017-06-16 |website=Vox |access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> Data from the CCES indicate that 75% of Obama-Trump voters supported repealing and replacing the [[Affordable Care Act]].<ref name="Levitz"/>
==Support for President Trump==
A September 2017 poll found that 70% of Obama-Trump voters approved of the job Trump was doing as president. This figure was significantly lower than the 88% approval rating among all Trump voters. Similarly, the percent of voters who disapprove of Trump's performance in this poll was much higher among Obama-Trump voters (22%) than among Trump voters as a whole (9%).<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/09/06/trump-obama-voters-poll-242334 |title=Poll: Obama-Trump voters drifting away from the president |date=2017-09-06 |website=POLITICO |access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>

{{short description|President Trump's policies for physical infrastructure}} {{Donald Trump series}}The '''infrastructure policy of Donald Trump''' includes ensuring U.S. energy independence (by catering to the fossil fuel, nuclear, and renewable energy industry), safeguarding the cybersecurity of the national power grid and other critical infrastructure, locking China out of the U.S. fifth-generation Internet market, and rolling back regulations to ease the process of planning and construction. While there have been no major infrastructure spending packages yet, some individual policies and projects have advanced piecemeal, especially in rural areas.
Although there is recognition of the need to upgrade American infrastructure from both sides of the political aisle, as of April 2020, no major infrastructure bill has been passed due to disagreements over the details of such a spending package, namely, what to spend on, how much to spend, and how to pay for it. 'Infrastructure' is a rather broad term that means different things to different people. In general, the aim of the Trump administration is revitalizing the national economy and enhancing national security despite the tendency of his own Republican Party to oppose large federal expenditures and tax hikes whereas members of the opposition Democratic Party typically favor investing in renewable energy and new infrastructure that could combat climate change, and tend to be less averse to deficit spending.
This article focuses exclusively on physical or [[hard infrastructure]], as opposed to [[soft infrastructure]], or public institutions.
== Views, vision, and standards == Infrastructure development is a priority of the Donald Trump administration. He considers the modernization of American [[infrastructure]] as an extension of his career as a real estate developer and a concrete item to add to his legacy as President.<ref name=":20">{{Cite news|last=|first=|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/05/17/trump-tax-hike-rumors-infrastructure-1331703|title=Trump aides try to quash tax hike rumors amid infrastructure talks|date=May 17, 2019|work=Politico|access-date=June 15, 2019}}</ref> He also views infrastructure investments as a tool to create jobs and to spur economic growth.<ref name=":33">{{Cite news|last=Edwards|first=Hayley Sweetlands|url=https://time.com/4247162/donald-trump-trains-infrastructure/|title=Trump Agrees With Democrats on High-Speed Trains|date=March 4, 2016|work=Time|access-date=September 16, 2019}}</ref> In this 2015 book ''Crippled America'', he cites the Senate Budget Committee estimate that "rebuilding America will create 13 million jobs."<ref name=":33" /> As early as May 2015, one month before launching his presidential campaign, Donald Trump expressed his desire to "fix" America's aging infrastructure,<ref name=":20" /> making it "second to none."<ref name="CSM-infra" /> He expressed concern about the state of American infrastructure on multiple occasions, drawing comparisons with other countries. For example, he stated that American passenger trains were slow compared to those in China and American airports to be dirty and dilapidated next to their counterparts from China, Saudi Arabia, or Qatar.<ref name=":33" /><ref>{{Cite news|last=Laing|first=Keith|url=https://thehill.com/policy/transportation/255554-trump-takes-shot-at-laguardia-airport|title=Trump takes a shot at NYC's LaGuardia Airport|date=September 30, 2015|work=The Hill|access-date=September 16, 2019}}</ref> He acknowledged that modernizing American infrastructure was going to be expensive but argued that in the end, such an investment would pay for itself. In this regard, his position is in line with that of the Democratic Party. President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden had themselves been advocating for more federal infrastructure spending.<ref name=":33" />
Extensive infrastructure spending is a key part of Trump's nationalist and populist economic platform, which also includes opposition to free trade, support for tariffs, and the repatriation of American jobs. This is unusual in the modern Republican Party, which typically endorses free-market or [[Neoliberalism|neoliberal]] economics.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Eatwell|first=Roger|title=National Populism - The Revolt Against Liberal Democracy|last2=Goodwin|first2=Matthew|publisher=Pelican Book|year=2018|isbn=978-0-241-31200-1|location=Great Britain|pages=|chapter=Chapter 2: Promises}}</ref> According to political scientists [[Roger Eatwell]] and [[Matthew Goodwin]], while working-class voters have been leaving the Democratic Party since the 1960s, the popularity of Trump's economic platform suggests there have been sizeable pockets of voters mainstream Republicans failed to reach. However, according to economist [[Robert Reich]], the fact that Trump appears more interested in marketing his brand name rather than pursuing public policy hampers his chances of success.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Eatwell|first=Roger|title=National Populism - The Revolt Against Liberal Democracy|last2=Goodwin|first2=Matthew|publisher=Pelican Book|year=2018|isbn=978-0-241-31200-1|location=Great Britain|pages=|chapter=Chapter 10: Towards Post-populism}}</ref>
On January 31, 2019, Trump issued an executive order encouraging the purchase of U.S.-made construction materials for public infrastructure projects, especially those that need funding from the federal government.<ref name="DJT-eo">Donald J. Trump. [https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/executive-order-strengthening-buy-american-preferences-infrastructure-projects/ Executive Order on Strengthening Buy-American Preferences for Infrastructure Projects]. Issued January 31, 2019.</ref> This followed his 2017 "Buy American, Hire American" executive order restricting the hiring of foreign workers and tightening standards for federal acquisitions. As of February 2019, Canadian officials were negotiating an exemption for their country.<ref name="FP-BAHA">[https://business.financialpost.com/news/economy/trump-signs-new-executive-order-to-strengthen-buy-america-initiative Trump orders agencies to buy U.S.-made steel, aluminum and cement 'to the greatest extent' possible]. ''Financial Post''. February 7, 2019. Accessed February 11, 2019.</ref>
== Environmental reviews of infrastructure projects == In April 2019, President Trump signed two executive orders intended to accelerate energy infrastructure projects. The first makes it harder for oil pipelines and other energy projects to be delayed due to environmental concerns. The second modernizes the approval process for projects crossing international borders. Speaking in front of union workers from the energy industry, the President stated that blocking energy projects "does not just hurt families and workers like you, it undermines our independence and national security."<ref name=":42">{{Cite news|last=Associated Press|first=|date=April 10, 2019|title=Trump signs orders to speed up energy projects|work=NBC News|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-signs-orders-speed-energy-projects-n993236|url-status=live|access-date=April 8, 2020}}</ref>
In early January 2020, the Trump administration announced revisions of the 50-year-old [[National Environmental Policy Act]] (NEPA) that would relax environmental regulations on infrastructure constructions in order to speed them up.<ref>{{Cite news|last=|first=|date=January 9, 2020|title=Trump proposes easing up regulations for major infrastructure projects|work=CBS News|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-proposes-easing-of-environmental-rules-to-speed-up-infrastructure-work-today-2020-01-09-live-stream/|url-status=live|access-date=January 14, 2020}}</ref> Federal agencies would no longer have to take climate change into account when assessing major infrastructure projects and would have to complete their comprehensive environmental reviews in two years. Infrastructure projects that require federal permits but little federal funding are exempt from such reviews. Nor would new projects have to account for "cumulative" effects. In the twenty-first century, this means investigating the effects of greenhouse gas emissions and sea level rise, among other things. In addition, instead of applying for permits from each relevant government agency, only one decision from the government would be necessary. Signed into law in 1970 by President Richard Nixon, NEPA requires the federal government to analyze the environmental impacts of a given infrastructure project in detail. Due to its wide scope, both supporters and opponents believe this is one of the most litigated laws in the United States.<ref name=":39">{{Cite news|last=Friedman|first=Lisa|date=January 3, 2020|title=Trump Rule Would Exclude Climate Change in Infrastructure Planning|work=The New York Times|department=Climate|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/03/climate/trump-nepa-climate-change.html|url-status=live|access-date=January 14, 2020}}</ref><ref name=":40">{{Cite news|last=Brangham|first=William|last2=Harder|first2=Amy|date=January 9, 2020|title=Trump seeks to relax environmental regulation of some infrastructure projects|work=PBS Newshour|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/show/trump-seeks-to-relax-environmental-regulation-of-some-infrastructure-projects|url-status=live|access-date=January 14, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Allassan|first=Fadel|date=January 9, 2020|title=Trump announces rule changes to exempt big projects from environmental review|work=Axios|url=https://www.axios.com/trump-environmental-review-rule-change-09ff8602-4ba2-4fc1-854a-cefa87375637.html|url-status=live|access-date=January 14, 2020}}</ref> NEPA was drafted in response to a [[1969 Santa Barbara oil spill|1969 oil spill off Santa Barbara]], California, that sparked public outcry, and other instances of air, land, and water pollution.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Knickmeyer|first=Ellen|date=January 9, 2020|title=WATCH: Trump unveils proposal that could speed up pipeline projects|work=PBS Newshour|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/watch-live-trump-to-unveil-proposal-that-could-speed-up-pipeline-projects|url-status=live|access-date=January 14, 2020}}</ref> Before 2020, there was only one major change. In 1983, it was decided that the use of worse-case scenarios should be limited.<ref name=":39" />
On the fiftieth anniversary of NEPA, President Trump wrote, "The environmental review process designed to improve decision-making has become increasingly complex and difficult to navigate" because of the "significant uncertainty and delays that can increase costs, derail important projects, and threaten jobs for American workers and labor union members." Trump asserted that the revisions would "benefit our economy and environment." In fact, construction workers' unions have long argued that NEPA has been a burden on energy and public transportation projects.<ref name=":39" /> Although the opponents of these proposed revisions were worried that they would make it easier for the oil and gas industry to build new pipelines, the Trump administration focused on schools and highways, which were probably of greater interest to the American people.<ref name=":40" /> If the proposed revisions survived their legal challenges, environmental activists would no longer be able to halt pipeline construction by litigation, a key tool they have been using since the middle of the Obama administration.<ref name=":39" /><ref name=":40" /> While there have been examples of bureaucracy being burdensome on building projects in the past, such a drastic change would likely invite even more lawsuits.<ref name=":40" />
After 60 days of public hearing, a final regulation can be expected, probably before the 2020 Presidential election.<ref name=":39" /><ref name=":40" />
== Background: State of American infrastructure (2015–2019) == Every four years, the [[American Society of Civil Engineers]] (ASCE) assembles a panel of civil engineers to analyze government data on aviation, bridges, roads, transit, dams, levees, parks, schools, solid waste, drinking water, and waste water.<ref name=":22">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/03/us-infrastructure-is-crumbling-and-it-needs-big-money-to-fix-it-asce.html|title=US infrastructure is crumbling, and it needs lots of money to fix it: Civil engineer group|last=Gillies|first=Trent|date=February 3, 2019|work=CNBC|access-date=June 16, 2019}}</ref> In its 2017 report, the Society gave American infrastructure an overall grade of D+ and recommended a $2 trillion increase in funding for infrastructure over a decade,<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-falls-short-on-infrastructure-after-promising-to-build-roads-bridges-and-consensus/2019/05/26/1027446e-7c9f-11e9-8bb7-0fc796cf2ec0_story.html|title=Trump falls short on infrastructure after promising to build roads, bridges and consensus|last=|first=|date=May 26, 2019|work=The Washington Post|access-date=June 2, 2019}}</ref> half of which for surface transportation, which includes public transit, roads, bridges, and rail.<ref name=":22" /> However, in the [[World Economic Forum]] (WEF) Global Competitiveness Report for 2016-17 the overall quality of American infrastructure jumped from 25th to 12th place out of 138 countries considered.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/measuring-up-u-s-infrastructure-against-other-countries|title=Measuring up U.S. infrastructure against other countries|last=Baroud|first=Hiba|date=February 18, 2018|work=PBS Newshour|access-date=June 2, 2019}}</ref> U.S. infrastructure ranked ninth in the 2017-18 report. Infrastructure is one of the "pillars" of the WEF Global Competitiveness Index.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://reports.weforum.org/global-competitiveness-index-2017-2018/competitiveness-rankings/#series=GCI.A.02|title=Global Competitiveness Index 2017-18. 2nd Pillar: Infrastructure|last=|first=|date=|website=World Economic Forum|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=June 8, 2019}}</ref> Nevertheless, while the U.S. has some of the most resilient infrastructure systems in the world, the situation is deteriorating with time as they are aging and increasingly vulnerable to disruptive events. U.S. infrastructure was built according to standards introduced 50 years ago, and these have become insufficient because of today's more frequent extreme weather events.<ref name=":2" />[[File:Chicago & Northwestern Metra (3474118661).jpg|thumb|Public transit in the U.S. is not as reliable as it is in other developed countries. ''Pictured'': A Chicago commuter train ([[Metra]]).]]
Moreover, current U.S. infrastructure practices do not do a good job of promoting environmental sustainability. [[List of countries by carbon dioxide emissions per capita|Carbon-dioxide emissions per capita]] is higher than that of other industrialized countries, such as France, whose level is three times lower.<ref name=":2" /> Some three quarters of American commuters travel by cars as public transit is not as reliable as it is in other developed countries. American railroads are generally reserved for freight.<ref name=":2" /> Indeed, this is reflected in the 2017 ASCE report, which gave American rail the highest score in all 16 categories; however, the score is brought down because of the quality of [[Public transportation in the United States|U.S. public transit]].<ref name=":22" /> Moreover, the quality and amount of rail per capita is low compared to other developed countries.
