However, it has been mired in multiple [[Criticism of Huawei|controversies]] involving alleged intellectual property theft and espionage.<ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/projects/la-fi-tn-huawei-5g-trade-war/|title=The Man Behind Huawei|last=|first=|date=April 10, 2019|work=The Los Angeles Times|access-date=June 4, 2019}}</ref> After an 11-month investigation, the U.S. House Intelligence Committee found in 2012 that Huawei and ZTE, another Chinese firm, were threats to national security and recommended that U.S. companies refrain from doing business with them.<ref name=":11" /> Under Donald Trump, the U.S. government has been trying to dissuade companies and other governments from around the world from using Huawei's technologies.<ref name=":11" /> In May 2019, the Trump administration added Huawei to the "entity list," which prevents it from acquiring technology from American firms without approval from the U.S. government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-48330310|title=Huawei's use of Android restricted by Google|last=|first=|date=May 20, 2019|work=BBC|access-date=June 4, 2019}}</ref> In October 2019, President Trump met with his Finnish counterpart, [[Sauli Niinistö|Sauli Niinisto]], to discuss alternatives to 5G technology from Huawei. Finland's technology giant [[Nokia]] has developed some 5G capabilities of its own,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-finland-huawei-tech/trump-finnish-president-to-discuss-5g-alternatives-to-chinas-huawei-like-nokia-idUSKBN1WG4AG|title=Trump, Finnish president to discuss 5G options to Huawei|last=|first=|date=October 1, 2019|work=Reuters|access-date=October 14, 2019|department=Technology News}}</ref> and is one of Huawei's chief competitors, alongside Sweden's [[Ericsson]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/06/04/tech/huawei-5g-nokia/index.html|title=Nokia is fighting hard to steal Huawei's 5G crown|last=Pham|first=Sherisse|date=June 4, 2019|work=CNN|access-date=October 14, 2019|department=Business}}</ref> In December 2017, telecommunications firms from around the world agreed upon a set of global standards for 5G so that the technology can be easily implemented. The race was on for the various equipment manufacturers for global dominance, including Huawei and ZTE from China, Nokia, Ericsson, Qualcomm and Intel (both from the U.S.). 5G is a key part of the geopolitical fault lines created by Donald Trump's desire to "make America great again" and China's stated goal of becoming a global hegemony in artificial intelligence by 2030; this technological race is a part of the U.S.-China trade war.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/06/a-major-factor-behind-the-us-china-trade-war-is-winning-in-a-crucial-t.html|title=A major factor behind the US-China trade war is winning at a $12 trillion technology — 5G|last=Kharpal|first=Arjun|date=June 6, 2018|work=CNBC|access-date=October 14, 2019|department=Tech}}</ref>
=== Telehealth === In late March 2020, President Trump signed into law a stimulus package worth around two trillion dollars, the biggest in American history, in order to alleviate the economic downturn due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic in the United States]]. Besides cash infusion for front-line hospitals, loans for struggling industries, aid for farmers, enhanced unemployment benefits, relief for married couples with young children, and tax cuts for retailers, it included $200 million for [[Telehealth|telemedicine]]. This would help doctors examine their patients remotely, using video-conferencing technology. At present, the FCC operates a rural healthcare program that subsidizes the use of telecommunications technology. FCC Chairman Ajit Pai personally requested this aid in early March.<ref name=":41">{{Cite news|last=Emma|first=Caitlin|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2020/03/25/whats-in-stimulus-package-coronavirus-149282|title=Here's what's in the $2 trillion stimulus package — and what's next|date=March 25, 2020|work=Politico|access-date=April 8, 2020|url-status=live|last2=Scholtes|first2=Jennifer}}</ref> Early that month, the President signed a bipartisan bill that extended Medicare coverage to include telemedicine in outbreak areas. Previously, it was restricted to rural residents who had to take long trips to see a doctor. Telemedicine reduces the need for travel, and therefore chances of vulnerable senior citizens catching COVID-19.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Alonso-Zaldivar|first=Ricardo|url=https://apnews.com/cd2b26c1d52f27146aad011b07a5f245|title=As coronavirus spreads, Medicare gets telemedicine option|date=March 6, 2020|work=Associated Press|access-date=April 14, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref>
==Transportation== {{See also|Transportation in the United States}}
=== Canals, ports, and harbors === The America's Water Infrastructure Act, signed into law by President Trump in October 2018 authorizes $6 billion in spending. Potential recipients for federal funding include the Houston-Galveston Navigation Channel Extension ($15.6 million), and the [[Ala Wai Canal]] project in Hawaii ($306.5 million). This bill includes a five-year "Buy American" provision, which requires the use of American-made construction materials used by projects funded by the Act.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Slowey|first=Kim|date=October 26, 2018|title=Trump authorizes $6B of water infrastructure projects|work=Construction Dive|url=https://www.constructiondive.com/news/trump-authorizes-6b-of-water-infrastructure-projects/540576/|url-status=live|access-date=May 24, 2020}}</ref>
===Civil aviation=== [[File:American Airlines Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner (N805AN) at LAX (22922365062).jpg|thumb|Some airliners are spending their own money on airport facilities. ''Pictured'': An American Airlines Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner at LAX.]] Shortly after taking office in 2017, Donald Trump unveiled an infrastructure plan worth a trillion dollars that includes a $2.4-billion cut to federal transportation programs. This plan would eliminate subsidies for long-distance trains and commercial flights to rural communities with limited transportation options, including those that helped Trump win the presidency. He wanted to relieve the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) of air traffic control and to turn it into a private nonprofit corporation.<ref>[https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/white-house/article138839948.html Trump proposes deep transportation cuts in rural regions that supported him]. McClathcy DC Bureau. March 16, 2017. Accessed February 14, 2019.</ref>
In June 2019, the FAA announced it was giving out $840 million in grants for improving airport facilities and President Trump proposed $17.1 billion in funding for the FAA. Trump's proposal made it through the House Appropriations Committee with $614 million more than requested. Therefore, the FAA had $17.7 billion to spend. [[Airport Improvement Program]]s (AIP) funds will go to over 380 airports in 47 states. One of the biggest grants is worth $29 million, which goes to runway reconstruction at [[Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport]] in Alaska. In addition, the House Appropriations Committee announced $3.3 billion in AIP grants to be handed out in 2020, plus $500 million for discretionary airport infrastructure spending.<ref name=":25">{{Cite news|url=https://www.constructiondive.com/news/faa-sees-177b-proposed-for-2020-allocates-840m-grants/556603/|title=FAA sees $17.7B proposed for 2020, allocates $840M grants|last=Slowey|first=Kim|date=June 11, 2019|work=Construction Dive|access-date=June 21, 2019}}</ref>
Some airliners themselves have been financing airport capital projects on their own. For example, [[American Airlines]] and [[Delta Air Lines|Delta]] have committed $1.6 billion and $1.8 billion, respectively, to modernize the facilities they use at the [[Los Angeles International Airport]] (LAX). Delta allocated another four billion dollars to the construction of a new terminal at the [[LaGuardia Airport|LaGuardia International Airport]] in New York City. At the same time, a number of airports are willing to spend money on their own facilities in order to reap the long-term economic benefits. In May 2019, the [[Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport|Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport]] (DFW) announced it would spend some $3.5 billion on a new terminal and on renovating an existing terminal for American Airlines, which uses the airport as one of its main hubs in the U.S.<ref name=":25" />
In early 2020, American airports saw their passenger numbers plummet due to the COVID-19 global pandemic. To help them cope with the crisis, the Trump administration provided $10 billion in financial aid with Congressional approval.<ref name=":43" />
===Public transportation=== In 2018, the Trump administration rolled out an infrastructure plan that allocates one quarter of the money available to rural areas, even though only 14% of Americans live there. This spells trouble for numerous large-scale urban projects and undermines aging [[Public transit|transit]] networks in large established cities such as Chicago or New York City, which need significant funds for repairs, maintenance, and modernization, because it favors new construction.<ref group="note">This does not mean such cities have no need or plans for transit expansions. See, for example, the Chicago "L" [[Chicago "L"#Red Line extension|Red Line Extension]].</ref> Another key aspect of this policy is that it relegates primary funding responsibility to local authorities and the private sector. Trump's aim with this funding policy is to realize his promise during the 2016 presidential campaign to bring jobs to rural areas, where employment prospects have been dim, and to transfer wealth from states that tend to vote Democrat to those that helped him win the election.<ref>[https://www.politico.com/story/2018/02/12/trump-infrastructure-blue-states-transit-405993 Trump takes aim at blue states in infrastructure plan]. Politico. February 12, 2018. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref> According to an analysis of data from the [[United States Department of Transportation|Department of Transportation]] by McClatchy, the Trump administration has been prioritizing rural transportation projects. Whereas the Obama administration directed 80% of the money from the Transportation Investment Generating Economic Recovery (TIGER) program to urban projects, under Trump, rural areas got 70% in funding, as of 2019.<ref name=":26">{{Cite news|url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/politics-government/congress/article231720058.html|title=Trump states and rural areas grab bigger chunk of transportation grant funds|last=|first=|date=June 21, 2019|work=McClatchy DC Bureau|access-date=June 22, 2019}}</ref> For example, funding for a proposed [[KC Streetcar|Kansas City Streetcar]] extension was rejected twice by the Trump administration, but money for a highway [[Interchange (road)|interchange]] in nearby [[Wyandotte County, Kansas|Wyandotte County]], turned down by the Obama administration, was granted. The Trump administration explained that this shift in priorities is to give rural areas their "fair share" in funding for transportation projects and to re-balance the "historic under-investment in rural America." In fact, while South Carolina received only 15% of what they requested under Obama, under Trump, they received 100%. Moreover, Alaska, Nebraska, Arkansas and Wyoming received more funding in the first two years of Donald Trump than they did under the entire presidency of Barack Obama whereas California, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Washington, New York and Illinois, states where Hillary Clinton won, got considerably less money.<ref name=":26" /> [[File:Construction at Hudson Yards (14794824672).jpg|thumb|360x360px|Construction at Hudson Yards, Manhattan, New York City.|alt=]]
The [[Gateway Program (Northeast Corridor)|Gateway Program]] is a plan to modernize railroad infrastructure between New York and New Jersey and to double the number of trains passing between those two states. This plan includes repairs to the old North River Tunnel, and the construction of the new Hudson Tunnel.<ref>[https://nec.amtrak.com/project/the-gateway-program/ The Gateway Program]. Amtrak Northeast Corridor. Accessed February 11, 2019.</ref> Existing tunnels between New Jersey and New York are over a century old and were seriously damaged by [[Hurricane Sandy]] in 2012. These rail tunnels and the bus terminals are currently operating at full capacity,<ref name="NYT-Hudson" /> as are the ferries and roads.<ref name=":19" /> They are used by both [[Amtrak]] (intercity rail) and [[NJ Transit]] (regional rapid transit). If these tunnels were not thoroughly repaired and a new tunnel was not built on time, the number of trains crossing the Hudson River during rush hours could drop from 24 to just six, with dire consequences for the regional economy.<ref name="NYT-Hudson" /> In fact, the Northeast Corridor is the most heavily traveled railway in the nation<ref>[https://nec.amtrak.com/news/gateway-program-development-corporation-releases-request-for-information-for-hudson-tunnel-project/ REQUEST FOR INFORMATION FOR HUDSON TUNNEL PROJECT]. Amtrak Northeast Corridor. August 10, 2017. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref> and the region is responsible for 20% of U.S. GDP.<ref name=":19" /> Experts estimate that if the Northeast Corridor was closed for just one day, it would cost the U.S. economy $100 million in lost economic activity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.crainsnewyork.com/op-ed/we-must-build-gateway-and-we-will|title=We must build Gateway—and we will (Op-ed)|last=DeFazio|first=Peter|date=May 31, 2019|website=Crain's New York Business|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=June 15, 2019}}</ref> The Obama administration tried but failed to fund the project in time. The Obama plan would have 50% of the funding coming from the federal government and the rest from the state governments of New York and New Jersey.<ref name="NYT-Hudson">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/08/nyregion/obama-administration-urges-quick-action-on-hudson-river-rail-tunnels.html |title=Obama Administration Urges Fast Action on New Hudson River Rail Tunnels |last=McGeehan |first=Patrick |date=May 7, 2015 |work=The New York Times |access-date=May 12, 2015}}</ref>
Although he was initially in favor of the Gateway Project, Trump later turned against it and urged fellow Republicans to cut funding for it.<ref name=":18">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/trump-pushes-republicans-to-oppose-crucial-new-york-new-jersey-tunnel-project/2018/03/02/06987446-1e6c-11e8-9de1-147dd2df3829_story.html |title=Trump pushes Republicans to oppose crucial New York-New Jersey tunnel project |last=DeBonis |first=Mike |date=March 2, 2018 |work=Washington Post |access-date=March 4, 2018 |last2=Dawsey |first2=Josh |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> Moreover, he dismissed the project as a local one that lacks national importance<ref name=":19">{{Cite news|url=https://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Subway-extension-to-New-Jersey-could-speed-13901393.php|title=Subway extension to New Jersey could speed commute for thousands|last=Goldman|first=Henry|date=May 28, 2019|work=Bloomberg (via SFGate)|access-date=June 15, 2019}}</ref> and a potential boondoggle.<ref name=":18" /> He subsequently cut money from the funds for the Gateway Program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newyork.cbslocal.com/2019/03/12/gateway-project-hudson-river-tunnel-north-river-tunnel-new-york-new-jersey/|title=N.Y., N.J. Lawmakers Scramble For Backup Plan After Trump 2020 Budget Cuts Money From Gateway Project Fund|last=|first=|date=March 12, 2019|work=CBS New York|access-date=June 24, 2019}}</ref> While supporters of the Gateway Project argue that it is one of the nation's most pressing infrastructure needs,<ref name=":19" /> opponents are wary of additional federal spending and the fact that money will be taken away from smaller projects for their districts.<ref name=":18" /> In response to federal inaction, an alternative has been proposed: [[7 Subway Extension#Extension to New Jersey|extending a subway line from New York to New Jersey]]. Under the plan, the [[New York City Subway]]'s [[IRT Flushing Line]] ({{NYCS trains|Flushing}}, currently connecting [[Flushing, Queens]], to [[Hudson Yards (neighborhood), Manhattan|Hudson Yards, Manhattan]]) would go under the Hudson River to an intermodal terminal in [[Secaucus, New Jersey]]. It was estimated to cost $6 billion in 2013, half of that of the Gateway program. However, it may not be enough as a replacement for Gateway.<ref name=":19" /> In late June 2019, the state governments of New York and New Jersey passed legislation to create the bi-state Gateway Development Commission, whose job it is to oversee the planning, funding and construction of the rail tunnels and bridges of Gateway Program. This bill stipulates that each state is responsible for 50% of the funding and creates standards for transparency and accountability. The Commission is capable of receiving funds from federal, state, and local sources.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.masstransitmag.com/rail/infrastructure/article/21085913/bistate-legislation-passed-to-establish-gateway-development-commission|title=Bi-state legislation passed to establish Gateway Development Commission|last=Wanek-Libman|first=Mischa|date=June 24, 2019|work=Mass Transit Magazine|access-date=June 24, 2019}}</ref>
Related to the Gateway Program is the [[Portal Bridge]] Replacement Project. Going over the Hackensack River in Northern New Jersey, the Portal Bridge is a two-track moveable [[Swing bridge|swing-span]] rail bridge that is a key piece of infrastructure in the Northeast Corridor. According to Amtrak and NJ Transit, intercity and regional trains carrying a total of 150,000 to 200,000 passengers cross the bridge each weekday. However, because the Portal Bridge is over a century old, it does not always function properly. Delays arise when the bridge fails to close completely.<ref name=":46">{{Cite news|last=Porter|first=David|date=November 15, 2014|title=New Jersey’s Portal Bridge, bane of the Northeast Corridor, is due for upgrade|work=The Washington Post|department=Politics|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/new-jerseys-portal-bridge-bane-of-the-northeast-corridor-is-due-for-upgrade/2014/11/15/36c34662-6d1e-11e4-a31c-77759fc1eacc_story.html|url-status=live|access-date=May 24, 2020}}</ref> Amtrak and NJ Transit reported that between 2014 and 2018, 85 delays occurred, each lasting for two hours at least.<ref name=":47">{{Cite news|last=|first=|date=February 11, 2020|title=New Jersey’s Portal Bridge OK’d For Federal Funds, But Gateway Project Doesn’t Make Cut|work=CBS New York|url=https://newyork.cbslocal.com/2020/02/11/portal-bridge-gateway-project-funding/|url-status=live|access-date=May 24, 2020}}</ref> Its proposed replacement would be a fixed structure standing 50 feet (15.24 meters) above mean high water, or twice the current height, thereby eliminating the need for openings. While it would not be able to accommodate additional trains, it would allow trains to cross at 90 mph (144 km/h) instead of just 60 mph (96 km/h).<ref name=":46" /> In February 2020, the [[Federal Transit Administration]] (FTA) raised the rating of the project from medium-low to medium-high, making it eligible for federal funding and allowing it to enter the engineering phase. It is set to receive $1.7 billion from the federal government. The New Jersey Department of Transportation estimated that once construction begins in full swing, the project would take about five years to complete.<ref name=":47" />[[File:Purple Line groundbreaking IMG 6385 (36872222485).jpg|thumb|Groundbreaking ceremony for Maryland's Purple Line in August 2017.]] Federal funding for smaller projects, such as $900 million for the Washington Metro's Purple Line, was approved.<ref>[https://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20171229/POLITICS/171229921/trump-administration-kills-gateway-tunnel-deal Trump administration kills Gateway tunnel deal]. Crain's New York. December 28, 2017. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref> However, Trump's highly ambitious infrastructure spending plan stalled due to fierce opposition from Democrats who took issue with the fact that Trump preferred private funding and highways to federal funding and public transit. Of the projected $1.5 trillion, the federal government would spend only $200 billion.<ref>[https://thehill.com/policy/transportation/388071-trumps-infrastructure-plan-hits-a-dead-end Trump's infrastructure plan hits a dead end]. ''The Hill''. May 17, 2018. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref> Under the Obama administration, funding for transit on one hand and for highways and bridges on the other hand were roughly equal. Under the Trump administration, some 70% of the funding would go to highways and bridges and only about 11% to transit.<ref>[https://usa.streetsblog.org/2018/12/12/tiger-is-a-roads-program-now/ Trump Turns Obama-Era Program into a Road Fund]. Streetblog USA. December 12, 2018. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref>
In February 2019, Governor [[Gavin Newsom]] reduced the scale of the [[California High-Speed Rail|California High-speed Rail]] project, from {{convert|520|mi}} linking Los Angeles to San Francisco down to {{convert|119|mi}} between Merced and Bakersfield, in response to spiraling costs. The State of California estimated the cost of Phase I of the project to be $77 billion, up $13 billion, but warned that the total cost could reach $100 billion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-california-rail/u-s-cancels-929-million-in-california-high-speed-rail-funds-after-appeal-rejected-idUSKCN1SM2F9|title=U.S. cancels $929 million in California high speed rail funds after appeal rejected|last=Shepardson|first=David|date=May 16, 2019|work=Reuters|access-date=June 2, 2019}}</ref> In fact, the project has been mired in cost overruns and delays. Moreover, even though it was initially planned to have one third of the funding from the private sector, the project failed to raise any funds from that source.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/12/californias-77-billion-high-speed-rail-project-is-in-trouble.html|title=California's $77 billion 'bullet train to nowhere' faces a murky future as political opposition ramps up|last=Daniels|first=Jeff|date=March 12, 2019|work=CNBC|access-date=June 15, 2019}}</ref> In May 2019, the Trump administration cancels $929 million in funding for the construction of the railway, whose trains could travel at speeds of up to {{convert|200|mph}}.<ref name=":30" /> In a statement, the [[Federal Railroad Administration]] (FRA) wrote that the [[California High-Speed Rail Authority|California High-speed Rail Authority]] (CHSRA) "has failed to make reasonable progress on the Project" and "has abandoned its original vision of a high-speed passenger rail service connecting San Francisco and Los Angeles, which was essential to its applications for FRA grant funding."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalrailwayreview.com/news/82242/trump-pulls-california-high-speed-funding/|title=Trump administration withdraws funding from California's high-speed rail|last=De Clerk|first=Eve|date=May 17, 2019|work=Global Railway Review|access-date=July 14, 2019}}</ref> As of June 2019, the project found itself under investigation for financial malpractice.<ref name=":30">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcbayarea.com/investigations/Probe-to-Examine-Alleged-Sweetheart-Deals-Tied-to-California-High-Speed-Rail-Project-510841411.html|title=Probe to Examine Alleged 'Sweetheart Deals' Tied to California High Speed Rail Project|last=Stock|first=Stephen|date=June 4, 2019|work=NBC Bay Area|access-date=June 15, 2019}}</ref> However, in July 2019, the Trump administration authorized the State of California to assume responsibility for ensuring the project is in compliance with federal environmental protection regulations, thereby lifting a major hurdle.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fresnobee.com/news/local/high-speed-rail/article233115545.html|title=Bullet train clears hurdle as Trump administration OKs state environmental oversight|last=Sheehan|first=Tim|date=July 25, 2019|work=The Fresno Bee|access-date=July 30, 2019}}</ref>
In June 2019, the FRA announced $326 million in funding for rail infrastructure upgrades for 45 projects in 29 states. These grants come under the Consolidated Rail Infrastructure and Safety Improvement (CRISI) Program, authorized by [[Fixing America's Surface Transportation Act]], and the Special Transportation Circumstances Program. One third of that amount will go to rural areas.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globalrailwayreview.com/news/83697/fra-grants-improve-infrastructure/|title=FRA announces investments to improve U.S. railroad infrastructure|last=|first=|date=June 14, 2019|work=Global Railway Review|access-date=July 14, 2019}}</ref>
In early April 2020, the Trump administration issued $25 billion in emergency funding for public transportation networks across the United States facing a precipitous drop in ridership due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Approved a week prior by Congress, the money would go primarily to densely populated urban areas, including $5.4 billion for New York City, $1.2 billion for Los Angeles, $1.02 billion for the District of Columbia, $883 million for Boston, $879 million for Philadelphia, $820 million for San Francisco and $520 million for Seattle. Meanwhile, some $2.2 billion would go to rural areas, the FTA announced. National passenger rail company Amtrak received a billion dollars.<ref name=":43">{{Cite news|last=Shepardson|first=David|date=April 2, 2020|title=Trump administration awards $25 billion in emergency transit funding|work=Reuters|department=Politics|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-transit-idUSKBN21K2JW|url-status=live|access-date=May 12, 2020}}</ref>
=== Priority transportation infrastructure projects === 50 large infrastructure projects with a total worth of $137 billion were prioritized in 2017. In order to qualify, a project must enhance national security, improve public safety, have 30% of its design complete, and be ready for construction.<ref name="GCR-Trump">[http://www.globalconstructionreview.com/news/trump-makes-137bn-lis7t-emerg7ency-infrastru7cture/ Trump makes $137bn list of “emergency” infrastructure schemes, all needing private finance]. Global Construction Review. January 30, 2018. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref> The following list taken from the top ten civil engineering projects that pertain to transportation. They are all public-private partnerships.<ref name="GCR-Trump" />
*[[File:86th Street Second Av. Subway Station Unveiled (31863534822).jpg|thumb|Phase I of the New York Second Avenue Subway entered service in early 2017.]][[Second Avenue Subway]], New York City, $14.2 billion. Phase 1 was completed on January 1, 2017.<ref>[https://www.amny.com/transit/second-avenue-subway-a-priority-for-trump-rep-maloney-says-1.13020262 Second Avenue subway a priority for Trump, Rep. Maloney says]. ''am New York''. Updated January 26, 2018. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref> Phase II is underway.<ref>[https://www.crainsnewyork.com/transportation/milestone-reached-second-avenue-subway-project Milestone reached in Second Avenue subway project]. Crain's New York. November 19, 2018. Accessed February 10, 2019.</ref> There are four phases total. When completed, the Second Avenue Subway would be {{convert|8.6|mi}} long with 16 stations and an estimated daily ridership of 560,000.<ref name="GCR-Trump" /> [[History of the Second Avenue Subway|First proposed in 1919]], this is the first major [[New York City Subway]] expansion in over half a century. The stations feature climate controls, wheelchair accessibility, wireless Internet, escalators, and elevators.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.amny.com/transit/the-second-avenue-subway-explained-1.11244882|title=The Second Avenue subway explained|last=|first=|date=March 19, 2018|work=am New York|access-date=June 22, 2019|department=Transit}}</ref> * Gateway Program, New York and New Jersey, $12 billion.<ref name="GCR-Trump" /> This project is described in detail above. * [[Texas Central Railway]], $12 billion. This is the {{convert|241|mi|adj=on}} private [[high-speed rail]] line that connects Houston to Dallas and cuts travel time from four and a half hours to just 90 minutes. At present, some 50,000 people travel along that route each week on the road.<ref name="GCR-Trump" /><ref name=":31">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wfaa.com/article/news/the-texas-bullet-train-now-looks-likely-heres-what-to-expect/287-617806536|title=The Texas bullet train now looks likely. Here's what to expect|last=Whitely|first=Jason|date=November 28, 2018|work=WFAA|access-date=July 28, 2019}}</ref> Its rolling stock will consist of the export version of the [[N700 Series Shinkansen|N-700 Series]] bullet train from Japan.<ref name=":31" /> * [[Washington Union Station]] Expansion and Refurbishment, District of Columbia, $8.7 billion. This is the second busiest train station in the United States and one of its national treasures. The project aims to renovate the concourse, temporarily closed in 1981 due to the risk of structural collapse, and the surrounding railways.<ref name="GCR-Trump" /> Scheduled to begin in Fall 2019, work will double the passenger capacity of Amtrak's concourse and will improve access between it and the Washington Metro's station.<ref name=":34" /> Amtrak said revitalizing the concourse will take about three years because the work "must be phased in order to avoid an unacceptable level of degradation to passenger capacity and retail disruption, while maintaining passenger access to train gates, Metrorail, and bus deck during construction."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dc.curbed.com/2019/1/7/18172532/dc-union-station-amtrak-concourse-renovations-transportation|title=Union Station Amtrak concourse to get more passenger space and other renovations by 2022|last=Glambrone|first=Andrew|date=January 7, 2019|work=Curbed Washington DC|access-date=October 14, 2019}}</ref> This intermodal transportation hub serves 100,000 passengers daily and is the busiest entryway to the Metro, with 28,000 riders each day, many of whom transfer from intercity rail, commuter rail, or buses.<ref name=":34">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/union-station-prepares-for-a-concourse-makeover/2019/01/12/2b3a772e-1383-11e9-b6ad-9cfd62dbb0a8_story.html|title=Union Station prepares for a concourse makeover|last=Lazo|first=Luz|date=January 12, 2019|work=The Washington Post|access-date=October 14, 2019|department=Transportation}}</ref> *15 bridges on [[Interstate 95 in Pennsylvania]], $8 billion. All of them need to be rebuilt or replaced urgently. Tolling might be introduced, though this suggestion has proved to be controversial.<ref name="GCR-Trump" /> *[[File:Washington Metro diagram sb.pdf|thumb|Diagram of the Washington Metro.]][[Purple Line (Maryland)|Purple Line]], Maryland, $5.6 billion. This railway adds {{convert|16|mi}} to the [[Washington Metro]]. This project was scheduled to go ahead regardless of election results.<ref name="GCR-Trump" /> Construction began in August 2017 and the Line is expected to open in October 2022.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/transportation/2018/09/27/purple-line-set-open-fall-despite-year-long-delay-construction-start-maryland-official-says|title=Purple Line set to open in fall of 2022, despite year-long delay in construction start, Maryland official says|last=Shaver|first=Katharine|date=September 27, 2019|work=The Washington Post|access-date=June 2, 2019}}</ref> The Purple Line enables passengers to access the Red, Green, and Orange Lines of the Washington Metro without having to travel through central Washington, D.C. (See diagram on the right.) *[[Gordie Howe International Bridge]], $4.5 billion, between [[Detroit]], Michigan and [[Windsor, Ontario]]. This cable-stayed bridge will connect the U.S. state of Michigan to the Canadian province of Ontario, allowing for more traffic to flow between the two neighbors and reducing dependence on the Ambassador Bridge, which currently carries 2.5 million cargo trucks per year, or 30% of truck traffic between Canada and the U.S.<ref name="GCR-Trump" /> The Bridging North America consortium, created to build and maintain the bridge, estimated that the project will create 2,500 jobs. There will be a multi-purpose path for pedestrians and cyclists and three lanes for vehicles in each direction. Construction commenced in October 2018 and is scheduled to complete in late 2024.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/windsor/gordie-howe-bridge-construction-1.4842489|title=$3.8B to build Gordie Howe bridge, complete by end of 2024|last=|first=|date=September 28, 2018|work=CBC News|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref> Once completed, it will be 853 m (0.53 mi) across and 2.5 km (1.56 mi) long, making it the longest [[cable-stayed bridge]] in North America.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/windsor/windsor-detroit-bridge-authority-bridging-north-america-1.4734671|title=Gordie Howe bridge will be the longest cable-stayed bridge in North America|last=|first=|date=July 5, 2018|work=CBC News|access-date=October 17, 2019}}</ref>
==Water management== In October 2018, President Trump signed into law the [[America's Water Infrastructure Act of 2018]], allocating more than $6 billion on water infrastructure spending of all kinds.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Birnbaum|first=Emily|date=October 10, 2018|title=Trump poised to sign bipartisan water infrastructure bill|work=The Hill|url=https://thehill.com/policy/transportation/410824-trump-to-sign-bipartisan-water-infrastructure-bill|url-status=live|access-date=May 17, 2020}}</ref> This bipartisan bill authorizes the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to manage water resource projects and policies nationwide. It also authorizes federal funding for various water infrastructure projects, including the expansion of water storage capabilities, and upgrades to wastewater, drinking and irrigation systems.<ref>[https://www.cnn.com/2018/10/23/politics/america-water-infrastructure-act-donald-trump-signing/index.html Trump signs bipartisan water infrastructure spending law]. CNN. October 23, 2018. Accessed February 14, 2019.</ref> This bill includes some $2.2 billion for a coastal barrier Texas, protecting it from flood in the future. The coastal barrier includes not just flood walls and sea walls but also pumping stations, drainage facilities, and floodgates for highways and railroads. The money may also be used for ecosystem repair, upgrades to port and inland waterways, flood control, dam renovations, and enhancing drinking water facilities. Moreover, the Act reauthorizes the Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act loan program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.constructiondive.com/news/texas-chosen-army-corps-coastal-barrier-plan-could-cost-up-to-32b/541035/|title=Texas' chosen Army Corps coastal barrier plan could cost up to $32B|last=Slowey|first=Kim|date=November 1, 2019|work=Construction Dive|access-date=July 7, 2019}}</ref>
In April 2019, after signing two executive orders on energy infrastructure projects, President Trump said he would order the Environmental Protection Agency to issue guidelines for state compliance with the [[Clean Water Act]].<ref name=":42" />
In May 2019, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) made $2.6 billion available for water infrastructure improvement across the United States. According to the Agency's own estimates, some $743 billion is needed, and the State Resolving Funds (SRFs), which require states to match federal funding and repay loans and interests, have provided $170 billion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-announces-availability-26-billion-new-funding-improve-water-infrastructure-across-0|title=EPA Announces Availability of $2.6 Billion in New Funding to Improve Water Infrastructure Across the United States|last=Senn|first=John|date=May 8, 2019|work=United States Environmental Protection Agency|access-date=June 3, 2019}}</ref>

{{Further|Impeachment of Donald Trump|Impeachment trial of Donald Trump}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Short description|Inquiry or investigations relating to a possible impeachment of U.S. President Donald Trump}} {{Use American English|date=October 2019}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2020}} {{Infobox impeachment process | image = Open Hearing with Dr. Fiona Hill and David Holmes.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = Open hearing testimony of [[Fiona Hill (presidential advisor)|Fiona Hill]] and [[David Holmes (diplomat)|David Holmes]] on November 21, 2019 | accused = [[Donald Trump]], 45th President of the United States | proponents = {{plainlist| * [[Nancy Pelosi]]
([[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House of Representatives]]) * [[Adam Schiff]]
(Chair of the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|House Intelligence Committee]]) * [[Jerry Nadler]]
(Chair of the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|House Judiciary Committee]]) }} | period = September 24 – December 3, 2019 ({{Age in years, months, weeks and days|2019|9|24|2019|12|3}}) | outcome = [[Impeachment in the United States|Impeachment]] inquiry completed; House Judiciary Committee approved two articles of impeachment | accusations = {{ubl|[[Abuse of power]]|[[Contempt of Congress|Obstruction of Congress]]}} | cause = [[Trump–Ukraine scandal|Allegations that Trump sought help from Ukrainian authorities]] to favor him in the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 U.S. presidential election]] | header_votes = Congressional votes | vote1 = Voting in the House Judiciary Committee | accusation1 = First article—abuse of power | votes_favor1 = 23 | votes_against1 = 17 | result1 = Approved | accusation2 = Second article—obstruction of Congress | votes_favor2 = 23 | votes_against2 = 17 | result2 = Approved | notes = The House voted on December 18, 2019, to [[Impeachment of Donald Trump|impeach Donald Trump]] on both charges. }} {{Trump–Ukraine scandal}} The '''impeachment inquiry against Donald Trump''', the incumbent [[president of the United States]], was initiated by [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|House Speaker]] [[Nancy Pelosi]] on September 24, 2019, after a [[whistleblower]] alleged that [[Donald Trump]] may have [[abuse of power|abused the power]] of the presidency. Trump was accused of withholding military aid as [[Trump–Ukraine scandal|a means of pressuring]] newly elected president of Ukraine [[Volodymyr Zelensky]] to pursue investigations of [[Joe Biden]] and his son [[Hunter Biden|Hunter]]{{efn|During the hearings, [[Gordon Sondland]] testified that Trump only wanted Ukraine to announce such an investigation and that it did not actually need to be performed.{{cite news |last1=Dibble |first1=Madison |title=Sondland: Trump only wanted Ukraine to announce investigation into Biden, not start real inquiry |url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/sondland-trump-only-wanted-ukraine-to-announce-investigation-into-biden-not-a-real-inquiry |accessdate=December 12, 2019 |work=Washington Examiner |date=November 20, 2019}}}} and to investigate [[Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal#CrowdStrike|a conspiracy theory]] that Ukraine, not Russia, was behind [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|interference in the 2016 presidential election]]. More than a week after Trump had put a hold on the previously approved aid,{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/president-trump-repeats-criticism-of-biden-in-impromptu-u-n-appearance-11569254230 |title=Trump Put Hold on Military Aid Ahead of Phone Call With Ukraine's President |last=Ballhaus |first=Rebecca |date=September 24, 2019 |last2=Restuccia |first2=Andrew |last3=Hughes |first3=Siobhan |url-access=subscription |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=October 2, 2019}}{{efn|Intended to help Ukraine in its [[War in Donbass|war against Russian-backed separatist forces in Donbass]]}} he made these requests in a July 25 phone call with the Ukrainian president,{{cite web |title=Telephone Conversation with President Zelenskyy of Ukraine |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Unclassified09.2019.pdf |website=WhiteHouse.gov |accessdate=December 10, 2019 |date=September 24, 2019}} which the whistleblower said was intended to help [[Donald Trump 2020 presidential campaign|Trump's reelection bid]].{{cite web |last=Carter |first=Brandon |title=READ: House Intel Committee Releases Whistleblower Complaint On Trump-Ukraine Call |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/09/26/764071379/read-house-intel-releases-whistleblower-complaint-on-trump-ukraine-call |website=NPR.org |accessdate=December 10, 2019 |date=September 26, 2019}} Believing critical military aid would be revoked, Zelensky made plans to announce investigations into the Bidens on the September 13 episode of [[CNN]]'s ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/07/world/europe/ukraine-trump-zelensky.html|title=Ukraine's Zelensky Bowed to Trump's Demands, Until Luck Spared Him|last=Kramer|first=Andrew E.|date=November 7, 2019|work=The New York Times|publisher=A. G. Sulzberger|OCLC=1645522|access-date=November 26, 2019|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} After Trump was told of the whistleblower complaint in late August{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/26/us/politics/trump-whistle-blower-complaint-ukraine.html|title=Trump Knew of Whistle-Blower Complaint When He Released Aid to Ukraine|first1=Michael S.|last1=Schmidt|first2=Julian E.|last2=Barnes|first3=Maggie|last3=Haberman|date=November 26, 2019|work=The New York Times|publisher=A. G. Sulzberger|ISSN=1553-8095|OCLC=1645522}} and elements of the events had begun to leak, the aid was released on September 11 and the planned interview was cancelled. Trump [[Declassified documents|declassified]] a non-verbatim summary of the call on September 24,{{Cite news |last1=Bajak |first1=Frank |title=Why Trump asked Ukraine's president about 'CrowdStrike' |url=https://apnews.com/aa1f66a1770d4995a6bada960a7d119e |accessdate=November 6, 2019 |work=Associated Press News |date=October 17, 2019}} the day the impeachment inquiry began. The whistleblower's complaint was given to [[United States Congress|Congress]] the following day and subsequently released to the public.{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/26/biggest-bombshells-in-trump-whistleblower-complaint-cover-up.html |title=An alleged cover-up, a secret server and more bombshells in Trump whistleblower complaint |last=Mangan |first=Dan |date=September 26, 2019 |website=[[CNBC]]|access-date=September 28, 2019}} The [[White House]] corroborated several of the allegations, including that a record of the call between Trump and Zelensky had been stored in a highly restricted system in the White House normally reserved for [[Classified information in the United States|classified information]]. In October, three congressional committees ([[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|Intelligence]], [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Reform|Oversight]], and [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|Foreign Affairs]]) deposed witnesses including Ukraine ambassador [[William B. Taylor Jr.|Bill Taylor]],{{Cite news |first=Stefan |last=Becket |first2=Arden |last2=Farhi |first3=Kathryn |last3=Watson |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/bill-taylor-opening-statement-read-the-full-text-of-the-top-us-diplomats-statement-to-congress/ |title=Top diplomat tells lawmakers Ukraine aid was directly tied to investigations |date=October 23, 2019 |work=[[CBS News]] |url-status=live |access-date=October 24, 2019 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20191108195849/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/bill-taylor-opening-statement-read-the-full-text-of-the-top-us-diplomats-statement-to-congress/ |archivedate=November 8, 2019}} [[Laura Cooper]] (the top [[Pentagon building|Pentagon]] official overseeing Ukraine-related U.S. policy),{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/laura-cooper-pentagon-official-overseeing-ukraine-testifies-impeachment-inquiry-n1070586 |title=Key Pentagon official finally testifies after Republicans storm impeachment hearing |date=October 23, 2019 |website=[[NBC News]]|first=Alex |last=Moe |first2=Rebecca |last2=Shabad |access-date=October 24, 2019}} and former White House official [[Fiona Hill (presidential advisor)|Fiona Hill]]. Witnesses testified that they believed Trump wanted Zelensky to publicly announce investigations into the Bidens and [[Burisma]] (a Ukrainian natural gas company on whose board Hunter Biden had served){{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/24/world/europe/ukraine-war-impeachment.html|title=The Cost of Trump's Aid Freeze in the Trenches of Ukraine's War|last=Kramer|first=Andrew E.|date=October 24, 2019|work=The New York Times|publisher=A. 18, 2019}} ==== Special Counsel Mueller's Report ==== The [[Mueller Report|report of Special Counsel Robert Mueller]], released on April 18, 2019, found that soon after the firing of James Comey and the appointment of the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)|Special Counsel]], Trump "engaged in conduct{{nbsp}}... involving public attacks on the investigation, non-public acts to control it, and efforts in both public and private to encourage witnesses not to cooperate with the investigation."{{cite book |title=The Mueller Report |date=2019 |publisher=Scribner |location=New York, NY |isbn=978-1-9821-2973-6 |pages=269}} The Mueller Report found "multiple acts by the President that were capable of exerting undue influence over law enforcement investigations, including the Russian-interference and obstruction investigation."{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |pages=419–420}} For example, the Mueller Report found "substantial evidence" or "evidence" that: * "The President's attempts to remove the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)|Special Counsel]] were linked to the Special Counsel's oversight of investigations that involved the President's conduct";{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |page=351}} * "The President's effort to have (Attorney General) Sessions limit the scope of the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)|Special Counsel's investigation]] to future election interference was intended to prevent further investigative scrutiny of the President's and his campaign's conduct";{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |page=359}} * "In repeatedly urging (White House counsel Donald) McGahn to dispute that he was ordered to have the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)|Special Counsel]] terminated, the President acted for the purpose of influencing McGahn's account in order to deflect or prevent further scrutiny of the President's conduct towards the investigation."{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |page=382}} * "... at least one purpose of the President's conduct towards (Attorney General) Jeff Sessions was to have Sessions assume control over the Russia investigation and supervise it in a way that would restrict its scope{{nbsp}}... A reasonable inference{{nbsp}}... is that the President believed that an unrecused Attorney General would play a protective role and could shield the President from the ongoing Russia investigation."{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |page=375}} * "... could support the inference that the President intended to discourage (attorney Michael) Cohen from cooperating with the government because Cohen's information would shed adverse light on the President's campaign-period conduct and statements."{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |page=417}} * "... the President's actions had the potential to influence (campaign adviser Paul) Manafort's decision on whether to cooperate with the government{{nbsp}}... The President's public statements during the Manafort trial, including during jury deliberations also had the potential to influence the trial jury."{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |page=393}} [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)|Special Counsel Robert Mueller]] concluded that "The President's efforts to influence the investigation were mostly unsuccessful, but that is largely because the persons who surrounded the President declined to carry out orders or accede to his requests."{{cite book |title=Mueller Report |page=420}} Nevertheless, the Mueller Report made no definitive conclusion as to whether Trump had committed criminal obstruction of justice.{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-mueller/mueller-says-he-did-not-exonerate-trump-us-policy-precluded-charges-idUSKCN1UJ0DF |title=Mueller says Trump was not exonerated; Trump declares victory |last=Morgan |first=David |date=July 24, 2019 |work=Reuters |last2=Wolfe |first2=Jan |access-date=July 27, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190727133528/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-mueller/mueller-says-he-did-not-exonerate-trump-us-policy-precluded-charges-idUSKCN1UJ0DF|archive-date=July 27, 2019 |url-status=live}} Instead, the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–2019)|Special Counsel]] strongly hinted that it was up to Congress to make such a determination based on the evidence presented in the report. One proposed investigation would concern [[Conspiracy theories related to the Trump–Ukraine scandal#CrowdStrike|a conspiracy theory]]—which originated on [[4chan]] in 2017 and was spread by blogs, social media, and [[Fox News]]—{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/trump-seized-conspiracy-theory-called-insurance-policy-now-it-s-n1062096|title=Trump seized on a conspiracy theory called the 'insurance policy'. cooperation, and bringing up a personal favor which then could be delegated.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/25/us/politics/trump-ukraine.html |title=Trump's Not-So-Excellent Day |last=Haberman |first=Maggie |authorlink=Maggie Haberman |date=September 25, 2019 |work=The New York Times |last2=Crowley |first2=Michael |last3=Rogers |first3=Katie |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=September 26, 2019}} In an interview, Giuliani defended Trump, calling the president's request of the Ukrainian president "perfectly appropriate", while also indicating that he himself may have made a similar request to Ukrainian officials.{{cite news |last=Itkowitz |first=Colby |title=Giuliani admits to asking Ukraine about Joe Biden after denying it 30 seconds earlier |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/09/20/giuliani-admits-asking-ukraine-about-joe-biden-after-denying-it-seconds-earlier/ |work=The Washington Post |date=September 20, 2019 |accessdate=October 2, 2019}} A second whistleblower, who is also an intelligence official, came forward on October{{nbsp}}5 with "first-hand knowledge of allegations" associated with the phone call between Trump and Zelensky, according to the lawyer representing both whistleblowers.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-49953225 |title=Trump impeachment: Second whistleblower emerges |date=October 7, 2019 |website=BBC News|accessdate=October 8, 2019}} ==== Further revelations ==== [[File:President Trump Delivers Remarks Upon Departure October 4 2019.webm|thumb|start=02:01|left|President Trump states on October 3, 2019, that "China should start an investigation into the Bidens"]] On September 27, 2019, the White House confirmed an allegation by the first whistleblower that a record of the call between Trump and Zelensky was sealed in a highly classified computer system at the advice of NSC lawyers.{{Cite news |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2019/09/27/politics/donald-trump-ukraine-transcript-white-house/index.html |title=First on CNN: White House says lawyers directed moving Ukraine transcript to highly |archive-url=https://archive.today/20191012224947/https://edition.cnn.com/2019/09/27/politics/donald-trump-ukraine-transcript-white-house/index.html |archive-date=October 12, 2019 |publisher=CNN}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.apnews.com/ec576ac2faa942d18450f7bdfac0ef24 |title=Subpoenas mark first concrete steps for Trump impeachment |last1=Miller |first1=Zeke |date=September 28, 2019 |accessdate=October 4, 2019 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20191012224337/https://www.apnews.com/ec576ac2faa942d18450f7bdfac0ef24 |archive-date=October 12, 2019 |work=Associated Press News |last2=Tucker |first2=Eric |last3=Balsamo |first3=Michael}} This came alongside media reports that the White House had used the most highly classified system to store memorandums of conversations with the leaders and officials of countries including Ukraine, [[Saudi Arabia]] and Russia. Administration officials had begun storing these transcripts into this system after Trump's conversations with Australia's prime minister [[Malcolm Turnbull]] and Mexico's president [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] leaked earlier in 2017.{{cite news |last1=Salama |first1=Vivian |title=Embarrassing Leaks Led to Clampdown on Trump's Phone Records |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/embarrassing-leaks-led-to-clampdown-on-trumps-phone-records-11569710889 |accessdate=November 10, 2019 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=September 28, 2019}} This was seen by critics and the media as a deliberate attempt to hide potentially damaging information.{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-whistleblower-server/a-computer-server-haunted-clinton-in-2016-now-it-may-be-trumps-turn-idUSKBN1WB2NE |first=Brad |last=Heath |title=A computer server haunted Clinton in 2016. Now it may be Trump's turn |work=Reuters |date=September 27, 2019 |accessdate=October 2, 2019}} On October 3, after saying the U.S. has "tremendous power" and "many options" in the [[China–United States trade war|trade war with China]] "if they don't do what we want", Trump was asked by a reporter on what he hoped Zelensky would do after his phone call. Trump responded by publicly urging both Ukraine and China to investigate the Bidens.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-publicly-calls-on-china-to-investigate-bidens/2019/10/03/2ae94f6a-e5f2-11e9-b403-f738899982d2_story.html |title=Trump publicly calls on China to investigate Bidens |last1=Rucker |first1=Philip |date=October 4, 2019 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=October 4, 2019 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20191012225550/https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-publicly-calls-on-china-to-investigate-bidens/2019/10/03/2ae94f6a-e5f2-11e9-b403-f738899982d2_story.html |archive-date=October 12, 2019 |last2=Bade |first2=Rachael |last3=Itkowitz |first3=Colby |url-access=limited}}{{cite news |last1=Borger |first1=Julian |last2=Gambino |first2=Lauren |title=Trump calls on China to investigate Biden in extraordinary demand |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/oct/03/trump-biden-china-investigation-demand |accessdate=October 5, 2019 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=October 4, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191027153313/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/oct/03/trump-biden-china-investigation-demand |archive-date=October 27, 2019}} In an interview with ''[[The New Yorker]]'' on December 16, Rudy Giuliani said removing the U.S. ambassador to Ukraine became imperative for him and Trump. "I needed Yovanovitch out of the way," Giuliani told the magazine.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-50826852|title=Rudy Giuliani 'forced Ukraine ambassador out'|date=December 17, 2019|accessdate=December 17, 2019|language=en-GB}} == House of Representatives investigations == {{external media| float = right| width=230px| video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?464684-1/speaker-pelosi-announces-formal-impeachment-inquiry-president-trump Announcement by Nancy Pelosi of formal impeachment inquiry, September 24, 2019], [[C-SPAN]]}} On the evening of September 24, 2019, Pelosi announced that six [[United States congressional committee#House committees|committees of the House of Representatives]] would begin a formal impeachment inquiry into President Trump. Pelosi accused Trump of betraying his [[Oath of office of the President of the United States|oath of office]], [[National security of the United States|U.S. national security]], and the integrity of the country's elections.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/pelosi-top-democrats-privately-discuss-creation-of-select-committee-for-impeachment/2019/09/24/af6f735a-dedf-11e9-b199-f638bf2c340f_story.html |title=Pelosi announces impeachment inquiry, says Trump's courting of foreign political help is a 'betrayal of national security' |last=Bade |first=Rachael |date=September 24, 2019 |work=The 24, 2019 |url-status=live}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/24/us/politics/democrats-impeachment-trump.html |title=Nancy Pelosi Announces Formal Impeachment Inquiry of Trump |accessdate=September 24, 2019}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/pelosi-announce-formal-impeachment-inquiry-trump-n1058251 |title=Nancy Pelosi announces Judiciary]], [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|Intelligence]], [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|Foreign Affairs]], [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Reform|Oversight and Reform]], and [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|Ways and Means]].{{cite news [[File:House Debate on Whistleblower Complaint sept 25 2019 program.533508.MP4-M20.webm|thumb|thumbtime=41:17|[[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] debate on the whistleblower complaint against President Trump on September 25, 2019]] Maguire, who had delayed the whistleblower complaint from reaching Congress, testified publicly before the House Intelligence Committee on September 26.{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/24/joseph-maguire-intelligence-senate-1509552 |title=Whistleblower wants to appear before Congress, Dems say |last=Bertr |first=Natasha |last2=Matishak |first2=Martin |website=Politico |date=September 24, 2019 |last3=Everett |first3=Burgess |accessdate=September 25, 2019}} Maguire defended his decision not to immediately forward the whistleblower complaint to Congress and explained that he had consulted the [[White House Counsel]] and the [[Office of Legal Counsel]] at the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] (DOJ), but was unable to determine whether the document was protected by [[executive privilege]]. Democrats on the committee questioned his actions, arguing that the law demands the forwarding of such complaints to the committee. Maguire countered that the situation was unique since the complaint involves communications of the president. Members of the House Intelligence Committee also asked Maguire why he chose to consult with White House lawyers when he was not required to do so by law, to which he responded that he believed "it would be prudent to have another opinion."{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/intelligence-chief-maguire-will-testify-to-congress-about-whistleblower-complaint/2019/09/25/ee98ae7c-dfb4-11e9-b199-f638bf2c340f_story.html |title=Acting intelligence chief Maguire defends his handling of whistleblower complaint in testimony before Congress |last=Harris |first=Shane |date=September 26, 2019 |work=The Washington Post |last2=Demirjian |first2=Karoun |last3=Nakashima |first3=Ellen |author3link=Ellen Nakashima |issn=0190-8286|accessdate=September 27, 2019}} In a private conference call with Democratic lawmakers on September 29, Pelosi laid out how three of these House committees would begin investigating the President's alleged abuse of power. The House Intelligence Committee would focus on the contents of the whistleblower complaint and whether the complaint may have been wrongfully hidden from Congress, while the Foreign Affairs Committee would focus on interactions the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] may have had with the president's personal attorney Giuliani, and the Oversight and Reform Committee would investigate whether White House classification systems were used to secure potentially damaging records of phone calls between the president and other world leaders.{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/09/29/democrats-impeachment-messaging-donald-trump-010934 |title=Dem leaders plot impeachment messaging war with Trump |last=Ferris |first=Sarah |date=September 29, 2019 |website=Politico|accessdate=September 30, 2019 }} === Requests for evidence and White House refusal === [[File:Cipollone White House Letter Regarding Trump Impeachment Inquiry, October 8, 2019.pdf|thumb|upright|Letter from White House Counsel to the House Speaker and committee chairs stating that the Trump administration will not participate in the House's "partisan and unconstitutional" inquiry]] On September 27, 2019, a subpoena was issued by the House to obtain documents Secretary of State [[Mike Pompeo]] had refused to release earlier. Said documents include several interactions between Trump, Giuliani, and Ukrainian government officials. The documents were requested to be filed with the involved committees probing the issue; the failure to do so "shall constitute evidence of obstruction of the House's impeachment inquiry", as stated in a letter written to Pompeo.{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/09/27/democrats-subpoena-pompeo-as-part-of-impeachment-inquiry-000159 |title=Democrats subpoena Pompeo as part of impeachment inquiry |last=Cheney |first=Kyle |date=September 27, 2019 |website=Politico |accessdate=September 28, 2019}} The subpoena came after several requests by the House to receive the documents from the Secretary which he did not fulfill. Several members of the House involved with the impeachment inquiry sent him subsequent letters stating that they will be meeting with members of the State Department who may provide further information.{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/27/house-panels-subpoena-secretary-of-state-pompeo-for-documents-related-to-ukraine-probe.html |title=House panels subpoena Secretary of State Pompeo for documents related to Trump impeachment probe |last=Pramuk |first=Jacob |date=September 27, 2019 |website=CNBC|accessdate=September 28, 2019}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2019/09/29/democrats-decide-rapid-timetable-trump-impeachment-inquiry/ |title=Democrats decide on rapid timetable for Trump impeachment inquiry |last=Lowell |first=Hugo |date=September 29, 2019 |work=The Telegraph|accessdate=September 30, 2019 |issn=0307-1235}} The following week, a subpoena was also issued to Giuliani for production of documents.{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/30/house-democrats-subpoena-trump-lawyer-rudy-giuliani-in-impeachment-probe.html |title=House Democrats subpoena Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani in impeachment probe |work=[[CNBC]] |date=September 30, 2019 |accessdate=September 30, 2019 |first=Jacob |last=Pramuk}} On October 4, 2019, the House Intelligence Committee issued subpoenas both to the White House and to Vice President [[Mike Pence]] for documents related to the whistleblower complaint.{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-impeachment-inquiry-house-democrats-subpoena-white-house-for-ukraine-documents-whistleblower-2019-10-05/|title=House Democrats subpoena White House for documents in impeachment inquiry|last=Tracy|first=Ben|date=October 5, 2019|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=October 5, 2019}} The White House documents requested include audio tapes, transcripts, notes, and other White House documents related to the whistleblower controversy.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/02/us/politics/impeachment-white-house-subpoena.html |title=We're Not Fooling Around:" House Democrats Vow to Subpoena |first1=Nicholas |last1=Fandos |first2=Peter |last2=Baker |work=The New York Times |date=October 2, 2019 |accessdate=October 5, 2019}} On October 8, 2019, in a letter from White House Counsel [[Pat Cipollone]] to House Speaker Pelosi and the three committee chairmen conducting the impeachment investigation, the White House announced that it would not cooperate with the investigation.{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/white-house-letter-to-nancy-pelosi-white-house-wont-cooperate-with-house-impeachment-inquiry-testimony-documents/ |title=White House won't cooperate with House impeachment inquiry, counsel says |last=Segers |first=Grace |date=October 9, 2019 |work=CBS News |access-date=October 15, 2019}} In the letter, Cipollone said the investigation "violates the Constitution, the rule of law, and every past precedent"{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/10/09/768540896/who-sets-the-rules-when-is-it-real-and-other-big-questions-on-impeachment |title=Fact Check: White House Legal Argument Against Impeachment Inquiry |last=Naylor |first=Brian |date=October 9, 2019 |work=NPR |access-date=October 15, 2019}} and that "The President cannot allow your constitutionally illegitimate proceedings to distract him and those in the Executive Branch."{{cite news |title=It's tempting to ignore Trump's unhinged letter to Congress. But this is different. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/trumps-proclamation-that-hell-ignore-congress-is-unconstitutional-and-unhinged/2019/10/09/d5353d82-eacd-11e9-9306-47cb0324fd44_story.html |accessdate=October 11, 2019 |work=The Washington Post |date=October 9, 2019 |department=Editorial}} The letter went on to say "[the investigation's] unprecedented actions have left the President with no choice. To fulfill his duties to the American people, the Constitution, the Executive Branch, and all future occupants of the Office of the Presidency, President Trump and his Administration cannot participate in your partisan and unconstitutional inquiry under these circumstances."{{cite news |url=https://time.com/5696071/impeachment-inquiry-congress-white-house-supreme-court/ |title=The White House and Congress Are Playing Constitutional Chicken |last=Abramson |first=Alana |last2=Berenson |first2=Tessa |date=October 9, 2019 |website=Time |accessdate=October 15, 2019}} House Speaker Pelosi responded to the letter saying "The White House should be warned that continued efforts to hide the truth of the president's abuse of power from the American people will be regarded as further evidence of obstruction."{{cite news |title=White House Declares War on Impeachment Inquiry, Claiming Effort to Undo Trump's Election |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/08/us/politics/sondland-trump-ukraine-impeach.html |first=Nicholas |last=Fandos |first2=Peter |last2=Baker |first3=Michael S. |last3=Schmidt |first4=Maggie |last4=Haberman |date=October 8, 2019 |accessdate=October 9, 2019 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}} House Democrats have suggested that defiance of their investigation could provide evidence for a separate article of impeachment on obstruction. In past impeachment probes, Congress has treated an obstruction of DOJ and Congressional investigations as an article of impeachment, either along with other alleged offenses (Johnson, Nixon) or even as its sole basis for articles of impeachment (Clinton). Giuliani's attorney, Jim A. Sale, sent a letter to the House Intelligence Committee on October 15, 2019, stating that Giuliani would not provide documents subpoenaed by the committee. Citing [[Attorney–client privilege|attorney–client]] and [[executive privilege]], the letter characterized the subpoena as "beyond the scope of legitimate inquiry".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/15/us/giuliani-subpoena-ukraine.html |title=Giuliani Defies Subpoena for Ukraine Documents |last=Shear |first=Michael D. |date=October 15, 2019 |work=The New York
