In Schiff's decline of the request to hear from Biden, he said he would not allow Republicans to use the hearings to conduct "sham investigations".{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/09/us/politics/republican-strategy-impeachment-trump.html|title=Republicans Argue Impeachment Case Falls Short of Proving Trump Misconduct|first1=Michael D.|last1=Shear|first2=Nicholas|last2=Fandos|date=November 9, 2019|newspaper=The New York Times}} Schiff also rejected Nunes's request to question the anonymous whistleblower, for the individual's safety and because subsequent evidence "not only confirms but far exceeds" the whistleblower's complaint, so "the whistleblower's testimony is therefore redundant and unnecessary".{{cite news |date=November 10, 2019 |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/09/politics/adam-schiff-whistleblower-impeachment-inquiry/index.html|title=Schiff says whistleblower testimony is 'redundant and unnecessary'|first=Manu|last=Raju|website=CNN}} As public hearings approached, a staff memo to Republican members of the three relevant committees outlined the major themes they should pursue in Trump's defense. This includes focusing on the July 25 call summary which they allege "shows no conditionality or evidence of pressure" and that both Presidents Trump and Zelensky have said there was no pressure. The memo contended that any concerns Zelensky may have had about negative consequences of publicly acknowledging he felt pressure from Trump were unwarranted.{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/11/12/20961073/trump-impeachment-hearings-republican-testimony-strategy|title=A Republican memo details the party's impeachment inquiry defenses. They aren't very strong.|first=Sean|last=Collins|date=November 12, 2019|website=Vox}} The memo also claims that the "Ukrainian government was not aware of a hold on U.S. security assistance" before the July 25 call. It also points out that "President Trump met with President Zelensky and U.S. security assistance flowed to Ukraine in September 2019—both of which occurred without Ukraine investigating President Trump's political rivals."{{cite web |date=November 12, 2019 |first=Zachary |last=Basu |first2=Jonathan |last2=Swan |url=https://www.axios.com/republicans-impeachment-defense-memo-b4f6eeeb-6dab-49ed-a8d2-48eb736cfd8f.html|title=Ahead of public hearings, GOP outlines theory of impeachment defense in memo to members|website=Axios}} The release of the Ukraine aid came two days after the House Intelligence Committee was notified of the whistleblower complaint and opened an investigation,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/11/us/politics/trump-ukraine-timeline.html|title=Key Dates at the Center of the Ukraine Matter|first1=Sharon|last1=LaFraniere|first2=Andrew E.|last2=Kramer|first3=Danny|last3=Hakim|date=November 11, 2019|work=The New York Times}} and two days after three House committees publicly announced an investigation into Giuliani's activities in Ukraine.{{cite news |date=September 9, 2019 |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/09/rudy-giuliani-ukraine-investigation-1486753 |title=House panels launch investigation into Giuliani's dealings with Ukraine|first=Caitlin|last=Oprysko|website=[[Politico]]}} As hearings began, Schiff said Trump may have committed bribery, and House Speaker Pelosi joined him on November 14; bribery is specifically listed as an impeachable offense in the Constitution.{{cite web|first=Caleb |last=Ecarma |url=https://www.mediaite.com/tv/how-did-democrats-decide-on-bribery-as-trumps-impeachable-offense/|title=How Did Democrats Decide on 'Bribery' as Trump's Offense?|date=November 22, 2019|website=Mediaite|language=en|access-date=November 23, 2019}} === November 13, 2019: Kent and Taylor === With live coverage on television, public hearings began at 10:00 a.m. [[Eastern Standard Time (North America)|EST]] on November 13, 2019, in which [[George P. Kent|George Kent]] and [[William B. Taylor Jr.|William Taylor]] testified before the House Intelligence Committee.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/impeachment-hearings-live-updates/2019/11/13/e974f486-057b-11ea-ac12-3325d49eacaa_story.html|title=Live updates: Trump asked E.U. ambassador about status of Ukrainian 'investigations', diplomat reveals in new testimony|last=Wagner|first=John|last2=Sonmez|first2=Felicia|date=November 13, 2019|website=The Washington Post|access-date=November 13, 2019}} After opening statements from Chairman Schiff and ranking member Representative [[Devin Nunes|Nunes]], Taylor and Kent read their openings statements. This was followed by questions from the Chairman and the majority counsel, [[Daniel S. Goldman]], and then by the Ranking Member and the minority counsel, [[Steve Castor]].{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/13/politics/who-are-dan-goldman-steve-castor-impeachment-lawyers/index.html|title=Staff lawyers to take star role in first hearings on impeachment|last=Rogers|first=Alex|date=November 13, 2019|website=CNN|access-date=November 13, 2019}} Taylor testified that the day after the Trump–Zelensky phone call, one of his aides, David Holmes, overheard Sondland speaking to Trump via cellphone in a [[Kyiv]] restaurant, hearing the president refer to "the investigations".{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/impeachment-hearings-begin-with-revelation-of-phone-call-implicating-trump-in-ukraine-scandal/2019/11/13/de8d21b8-063b-11ea-b17d-8b867891d39d_story.html |date=November 13, 2019 |title=Impeachment hearings begin with new evidence of phone call implicating Trump in Ukraine controversy|first1=Karoun|last1=Demirjian|website=The Washington Post}} Another diplomat, Suriya Jayanti, also overheard the call. Holmes testified behind closed doors on November 15 that he heard Trump ask, "so, he's gonna do the investigation?" to which Sondland replied, "he's gonna do it", adding that Zelensky would do "anything you ask him to". Holmes also testified that Sondland later told him that Trump "did not give a shit about Ukraine" and "only cared about the big stuff{{nbsp}}... that benefits the president like the Biden investigation that Mr. Giuliani was pushing."{{cite news |first=Veronica |last=Rocha |first2=Meg |last2=Wagner |url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/impeachment-hearing-11-15-19/index.html|title=Former U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine testifies: Live updates|date=November 15, 2019|website=CNN|accessdate=November 15, 2019}} Analysts noted that the Sondland call itself constituted a major security breach, as it could have been intercepted by foreign intelligence services.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/ambassadors-cellphone-call-to-trump-from-kyiv-restaurant-was-a-stunning-breach-of-security-former-officials-say/2019/11/13/37d75752-0641-11ea-b17d-8b867891d39d_story.html|title=Ambassador's cellphone call to Trump from Kyiv restaurant was a stunning breach of security, former officials say|last=Nakashima|first=Ellen|date=November 13, 2019|website=The Washington Post|access-date=November 14, 2019}} According to data from [[Nielsen Corporation|Nielsen]], the first day of hearings had 13,098,000 viewers tuning in on various cable and broadcast channels (not including PBS, {{nowrap|C-SPAN}}, and online streaming).{{cite news |last=Patten |first=Dominic |url=https://deadline.com/2019/11/impeachment-hearings-tv-ratings-donald-trump-fox-news-cnn-msnbc-1202786141/ |title=Impeachment Hearings Debut With 13M Viewers; Fox News Tops Cable & Broadcast |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=November 14, 2019 |accessdate=November 14, 2019}} === November 15, 2019: Yovanovitch === [[Marie Yovanovitch]]'s testimony began at 9:00 a.m. EST and lasted six hours.{{cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-impeachment-hearings-yovanovitch-testimony-updates-2019-11|title=Marie Yovanovitch took aim at Trump, Rudy Giuliani, and top brass at the State Department in damning testimony|first1=Sonam|last1=Sheth |first2=Eliza|last2=Relman|date=Nov 15, 2019|accessdate=Nov 16, 2019|work=Business Insider}} She directly contradicted the Republican theory that Ukraine had tried to undermine Trump in the 2016 elections. She said she had three contacts with Giuliani, not involving the current allegations, and did not know why he chose to attack and discredit her.{{cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/key-takeaways-testimony-ukraine-ambassador-marie-yovanovitch/story?id=67044743|title=5 key takeaways from testimony by former Ukraine Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch|last=Flaherty|first=Anne|date=November 15, 2019|work=ABC News|accessdate=November 15, 2019}} She said his allegations against her were false and that no one in the State Department believed them. She added that she was "shocked and devastated" when Trump disparaged her and said she was "going to go through some things" during his telephone call with Zelensky.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/15/politics/public-impeachment-hearings-day-2/index.html|title=Former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine tells impeachment inquiry she was 'shocked and devastated' after being removed from her post|last1=Herb|first1=Jeremy|last2=Raju|first2=Manu|date=November 15, 2019|work=CNN|accessdate=November 15, 2019}} During her testimony, Trump berated her on Twitter, questioning her competence and saying the Ukrainian president had spoken unfavourably about her.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-50428537|title=How a Trump tweet shook impeachment hearing|first=Anthony|last=Zurcher|date=November 15, 2019|accessdate=November 16, 2019|work=BBC News}} Chairman Schiff informed Yovanovitch of the tweet during the hearing; she said it was "very intimidating".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-50436521|title=Trump impeachment inquiry: Envoy 'intimidated' by tweets during testimony|date=November 15, 2019|work=BBC News|accessdate=November 16, 2019}} Trump's behavior was labelled as [[witness intimidation]] by Democrats. [[Eric Swalwell]], who participated in questioning Yovanovitch during the hearing, said this could be laid out as a separate article of impeachment: "it's evidence of more obstruction".{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-impeachment/trump-attacks-impeachment-witness-on-twitter-democrats-see-intimidation-idUSKBN1XP155 |title=Trump attacks impeachment witness on Twitter, Democrats see intimidation |work=Reuters |first=Susan |last=Cornwell |first2=Richard |last2=Cowan |first3=Patricia |last3=Zengerle |date=November 15, 2019|accessdate=November 16, 2019}} === November 19, 2019 === ==== Vindman and Williams ==== Lieutenant Colonel [[Alexander Vindman]] testified in person before the U.S. House of Representatives.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/11/18/who-is-alexander-vindman-why-does-his-public-testimony-matter/|title=Who is Alexander Vindman and why does his public testimony matter?|work=The Washington Post|date=November 19, 2019|first=Amber|last=Phillips|accessdate=November 20, 2019}} In his testimony, Vindman said he had made a report to an intelligence official about what he heard during Trump's call with the Ukrainian President and felt what the President mentioned during the phone conversation was "improper".{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/11/19/impeachment-hearings-live-highlights-and-updates-071459|title=Election meddling, an 'improper' call, and twins: What we learned in Vindman and Williams' testimony|work=Politico|first1=Natasha|last1=Bertrand|first2=Quint|last2=Forgey|first3=Abbey|last3=Marshall|date=November 19, 2019|accessdate=November 20, 2019}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/lt-col-alexander-vindman-reveals-in-testimony-that-he-told-an-intelligence-official-about-trumps-call-with-ukrainian-leader/2019/11/19/61c46b16-0ae4-11ea-8397-a955cd542d00_story.html|title=Trump said his Ukraine call was 'perfect'. Impeachment witnesses testified otherwise.|first1=Karoun|last1=Demirjian|first2=Mike|last2=DeBonis|first3=Matt|last3=Zapotosky|accessdate=November 20, 2019|date=November 19, 2019|work=The Washington Post}} Testifying alongside Vindman was Vice President Mike Pence's chief European security adviser [[Jennifer Williams]]. Williams testified that when Zelensky was elected, Pence initially agreed to attend the inauguration if his schedule permitted, but that plan was cancelled when on May 13, Williams was informed that President Trump had decided Pence would not represent the U.S. at the inauguration in Ukraine after all.{{cite news |title=Read Jennifer Williams's Prepared Opening Statement From the Impeachment Hearing |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 19, 2019 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/19/us/politics/williams-opening-statement-impeachment.html}} Williams testified that she listened to Trump's phone conversation with Zelensky and felt it was "unusual".{{cite news |first=Michael D. |last=Shear |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/19/us/politics/jennifer-williams.html|title=Who Is Jennifer Williams? Pence Aid Listened to Trump–Zelensky Call |date=November 19, 2019 |accessdate=November 20, 2019 |newspaper=The New York Times}}{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/11/19/trump-ukraine-scrutiny-officials-testimony-071395|title='Improper' and 'unusual': White House aides criticize Trump's Ukraine call|work=Politico|first1=Andrew|last1=Desiderio|first2=Kyle|last2=Cheney|date=November 19, 2019|accessdate=November 20, 2019}} Both Vindman and Williams acknowledged the Trump administration's interest in obtaining knowledge of the Burisma controversy as well.{{cite news |first=Aaron |last=Blake |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/11/19/early-takeaways-alexander-vindmans-jennifer-williamss-testimony/|title=7 Takeaways From Tuesday's Impeachment Hearings|work=The Washington Post|date=November 19, 2019|accessdate=November 20, 2019}} In questioning Vindman, Devin Nunes repeatedly demanded that he name all individuals to whom he had spoken. In a heated exchange, Vindman refused, and Schiff rebuked Nunes for trying to violate federally protected anonymity.{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/video/national/trump-impeachment-hearings/vindman-refuses-to-name-intelligence-community-colleagues-or-whistleblower/2019/11/19/58a1acd3-a4ba-4a1f-9987-abb9e26d1e50_video.html |title=Vindman refuses to name intelligence community colleagues or whistleblower |work=The Washington Post |date=November 19, 2019 |access-date=November 20, 2019 |language=en}} ==== Volker and Morrison ==== At the request of Republicans, former U.S. Special Representative for Ukraine [[Kurt Volker]] and former National Security presidential adviser on Europe and Russia [[Tim Morrison (presidential advisor)|Tim Morrison]] gave public testimony before the House Intelligence Committee.{{cite news |first=Veronica |last=Rocha |first2=Meg |last2=Wagner |first3=Amanda |last3=Wills |accessdate=May 14, 2020 |url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/impeachment-hearing-11-19-19/h_fcef5e3a2b318f1fee6c3405a9b80d06|title=Morrison and Volker are the witnesses Republicans requested|date=November 19, 2019|website=CNN}} In his testimony, Volker recanted his deposition denial of seeing no indication that Trump had conditioned a White House meeting and military assistance for Ukraine on a promise from the country's president to investigate Trump's political rivals.{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/11/19/kurt-volker-public-impeachment-hearing-071566|first=Kyle|last=Cheney|title='I have learned many things': Kurt Volker revises Ukraine testimony|work=Politico|date=November 19, 2019|accessdate=November 19, 2019}} Asked why he recanted, Volker said "I have learned many things" since the previous closed-door hearing on October 3, 2019. During his testimony, Morrison said Sondland confirmed to him that there was indeed a ''quid pro quo'' for U.S. aid to Ukraine and that Sondland told him this following the September{{nbsp}}1 telephone conversation with Yermak.{{cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/11/19/20973157/impeachment-hearings-morrison-quid-pro-quo-ukraine|first=Alex|last=Ward|title=One of the news|url=https://theweek.com/speedreads/879534/former-nsc-official-tim-morrison-confirms-ukraine-quid-pro-quo-during-public-testimony |first=Catherine |last=Garcia |title=Former NSC official Tim news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/6-things-we-learned-gordon-sondland-s-impeachment-testimony-so-n1086841|title=6 things we learned from Gordon Sondland's impeachment He additionally stated that everyone in the administration "was in the loop", specifically naming John Bolton, Mike Pompeo, Ulrich Brechbuhl and Mike Pence, saying "they knew what they were doing and why."{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/20/politics/public-impeachment-hearing-day-4/index.html|title=Ambassador says 'everyone was in the loop' on pushing Ukrainians to investigate Bidens |first1=Jeremy |last1=Herb |first2=Manu |last2=Raju |date=November 21, 2019 |website=CNN |access-date=November 20, 2019}}{{cite news |first=Philip |last=Ewing |first2=Brian |last2=Naylor |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/11/20/778657263/watch-live-sondland-key-impeachment-witness-headlines-wednesday-hearing |title=Sondland Says Top Trump Officials Knew Of Push For Ukraine Investigations |website=NPR.org |accessdate=May 14, 2020 }} Sondland also said Trump had never directly told him that the aid package to Ukraine was related to the announcement of investigations, but that Sondland nevertheless believed it was.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/20/us/politics/sondland-in-act-of-defiance-says-he-followed-trumps-orders-in-ukraine-pressure-scheme.html|title=Sondland, in Act of Defiance, Says He Followed Trump's Orders in Ukraine Pressure Scheme|last=Fandos|first=Nicholas|date=November 20, 2019|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 20, 2019|last2=Schmidt|first2=Michael S.|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Hours after Sondland's testimony, Pence's Chief of Staff [[Marc Short]] issued a statement denying Sondland's claim that Pence and Sondland discussed the alleged ''quid pro quo''. The denial stated the vice president "never had a conversation with Gordon Sondland about investigating the Bidens, Burisma, or the conditional release of financial aid to Ukraine based upon potential investigations".{{cite news |first=Kevin |last=Liptak |date=November 20, 2019 |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/20/politics/mike-pence-ukraine-impeachment-gordon-sondland/index.html|title=Sondland letter stating that next steps towards impeachment will be taken when a committee report regarding the impeachment inquiry will be sent to the House Judiciary Committee when Congress returns from its for impeachment inquiry|publisher=CNN|date=November 25, 2019|accessdate=November 25, 2019}}{{cite news |last1=Wagner |first1=John |last2=Sonmez |first2=Felicia |last3=Brittany |first3=Shammas |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/live-impeachment-inquiry-updates/2019/11/25/0eabfc32-0f71-11ea-b0fc-62cc38411ebb_story.html |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=November 26, 2019 |date=November 25, 2019}} A draft report was circulated among the membership of the House Intelligence Committee on December 2; the next day, it was released to the public.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/03/us/politics/impeachment-trump-intelligence-committee.html |title=Impeachment Report Alleges Trump Solicited Foreign Election Interference |last=Shear |url=https://www.rawstory.com/2019/11/intel-chairman-adam-schiff-announces-tuesday-vote-on-impeachment-inquiry-report-on-donald-trump/ |title=Intel Chairman Adam Schiff announces Tuesday vote on impeachment inquiry report on Donald Trump |publisher=Rawstory.com |date=November 30, 2019 |accessdate=December 4, 2019}} On December 3, the House Intelligence Committee voted 13–9 along party lines news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/03/politics/house-intelligence-committee-report/index.html|title=House Democrats vote to send impeachment report to Judiciary Committee|first1=Manu|last1=Raju|first2=Jeremy|last2=Herb|publisher=CNN|date=December 3, 2019|accessdate=December 4, 2019}}{{cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/house-intel-committee-trump-impeachment-report-vote|title=House Democrats vote to adopt Trump impeachment report, blast scheme to 'solicit foreign interference' in 2020 race|first1=Ronn|last1=Blitzer|first2=Gregg|last2=Re|publisher=Fox News|date=December 3, 2019|accessdate=December 4, 2019}}{{Cite web|url=https://intelligence.house.gov/uploadedfiles/20191203_-_full_report___hpsci_impeachment_inquiry_-_20191203.pdf|title=Report of the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, Pursuant to H. Res. 660 in Consultation with the House Committee on Oversight and Reform and the House Committee on Foreign Affairs|last=House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|date=December 3, 2019|website=U.S. House of Representatives Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|access-date=December 5, 2019}} The report's preface states:
[T]he impeachment inquiry has found that President Trump, personally and acting through agents within and outside of the U.S. government, solicited the interference of a foreign government, Ukraine, to benefit his reelection. In furtherance of this scheme, President Trump conditioned official acts on a public announcement by the new Ukrainian President, Volodymyr Zelensky, of politically-motivated investigations, including one into President Trump's domestic political opponent. In pressuring President Zelensky to carry out his demand, President Trump withheld a White House meeting desperately sought by the Ukrainian President, and critical U.S. military assistance to fight Russian aggression in eastern Ukraine. The President engaged in this course of conduct for the benefit of his presidential reelection, to harm the election prospects of a political rival, and to influence our nation's upcoming presidential election to his advantage. In doing so, the President placed his own personal and political interests above the national interests of the United States, sought to undermine the integrity of the U.S. presidential election process, and endangered U.S. national security. At the center of this investigation is the memorandum prepared following President Trump's July 25, 2019, phone call with Ukraine's President, which the White House declassified and released under significant public pressure. The call record alone is stark evidence of misconduct; a demonstration of the President's prioritization of his political benefit over the national interest. In response to President Zelensky's appreciation for vital U.S. military assistance, which President Trump froze without explanation, President Trump asked for "a favor though": two specific investigations designed to assist his reelection efforts.{{Rp|8–9}}
The Republicans of the House Committees had released a countering report the previous day, saying in part that the evidence does not support accusations. "The evidence presented does not prove any of these Democrat allegations, and none of the Democrats' witnesses testified to having evidence of bribery, extortion, or any high crime or misdemeanor," said the draft report.{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2019/12/02/house-gop-draft-report-defends-president-trump-impeachment-inquiry/2590245001/ |newspaper=USA Today |first=Bart |last=Jansen |first2=Christal |last2=Hayes |title=House GOP report on impeachment inquiry defends Trump's dealings with Ukraine |date=December 2, 2019 |accessdate=December 12, 2019}}{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/12/02/784183484/read-republican-report-on-the-impeachment-inquiry |title=READ: Republican Report On The Impeachment Inquiry |date=December 2, 2019 |accessdate=December 12, 2019}} This report also painted the push to impeachment as solely politically motivated. Its executive summary states that "The Democrats are trying to impeach a duly elected president based on the accusations and assumptions of unelected bureaucrats who disagreed with President Trump's policy initiatives and processes."{{cite news |first=Jessica |last=Taylor |url=https://www.npr.org/2019/12/02/784260364/house-gop-rebuts-democrats-impeachment-efforts-no-bribery-extortion-proven |title=House GOP Rebuts Democrats' Impeachment Efforts: No 'Bribery, Extortion' Proven |date=December 2, 2019 |accessdate=December 12, 2019}} This report concluded the inquiry stage of the impeachment process and the house then voted on the approved articles of impeachment; [[Impeachment of Donald Trump|Trump was impeached]] on December 18, 2019. == Responses == === White House === In the wake of In the October{{nbsp}}8 letter, the White House officially declined to cooperate with what they claimed was an illegitimate effort "to overturn the results of the 2016 election". The eight-page letter said the investigation "violates the Constitution, the rule of law, and every past precedent". Pelosi responded to the letter: "The White House should be warned that continued efforts to hide the truth of the president's abuse of power from the American people will be regarded as further evidence of obstruction."{{Cite news |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2019-10-08/read-white-house-letter-declares-impeachment-inquiry-unconstitutional |title=READ: White House Letter Declares Impeachment Inquiry Unconstitutional |last1=Hagen |first1=Lisa |date=October 8, 2019 |work=US News and World Report |accessdate=October 8, 2019}} During an October 17 press conference, White House acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney said he "was involved with the process" of the freezing of military aid. Two, Trump felt Ukraine was a "corrupt place" which included having "corruption related to the DNC server" concerning "what happened in 2016". As a result, reporter [[Jonathan Karl]] told Mulvaney "what you just described is a ''quid pro quo''. Bakaj]], the lead attorney representing the whistleblowers, sent a joint letter to Maguire on September 28, made public on September 29, in which they raised concerns about the language used by Trump, amongst other things. In the letter, the lawyers state "The events of the past week have heightened our concerns that our client's identity will be disclosed publicly and that, as a result, our client will be put in harm's way." The letter also mentioned the $50,000 "bounty" that two conservative Trump supporters have offered as a reward for information about the whistleblower.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-49881847 |title=Trump is endangering whistleblower, lawyers warn |date=September 30, 2019 |work=BBC News|access-date=September 30, 2019}} [[Mark Zaid]], co-counsel for the whistleblower, said in a statement in September 2019 that whistleblowers' identities are protected by law and cited testimony by Maguire which drew upon the [[Whistleblower Protection Act]]. The statement was released after Trump questioned on Twitter the validity of the whistleblower's statements.{{cite web |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/463687-trump-white-house-trying-to-find-out-whistleblowers-identity |title=Trump: White House 'trying to find out' whistleblower's identity |last=Lejeune |first=Tristan |date=September 30, 2019 |website=The Hill|access-date=September 30, 2019}} Bakaj took to Twitter to issue a warning on September 30 that the whistleblower is entitled to anonymity, is protected by laws and policies, and is not to be retaliated against; to do so would violate federal law. Bakaj argued in an October 25 ''[[Washington Post]]'' op-ed that the identity of his client is no longer pertinent after further events corroborated his client's account of the matter.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/outlook/we-represent-the-whistleblower-their-identity-is-no-longer-relevant/2019/10/25/d2ff25a2-f6a1-11e9-8cf0-4cc99f74d127_story.html |date=October 25, 2019 |title=We represent the whistleblower. "This is the case because the Department of Justice under Bill Barr expressly declined to investigate this matter after a criminal referral had been made."{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2019/10/25/trump-impeachment-inquiry-why-didnt-doj-look-harder-ukraine-call/4024155002/ |title=As Trump impeachment probe heats up, some say Congress is doing inquiry the Justice Department should've done |last=Johnson |first=Kevin |date=October 25, 2019 |work=USA Today |accessdate=October 25, 2019}} ==== For impeachment inquiry ==== A notable Republican critic of Trump, Senator [[Mitt Romney]] of [[Utah]], called Trump's actions "troubling in the extreme" and "wrong and appalling". Romney said it strained credulity to say Trump's actions were anything other than politically motivated.{{Cite news |url=https://www.sltrib.com/news/politics/2019/10/04/mitt-romney-says-it/ |title=Mitt Romney ratchets up his response to Trump accusations going from 'troubling' to 'appalling' |last=Wood |first=Benjamin |date=October 4, 2019 |work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|access-date=October 4, 2019}} However, in a later interview with ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', Romney called his relationship with Trump "cordial and cooperative". John Kasich says he's now for impeaching Trump |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/18/politics/kasich-calls-for-trump-impeachment/index.html |work=CNN |access-date=October 18, 2019}}; {{Cite news |last=Klar |first=Rebecca |date=October 18, 2019 |title=Kasich says he'd back impeachment |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/466487-kasich-says-hed-back-impeachment |work=The Hill Party presidential debates and forums|2020 Democratic Party presidential debate]], [[Andrew Yang]] said that while he supports impeaching Trump, he believes it may not be successful and would not |url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/03/politics/mccarthy-pelosi-suspend-inquiry/index.html |title=Kevin McCarthy calls on Nancy Pelosi to suspend impeachment inquiry |date=October 3, 2019}} Several and the [[Investigation into the 2012 Benghazi attack]], joined Trump's resistance to the investigation.{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/gop-players-in-benghazi-probe-drop-strong-defense-of-congressional-oversight/2019/10/09/9dc2a99e-eaa4-11e9-9c6d-436a0df4f31d_story.html |title=GOP players about to commence, some carrying cellphones in violation of security protocols.{{Cite news Sergeant at Arms]] was summoned to intervene.{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Desiderio |first2=Melanie |last2=Zanona |date=October 23, 2019 |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/23/impeachment-republicans-trump-055688 |title=Impeachment deposition delayed after Republicans storm proceedings |website=Politico}} Days earlier, Gaetz—who |url=https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/impeachment-inquiry-10-14-2019/h_fe1782530e232ad17a875ad1e3ec8823 |first=Jeremy |last=Herb |first2=Manu |last2=Raju |first3=Laurie |last3=Ure |title=A GOP congressman says he was kicked out of other committees' deposition of Fiona Hill |date=October 14, 2019 |website=CNN}} On October 24, Senator Graham, chair of the [[United States Senate Committee on Res 378]}}) condemning the closed door impeachment process{{cite web |url=https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/press/rep/releases/chairman-graham-introduces-resolution-condemning-house-of-representatives-closed-door-impeachment-process |title=Chairman Graham Introduces Resolution Condemning House of Representatives' Closed Door Impeachment Process |publisher=Senate Judiciary Committee |date=October 24, 2019}}{{cite web |last=Zhou |first=Li |title='I'm not here to tell you that Donald Trump's done nothing wrong:' Lindsey Graham takes on impeachment process |url=https://www.vox.com/2019/10/24/20930509/lindsey-graham-resolution-condemn-house-impeachment-inquiry |website=Vox |accessdate=October 31, 2019 |date=October 24, 2019}} and urging the House to hold a formal vote to initiate the impeachment inquiry, which by October 28, 50 Republican senators cosponsored.{{cite web |url=https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/press/rep/releases/volume-ii-senate-gop-condemns-house-of-representatives-closed-door-impeachment-process |website=senate.gov |accessdate=December 12, 2019 |title=Volume II: Senate GOP Condemns House of Representatives' Closed Door Impeachment Process |date=October 28, 2019}}{{Cite news |last1=Everett |first1=Burgess |last2=Cook |first2=Nancy |title=After McConnell advice, Trump lays off GOP senators on impeachment |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/10/30/trump-senate-republicans-062360 |accessdate=October 31, 2019 |work=Politico |date=October 30, 2019}} {{as of|2019|11}}, only three Republican Senators, of the 53 in the Senate, [[Susan Collins]] of Maine, [[Lisa Murkowski]] of Alaska, and Mitt Romney of Utah, declined to cosponsor the resolution opposing the impeachment process.{{cite news |first=Adam |last=Edelman |date=November 9, 2019 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/only-3-senate-republicans-aren-t-defending-trump-impeachment-inquiry-n1078906|title=Only 3 Senate Republicans aren't defending Trump from the impeachment inquiry. Here's why.|website=NBC News|access-date=November 10, 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/467842-murkowski-collins-say-they-wont-co-sponsor-grahams-impeachment-resolution|title=Murkowski, Collins say they won't co-sponsor Graham's impeachment resolution|last=Carney|first=Jordain|date=October 28, 2019|website=The Hill|access-date=November 10, 2019}} As the articles of impeachment moved to a vote before the full House and referral to the Senate for trial, Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell met with White House Counsel [[Pat Cipollone]] and congressional liaison [[Eric Ueland]], later stating, "everything I do during this I'm coordinating with the White House counsel. There will be no difference between the president's position and our position as to how to handle this."{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/474399-mcconnell-says-hell-be-in-total-coordination-with-white-house-on-impeachment|title=McConnell says he'll be in 'total coordination' with White House on impeachment trial strategy|first=Jordain|last=Carney|date=December 12, 2019|website=TheHill}} McConnell also said there was "no chance" the Senate would convict Trump and remove him from office while declaring his wish that all Senate Republicans would acquit Trump of both articles of impeachment.{{cite news |last1=Egan |first1=Lauren |title=McConnell: 'There's no chance' Trump is removed from office |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/trump-impeachment-inquiry/mcconnell-there-s-no-chance-trump-removed-office-n1101286 |accessdate=December 16, 2019 |date=December 13, 2019}} Two days later, Judiciary Committee chairman Graham said, "I am trying to give a pretty clear signal I have made up my mind. I'm not trying to pretend to be a fair juror here{{nbsp}}... I will do everything I can to make [the impeachment trial] die quickly."{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/12/14/politics/lindsey-graham-trump-impeachment-trial/index.html|title='I'm not trying to pretend to be a fair juror here': Graham predicts Trump impeachment will 'die quickly' in Senate|author=Veronica Stracqualursi|website=CNN}} The Constitution requires senators to take an impeachment oath, which by Senate rules then in effect stated, "I will do impartial justice according to the Constitution and laws, so help me God."{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/house/474487-rep-demings-senator-mcconnell-violated-oath-must-recuse-himself|title=House Democrat calls on McConnell to recuse himself from impeachment trial|first=Martin|last=Johnson|date=December 13, 2019|website=TheHill}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/CDOC-99sdoc33/html/CDOC-99sdoc33.htm|title=PROCEDURE AND GUIDELINES FOR IMPEACHMENT TRIALS IN THE UNITED STATES SENATE (REVISED EDITION)|website=www.govinfo.gov|access-date=December 15, 2019}} House Democrats [[Collin Peterson]] of Minnesota and [[Jeff Van Drew]] of New Jersey, the only two Democrats to vote against the initial October resolution, went public with their intentions to again vote against impeachment ahead of the House vote.{{cite news |url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2019/12/14/collin-peterson-says-likely-vote-against-impeachment |title=Peterson says he'll likely vote against impeachment |website=MPR News |date=December 14, 2019 |author=MPR News Staff}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2019/12/15/jeff-van-drew-party-switch-085169 |title=Jeff Van Drew party switch came as Democrats abandoned him |website=Politico |date=December 15, 2019 |last=Friedman |first=Matt}} Peterson issued that his "biggest problem" was that impeachment was always sought after by Democrats, "[T]hey've spent a year trying to figure out how they can make a case for it. That's backwards. I just don't agree with this." === Legal professionals and academics === ==== Academics ==== Many historians and diplomats have called the severity of the allegations "unprecedented" in American history.{{cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-behavior-with-ukraine-stupid-and-unprecedented-historian-2019-9 |title=Trump's actions with Ukraine were 'profoundly stupid' and beyond anything any president has ever done, historians and veteran diplomats say |last=Haltiwanger |first=John |website=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=September 29, 2019 |date=September 28, 2019}} Elaine Kamarck has described how this inquiry is different from Nixon's Watergate: "the president himself is directly involved in all four of the likely articles of impeachment": obstruction of justice, violation of federal election law (a possible constitutional abuse of power), obstruction of Congress, and violation of the emoluments clause.{{cite web|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/fixgov/2019/10/18/all-roads-lead-to-putin-this-week-in-impeachment/|title=All roads lead to Putin: This week in impeachment|last=Kamarck|first=Elaine|date=October 18, 2019|publisher=[[Brookings Institution]]|access-date=November 17, 2019}} Some academics responded to tweets by Trump in which he quoted [[Robert Jeffress]], a prominent Southern Baptist pastor who warned of a "Civil War-like fracture" if Democrats continued the inquiry. On Twitter, [[Harvard Law School]] professor John Coates cautioned that the tweet was an independent basis for impeachment as the sitting president was threatening civil war if Congress exercised its constitutionally authorized power.{{cite web |url=https://www.newsweek.com/trump-civil-war-tweet-grounds-impeachment-1462044 |title=Trump's 'Civil War' Quote Tweet Is Actually Grounds for Impeachment, Says Harvard Law Professor |last=Hutzler |first=Alexandra |date=September 30, 2019 |website=[[Newsweek]] |access-date=October 1, 2019}} A fellow faculty member of Harvard Law, [[Laurence Tribe]], agreed but cautioned that, due to the typical tone of Trump's tweets, the statement could be interpreted as "typical Trumpian [[bloviating]]" that would not be taken seriously or literally.{{cite web |url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/john-coates-donald-trump-civil-war-tweet-impeachment_n_5d926a6ae4b0019647ad2dc7 |title=Trump's 'Civil War' Tweet May Be Grounds For Impeachment: Harvard Law Professor |last=Moye |first=David |date=September 30, 2019 |website=[[HuffPost]]|access-date=October 1, 2019}} ==== Legal professionals ==== A group of 17 former [[Watergate]] special prosecutors published an opinion piece in ''The Washington Post'' in which they said the public record contains ''[[prima facie]]'' evidence that Trump had committed impeachable acts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/we-investigated-the-watergate-scandal-we-believe-trump-should-be-impeached/2019/10/10/5cf0c2ce-eb72-11e9-9306-47cb0324fd44_story.html|title=We investigated the Watergate scandal. We believe Trump should be impeached.|last1=17 former Watergate special prosecutors|date=October 10, 2019|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=October 11, 2019}} [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg|Supreme Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg]], briefly spoke about the impeachment after she was directly asked about the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] intervening in the process after Trump had tweeted the suggestion on December 2. Ginsburg highlighted the reactive nature of the U.S. Judicial system, and cautioned that any senator who shows bias before the trial should not be allowed to serve as jurors in the impeachment trial, as any legal professional would be disqualified from a case if they acted similarly.{{Cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/ruth-bader-ginsburg-the-president-is-not-a-lawyer|title=Ruth Bader Ginsburg says Trump 'not a lawyer' after he suggests Supreme Court could halt impeachment|last=Stimson|first=Brie|date=December 18, 2019|website=Fox News|language=en-US|access-date=December 19, 2019}} ''USA Today''{{'}}s Supreme Court correspondent Richard Wolf published an overview of the opinions of various legal experts, including law professors. The University of Texas's [[Sanford Levinson]] says "nobody really knows" how to define the "[[High crimes and misdemeanors#United States|high crimes and misdemeanors]]" of the Constitution's impeachment clause. According to Georgetown University's [[Randy Barnett]], "The Constitution gets violated all the time. That doesn't make the violation of the Constitution a high crime or misdemeanor." Barnett further states that Trump's accusers "have been alleging impeachable offenses since before [he] took the oath of office". The University of Southern California's [[Orin Kerr]] says, "It's about abusing the office, not about violating a technical provision of a particular clause," and {{nowrap|"[Trump}} is] taking care of himself, not taking care of the country."{{Cite news |last1=Wolf |first1=Richard |title=Article II of the Constitution: Trump's 'right to do whatever I want?' Or a road map for impeachment? |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2019/10/24/impeachment-donald-trump-constitution-violation-emoluments/4056323002/ |accessdate=October 30, 2019 |work=[[USA Today]] |date=October 24, 2019}} Following public impeachment inquiry hearings in the Intelligence and Judiciary House committees, more than 850 legal scholars signed an open letter stating Trump committed "impeachable conduct", asserting "his conduct is precisely the type of threat to our democracy that the Founders feared when they included the remedy of impeachment in the Constitution."{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasobserver.com/news/texas-law-professors-sign-open-letter-calling-for-donald-trumps-impeachment-11810447|title=Texas Law Professors Sign Letter Calling for Trump's Impeachment|first=Silas|last=Allen|date=December 11, 2019|website=Dallas Observer |accessdate=December 12, 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/@legalscholarsonimpeachment/letter-to-congress-from-legal-scholars-6c18b5b6d116|title=Letter to Congress from Legal Scholars|author=Legal Scholars on Impeachment |date=December 6, 2019|website=Medium |accessdate=December 12, 2019}} Another open letter signed by more than 1500 historians called for impeachment, stating, "it is our considered judgment that if President Trump's misconduct does not rise to the level of impeachment, then virtually nothing does."{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyprincetonian.com/article/2019/12/15-u-affiliated-historians-sign-letter-supporting-impeachment|title=15 U.-affiliated historians sign letter supporting impeachment|website=The Princetonian}}{{cite web |author1=Historians on Impeachment |title=HISTORIANS' STATEMENT ON THE IMPEACHMENT OF PRESIDENT TRUMP |url=https://medium.com/@historiansonimpeachment/historians-statement-on-the-impeachment-of-president-trump-6e4ed2277b16 |website=[[Medium (website)|Medium]] |accessdate=December 17, 2019 |date=December 16, 2019}} === Others === In December 2019, ''[[Christianity Today]]'' published an editorial ("Trump Should Be Removed from Office") calling for Trump's removal from office, asserting among other criticisms that he "attempted to use his political power to coerce a foreign leader to harass and discredit one of the president's political opponents. That is not only a violation of the Constitution; more importantly, it is profoundly immoral."{{Cite web|url=https://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2019/december-web-only/trump-should-be-removed-from-office.html|title=Trump Should Be Removed from Office|first=Mark|last=Galli|authorlink = Mark Galli|website=ChristianityToday.com}} == Public opinion == An analysis of polls showed that support for impeachment among the public grew after the Trump–Ukraine scandal first became public knowledge in September 2019, but through mid-December, Americans remained sharply divided on whether Trump should be removed from office.{{cite web |url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/do-americans-support-impeaching-president-trump/ |title=Do Americans Support Impeaching Trump? |last=Bycoffe |first=Aaron |date=December 17, 2019 |website=FiveThirtyEight|access-date=December 17, 2019}} In a [[YouGov]] poll on September 24, 2019, respondents said 55% would support, 26% would oppose, and 19% of respondents were undecided on impeachment if Trump was confirmed to have pressured the Ukrainian government.{{cite web |url=https://today.yougov.com/topics/politics/articles-reports/2019/09/26/impeachment-trump-support-poll-survey-yougov |title=Most Americans support impeachment if Trump pressured Ukraine |last=Ballard |first=Jamie |date=September 26, 2019 |website=[[YouGov]] |access-date=September 26, 2019}} A [[Marist Poll]] for [[NPR]] and [[PBS]] around the same time frame claimed that a 50–46 plurality approved of the House's decision to start an impeachment inquiry. A poll by ''[[Politico]]'' and [[Morning Consult]], released shortly after Pelosi announced her support for the inquiry, said support for impeachment increased seven percentage points week-over-week.{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/26/poll-support-impeachment-trump-1515012 |title=Support for impeachment jumps in new poll |work=[[Politico]] |first=Steven |last=Shepard |date=September 26, 2019 |accessdate=September 26, 2019}} A ''[[Business Insider]]'' poll on September 27 stated that 45% supported an impeachment inquiry, while 30% opposed.{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2019/09/27/america-backs-impeachment-inquiry-donald-trump-new-polls-suggest/ |title=America backs impeachment inquiry into Donald Trump, new polls suggest |last=Sabur |first=Rozina |date=September 27, 2019 |work=The Telegraph|access-date=September 27, 2019 |issn=0307-1235}} A September 30 [[Quinnipiac University]] poll stated that 56% of those polled thought members of Congress who support impeaching President Trump are doing so more on the basis of partisan politics than on the basis of the facts.{{cite web |url=https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=3642 |title=Support For Impeachment Grows Quinnipiac University National Poll Finds; Majority Of Voters Approve Of Impeachment Inquiry |website=Quinnipiac University Poll |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190930202009/https://poll.qu.edu/national/release-detail?ReleaseID=3642|archive-date=September 30, 2019 |date=September 30, 2019|access-date=September 30, 2019}} A poll conducted by ''[[The Economist]]'' and YouGov from October 16, 2019, stated that under half of their polled adults supported impeachment, and most of those respondents also support removal from office. Besides, it noted that a significant proportion of Americans (70% of Republicans, 38% of independents, and 13% of Democrats) believe a [[Deep state in the United States|deep state]] is trying to obstruct or unseat President Trump.{{cite web |url=https://today.yougov.com/topics/politics/articles-reports/2019/10/16/americans-favor-impeachment-want-trump-removed |title=Americans who favor impeachment want President Trump removed, too |work=[[YouGov]] |access-date=October 19, 2019 |first=Kathy |last=Frankovic |date=October 16, 2019}} An October 17 poll from the Pew Research Center of 3,487 adults found that 54% were in favor of impeachment and 44% opposed.{{cite web |url=https://www.people-press.org/2019/10/17/modest-changes-in-views-of-impeachment-proceedings-since-early-september/ |title=Modest Changes in Views of Impeachment Proceedings Since Early September |date=October 17, 2019 |website=Pew Research Center for the People and the Press| access-date=October 17, 2019}} A poll conducted on November 11–15, 2019, by NPR, ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'' and Marist Poll of registered American voters showed 45% of respondents favored impeachment and removal from office, while 44% of those polled opposed the idea.{{cite news |last1=Marist Poll |title=POLITICSNPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist Poll Results & Analysis |url=http://maristpoll.marist.edu/npr-pbs-newshour-marist-poll-results-analysis-9/#sthash.8BfeK8bz.dpbs |accessdate=November 21, 2019 |publisher=Marist Poll |date=November 20, 2019}} A poll on November 16–17, 2019, by ''[[ABC News]]'' and ''[[Ipsos]]'', stated that 51% of those polled believe Trump was wrong in how he handled the Ukrainian situation and should be impeached. Ipsos also said 21% of polled American adults had made up their minds on impeachment due to the hearings, while the others polled said they had made up their mind prior to the hearings.{{cite news|url=https://www.ipsos.com/en-us/news-polls/abc-news-impeachment-hearings-Nov-18|title=ABC News/Ipsos Poll: Impact of the First Days of Impeachment Hearings on American Public Opinion|work=Ipsos|date=November 18, 2019|accessdate=November 19, 2019}}{{cite web |title=A survey of the American general population |url=https://www.ipsos.com/sites/default/files/ct/news/documents/2019-11/topline-abc-ipsos-impeachment-hearings-11182019.pdf |website=Ipsos |publisher=Ipsos KnowledgePanel |accessdate=November 20, 2019}} {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:90%; text-align:center;" |+ Polling of support for the impeachment inquiry among Americans |- style="vertical-align:bottom; font-size:90%;" ! '''Reality distortion field''' (or RDF) is a term first used by [[Bud Tribble]] at [[Apple Inc.|Apple Computer]] in 1981, to describe company co-founder [[Steve Jobs]]' [[charisma]] and its effects on the developers working on the [[Macintosh]] project.<ref name=Hertzfeld>{{cite web |url=http://www.folklore.org/StoryView.py?project=Macintosh&story=Reality_Distortion_Field.txt |title=Reality Distortion Field |first=Andy |last=Hertzfeld |publisher=Folklore.org |date=February 1981 }}</ref> Tribble said that the term came from ''[[Star Trek]]'',<ref name=Hertzfeld /> where in [[The Menagerie (Star Trek: The Original Series)|the Menagerie]] episode, it was used to describe how the aliens created their own new world through mental force.
==Steve Jobs== In Chapter Three of ''[[Steve Jobs (book)|Steve Jobs]]'', biographer [[Walter Isaacson]] states that around 1972, while Jobs was attending [[Reed College]], [[Robert Friedland]] "taught Steve the reality distortion field." The RDF was said by [[Andy Hertzfeld]] to be Steve Jobs' ability to convince himself, and others around him, to believe almost anything with a mix of charm, charisma, [[bravery|bravado]], [[hyperbole]], [[marketing]], appeasement and persistence. It was said to distort his co-workers' sense of proportion and scales of difficulties and to make them believe that whatever impossible task he had at hand was possible. Jobs could also use the reality distortion field to appropriate others' ideas as his own, sometimes proposing an idea back to its originator, only a week after dismissing it.<ref name=Hertzfeld />
The term has been used to refer to Jobs' keynote speeches ("[[Stevenote]]s") by observers and devoted users of [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] [[Apple Macintosh|computers]] and products<ref>{{cite web|url=http://creativepro.com/notes-epicenter-exploring-reality-distortion-field/|title=Notes from the Epicenter: Exploring the Reality Distortion Field|last=Dudrow|first=Andrea|date=October 16, 2000|website=|publisher=CreativePro|access-date=}}</ref>, and derisively by Apple's competitors in [[Criticism of Apple Inc.|criticisms of Apple]]. On [[Research In Motion]]'s official [[BlackBerry]] [[blog]], [[Jim Balsillie]] introduced a blog post by saying "For those of us who live outside of Apple's distortion field".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.blackberry.com/2010/10/rim-responds-to-apples-distortion-field/ |title=RIM Responds to Apple's ‘Distortion Field' |publisher=Inside BlackBerry |date=October 19, 2010}}</ref>
==Other instances== The term has been extended, with a mixture of awe and scorn, to other managers and leaders in industry who try to convince their employees to become passionately committed to projects without regard to their overall difficulty or to competitive forces in the market. It is sometimes used with regard to excessively-hyped products that are not necessarily connected with any one person.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.davidtemkin.com/mtarchive/000012.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618065115/http://www.davidtemkin.com/mtarchive/000012.html |archivedate=June 18, 2010 |title=The Ajax Reality Distortion Field |publisher=davidtemkin.com |date=April 12, 2005}}</ref> * [[Bill Clinton]]'s charisma has been called a reality distortion field.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fourhourworkweek.com/blog/2010/11/21/bill-clinton-reality-distortion-field/ |title=How It Works: Clinton's "Reality Distortion Field" Charisma |first=Tim |last=Ferriss |date=November 21, 2010}}</ref> * The chess champion [[Bobby Fischer]] was said to have a "Fischer aura" surrounding him that disoriented [[Boris Spassky]] and other opponents.<ref name="darrach19720811">{{cite news | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EVUEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&rview=1&pg=PA40#v=onepage&q&f=true | title=Bobby is Not a Nasty Kid | work=Life | date=1972-08-11 | accessdate=March 25, 2013 | author=Darrach, Brad | pages=40}}</ref> * [[Theranos]] founder [[Elizabeth Holmes]] was said to have generated an RDF around her product, the Edison blood analyzer.<ref>https://www.unz.com/isteve/the-elizabeth-holmes-reality-distortion-field/</ref> * The term has been also associated with [[Donald Trump]]'s approach to running his [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 campaign for United States President]] and his [[Presidency of Donald Trump|presidency]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2016-06-16/peeking-inside-trump-s-smoke-and-mirrors-tour|title=A Peek Inside Trump's Smoke and Mirrors Tour|last=O'Brien|first=Timothy L.|date=2016-06-16|website=Bloomberg View|access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> *''[[Financial Times]]'' used the term when describing [[Elon Musk]].<ref>Richard Waters. [https://www.ft.com/content/8ca82034-86d0-11e6-bcfc-debbef66f80e Elon Musk, billionaire tech idealist and space entrepreneur]. ''[[Financial Times]]''.</ref> *A parody of a reality distortion field appeared in a 2010 ''[[Dilbert]]'' strip in which a reality distortion field emitter is used during a [[keynote|keynote speech]] by [[Dogbert]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dilbert.com/strips/comic/2010-09-23/ |title=Dilbert comic strip for 2010-09-23 |publisher=The official Dilbert comic strips archive}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Charismatic authority]] * [[Cult of personality]] * [[Gaslighting]] * [[Locus of control]] * [[Magical thinking]] * [[Propaganda]] * [[Suggestibility]] * [[Suspension of disbelief]]

page.title: United States threat for destruction of Iranian cultural sites

revision.text:
On Saturday, 4 January 2020 American President [[Donald Trump]] said if Iran retaliate for assassination of General [[Qasem Soleimani]], "the United States will hit 52 Iranian sites, some at a very high level and important to Iran and the Iranian culture, very fast and very hard." The threat was widely described as a "pretty clear promise of a war crime" and was condemned by the international community. However, on Sunday, Donald Trump renewed the threat, and said "They're allowed to kill our people, ...and we're not allowed to touch their cultural sites? It doesn't work that way."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jan/06/suleimani-killing-donald-trump-defends-threat-to-hit-cultural-sites-in-iran|title=Trump defends ‘war crime’ threat to target cultural sites in Iran|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{Cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2020/01/05/world/trump-iran-cultural-sites-war-crime/index.html|title=Trump's threatened attack on Iranian cultural sites could be a war crime if carried out|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="auto5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2020/jan/06/trump-threat-destruction-iran-heritage-war-crime|title=Trump defends ‘war crime’ threat to target cultural sites in Iran|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2020/jan/06/trump-threat-destruction-iran-heritage-war-crime|title=Trump's threat to destroy Iranian heritage would be a war crime|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2020/01/06/disturbing-history-behind-trumps-idea-target-iranian-cultural-sites/|title=The disturbing history behind Trump’s threat to target Iranian cultural sites|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-51014237|title=Trump under fire for threat to Iranian cultural sites|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="auto4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2020/01/06/794006073/trump-says-hell-target-iran-s-cultural-sites-that-s-illegal|title=Trump Says He'll Target Iran's Cultural Sites. That's Illegal|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>
In response, Iranian officials compared the United States to the ISIS, Nazi Germany and barbarian tribes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/51ddb3630b257a686918c9610b31a50e|title=Trump’s threats draw Iran’s cultural sites into tensions|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sputniknews.com/middleeast/202001051077952393-zarif-compares-trump-to-barbarians-of-ancient-times-over-threat-to-target-irans-cultural-sites/|title=Iran's Foreign Minister Compares Trump to Ancient ‘Barbarians’ Over Threat to Target Cultural Sites|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thehill.com/policy/international/476808-iran-labels-trump-a-terrorist-in-a-suit|title=Iranian official labels Trump a 'terrorist in a suit'|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2020/01/05/iran-calls-trump-a-terrorist-in-a-suit-for-killing-soleimani/|title=Iran calls Trump a ‘terrorist in a suit’ for killing Soleimani|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> Targeting cultural sites is a war crime under the 1954 Hague Convention.<ref name="auto3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/iranian-minister-calls-donald-trump-terrorist-1480453|title=Iranian Minister Calls Donald Trump A 'Terrorist In A Suit'|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Threats ==
=== First threat === In a series of tweets, Trump wrote that "if Iran strikes any Americans, or American assets," the U.S. has targeted 52 Iranian sites, "some at a very high level & important to Iran & the Iranian culture, and those targets, and Iran itself, WILL BE HIT VERY FAST AND VERY HARD."<ref name="auto4" />
=== Second threat === A day after the first threat, Trump, speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One, defended his threat and said: "They’re allowed to kill our people, They’re allowed to torture and maim our people. They’re allowed to use roadside bombs and blow up our people. And we’re not allowed to touch their cultural site? It doesn’t work that way.”<ref name="auto5" />
== Reactions ==
=== United States === The Pentagon tried to distance itself from Trump's tweets about targeting cultural sites. Defense Secretary Mark Esper was asked if the US would target cultural sites, and he said that the US will “follow the laws of armed conflict.”<ref name="auto5" /> When asked if that meant "no, because targeting a cultural site is a war crime?", Esper said "That's the laws of armed conflict." However, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo defended Trump's tweets.<ref name="auto1" />
US senators Elizabeth Warren and Chris Murphy labeled the tweets as "threatening to commit war crimes."<ref name="auto" /> Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez tweeted that "Threatening to target and kill innocent families, women and children - which is what you’re doing by targeting cultural sites - does not make you a “tough guy.” It does not make you “strategic.” It makes you a monster."<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.foxnews.com/politics/democrats-rebuke-trump-for-targeting-52-iranian-sites-threatenign-war-crimes|title=AOC calls Trump 'a monster' over threat to Iran; Omar, other Democrats warn of potential 'war crimes'|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>
Joe Biden also warned against "Trump's irrational behavior."<ref name="auto2" /> "The President of the United States is threatening to commit war crimes on Twitter. God help us all!", said Congresswoman Ilhan Omar.<ref name="auto3" />
=== Iran === Iran's Foreign Minister, Javad Zarif, said Trump violated international law in “Friday’s cowardly assassinations” and “threatens to commit again new breaches of JUS COGENS. Targeting cultural sites is a WAR CRIME.”<ref name="auto3" />
In another tweet, Zarif wrote: "A reminder to those hallucinating about emulating ISIS war crimes by targeting our cultural heritage: Through MILLENNIA of history, barbarians have come and ravaged our cities, razed our monuments and burnt our libraries. Where are they now? We're still here, & standing tall."<ref name="auto3" />
"Like ISIS, like Hitler, Like Genghis! They all hate cultures. Trump is a ‘terrorist in a suit.’ He will learn history very soon that NOBODY can defeat ‘the Great Iranian Nation & Culture", wrote Azari Jahromi, Iran's Minister of Communications and Information Technology, on Twitter.<ref name="auto3" />
Iranian President Rouhani responded to Trump's warning: "Those who refer to the number 52 should also remember the number 290", referring to the 1988 shooting down of an Iran Air Flight 655, by a U.S. warship in which 290 were killed.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://thehill.com/policy/international/middle-east-north-africa/476970-rouhani-points-to-downing-of-iranian-airliner |title=Rouhani points to US downing of Iranian airliner in response to Trump threat |date=6 January 2020 |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |access-date=9 January 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200107065435/https://thehill.com/policy/international/middle-east-north-africa/476970-rouhani-points-to-downing-of-iranian-airliner |archive-date=7 January 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref>
Using the hashtag #IranianCulturalSites, Iranian people responded to the Trump's tweets by sharing photos of their favorite Iranian cultural sites.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.commondreams.org/news/2020/01/05/iranians-flood-twitter-photos-favorite-cultural-sites-trump-threatens-them|title=Iranians Flood Twitter With Photos of Favorite Cultural Sites as Trump Threatens Them With Destruction|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> BBC reported that Trump's tweets made Iranians, who were divided as soon as the news of the killing of Qasem Soleimani broke, united against the United States.
=== Worldwide === Audrey Azoulay, the director general of the UN's cultural organisation, Unesco, said both Iran and the US had signed a 1972 convention to protect the world's natural and cultural heritage. UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said cultural sites were protected by international law. He also said that Britain expected that to be respected.<ref name="auto" /> The British Prime Minister, Boris Johnson warned the US that "attacking Iranian cultural sites could constitute a war crime under international law."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/iran-war-trump-boris-johnson-cultural-sites-soleimani-iraq-a9272076.html|title=Iran crisis: Boris Johnson warns Trump not to break international law by bombing cultural sites|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>
Francesco Bandarin, a former senior official at UNESCO, wrote "if the US destroys Iranian cultural sites, President Trump will be criminally liable by international law."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theartnewspaper.com/analysis/if-the-us-destroys-iranian-cultural-sites-president-trump-will-be-criminally-liable-by-international-law|title=If the US destroys Iranian cultural sites, President Trump will be criminally liable by international law|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres, without mentioning Trump, stressed that international cooperation must continue to preserve humanity's treasures.<ref name="apnews.com">{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/e456bc97066894a04b23b384fec6cded|title=Trump retreats from threat to attack Iranian cultural sites|last=|first=|date=|website=|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Aftermath == On Tuesday, Donald Trump backed away from his threats to target Iranian cultural sites. "I like to obey the law." he said during an Oval Office appearance. He also added: "Think of it. They kill our people. They blow up our people. And then we have to be very gentle with their cultural institutions? But I’m OK with it. It’s OK with me.”<ref name="apnews.com"/>
